A more accurate picture of its AOO would be realized if the area cover of only the massive corals was known. Coral reef habitat has declined by 59% over the past 41 years. Its generation length is short and three generations is inferred as no more than 10 years. It is susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific declines are not available at this time. Based on this information, a suspected population decline of >30% is projected to occur over the next ten years due to predation by the invasive lionfish. Therefore, it is listed as VU A3ce. We recommend improved monitoring on the effects of habitat degradation and predation by the invasive lionfish.
habitat: This species inhabits coral reefs in fairly deep water. It can be found in spur and groove and drop-off habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). It remains in relatively continuous close physical contact with live corals. Individuals observed at night and during the day spend most of the time resting on live corals, with only a few brief forays onto nearby algal mats, or off the coral to feed (Böhlke and Robins 1977). Most photographs of C. lipernes available show it perched on live massive coral, which may indicate that this species is dependent on live massive coral to some degree (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is usually solitary, but sometimes swims close to the reef in small groups. It is diurnally active. Fishes of this genus are sequential protogynous hermaphrodites (Cole and Shapiro 1990; Thacker and Cole 2002). The maximum recorded length is 3 cm (Robins and Ray). Proxy life history data based on a study of Coryphopterus kuna: Larvae settle around 7-9 mm SL, adults mature at 10–11 mm SL and then only attain about 17 mm SL. It has a 60-day pelagic larval life and matures rapidly. They are sexually active in as few as three weeks and live for about two months after settlement. This is the first reported fish in which the pelagic larval duration is generally longer than the post-settlement lifespan, which indicates that C. kuna may represent the extreme of a bipartite life-history strategy: a relatively slow-growing pelagic larval stage, often with delayed metamorphosis, in combination with a rapidly maturing, high-mortality adult stage (Victor et al. 2010). Based on this information, it is inferred that three generation lengths are almost certainly no more than ten years.
threats: This species is likely dependent on live coral to some degree as it is typically found resting on live coral. Thus, C. lipernes may be adversely impacted by decreases in live coral cover. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover has been directly observed in the Caribbean (Jackson et al. 2014). Coryphopterus spp. are highly predated upon by lionfish, however, it is not yet known how this threat is specifically impacting the overall population of this species. This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (Green et al. 2012).
population: Collections and observations indicate that Coryphopterus lipernes is widespread in the Caribbean and Bahamas, but does not occur abundantly (Böhlke and Robins 1977). Sampling at euphotic and mesophotic depths (15-50 m) in Puerto-Rico revealed this species to be the thirteenth most abundant species, with peak abundances at 25 m (Garcia-Sais 2010).
range: Coryphopterus lipernes is distributed in the western Atlantic from the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys and northwestern Cuba, and throughout the Caribbean Sea (Robins and Ray 1986, Smith 1997, R. Robertson and P. Chevalier pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 11,151 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013).
useTrade: Coryphopterus lipernes is found in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Half of its range in the Gulf of Mexico is contained entirely within the Florida Keys National Sanctuary, however, conservation measures have not been successful towards stopping coral reef decline (Toth et al. 2014).

rationale: This widely distributed species is common and abundant where it occurs on coral and rocky reef. Coral reef habitat has declined by 59% over the past 41 years. Its generation length is short and three generations is inferred as no more than 10 years. It has been documented as susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific declines are not available at this time. Based on this information, a suspected population decline of >30% is projected to occur over the next ten years due to predation by the invasive lionfish. Therefore, it is listed as VU A3ce. We recommend improved monitoring on the effects of habitat degradation and predation by the invasive lionfish.
habitat: Coryphopterus personatus occurs in schools near large coral columns and heads at the edges and slopes of patch reefs (depths of five to 25 m) (Bohlke and Robins 1960) and feeds on plankton. It hovers above bottom in caves and shaded areas in reefs (Smith 1997). It is a benthic spawner. Fishes of this genus are sequential protogynous hermaphrodites (Cole and Shapiro 1990, Thacker and Cole 2002). Sex reversal is completed in nine days (Sadovy and Shapiro 1987, Cole and Robertson 1988). Females outnumber males at approximately four to one, male and female size distributions show considerable overlap, but may differ, and there occur small males which are smaller than the smallest mature females (Cole and Robertson 1988). This species has been bred in captivity, however rearing this species has proven difficult due to the need for small first foods and a long larval duration. Proxy life history data based on a study of Coryphopterus kuna: Larvae settle around 7-9 mm SL, adults mature at 10–11 mm SL and then only attain about 17 mm SL. It has a 60-day pelagic larval life and matures rapidly. They are sexually active in as few as three weeks and live for about two months after settlement. This is the first reported fish in which the pelagic larval duration is generally longer than the post-settlement lifespan, which indicates that C. kuna may represent the extreme of a bipartite life-history strategy: a relatively slow-growing pelagic larval stage, often with delayed metamorphosis, in combination with a rapidly maturing, high-mortality adult stage (Victor et al. 2010). Based on this information, it is inferred that three generation lengths are almost certainly no more than ten years.
threats: Coryphopterus personatus has been identified as a primary prey item of the invasive Lionfish in the Bahamas and likely in the remainder of its range (Morris and Akins 2009, Cote and Maljkovic 2010, Green et al. 2012, Green and Cote 2014). This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012). Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean (Jackson et al. 2014).
population: This species can be common and locally abundant in many parts of its range. In a study conducted off Belize and Honduras, it was dominant in drop-off habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). It is a common inhabitant of live reef areas (particularly isolated coral heads) in the Florida Keys, Bermuda, the Bahamas, Haiti and the Virgin Islands (Böhlke and Robins 1962). It was also dominant on artificial reefs in Florida (Sathe and Thanner 2009).
range: Coryphopterus personatus is distributed in the western Atlantic from Bermuda, south Florida, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys and from Veracruz, Mexico along the northern Yucatan to northwestern Cuba, and throughout the Caribbean Sea (Robins and Ray 1986, Smith 1997, R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: Coryphopterus personatus can be found in the aquarium trade where it retails for low values.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Coryphopterus alloides is relatively widespread, but not known to be common. It is strictly associated with coral reef habitat, which has declined by 59% over the past 41 years. Its AOO is estimated at 5,578 km2. Its generation length is short and three generation lengths are inferred as no more than 10 years. It is susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish, which now occurs throughout the entire range of this species. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific declines are not available at this time. Based on this information, a suspected population decline of >30% is projected to occur over the next ten years due to predation by the invasive lionfish. Therefore, it is listed as VU A3ce. We recommend improved monitoring on the effects of habitat degradation and predation by the invasive lionfish.
habitat: Coryphopterus alloides is a reef-associated species that inhabits coral heads in clear waters at depths greater than eight metres. It is a benthic spawner (Robins and Ray 1986). Fishes of this genus are sequential protogynous hermaphrodites (Thacker and Cole 2002). The maximum recorded length is 4 cm TL. Proxy life history data based on a study of Coryphopterus kuna: larvae settle around 7-9 mm SL, adults mature at 10–11 mm SL and then only attain about 17 mm SL. It has a 60-day pelagic larval life and matures rapidly. It is sexually active in as few as three weeks and lives for about two months after settlement. This is the first reported fish in which the pelagic larval duration is generally longer than the post-settlement lifespan, which indicates that C. kuna may represent the extreme of a bipartite life-history strategy: a relatively slow-growing pelagic larval stage, often with delayed metamorphosis, in combination with a rapidly maturing, high-mortality adult stage (Victor et al. 2010). Based on this information, it is inferred that three generation lengths are almost certainly no more than ten years.
threats: Coryphopterus alloides is strictly reef-associated and may be impacted by loss of coral habitat. Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean (Jackson et al. 2014). It may also be threatened by predation from the invasive lionfish (Morris and Akins 2009). This species is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: Data are limited on subpopulations of this species.
range: Coryphopterus alloides has been reported from the upper Florida Keys, the Bahamas, northeastern Cuba, in the Caribbean from the Cayman Islands, Hispaniola to Dominica, Trinidad and Tobago, and along Central and South America from Belize to the Honduran Bay Islands, the Providencia Islands (Colombia), Colon (Panama), and Curacao (Robins and Ray 1986, Victor 2014). It does not occur in the Gulf of Mexico (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 5,578 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013).
useTrade: Coryphopterus alloides is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures for Coryphopterus alloides. Further research is needed into the distribution, habitats and ecology and possible threats to this species

rationale:
This widely distributed species can be abundant where it occurs in coral reef habitat and is often associated with sponges. Its estimated global AOO is less than 2,000 km2 and is severely fragmented due to its preference for Montastrea annularis. In addition, the larval retention of this species is very localized and therefore, has a very low probability of reseeding depleted subpopulations. Given this information, it meets the threshold for Vulnerable under B2. It is threatened by the loss of coral reef habitat throughout its entire range (at least 20% over a 41 year period). It has been documented in the diet of the invasive lionfish, which may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed as cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, it is listed as VU B2ab(iii) globally.

In the Gulf of Mexico, its AOO is 25 km2 and its EOO is 2,915 km2. Its separate subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico off Veracruz is threatened by pollution and coastal development, which are degrading and potentially destroying coral reefs. Given this information, it meets Vulnerable under D2 and the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2. The invasive lionfish may constitute a further threat to its population, however, further research is needed. It has been documented in the diet, but cleaner gobies are generally not considered preferred lionfish prey items. Therefore, in the Gulf of Mexico it is listed as EN B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii). This species should be monitored as further loss of coral could quickly cause it to regionally qualify for CR.
habitat: Elacatinus prochilos is a reef-associated cleaner goby that occurs in groups near coral heads with a preference for Montastrea annularis and sponges (Lieske and Myers 1994, Wilson 1998, Dennis et al. 2004). At coral cleaning stations it is more frequently solitary or found in small groups, while groups of up to 40 individuals were observed on sponge cleaning stations. It forms dominance hierarchies based on body size. Differences in substrate are linked to marked differences in social behaviour, cleaning activity and diet, with gobies on sponges cleaning less than gobies on corals (Whiteman and Côté 2004). Fish that range in size from six to 34 mm can be found co-occurring on the same substrate (Wilson 2005). This species is monogamous (Whiteman and Côté 2004) and sexes can be distinguished by the shape of the urogenital papilla (Thresher 1984). It consumes Gnathiid isopod larvae and caligid copepods in addition to fish scales, mucous, coral polyps and sponges. It is thought to consume less ectoparasites than other Caribbean and Pacific members of the genus (Arnal and Côte 2000). It does not undergo ontogenetic habitat shifts except when reproductive individuals leave live coral heads and build nests in small holes within the reef; however, young fish and fish of reproductive size are often present on coral heads together (Wilson 2005, Wilson pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Elacatinus prochilos is likely impacted by loss of coral reef habitat. There was an overall 59% decline in coral cover in the entire Caribbean between 1970-2011, and specifically an average of approximately 20% within the range of this species (Jackson et al. 2014). Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014). This area is impacted by commercial shipping activity that enters directly through the marine protected area and runoff contamination from heavy metals, faeces, fertilizers and pesticide pollutants (Ortiz-Lozano 2012). The Mexican government has recently been seeking to expand the Port of Veracruz onto the reef area, which would involve direct removal of reef habitat (Ortiz-Lozano et al. 2013). There have also been significant declines in Acroporid corals with no sign of recovery and a high prevalence of disease on stony corals (Rangel-Avalos et al. 2007). It has been recorded in the diet of the invasive Lionfish in the Mexican Caribbean, however, this is likely not a major threat considering lionfish uncommonly consume cleaner fishes (Villasenor-Derbez and Herrera-Perez 2014, Green and Cote 2014).
population: Elacatinus prochilos is abundant. Populations have been described as unstructured (Whiteman and Côté 2004, Wilson 2005). Despite an extended pelagic larval duration of 21 days, the retention of larvae of a sister and co-occurring species (E. evelynae) is almost exclusively localized. This indicates that the potential for subpopulations to receive propagules from elsewhere is very low (Taylor and Hellberg 2003).
range: Elacatinus prochilos is distributed in the western Atlantic from Veracruz, Mexico in the Gulf of Mexico and in the Caribbean from Jamaica along the Antilles to Tobago and from Quintana Roo, Mexico to Roatan, Honduras and Las Isles de Cisne (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). It is known from three potentially widely separated subpopulations (Colin 2010). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 3,214 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013). Between 1970-2011 (41 years), the following coral cover declines were directly observed within its range: 17% Veracruz (1965-1999), 18% USVI, 30% Puerto Rico, 6% Barbados, 28% Jamaica, and 16.5% Belize (average 20%). Furthermore, considering it specifically prefers the boulder star coral, Montastrea annularis, its AOO is therefore assumed to be less than 2,000 km2. The subpopulation in the Gulf of Mexico is restricted to the Veracruz Reef System, where its AOO is 25 km2 and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,915 km2. Between 1965-1999 (34 years), a 17% decline in coral cover was directly observed off Veracruz (Jackson et al. 2014).
useTrade: Elacatinus prochilos has been used as an indicator of habitat quality (Wilson 2005). It could possibly be targeted for the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: This species is restricted to shallow brackish and freshwater habitats in two locations off Panama: Bocas Del Toro and the Panama Canal Zone. Its estimated EOO is 18,996 km<sup>2 </sup>and its AOO is 1,834 km<sup>2</sup>, which meets the thresholds for Vulnerable under B1 and B2. A significant decline in its population within the Panama Canal Zone has been directly observed and likely caused by predation from invasive cichlids and expansion of the Panama Canal. Its habitat is also susceptible to degradation in Bocas Del Toro due to increasing coastal development and pollution. Therefore, it is listed as Vulnerable under B1ab(iii)+ B2ab(iii).
habitat: This species is found in brackish and fresh waters to a depth of six metres. It is associated with the entry point of coastal streams and estuaries, and is never found in pure seawater.
threats: This species is threatened by freshwater pollution. In addition, predation by introduced cichlid fishes also poses a serious threat to this species, and is thought to be a major reason for population decline in the canal. Coastal development for tourism is also serious threat, especially for the Atlantic subpopulations in Bocas del Toro. Similarly, the planned future expansion of the Panama canal will continue add to destruction of habitat.
population: This species can be relatively common. It was recorded in Gatun and Pedro Miguel Locks in the 1970s (Hoese 1971). However, extensive sampling between 2000-2005 discovered no specimens in those areas.
range: This species has a very restricted range along the Caribbean coast of Panama where it is known only from brackish to freshwater habitats in Bocas del Toro and the Panama Canal Zone around Colon (two locations). It is a resident in the fresh water zones of the Panama Canal and has moved through the canal to the Pacific coast of Panama at the entrance to the Panama Canal (McCosker and Dawson 1975). A record from Jamaica is not valid as Gobiosoma spes and specimens from Barbados require further investigation (J. Van Tassell pers. comm. 2015). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 18,996 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to 10 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 1,834 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 10 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Additional research is needed into the species distribution, natural history and threats. Population monitoring is recommended.

rationale: Altrichthys curatus is found in a limited range in the Philippines and its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 1,300 km² based on its coral habitat. This species does not have a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors.We infer its population is declining based on declines in coral cover that are common in this region. It is known from only one location, and its habitat is declining in area and quality. Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B (VU B2ab(iii,v)).
habitat: Altrichthys curatus is found on sheltered coastal reefs in rich coral areas between depths of about 0.5-10 m, where zooplankton is the main source of this fish's diet. It is closely associated with branching corals, particularly Porites cylindrica and Echinopora horrida. Unlike most pomacentrids, this species lacks a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents (Allen 1991). Parental care is associated with territoriality, therefore this species may be more susceptible to habitat loss than other pomacentrids.
threats: This species is likely to be impacted by loss of coral cover, which is common in this region. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors (Arceo et al. 2001, Bruno and Selig 2007).
population: Currently this species is common and locally abundant (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is associated with areas of live coral, and, because of continued degradation of coral reefs within its range, its population is declining.
range: Altrichthys curatus is located in the Philippines at Calamianes and Cuyo island groups (Allen 1999) and the northern tip of Palawan (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). Based on this distribution and coral habitat (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010), we estimate its AOO to be about 1,300 km².
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in several marine protected areas (MPAs); however, the efficacy of these MPAs is uncertain.

rationale: Altrichthys azurelineatus is found within a limited range in the Philippines and its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 1,400 km² based on its coral habitat. This species does not have a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors. We infer its population is declining based on declines in coral cover and area that are common in this region. It is known from only one location, and its habitat is declining in area and quality. Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B (VU B2ab(iii,v)).
habitat: This species is found on sheltered coastal reefs in rich coral areas between depths of about 0.5-10 m with an average depth of 3-4 m. It is closely associated with branching corals, particularly Porites cylindrica and Echinopora horrida. Zooplankton is the main source of this fish's diet. Unlike most pomacentrids, this species lacks a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents (Allen 1991). Parental care is associated with territoriality, therefore this species may be more susceptible to habitat loss than other pomacentrids.
threats: This species is likely to be impacted by loss of coral cover, which is common in this region. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors (Arceo et al. 2001, Bruno and Selig 2007).
population: Currently this species is common and locally abundant (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is associated with areas of live coral, and, because of continued degradation of coral reefs within its range, its population is declining.
range: Altrichthys azurelineatus is only known from the Philippines in the western Central Pacific, specifically from the Calamianes Islands and northern Palawan (Allen 1991). Based on this distribution and its coral habitat (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010), we estimate its AOO to be about 1,400 km².
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in several marine protected areas (MPAs), however, the efficacy of these MPAs is uncertain.

rationale: Amblyglyphidodon batunai is fairly widespread, and currently locally abundant in parts of its range. However, this species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals that have undergone significant declines in the area where A. batunai is found. Direct observation indicates declines up to 75% in marine protected areas over the past 13 years in northern Papua New Guinea for its congener A. turnatensis. Where this species occurs, somewhere between 30% and 50% of Acropora species are assessed as threatened with extinction. We infer that over its range this species has declined by more than 30% due to habitat loss from Acropora degradation. Because this species is locally abundant in some parts of its range, we infer that overall losses are somewhere between 30% and 50% over three generation lengths (9-12 years); therefore this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A (VU A2bc).
habitat: Amblyglyphidodon batunai currently is common among coral-rich areas of sheltered coastal reefs (Lieske and Myers 1994) with algae and staghorn corals to about 15 m depth, but more common from 1-5 m. Individuals spawn in groups and each pair claims a small section of the reef. Eggs are laid on a cleared section of the coral and guarded by the parents (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). This species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals (Allen 1991), and it is not found in areas without branching Acropora corals.
threats: This species is closely associated with branching Acropora which has undergone significant declines due to coastal development, destructive fishing methods, and increased bleaching events presumably due to climate change throughout most of the range of this species. Therefore, its habitat is under threat.
population:
Amblyglyphidodon batunai is closely associated with branching Acropora corals. In northern Papua New Guinea, particularly in Madang Lagoon, Acropora cover has been declining over the past 13 years, with associated declines in A. ternatensis, a congener to A. batunai with very similar habitat requirements (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). Fish transect data recorded almost every year for the past 13 years has measured a population decline in A. ternatensis of approximately 75% (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). We infer that Acropora declines throughout this species' range would result in similar population declines of A. batunai.

From 1998-2004 there was a 30% overall destruction of coral reefs, of which 8% has recovered. In 2004, 28% of coral reefs remaining were considered to be at the critical stage (Wilkinson 2004). Of those coral reefs destroyed, Acropora spp. are considered most affected in coral cover declines and a high percentage of Acropora in this region are considered vulnerable to extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008). 

We infer that the generation length for this species is 3-4 years based on longevity data for the family Pomacentridae which is generally estimated at a maximum of around 10 years in the wild (Allen 1991). Pomacentrids mature fairly early, typically between 1-2 years and the average mature age is 3-4 years in a population. Based on the documented population declines in the sister species A. ternatensis related to coral reef declines, the status of Acropora reefs in the region, we infer that A. batunai is declining at a rate exceeding than 30% over the past three generation lengths (9-12 years).
range: Amblyglyphidodon batunai is located in the Indo-Australian Archipelago including Indonesia, Philippines, Papua New Guinea, and northern Australia, including Western Australia and Northern Territory (Allen 1991). In addition, it was recently recorded from Palau and Federated States of Micronesia, specifically Yap and Chuuk (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in numerous marine protected areas throughout its range. However, population declines are still occurring in at least some of these protected areas (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: This species is fairly widespread and currently is locally abundant in parts of its range. However, it is closely associated with branching Acropora corals that have undergone significant declines in the area where this species is found. Direct observation indicates declines of up to 75% in marine protected areas over the past 13 years in northern Papua New Guinea. Where this species occurs, somewhere between 30 and 50% of Acropora species are threatened with extinction. We infer that over its range this species has declined greater than 30% due to habitat loss from Acropora degradation. Because this species is locally abundant in some parts of its range, we infer that overall losses are somewhere between 30 and 50% over three generation lengths (9-12 years, which corresponds approximately to the generation length used for Acropora). Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A (VU A2bc).
habitat:
Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is common among coral-rich areas of sheltered coastal reefs with algae and staghorn corals to about 15 m depth, but more common from 1-5 m (Lieske and Myers 1994). They spawn in groups and each pair claims a small section of the reef. Its eggs are laid on a cleared section of the coral and guarded by the parents (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). This species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals (Allen 1991). Conversely, it is not found in areas without branching Acropora corals.

Longevity data for the family Pomacentridae suggest that these species reach a maximum of around 10 years in the wild (Allen 1991). Pomacentrids mature fairly early, typically between 1-2 years and the average mature age is 3-4 years in a population. Thus, we infer that the generation length is about 3-4 years.
threats: This species is closely associated with branching Acropora, which has undergone significant declines (coastal development, destructive fishing methods, increased bleaching events presumably due to climate change) throughout most of the range of this species; therefore, its habitat is under threat.
population:
Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is locally abundant in some parts of its range (Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is especially abundant around the rock islands in Palau. It is very common in sheltered mangrove-lined channels in the Solomon Islands (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010).

This species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals. In northern Papua New Guinea, particularly in Madang Lagoon, Acropora cover has been declining over the past 13 years, with associated declines in A. ternatensis (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). Fish transect data recorded almost every year for the past 13 years has measured a population decline in this species of approximately 75% in northern Papua New Guinea (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). We infer that Acropora declines throughout this species' range would result in similar population declines of A. ternatensis.

From 1998-2004 there was a 30% overall destruction of coral reefs, of which 8% has recovered. In 2004, 28% of coral reefs remaining were considered to be at the critical stage (Wilkinson 2004). Of those coral reefs destroyed, Acropora is considered most affected in coral cover declines and a high percentage of Acropora in this region are considered vulnerable to extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

Based on these data, we infer that the A. ternatensis population is also declining at a rate greater than 30% over the last three generations (9-12 years).
range: Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is found in the Coral Triangle, including Indonesia, Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Palau, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu (Allen 1991).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in numerous marine protected areas (MPAs) throughout its range. However, population declines are still occurring in at least some of these MPAs (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: Rhomboplites aurorubens is widely distributed in deeper waters from North America through Brazil. Generation length is estimated as six to 14 years. Biomass declines of 20-66% over the past three generation lengths or more have been reported in parts of its range including the U.S. southeast coast and the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. Commercial landings have increased in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico as the fishery is becoming more efficient, but landings have decreased in the Mexican Gulf of Mexico. It is considered overexploited in Trinidad and Tobago and in Puerto Rico, and reductions of CPUE in the order of 50% have been documented in Venezuela. There is evidence of overfishing in several regions of Brazil. It is federally managed in U.S. waters, and stock assessments conclude it is currently not overfished nor undergoing overfishing. It is not targeted in Cuba and may find some refuge in deeper areas in its range. We suspect an estimated decline of at least 30% in its population over the past three generation lengths overall and it is listed as Vulnerable under A2bd. It is strongly recommended that population and fishery monitoring of this species be conducted and that management be developed or improved in areas it is fished.
habitat:
This species is found in moderately deep waters, most common over rock, gravel or sand bottoms near the edge of continental and insular shelves commonly from 40-100 m depth (Cervigón et al. 1993). Young fish occur in shallower depths. It often forms large schools, particularly the younger fish. This species feeds on benthic and pelagic fishes, shrimps, crabs, polychaetes, cephalopods and other invertebrates (Sedberry and Cuellar 1993). The spawning season for Gulf Vermilion Snapper is mid-April through mid-September (SEDAR 2006). The spawning period off North and South Carolina (Cuellar et al. 1996) and west-central Florida (Hood and Johnson 1999) is approximately the same. In Trinidad and Tobago, spawning occurs throughout the year, with a period of peak spawning from about June to November (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 1999). This species spawns between February and March in Abrolhos Bank, Brazil (Freitas et al. 2011).

In the eastern Gulf of Mexico, approximately 80% of females were found to be mature at one year of age, and 100% were mature by two years of age (Hood and Johnson 1999). This species can live approximately 20 to 26 years in the Gulf of Mexico based on otolith data (Allman et al. 2005, Johnson et al. 2010). Individuals recruit to the handline and recreational fisheries at about four to five years, and few individuals above 10 years are caught in any sector (SEDAR 2006). The average age of mature adults based on age frequency in commercial and recreational landings, is approximately five years (SEDAR 2006). In Trinidad and Tobago, this species appears to grow slower and attain a smaller asymptotic length, but has a longer lifespan than found in populations in higher latitudes. This may be attributed to different levels of exploitation, which may be higher in the latter areas (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 1999). A comparison of commercially caught legal and sub-legal Vermilion Snapper in the southwest US, suggested that the commercial crews are capturing large, young snapper, which may result in the heavily exploited stocks consisting predominantly of slow-growing individuals. Further, although the average growth rate appeared to have increased as compared to previous time periods (1979-1981 and 1985-1993), larger fish were not growing faster, suggesting that the portion of the population that is larger than the minimum size limit may be old, slow-growing individuals (Stephen et al. 2011).

Generation length was calculated with two primary IUCN approaches: 1). age of first reproduction + [z * (longevity-age of first reproduction)] and 2). 1/adult mortality + age of first reproduction. Estimates were 14 and six years respectively for each method using data from SERO (2010), for the US Gulf of Mexico, resulting in an estimated three generation length range of 18-42 years.
threats: This species is one of the more common deep-water lutjanids caught in the southeastern U.S., Gulf of Mexico, Caribbean and Brazil. Apart from being targeted in many fisheries, it is also caught as bycatch in shrimp trawls. An analysis of electric-reel, rod and hand-line fishing impacts on this species concluded that in terms of gear impacts on several aspects of this species and its larger community, the species is a yellow (good alternative, Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch) seafood recommendation (Fisher 2013). It has been recorded in the diet of the invasive Lionfish in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico (Dahl and Patterson 2014). Areas of high invasive Lionfish density may also affect populations on a localized basis; therefore, Lionfish removal may indirectly reduce predation on this species as with other lutjanids.
population:
This species is abundant, sizeable and important in many deeper water commercial, recreational and artisanal fisheries in its range.

United States
Genetic differentiation of Vermilion Snapper in southeast U.S. waters and the Gulf of Mexico was so small that it is likely that only one stock of Vermilion Snapper occurs in U.S. waters (Bagley et al. 1999). In Florida state waters, the majority of landings (80%) are in the Gulf of Mexico, with 64% of the statewide landings in the commercial sector (FWC 2014). Landings for this species in the US Gulf of Mexico were relatively low until the mid-1970s, when commercial landings increased every year until a peak in 1993 of approximately 1,200 mt, and then declined 33% by 1996. After 1996, there has been an overall increasing trend in commercial landings through 2012 (NMFS pers. comm. 2014). Recreational landings increased through the 1980s, then declined by about 50% between 1992 and 1996; recreational landings have remained fairly stable with moderate increases since 1996 (Schirripa 2000, NMFS pers. comm 2014). In the southeast U.S., total biomass and spawning biomass both gradually declined during the 1950s and 1960s, then steeply declined during the mid-1970s through 1980s. The SEDAR 17 (2008) assessment indicated that F2007 for Vermilion Snapper in southeast U.S. waters exceeded MFMT (F2007/FMSY = 1.27), which indicates overfishing. Spawning biomass had remained above MSST (SSB2007/SSBMSY = 0.86) throughout the time series, indicating that the stock was not overfished in 2007. However, the SEDAR 17 update stock assessment (2012) suggested much uncertainty in the terminal estimate of South Atlantic U.S. Vermilion Snapper status. The stock in 2011 was estimated to be not overfished (SSB2011/SSBMSY = 0.98) and not undergoing overfishing (F2009-2011/FMSY = 0.67). Since the mid-1970s in the southeast US, there has been more than a 60% decline in total biomass (1975 - 2011); current biomass is estimated to be below BMSY (SEDAR 2012, see figure 19 on pg. 77). In the South Atlantic, the estimated decline over three generation lengths is 20% over 18 years to 66% over 42 years (SEDAR 2012). It is not considered overfished or undergoing overfishing in the SAFMC. Discard mortality for R. aurorubens, inferred by the percentage of individuals that floated during a hook-and-line catch-and-release study, was 14-16% at depths of 36-54 m off the coast of South Carolina (Collins 2013). Based on summary information from FWC (2014), the SEDAR 9 (2006) assessment indicated that F2004 for the Gulf of Mexico Vermilion Snapper stock did not exceed MFMT (F2004/FMSY = 0.65). Spawning stock biomass was greater than MSST, and the SEDAR panel concluded the Gulf stock was not overfished at the beginning of 2005. The SEDAR 9 update stock assessment (2011) maintained that Gulf Vermilion Snapper stock was not overfished and was not experiencing overfishing through 2010. Based on SEDAR 9 (2006), biomass in the Gulf of Mexico declined by 45% over the past 19 yrs and SSB by 33.5% over the past 24 yr (within an estimated range of three generation lengths of 18-42 years). A stock assessment for R. aurorubens that accounted for changes in shrimp trawl fishing effort, expected to change bycatch rates of R. aurorubens, suggested that the population was not overfished or experiencing overfishing in the US waters of the Gulf of Mexico (Linton et al. 2011). It is not considered overfished or undergoing overfishing in the GMFMC. SEDAR 9 (2006) reports that R. aurorubens landings increased from 5.0 mt in 1955 to 1,061.2 mt in 2013 in the U.S. Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico combined.

Mexico
Landings from Mexico from 2005-2011 suggest a 62% decline over seven years, dropping from 2,794 mt in 2005 to 1,062 mt in 2011 (FAO Fisheries and Aquaculture Division 2011). Before 2005, this species was recorded as mixed-catch in Mexico

Cuba
Landings of R. aurorubens are not available from Cuba, where this species is common, but is not heavily caught (R. Claro pers. comm. 2014).

Trinidad and Tobago
Preliminary stock assessments conducted on snappers landed by the fishpot fishery of Tobago in 1993 indicated that, at that time, this species was over-exploited (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 1993, Lovelace and Solomon 2006).

Puerto Rico
In Puerto Rico, this species was considered overfished in the 1970s (Boardman and Weiler 1980). The Caribbean FMC groups Vermilion Snapper with other snappers and its current exploitation status is unknown.

Venezuela
In northeastern Venezuela, CPUE for handline catches of this species in artisanal fleets declined by more than 50% in 10 years between 1981-1992 (Mendoza and Larez 1996).

Brazil
Stock evaluation was conducted for the east central coast of Brazil (Klippel et al. 2005) during the REVIZEE program. This species was considered severely overexploited (Klippel et al. 2005, Vasconcellos et al. 2007). Towards the end of the 1990s, exploitation rates were well above the recommended limits (Klippel et al. 2005), a point reinforced for the Abrolhos Reef system by Frietas et al. (2011). This species is caught in other regions of Brazil, where it can be reported in separate or mixed categories with other deep water lutjanids.
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S. coast, Bermuda, the Bahamas, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea, and along the South American coast to Santa Catarina, Brazil (Allen 1985, Moura 2003). Its depth range is 20-300 m.
useTrade: This species is heavily fished throughout its range. It is targeted in commercial, artisanal and recreational fisheries. It is caught with hook and line, trawling and traps.
conservationActions: In the southeast US, Vermilion Snapper is managed as part of the Snapper Grouper Fishery Management Plan (FMP) of the SAFMC. Regulations currently include a minimum size limit of 12 inches total length, gear restrictions, an Annual Catch Limit (ACL), and a recreational bag limit of five per person/day in addition to the aggregate 10 snapper allowed per recreational person/day. The recreational ACL was 412,480 lbs for entire year in 2015. The commercial ACL was 876,520 for 2015, with the ACL split into two seasons (438,260 for 1 January through 30 June, and an equal amount for 1 July through 31 December). The commercial and recreational sectors are also now required to use non-stainless steel circle hooks when fishing natural baits north of 28°N latitude and dehooking tools to reduce bycatch mortality. There is a 1,000-lbs. (gutted weight) trip limit for Vermilion Snapper (reduced to 500 lbs. since 75% of the quota has been met or projected to be met). Commercial snapper/grouper vessels must have onboard NMFS-approved sea turtle release gear and follow Smalltooth Sawfish release protocol. Several SAFMC marine protected areas that prohibit fishing for snapper/grouper species include preferred habitat and known spawning locations for Vermilion Snapper off South Carolina and Florida (Sedberry et al. 2006). In the federal waters of the Gulf of Mexico, Vermilion Snapper is managed through the Reef Fish FMP. Management measures for the recreational fishery include gear restrictions, special management zones, a minimum size limit of 10 inches total length for up to 10 Vermilion Snapper per person/day within the 20-fish reef fish aggregate recreational bag limit. Non-stainless steel circle hooks and dehooking devices are required. Vermilion Snapper may not be used as bait. For-hire recreational vessels must comply with the more restrictive of state or federal regulations when fishing in state waters. Commercial regulations include the 10-in total length minimum size. There are no commercial trip limits or ACLs in the Gulf of Mexico. Vermilion Snapper is also included in the FMP for the Shallow Water Reef Fish Fishery of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands as part of Snapper Unit 1, along with Silk, Black and Blackfin Snapper. Management measures include gear restrictions and seasonal closures. The presence of deep reef marine protected areas may also provide protection from fishing in some countries.

rationale: Gobiodon axillaris is present in scattered localities across the Indo-West Pacific. It lives commensally among Acropora corals, particularly A. millepora and A. nasuta, which are experiencing declines globally due to a variety of threats. Acropora millepora and A. nasuta have declined by at least 20% over 30 years. Reef-building corals are experiencing declines globally due to a variety of threats including increasing sea surface temperatures, increasing severity of ENSO events and storms, and ocean acidification. In south and southeast Asia 65% of coral reefs have been effectively lost and an average of 27% have been lost among north Asia, the southwest Pacific Islands, and the Polynesian Islands between 1988 - 2008 where G. axillaris occurs. In addition, of the reefs remaining in south and southeast Asia, 40% of them are at a critical stage with 22% and 17% of those in north Asia and the southwest Pacific Islands, respectively, also at a critical stage. Over the past 10 years, given the severity of local and regional threats to coral reef ecosystems, as well as the impact of ocean acidification and increasing warming events, the rate of decline has probably not changed. Since this species is reliant on coral reef habitats and cannot survive on bleached or algae covered corals, it is an appropriate proxy for species population estimates. This species has experienced an average coral decline (effectively lost reefs) of 46% across its range from 1988 - 2008 resulting an estimated decline in habitat of about 27% over the past 10 years (2008 - 2018). This documented decline approaches the criteria for a Vulnerable listing but given the likelihood of continued coral habitat decline in the regions where this species occurs in addition to the documented critical stage reefs, habitat decline over a 10 year timeframe spanning some past and some future, e.g. 2015-2025, probably exceeds 30%. Therefore G. axillaris is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A4c.
habitat: Gobiodon axillaris is a marine, reef-associated, coral-commensal species (Harold et al. 2008), found occupying Acropora corals (Munday 2000). The maximum recorded length for this species is 5 cm. Adults mostly occupy A. nasuta and A. millepora (Munday 1999). Gobies are generally short lived species and probably have a generation length of less than three years.
threats: Reef-associated fish species, such as this one, have been documented to be particularly vulnerable to deleterious climatic changes (Comte and Olden 2017). This species appears to be associated only with particular species of Acropora corals. Reef-building corals are experiencing declines globally due to a variety of local and regional threats (Bruno and Selig 2007, Carpenter et al. 2008, Richards et al. 2008) including temperature extremes leading to bleaching and increased susceptibility to disease, increased severity of ENSO events and storms, and ocean acidification. Additionally, Gobiodon spp. do not survive on bleached or algae-covered corals (Sano et al. 1987, H. Larson pers. comm. 2019).
population: Given that this species is a coral-commensal species, specifically on Acropora spp., coral habitat is used as a proxy for population data. This species prefers A. millepora, and A. nasuta as adults, which have declined by at least 20% across this species' range over three generation lengths (30 years) (Richards et al. 2008), and probably more when updated coral data are available. In south and southeast Asia 65% of coral reefs have been effectively lost and an average of 27% have been lost among north Asia, the southwest Pacific Islands, and the Polynesian Islands between 1988 - 2008 (Wilkinson 2008). In addition, of the reefs remaining in south and southeast Asia, 40% of them are at a critical stage (50-90% loss of corals and are likely to become effectively lost in 10-20 years) with 22% and 17% of those in north Asia and the southwest Pacific Islands, respectively, also at a critical stage (Wilkinson 2008). Over the past 10 years, given the severity of local and regional threats to coral reef ecosystems, as well as the impact of ocean acidification and increasing warming events, the rate of decline, about 1-2% per year in the Indo-Pacific since 1997 (Bruno and Selig 2007, Carpenter et al. 2008), has probably not changed.
range: Gobiodon axillaris is broadly distributed in the Indo-West Pacific, from the Red Sea and Socotra (Yemen), Lizard Island (Australia) (Munday et al. 1997, Harold et al. 2008), Malaysia, Papua New Guinea (Munday 2000), the Ryukus (Japan), the Marianas, the Solomon Islands, Tonga, and Fiji (H. Larson in press). This species is found from 1-3 m depth.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place, though parts of this species range do overlap with marine protected areas (IUCN-UNEP 2018).

rationale:
Balistes puncatus is relatively widespread triggerfish in the eastern Atlantic, from Morocco to Angola. There have been pronounced triggerfish catch declines in Ghana and Togo over the past several decades. Overall, this species biomass decreased significantly from 1987-89 with virtually the same fishing effort; and from 1989-91 there was virtually no biomass recorded of triggerfishes in Ghanaian coastal waters. Some studies indicate that the fishery may have been under-exploited, with significant declines due to changes in environmental conditions. However, the Balistes fishery has not revived in Ghana, and more research is needed on the impact of environmental changes on this species population. 

Regardless, this species population has declined more than 99% in the Gulf of Guinea over the past 18-21 years (three generation lengths), which represents approximately one-third of its global range. Thus, overall population declines are inferred to be at least 30% over its entire range in the Eastern Central Atlantic. This species is therefore listed as Vulnerable under A2bd. It is highly recommended that population estimates and environmental conditions be reassessed throughout a wider parts of its range to confirm that this species is not more highly threatened.
habitat:
This species inhabits sandy and rocky bottom areas in coastal waters. The Fridtjof Nansen survey in 2005 in the western Gulf of Guinea caught this species in waters from Côte d’Ivoire to Benin, at depths of  22 to 32 m. The highest numbers of B. punctatus (26) were reported in a catch off Togo at a depth of 23 m (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). 

The lengths of aged individuals from the Fridtjof Nansen survey in 2005 ranged from 160 to 280 mm, with four to five year old fish being the most dominant. Approximately 68 % of the fish were less than seven years old.  Based on the growth parameter of B. capriscus: L∞= 295.27±15.22 mm and K = 0.40 (1/year), the growth parameters obtained from all back-calculation including end-points (derived data) of Balistes punctatus are calculated as L∞= 275.76±3.38 mm and K = 0.48 (1/year). Overall, the growth of B. capriscus and B. punctatus in the western Gulf of Guinea has not changed significantly for the last two-and-half decades (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). Based on similar life history characteristics with Balistes capriscus (i.e. similar size and habitat requirements), a generation length of six to seven years is estimated for this species.
threats: There have been declines in abundance of this species in the Gulf of Guinea (Aggrey-Fynn 2007) due to overexploitation and environmental factors.
population:
Reported catches for this species have essentially disappeared in approximately one-third of its range (in Togo and Ghana) in the Eastern Central Atlantic over the past 22 years (1988-2010).

FAO capture production for triggerfishes in the eastern central Atlantic show pronounced declines in catch in Ghana and Togo since 1987. Since the early 1970s, FAO annual catches of triggerfish in the Eastern Central Atlantic show two separate peaks between 1972 and 2003. The first catch peak (12,563 tons) occurred in 1979, and the second peak (17,250 tons) in 1986/87. Before 1979, triggerfish catch levels fluctuated from 2,830 tons (1972) to 9,138 tons (1977). In between 1979 and 1986/87, triggerfish catch fell to ‘regular or stable’ annual levels (c. 5,000-8,000 tons/year). However, triggerfish catch experienced a ‘sharp’ decline in 1988 to 2,862 tons and continued to decline to date with less than 0.5 tonnes reported in 2009 (FAO FishStat). Catch effort relationships available from 1972-1991, indicate that inshore triggerfish catches generally increased with inshore effort. Inshore catch decreased dramatically from 1979-80 with relatively similar fishing effort and continued to decrease until 1980-84, catches increased in 1984-1986 with increased effort and then decreased progressively with effort from 1987-91 (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). Overall, triggerfish biomass was highest in 1985 and then has steadily decreased until 1991 and to present. The biomass decrease was quite significant from 1987-89 at virtually the same effort; and 1989-91 there was virtually no biomass of the triggerfish resource in Ghanaian coastal waters (Koranteng 1998, Aggrey-Fynn 2007).

Historically, there is evidence of triggerfish exploitations in the early 1980s. FAO reported catches from the Soviet Union from fishing divisions deployed in Cape Verde, Sahara and Sherbro also show declines from 1970-1989. In the early 1980s, catches reported from Ghana were closer to the optimum fishing level, and there was no strong evidence that exploitation of triggerfish might have contributed significantly in the sudden collapse of the triggerfish resource in Ghana and the entire western Gulf of Guinea in the late 1980s. There is no previous report on mortality (M) for blue-spotted triggerfish, however Aggrey-Fynn (2007) have since estimated M = 0.8615. Although current exploitation rates show an under-exploited fishery, the Balistes fishery has not revived in Ghana, which could be attributed to local environmental factors. These environmental factors include the intense cooling along the coast of Ghana in recent years and triggerfish migration from cold coastal waters to warm offshore waters, and the unusual minimum mean temperatures experienced in 1979 and 1987 that have not been recorded again in coastal waters of Ghana (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). 

In 1979-1980, the demersal component of triggerfish assessed in bottom trawl surveys was 99,000 t (or 57.2 kg ha-1), or 62% of the total demersal fish biomass in Ghanian coastal waters (Koranteng and Pauly 2002). In May 1981-March 1982, the estimated biomass was between 314,000 and 500,000 t (Stromme et al. 1982, Ofori-Adu 1987, Ofori-Adu 1994, Aggrey-Fynn 2007).
range: Balistes punctatus is distributed in the Eastern Atlantic from Morocco to Angola, including Madeira, the Canary Islands and Cape Verde. It is found in photic waters up to 200 m deep.
useTrade: Balistes punctatus is an important coastal demersal resource in Ghana (Aggrey-Fynn 2007). It is also a minor component of the aquarium trade; online prices range from $249.95-$379.95 (bluezooaquatics.com accessed 28 April 2011).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. The distribution overlaps with marine reserves in parts of its range.

rationale: Canthigaster marquesensis is a coral-reef associated species which known from the Marquesas Islands, French Polynesia, and has been collected from Nukuhiva, Fatuhiva, Uapou, and Tahuata Islands. It is found at depths ranging from 12–42 metres. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species is 7,770 km2. The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 511 km2. AOO was calculated using ArcGIS based on a bathymetric clip of one to 50 m depth range from the ETOPO global relief model. Canthigaster marquensis is likely dependent on live coral cover for suitable habitat. Although most reefs in remote French Polynesia are in relatively good condition, severe bleaching events have been observed in the archipelago in response to warming sea-surface temperatures. Canthigaster marquesensis is vulnerable to habitat loss due to coral bleaching caused by global warming, and is found in few locations (under 10). It is therefore listed as Vulnerable under criteria B2ab(iii).
habitat:
Canthigaster marquesensis is associated with coral reefs.

There is no information on the spawning or social structure of C. marquesensis available. However, spawning, sexual dimorphism, and social structure have been observed in the field in other species of Canthigaster. In all species for which spawning has been described, males are larger than females and defend territories that include multiple females. Spawning occurs during the day and involves  the preparation of an algal nest on the substratum by the females into which eggs are deposited and fertilized by the male, and spawning occurs in multiple bouts, with no parental care after the last bout. This is consistent with field observations of spawning, social organization, and sexual dimorphism in other Canthigaster species (Gladstone 1987, Kobayashi 1988, Sikkel 1990, Sikkel and Sikkel 2012).

Canthigaster spp. are known for their general lack of characters, and are generally differentiated on the basis of colour differences.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads, and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Canthigaster marquesensis is likely to be impacted by habitat degradation due to coral reef loss in parts of its range. In Polynesia Mana, which contains 6,733 km2 of coral reef, the reefs are mostly healthy and under relatively low threat levels, with only 3% regarded as destroyed (90% loss in coral cover with little prospect for recovery) and 2% regarded as critically threatened (50–90% loss of coral cover) (Wilkinson et al. 2008). However, large-scale coral bleaching events have been observed in parts of French Polynesia in response to warming mean monthly temperatures (Mumby et al. 2001). Global warming is likely to negatively impact the habitat of this species.
population:
There is no species-specific population information available for C. marquesensis. Specimens of C. marquesensis are moderately common in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 28 March 2012). A database search revealed 17 museum collection specimens, all from the Marquesas, French Polynesia (FishNet2 search, 26 March 2012).

Due to its association with coral reefs, C. marquesensis may be experiencing population declines due to habitat loss in parts of its range.
range: Canthigaster marquesensis is known only from Marquesas Islands, French Polynesia at depths of 12–42 metres (Randall 2005). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) for this species is 7,770 km2 and the estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 511 km2.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species. It is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for C. marquesensis, however its distribution overlaps with marine protected areas.

rationale: Arothron inconditus is endemic to coastal South Africa, where it is associated with a variety of habitats, including beaches and river mouths, at depths ranging from 1 to 20 metres. Arothron inconditus does not appear to be common and there are few records of this species in museum collections. It is a shallow-water, limited ranging species with an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 742 km2 . AOO was calculated using ArcGIS based on a bathymetric clip of 1-20 m depth range from the ETOPO global relief model. It is known from few locations (<10), and is likely impacted by habitat loss due to coastal development. In particular, south central Durban is among the most heavily industrialized and polluted areas of South Africa. Therefore, A. inconditus is assessed as Vulnerable under Criteria B2ab(iii).
habitat:
Arothron inconditus is a colonial sessile insectivore (Halpern and Floeter 2008). In South Africa, juveniles of this species ranging in size from 36–65 mm (TL) can be found in quartzitic sandstone tide pools (Beckley 1985). This species has been recorded at great depths ranging from 100–400 metres, although this remains to be confirmed (Heemstra et al. 2006). SAIAB records 15 specimens in their collections, which were collected from habitats such as beaches and river mouths (SAIAB accessed 2012–01–18).

Fishes of the genus Arothron are widely distributed throughout the tropical regions of the Indo-western Pacific. Species have been distinguished primarily on the basis of their distinctive colour patterns due to morphological similarities between species.

Tetraodontids are characterized by a tough skin that is often covered with small spinulous scales, a beak-like dental plate divided by a median suture, a slit-like gill opening anterior to the base of the pectoral fin, no pelvic fins, no fin spines, a single usually short-based dorsal fin, a single usually short-based anal fin, and no ribs. They are capable of inflating their abdomens with water when frightened or  disturbed and are capable of producing and accumulating toxins such as tetrodotoxin and saxitoxin in the skin, gonads,  and liver. The degree of toxicity varies by species, and also according to geographic area and season (Allen and Randall 1977, Allen and Erdmann 2012). Fishes in the family Tetraodontidae have the smallest vertebrate genomes known to date (Neafsey and Palumbi 2003).
threats: Arothron inconditus is a limited-range endemic species which is found in shallow waters to depths of 10 m. It is likely to be impacted by coastal development in parts of its range. In particular, south-central Durban is heavily industrialized, and is considered to be one of the most heavily polluted areas of South Africa (Nriagu et al. 1999).
population:
There is no species-specific population information available for A. inconditus. Specimens of A. inconditus are rare in museum collections (FishNet2 searched 2012–03–28).

Arotheron inconditus specimens can be found in the museum records of Fishbase and the South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity (Fishbase.com 2011, SAIAB 2011). South African Institute for Aquatic Biology (SAIAB) records 15 specimens from diverse habitats. No specimens have been added to the collections of this facility since 1980, and no additional specimens have been located.
range: Arothron inconditus is endemic to the Southeast Atlantic, and is known from Knysna to East London, South Africa (Heemstra et al. 2006). SAIAB records indicate that this species was collected in 1981 in the Durban Harbor, which extends the known range of this species to the north east coast of South Africa (SAIAB accessed 12 January 2012). It is found at depths ranging from 1–20 metres. The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 724 km2.
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available for this species. It is unlikely to be utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for A. inconditus, however its distribution overlaps with several marine protected areas (World Database of Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: The Shortjaw Bonefish occurs from Hawaii and French Polynesia to the Seychelles in the western Indian Ocean, north to southern Japan and south to Lord Howe Island, Australia. Reflecting results in Colborn et al. (2001), the geographic range of A. glossodonta is likely representative of multiple species. Data on population decline are available from only a few locations, despite the expansive geographic range. In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they comprised only 7.5% of the total catch. This decline (37.1% in 15 years) was a result of overfishing, as opposed to a change in fishing method and effort (Beets 2000). Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). In Tarawa Lagoon, Kiribati, recent studies have demonstrated significant declines in abundance and average size of bonefish in the catch between 1977 and the late 1990s. Given fisheries characteristics throughout the region, we expect that in areas where bonefish are exposed to fishing effort that Tarawa serves as an example of what would likely occur in other areas throughout its range.  In addition, although data on population decline is limited, this species may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al.(2001) estimate that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year.  Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010).  The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007).  In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines.  In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011).  Given the  declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the Indo-Pacific region, so there is little economic incentive for conservation; we do not expect conservation to be occurring at present. Therefore, we estimate global decline to equal or exceed 30% over three generation lengths in the past (13.5 years), with some substantially greater localized depletions in parts of the Indo-Pacific. Perhaps the greatest hindrances to the global conservation of this species are uncertainties about population connectivity and taxonomic resolution. This species is currently listed as Vulnerable under A2bcd.
habitat:
This species is found on shallow flats, sandy bottoms, seagrass beds, mangrove shorelines and reef and rubble habitats. Like A. vulpes, A. glossodonta may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al. (2001) estimates that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year. Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010). The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007). In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines. In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011). Given the declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories.

Larvae of A. glossodonta are morphologically indistinguishable from A. argentea (then listed as A. forsteri) (Friedlander et al. 2008). Mean larval stage is 56 days (Friedlander et al. 2008). Maximum age recorded is 11 years  (Friedlander et al. 2008). Sex ratio varies widely across its distribution (1 to 1.25 in a study by Friedlander and 1–6.75 in another (Beets 2000). Although minimum size and age at maturity is not known, Albula sp. reared in the lab were sexually mature at two and three years of age (Pfeiler et al. 2000). Using equation number five of section 4.4 of the Guidelines for Using the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN Standards and Petitions Working Group 2008), if generation length = age of first reproduction + z*(length of the reproductive period), and age at first reproduction is estimated at 2.5 years, z is estimated to be 0.5 based on survivorship and relative fecundity with age, and the length of the reproductive period is estimated at 8.5 years, then generation length is estimated to be 4.5 years.

This species primarily feeds on crustaceans, including mantis shrimps and crab, also polychaetes, bivalves and amphipods (Friedlander 1997). Crustaceans comprised more than 50% of the diet in a Hawaiian study (Friedlander 1997).

Natural mortality from sharks is very high at Palmyra Atoll (Adams pers. comm. 2011). The maximum size for this species is 90 cm (SL) (Myers 1991).
threats:
Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have decreased dramatically over the past few decades, presumably because of overfishing and loss of habitat, from over 300,000lbs in 1900 to less than 3,000lbs. since 2002. Bonefish were the most important species in the commercial seine fishery between 1966 and 1970, with average annual yields of nearly 18,000 pounds. Although the presence of multiple species within the fishery makes species-specific declines hard to pinpoint, the commercial seine catch now averages only 581lbs per year, accounting for less than 8% of the catch. Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have declined from over 136.4 mt in 1900 to only 1.2 mt in 2001. This figure, however, includes all bonefish species in Hawaii (Friedlander et al. 2008).

Heavy fishing pressure and degradation of habitats at Tarawa and Kiritimati Atolls have resulted in the loss of pre-spawning staging sites and spawning migration routes, which may be responsible for the observed declines in bonefish catches, average size, and sex ratios at these locations (Friedlander et al. 2008). There are declines in CPUE, mean length and weight of fish and also a change in sex ratio (Beets 2000). Sex ratio (F:M) was 0.71:1 in 1977 and in 1992–1993 it was recorded as 0.15:1. In 1977, mean length was 46.4 cm and mean weight was 1.3 kg. In 1992, mean length recorded was 37.6 cm and mean weight was 0.84 kg. There was a decrease in the smallest size of sexually mature individuals between the two time periods: in 1977 the smallest size of sexually mature males was 42.5 cm  and 46.5 cm for females; in 1992 is was 32 cm for males and 35 cm for females. In addition, Beets (2000) conservatively estimates that the 30% of total catch was non-reproductive. In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they comprised only 7.5% of the total catch. Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). The effects of catch-and-release fishing on this species are unclear.

Unrestrained growth of human populations in the coastal zones has also accelerated habitat destruction, water quality degradation, and disruption of prey species dynamics. Fishing and habitat loss and degradation may pose the most significant threats to this species. Disruptions to shallow coastal ecosystems such as seagrasses and mangroves due to climate change may pose significant future threats to this species, particularly in areas with accelerated rates of coastal development and urbanization.

The limited range of this species may also make it vulnerable to local threats, such as habitat loss (Friedlander et al. 2008). It has been noted that habitat alteration, fragmentation and loss may contribute to the decline in abundance of this species in Tarawa (Beets 2000). Bonefish are closely associated with mangroves,seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Given the dramatic declines in these habitats (Mumby et al. 2004, Valiela et al. 2001, Polidoro et al. 2010, Orth et al. 2006, Short et al. 2011), we infer that comparable regional declines are likely throughout its range. Valiela et al. (2001) estimates that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year. Since bonefish rely upon habitats of limited extent, they are especially susceptible to habitat loss and degradation, particularly due to climatic and anthropogenic influences. These habitats are often fragmented in nature, exacerbating this issue. As with other coastal species, fragmentation will likely have direct and indirect negative impacts on bonefish.
population:
As multiple species within the genus are morphologically indistinguishable, there is limited species-specific information available on population status. Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have declined from over 136.4 mt in 1900 to only 1.2 mt in 2001. This figure, however, includes all bonefish species in Hawaii (Friedlander et al. 2008). A recreational fishing guide on Oahu indicated that although netting of bonefish continues, it is not as prevalent as it once was (Adams pers. comm. 2011). It is therefore unclear whether the decline in landings is due to a change in effort or a true change in population size. Capture of recruits (CPUE) of Albula spp. in Kahana, Hawaii was highest in 1999 and has declined by 79% since that time (Friedlander et al. 2008).

This species is rare in Mauritius (Sato et al. 2008).

In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they were 7.5% of the total catch. This decline (37.1% in 15 years) was a result of overfishing, as opposed to a change in fishing method and effort (Beets 2000). Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). A survey from the Fisheries Division of Kiribati conducted in 1995 shows that bonefish was the second-most common species caught, accounting for 7% of total catch. Gill nets caught 82% of the bonefish, with handlines providing the remainder (18%) of the catch (Friedlander et al. 2008). In Tarawa Lagoon, Kiribati, recent studies have demonstrated significant declines in abundance and average size of bonefish in the catch between 1977 and the late 1990s. The annual take of bonefish from Tarawa Lagoon is between 1,000,000 and 5,000,000 fish per year, but no stock assessment has been conducted (Friedlander et al. 2008). This species is probably the most abundant molluscivorous fish in the lagoon (Beets 2001). Comparison data from fished and protected locations at Palmyra Atoll show significant differences in population characteristics which may indicate that threats are expressed asymmetrically across its range (Adams pers. comm. 2011).  Given fisheries characteristics throughout the region, we expect that in areas where bonefish are exposed to fishing effort that Tarawa serves as an example of what would likely occur in other areas throughout its range. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the Indo-Pacific, so there is little economic incentive for conservation.  Therefore, we do not expect conservation to be occurring at present.

Like A. vulpes, A. glossodonta  may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al.
