(2001) estimate that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year.   Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010).  The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007).  In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines.  In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011).  Given the  declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories.

Given population declines of at least 30%  over three generation lengths at Tarawa, significant habitat loss throughout much of its range, we estimate global decline to equal or exceed 30% over three generation lengths (13.5 years), with some substantially greater localized depletions in parts of the Indo-Pacific.
range: The Shortjaw Bonefish occurs from Hawaii and French Polynesia to the Seychelles in the western Indian Ocean, north to southern Japan and south to Lord Howe Island, Australia. Its type locality is in the Red Sea (Bowen et al. 2008). Reflecting results in Colborn et al. (2001), the geographic range of A. glossodonta is likely representative of multiple species.
useTrade: Bonefishes are targeted by commercial, recreational, and subsistence fishers throughout the Pacific, including the Hawaiian Islands and Cooke Islands. Subsistence fishing for bonefish in locations such as Tarawa consists of one of the most important protein sources for the island's human population (Friedlander et al. 2008).
conservationActions: State regulations in Hawaii recently raised the minimum size regulation from 23 cm (9 in.) total length (TL) to 36 cm (14 in.) TL, although there is neither a closed season nor bag limit (Friedlander et al. 2008). Albula glossodonta likely occurs in Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) in parts of its range. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the much of the Indo-Pacific, so there is little economic incentive for conservation.

rationale: This species is known only from two streams on the island of Futuna, which have a length of 2 km and 1.5 km: its area of occupancy is less than 10 km²<sup></sup>, and extent of occurrence is less than 100 km²<sup></sup>. The species is rare and due to the topography  of Futuna (very few or no estuaries), the preferred estuarine habitat of the species is  very rare and short (only 50 m long). Whilst there are no major threats currently known to the species, any future threats to the coastal and estuarine habitat preferred by this species could have a significant negative impact and drive this species towards extinction in a very short time. This species is therefore listed as Vulnerable (D2).
habitat: The species has been found only in two rivers, and due to the topography  of Futuna (little or no estuaries), the preferred estuarine habitat is  very small (only 50 m long). The species prefers sandy bottoms in the lower courses of rivers. The species is amphidromous (Keith and Marquet 2006 and 2011).
threats: There are no major threats currently known to this species. However, any threats to coastal rivers and estuaries (especially any barriers  to the species' migration) could affect this species in a very short time, due to its dependence on a very small area of estuarine habitat.
population: This species is very rare (Keith and Marquet 2006 and 2011).
range: This species is endemic to the island of Futuna (Wallis and Futuna). Futuna has an area of 84 km². It has been found in only two rivers on this island.
useTrade: There is no information on use or trade.
conservationActions: This species is not protected.

rationale:
This species is endemic to the Gulf of Mexico where it is restricted to vegetated estuarine salt marsh habitats from the Florida panhandle to southern Texas. It is sporadically distributed throughout its range and the overall population size is unknown. Due to the lack of sampling effort, it is likely to be more common than existing records suggest. Since the species is restricted to shallow marshes that are patchily distributed across this area, its area of occupancy (AOO) is likely less than 2,000 km². It is suspected that there have been significant population declines and population fragmentation over the last 10 years due to hardened shorelines, decreased freshwater flows into marshes, and marsh wetland loss, but there are no quantitative data available to confirm this decline or to determine the size of the reduction.

This fish is known to inhabit at least three natural reserves within its distribution. There are also ongoing programs focused on the restoration of its habitat, but success of these programs has not yet been determined. It is under review for placement on the US Endangered Species Act; it is considered threatened in Florida and it is considered to be vulnerable throughout the remainder if its range. However, quantitative information on population trend is lacking.

Based on its current restricted range and suspected continuing decline in range, habitat, and population size, it is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B2 (VU B2ab(iii)).
habitat: This intertidal, non-migratory species occurs in marine and brackish waters within subtropical climates (Baensch and Riehl 1991, Huber 1996). It inhabits estuaries, coastal salt marshes, and back-water sloughs. It occurs most abundantly in shallow, tidal Spartina cordgrass marshes and Juncus rush salt marshes and often schools in large numbers in the freshwater fringe of saltwater marshes (0-28 psu) (Thompson 1980, H. Jelks pers. comm. 2014). It likely feeds on small invertebrates (NOAA NOS 2009). Its maximum size is 6.5 cm TL (Robins and Ray 1986). It exhibits sexual dimorphism in body length, with females larger than males by a quarter to one-half of an inch (NOAA NOS 2009). It reproduces by internal fertilization via an elongate contact organ structure located on the anal fun of the males. Spawning occurs between March to August in shallow, flooded marsh areas. Females exhibit asynchronous oocyte development and have the ability to spawn over successive days, which is further supported by the presence of multiple oocyte stages (Lang et al. 2012). Size at first maturity for males is estimated to be ~2.1 cm. Larvae are usually seen in May and June and juveniles appear in July (Thompson 1999). Its average lifespan in the wild is 2-3 years (NOAA NOS 2009).
threats:
This species is dependent on a specific salinity range within coastal salt marshes with small interconnected intertidal creeks, a habitat that is being altered due to development throughout its restricted range (Lopez et al. 2011). It is highly susceptible to coastal development and hardening of shorelines (habitat alteration/destruction) and pollution.

In Louisiana, flooded marsh areas that provide important feeding, shelter, and breeding areas for this species are being destroyed by coastal erosion due to subsidence. This is a major problem throughout the lower Mississippi River delta system and on several barrier islands around Louisiana. Some areas where this species has been collected in that past have been eliminated by coastal erosion.

In addition to natural erosion, disposal of dredged materials along the coast will also lead to a loss or reduction of flooded areas (Schmitt and Chiappone 2012). As erosion causes further habitat loss and fragmentation, genetic diversity of this species is at risk because significant genetic mixing of separated populations is not likely to occur (Poss 1999). Population decline due to pollution and habitat loss is unknown, but likely and estimated to be <30% over 10 years or three generations (Schmitt and Chiappone 2012).
population: The overall population size is unknown for this species. It is likely more common than records suggest, which is likely due to sampling effort (Lopez et al. 2011, Lang et al. 2012, J. Tolan pers. comm. 2014). It is most common between southeastern Louisiana and Florida (Lee et al. 1980). Simpson and Gunter (1956) recorded this species as the rarest cyprinodontid collected among sixty stations from the Rio Grande, Texas to the Sabine River, Louisiana (400 miles). More up-to-date collection records are needed. It is consistently represented in collections from Louisiana following the 2010 oil spill (Jordan pers. comm. 2014). Significant population declines and population fragmentation are suspected over the last 10 years (which is longer than three generation lengths) due to hardened shorelines, decreased freshwater flows into marshes, and marsh wetland loss. However quantitative information on population trend is lacking.
range: This species is distributed in the Gulf of Mexico from Escambia Bay, Florida west to Aransas Bay, Texas (Simpson and Gunter 1956, Hoese and Moore 1977, Thompson 1998, Gilbert 1992, J. Tolan and H. Jelks pers. comm. 2014). It may be expanding its range off Texas (F. Pezold pers. comm. 2011). Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 163,078 km² (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 0-5 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated AOO is 21,834 km² (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 0-5 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO), but since it is restricted to shallow marshes that are patchily distributed across this area, its AOO is likely less than 2,000 km².
useTrade: This species could potentially be used for bait (H. Jelks and J. Tolan pers. comm. 2014).
conservationActions: This species is federally listed as a Species of Concern due to its rarity, impacts from human activities, and lack of information on its biology and ecology. It was removed from NOAA's National Marine Service Species of Concern list in 2011 and placed under the Endangered Species Act (ESA) (NOAA NMFS 2011). The American Fisheries Society listed F. jenkinsi as vulnerable throughout its distribution. It is also listed as threatened in Florida. It is also considered a species of Greatest Conservation Needed in Florida, Louisiana, and Mississippi (NOAA NOS 2008). It is present in three estuarine reserves within its distribution, including Weeks Bay in Alabama and Grand Bay in Mississippi, and Mission Aransas National Estuarine Research Reserve (NOAA NOS 2009). There are also several ongoing programs focused on restoring coastal marsh habitats for this species, but success of these programs has not yet been determined (NOAA NOS 2008).

rationale: The Bluegill Bully (Gobiomorphus hubbsi) is endemic to New Zealand where it occurs in the main North and South Islands as well as on Great Barrier Island. Due to its specific habitat niche requirements, this species has one of the patchiest distributions of all Gobiomorphus species in New Zealand. It is mostly found in low altitude rivers, close to the coast. Preferred habitats are fast flowing streams and rivers with gravel or cobble substrate, riffles and on the edges of rapids and torrents. It seems to be the most habitat and morphologically specific of all the Gobiomorphus species in New Zealand. G. hubbsi may be locally abundant at sites of preferred specific habitat, however the population of this species is considered to have been declining over the last thirty years and it is nationally assessed as 'At risk - declining', based on on-going or predicted population declines, according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system. The primary threat to this species is habitat loss caused by water abstraction. The particular river habitats and catchment position that this species prefers are also the ones that are under increasing levels of water abstraction pressure in many areas. Other threats include land use changes that cause increased sedimentation of interstitial spaces in the river substrate and artificial barriers to migration that are present in many parts of this species' range. Analysis of New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) data show a decline in the national presence/absence records of this species from 9% in 2001 to 5.8% in 2011, which is considered to provide an appropriate indication of overall population trend. This continues an apparent decline in presence/absence reporting in the NZFFD since the early 1990s and the five year rolling average of occurrence from 2005-2011 (the most recent data available) in the NZFFD is the lowest on record. This species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable based on an inferred overall population decline of at least 30% over the past 10 years. Continual decline in area of occupancy (AOO), extent of occurrence (EOO) and habitat quality is expected into the future leading to further population declines. Future rate of decline is expected to be unpredictable due to the widespread but fragmented nature of the population of this species, meaning threats and freshwater management will have a significant, but as yet unknown influence on the decline rate.
habitat: This species is mostly found in low altitude rivers, close to the coast. Preferred habitats are fast flowing streams and rivers with gravel or cobble substrate, riffles and on the edges of rapids and torrents (McDowall 2000). This species may be locally abundant in some large open canopy cobble or braided systems and they can dominate numerically in fast flowing rivers where conditions are favourable. G. hubbsi seem to be the most habitat and morphologically specific (tubular for moving between interstices, upturned mouth for invertebrate grazing and strong pelvic fins) of all the Gobiomorphus species in New Zealand (B. David pers. comm. 2014). It frequently tends to occur with Torrentfish (Cheimarrichthys fosteri), but seems to occupy a different habitat niche and is more hyporheic (McDowall 2000, B. David pers. comm. 2014). This species is considered obligately amphidromous. Adults are thought to spawn once a year in the spring. Males establish a territory beneath a rock where the female deposits eggs in a single layer. The male fertilises the eggs, which he then guards until hatching. Larvae rear at sea and small juveniles return to freshwater after several months (at a size of about 20mm) and migrate upstream (Atkinson and Joy 2009). The maximum total length is up to 93 mm. This species live up to 3 years and the estimated generation time is 1-2 years (McDowall 2000, NIWA 2013).
threats: The primary threat to this species is habitat loss caused by water abstraction, which is considered to be the main cause of the current population decline. The particular river habitats and catchment position that this species prefers are also the ones that are under increasing levels of water abstraction pressure in many areas. Other threats include land use changes that cause increased sedimentation of interstitial spaces in the river substrate and artificial barriers to migration that are present in many parts of this species' range.
population: This species may be locally abundant at sites of preferred specific habitat, however their distribution is patchy with a small area of occupancy (AOO) of 42 km2 (David pers. comm. 2014, NZFFD 2011). The population of this species is considered to have been declining over the last thirty years (R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014). Analysis of New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) data show a decline in the national presence/absence records of this species from 9% in 2001 to 5.8% in 2011, which is considered to provide an appropriate indication of overall population trend. This continues an apparent decline in presence/absence reporting in the NZFFD since the early 1990s and the five year rolling average of occurrence from 2005-2011 (the most recent data available) in the NZFFD is the lowest on record (NZFFD 2011, R Allibone, pers. comm. 2014). This species is nationally assessed as 'At risk - declining', based on on-going or predicted population declines according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system (Goodman et al. 2014).
range: The Bluegill Bully (Gobiomorphus hubbsi) is endemic to New Zealand where it occurs in the main North and South Islands as well as on Great Barrier Island (McDowall 2000). Due to its specific habitat niche requirements, this species has one of the patchiest distributions of all Gobiomorphus species in New Zealand (with the exception of the Tarndale Bully (Gobiomorphus alpinus)) (David pers. comm. 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: Torrentfish (Cheimarrichthys fosteri) is endemic to New Zealand where it is found in areas of suitable habitat in both the North and South Island. This species is considered obligately amphidromous and is found in fast flowing rivers with gravel substrate, often occupying the fastest flowing areas particularly in riffles, rapids and torrents. The maximum lifespan for this species is 8 years, with a maximum total length of up to 200 mm. The estimated generation time is 2-3 years. Although no complete population information is available for Cheimarricthys fosteri, it is considered that there has been a significant population decline of this species over the past ten years. Presence/absence records from the national New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) for the decades 1960-69, 1970-79, 1980-89, 1990-99 were assessed. A second analysis was carried out to eliminate method bias, using only electric fishing records to remove any effect of an increase in use of spotlighting, trapping or netting. A third analysis of the data was aimed at reducing the effect of inland distance and altitude and removed all records over 100 m and using just electric fishing records. All three analyses showed exactly the same trend that the decade from 2000-09 had 50% less C. fosteri than that of any of the preceding four decades. Additionally, data collected from the Manawatu River show that the number of sites where this species occurs has declined by about 50% and the number of specimens caught at these sites has also declined. The area fished is not available for all sites, but from the sites that do have these data available, it appears that the average area fished is the same for during the 1990s and 2000s, or has increased even as the catch rate has dropped. According to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system, this species is nationally assessed as 'At risk - declining - C(1/1)', which is based on a large population but with an ongoing or predicated decline of 10-70%. The primary threats to this species include barriers to upstream migration, habitat loss through water abstraction and land use changes causing habitat degradation throughout much of this species range. Additionally, considering long-term climate trends and water abstraction pressures, the availability of fast-flowing water for this very habitat specific species will likely to continue to decline. Considering analysis of data from the New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database and findings of long-term site-specific research, it is considered reasonable to infer there has been at least a 30% population decline over the last ten years, with a continuing reduction in area of occupancy (AOO), extent of occurrence (EOO) and habitat quality, therefore this species has been assessed as Vulnerable. This is considered a reserved assessment and it is suspected that if actual population trend data were available, it may reveal a greater rate of decline, quite likely to exceed 50% over the past ten years, which would justify this species being assessed as Endangered.
habitat: This species is considered obligately amphidromous. Spawning sites have not been formally described but aggregations of ripe females in lower river reaches have been documented. This species is found in fast flowing gravelly rivers, often occupying the fastest flowing areas particularly in riffles, rapids and torrents (McDowall 2000). It is generally found in more open canopy areas. This species feeds at night by grazing aquatic insects from stones and also from the drift. This species has an interesting size distribution; size tends to increase with increasing distances inland (Scrimgeour 1986). The maximum lifespan for this species is 8 years, with a maximum total length of up to 200 mm. The estimated generation time is 2-3 years (Tana 2009). Adults probably spawn once a year in summer or autumn. Larvae rear at sea and small juveniles return to freshwater when they reach a size of 16-20 mm in spring or summer.
threats: This species is a poor climber and therefore barriers to upstream migration limit inland penetration in many river systems throughout this species' range (Tana 2009). Habitat loss through water abstraction and land use changes causing increased sedimentation of interstitial spaces in the river substrate are also threats to this species. Additionally, considering long-term climate trends and water abstraction pressures, the availability of fast-flowing water for this very habitat-specific species will probably continue to decline.
population: Although no complete population information is available for this species, it is considered that there has been a significant population decline over the past ten years (R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014). Presence/absence records from the national New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) for the decades 1960-69, 1970-79, 1980-89 and 1990-99 were assessed. A second analysis was carried out to eliminate method bias, using only electric fishing records to remove any effect of an increase in use of spotlighting, trapping or netting. A third analysis of the data was aimed at reducing the effect of inland distance and altitude and removed all records over 100 m and using just electric fishing records. All three analyses showed exactly the same trend that the decade from 2000-09 had 50% less C. fosteri than that of any of the preceding four decades (Allibone et al. 2009; R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014). Additionally, data collected from the Manawatu River show that the number of sites where this species occurs has declined by about 50% and the number of specimens caught at these sites has also declined. The area fished is not available for all sites, but from the sites that do have these data available, it appears that the average area fished is the same for during the 1990s and 2000s, or has increased even as the catch rate has dropped (R. Allibone pers. comm. 2014). According to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system, this species is nationally assessed as 'At risk - declining - C(1/1)', which is based on a large population but with an ongoing or predicated decline of 10-70% (Goodman et al. 2014).
range: The Torrentfish (Cheimarrichthys fosteri) is endemic to New Zealand where it is found in areas of suitable habitat in both the North and South Island. It has not been recorded on Stewart or Chatham Islands (McDowall 2000). Upstream / inland penetration in river systems is substantial and this species is known to occur at 700 m elevation and 289 km upstream from the sea. High elevation is typically achieved only at relatively short distances inland, whereas long inland penetration is achieved typically only in low-gradient river systems (Tana 2009). Sparse distribution in some areas, particularly in eastern New Zealand may be due in part to absence or sparseness of riverine gravels. Absence from other areas, such as around Cook and Foveaux straits, the Marlborough Sounds, Fiordland and Stewart and Chatham Islands, may result from oceanographic conditions that do not favour return to rivers of the marine living juveniles (Tana 2009). Ecological and behavioural variables relating to the marine life intervals are the predominating factors influencing distribution and historical influences are of minor importance (Tana 2009).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no targeted conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable in view of drastic declines in abundance that have occurred in many areas in recent decades. The degree of decline over the entire range over the past three generations (about 15 years) is uncertain but probably exceeds 30 percent. Range extent and area of occupancy have not declined very much if at all.
habitat:
Habitat includes riverine, estuarine, and Atlantic coastal waters; also in certain lakes and reservoirs in the southeastern United States. Adults occur in saltwater except during the breeding season; they occur up to at least 200 km offshore. Juveniles move to sea when about 1 month old.

Spawning occurs in fresh or brackish water, in tidally influenced portions of coastal rivers (Bozeman and Van Den Avyle 1989). According to Lee et al. 1980, spawning occurs in deep swift water over hard substrates. According to Bozeman and Van Den Avyle 1989, spawning occurs in shallow areas covered with vegetation, old rice fields, and river swamps and small tributaries above tidal influence. Eggs sink and adhere to objects on the bottom (Scott and Crossman 1973); after a few hours the eggs unstick and drift downstream (Dadswell 1980). Larvae occur in or slightly downstream from spawning areas; juveniles may exhibit net upstream movement until emigration from freshwater in summer or fall (or, in some areas, the next spring) (Fay et al. 1983). Nursery areas in the Neuse River, North Carolina, were characterized by deep, black water draining hardwood swamps, with little salinity or current and with a mud or detritus bottom (Bozeman and Van Den Avyle 1989).
threats: Dams have reduced freshwater range and abundance (Page and Burr 2011). Habitat degradation, fishing, bycatch, and predation by recovering striped bass populations also have contributed to the decline (NMFS 2009).
population:
This species is represented by a large number of occurrences (subpopulations).

Total adult population size is unknown but surely exceeds 100,000 and likely exceeds 1,000,000. This is one of the most numerous fish species in the Hudson River estuary in New York (Hurst et al. 2004).

Abundance of river herring (alewife and blueback herring) has declined drastically in recent decades (NMFS 2009).
range: Range encompasses the North American Atlantic coast from Nova Scotia to the St. Johns River, Florida. The species has been introduced in reservoirs in several states, and in the Tennessee River system in Tennessee (Bozeman and Van Den Avyle 1989, Page and Burr 2011).
useTrade: Historically valuable in commercial fisheries.
conservationActions: Conservation needs include habitat protection and restoration, species management, and research on trends and threats.

rationale: This species is endemic to southern India, and is only known from 8 specimens, with the most recent collected in 1982. Little is known on its population. This species is only found in estuaries and near shore lagoons, a habitat that is highly fragmented and threatened by pollution and coastal development. As it only occurs in estuaries and lagoons of southern India,  most of which have been modified and/or polluted, the AOO is likely to be less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. Given that the AOO is estimated to be less than 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>, the population is severely fragmented, and there is continuing decline in habitat quality, this species is listed as Vulnerable under Criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat: Although there is very scarce habitat and ecology information available, it is a benthic species that inhabits marine and estuarine waters of coral reefs and lagoons (Mishra et al. 1999, Ramesh et al. 2008, Bhat et al. 2014). The maximum recorded length for this species is 7.8 cm TL (Wijeyaratne and Perera 1992).
threats: This species is found in estuaries and coastal lagoons, which are fragmented and threatened by coastal development and pollution.
population: Population data are limited for this species. This species is only known from 8 specimens, with the most recent collected in 1982.
range: This is a Western Indian Ocean species known only from India, from Madras (Chennai) to Trivandum (Pillai 1965, Venkateswarlu and Rao 1986, Mishra et al. 1999, Sekhar 2013, Bhat et al. 2014, Mohanty et al. 2015, Chakraborty et al. 2017). Records from Sri Lanka need to be verified (Wijeyaratne and Perera 1992). Based on the length of the coastline potentially occupied by this species, the AOO could be as high as 4,072 km2; however, as it is known only from estuaries and lagoons, which occupy a relatively small proportion of India’s coast, the AOO is likely to be less than 2,000 km2.
useTrade: This species is sought after in the ornamental fish trade (Mohanty et al. 2015).
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for A. griseus; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas; such as Pulicat Wildlife Sanctuary, India (Sivakumar 2013, IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: The Malabar Sole, Cynoglossus macrostomus, is a small-sized flatfish is known only from shallow, coastal waters of India, where it is found on soft sediments. This species is a desirable foodfish in India, although not directly targeted. Instead, it is taken in mixed-species demersal trawl fisheries and as bycatch in shrimp trawl fisheries. Historically, national landings of tonguesoles were reported in aggregate until 2007, when efforts were made to begin reporting landings by species, at least for the common species, such as Malabar Sole. Therefore, reliable population size and trend data are not directly available for Malabaar Sole prior to 2007. Historically, this species constituted a major component of the total flatfish landings, often representing more than 80% of the total catch of flatfishes. Since 2007, landings reported as C. macrostomus at the national level increased continually to 2012-2013, followed by a rapid decline to less than 20% of maximum landings. Similar declines were also documented in Indian waters for other species (such as sardines and other small pelagics); however, the causes of these declines have been variously attributed to population collapses (due to overexploitation or climatological factors) and to changes in fishing patterns and practices. Simultaneously, mechanized fishing effort, which is efficient at demersal trawling, increased over this time period and likely resulted in increased fishing pressure on this species. Exploitation ratios for this species are typically high; therefore, research is needed to clarify trends in fishing practices to determine changes in effort and whether landing declines can be attributed to population declines. Although mechanized fishing effort, which is efficient at demersal trawling, increased between 1985 and 2011, effort data for the past 10 years are not available. As such, it is difficult to definitively attribute these declines in landings to declines in population size. However, this species is a desirable foodfish in India, and at least some of the decline in landings in recent years is probably attributable to a decline in population size. Therefore, we suspect that population size has declined by at least 30% (and probably more) over the previous 10 years. Based on this estimated decline, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A2bd. We recommend a fisheries-independent research program be implemented to determine population trends in this species.
habitat: This species inhabits shallow muddy and sandy bottoms of the continental shelf and within the Malabar upwelling ecosystem (Jayaprakash 2002). Sudden increases in catches along the Kerala coast suggest large scale movements of these fishes following the monsoon season (Khan and Nandakumaran 1993, Jayaprakash 2000, Nair 2007). These movements are partly correlated with cyclical patterns of productivity and intensity of detritus, and settlement of food organisms to the benthos in inshore waters (Munroe 2015). Its diet consists of benthic invertebrates (Jayaprakash 2000). Its spawning season occurs from October to May, with peak activity occurring between October and January (Feroz Khan et al. 1993). Maximum recorded total length is 17.3 cm (Victor 1978). Maturity begins around 12 cm (Nair 2007) at 1-2 years of age (Feroz Khan and Nandakumaran 1993, Jayaprakash 2000, Manojkumar et al. 2014). Maximum age is about 5 years and natural mortality is 1.1 (Manojkumar et al. 2014); therefore, the generation length is suspected to be less than 3 years.
threats: This species is heavily exploited along the coast of India, particularly off Kerala (Manojkumar et al. 2014). It accounted for 35% by number and 26% by weight of juvenile sole captured in the commercial trawl fisheries of Mangalore and Malpe (Dineshbabu et al. 2009). Exploitation of both juveniles and adults increases susceptibility of this species to overexploitation.
population:
Species-specific population data are limited for this species. It is a major component of the flatfish landings in India (Vivekanandan et al. 2003, Nair 2007, Manojkumar et al. 2014). In Kerala, approximately 95% of flatfish landings consist of Malabar Sole (Jayaprakash 2000, Vivekanandan et al. 2003). Off Calicut, this species made up 5.8% of the total catch between 1987 and 1992 (Feroz Khan et al. 1993) and 93% of flatfish landings between 1993 and 2004 (Manojkumar 2006). Trends in abundance were correlated with southwest monsoon rainfall, sea level and solar periodicity at the decadal scale (Jayaprakash 2002).

Historically, national landings of tonguesoles were reported in aggregate; in 2007, efforts were made to begin reporting landings by species, at least for common species, such as the Malabar Sole. Since 2007, landings reported as C. macrostomus at the national level increased continually from 3,700 t to 35,000 t in 2013, followed by a rapid decline to less than 5,000 t in 2015, where it has since remained (CMFRI 2019). Similar declines were documented in Indian waters for other species (such as the Indian Oil Sardine: CMFRI 2019); however, the causes of these declines have been variously attributed to population collapses (due to overexploitation or climatological factors) and to changes in fishing patterns and practices (Kripa et al. 2018, Shetye et al. 2019). However, mechanized fishing effort, which is efficient at demersal trawling, increased from 1985-2011 (Manojkumar et al. 2014); more recent information on effort is not currently available. Although mechanized fishing effort, which is efficient at demersal trawling, increased between 1985 and 2011, effort data for the past 10 years are not available. As such, it is difficult to definitively attribute these declines in landings to declines in population size. However, this species is a desirable foodfish in India, and at least some of the decline in landings in recent years is probably attributable to a decline in population size. Therefore, we suspect that population size has declined by at least 30% (and probably more) over the previous 10 years.
range: This species is distributed along the entire coast of India, from southern Gujarat to West Bengal (Menon 1977, Feroz Khan et al. 1993, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003). It is found at depths ranging from 9 to 120 metres (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003).
useTrade: Species of Cynoglossus were previously not highly desired foodfishes, but in recent years tonguesoles have become important species along the west coast of India (Khan and Nandakumarn 1993, Vivekandandan et al. 2003, Nair 2007). In 2018, species of Cynoglossus accounted for 2.75% of the total demersal fish landings (R. Nair pers. comm. 2019). This species is a major contributor to the commercial fishery along the Calicut coast; however, a specialized fishery targeted only for this species does not exist. Most of the landings result from bycatch of other fisheries (Rajaguru 1992, Khan and Nandakumaran 1993, Jayprakash 2000, Nair 2007), including prawn trawl fisheries (Feroz Khan et al. 1993). The area between Quilon to the north of Kerala is an important zone for Malabar Sole landings (Manojkumar et al. 2014). Malabar Sole are commercially important on the Malabar Coast of India partly because it is the only fish available during certain periods of the year in the region (Seshappa et al. 1955). Catches are mostly made within two to three months immediately after the completion of the southwest monsoon when large shoals of Malabar Sole occur at the surface of nearshore waters (Sheshappa 1973).
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. In Kerala, India, a minimum legal size of 9 cm total length has been implemented and seasonal and spatial limits to mechanized fishing vessels have been enacted (Najmudeen and Zacharia 2019).

rationale:
This demersal, migratory species is endemic to the Gulf of California, Mexico. It inhabits coastal areas and is dependent on shallow water in the Upper Gulf for spawning and nursery habitat. This region has been altered by the damming of the Colorado River in the 1930s, resulting in increased salinity. The estimated generation length is about 12 years. A variety of intrinsic characteristics (e.g. late-maturing, long-lived, predictable spawning behaviour in a relatively small area) make it particularly susceptible to overfishing. An important extrinsic factor, the extremely high economic value of the swim bladder of the species, is a major incentive to catch this species for swim bladder extraction and export. This market pressure is ongoing, if not increasing, and is facilitated by a lack of effective surveillance and law enforcement in the region. Although the legal fishery was closed in 1975 due to concerns about overexploitation, there has been an exponential increase in poaching driven by illegal trade in its swim bladder to China since 2011. Poaching is highest in the Upper Gulf spawning grounds, with the preferred gear being gillnet, and has extended south to the archipelago during the non-spawning season. The capture as bycatch of the Critically Endangered Vaquita Porpoise (Phocoena sinus) in these gillnets has driven this endemic marine mammal to the brink of extinction.

There are no estimates of Totoaba population size (defined as number of mature individuals according to the IUCN Red List Guidelines). Estimates of effective population size are available, ranging from around 2,000–11,000 breeding adults, but this cannot be applied as an estimate of the population size per the Red List Guidelines. There is some evidence from genetic diversity and age-size structure of samples that suggests population stability. From 2015–2019, nearly 700,000 captive-bred juvenile Totoaba individuals were released into the wild to support population recovery, but further study is needed to understand the impact of these releases. Several studies have modelled potential biomass trajectories based on historical commercial catches and more recent estimates of illegal catch to evaluate different management scenarios and the level of effective protection. However, the models are not fitted to available data but rather driven by assumptions about population depletion, so they are not appropriate to apply to a Red List categorization, nor to construct an index of mature individuals.

Therefore, we used poaching severity as the basis for this Red List assessment. A precautionary approach is taken here for three reasons: 1) the species has been subject to sharply increased rates of poaching targeting large adult Totoaba for approximately one generation (since the early 2010s) despite legal protection and increased enforcement; 2) given the ineffectiveness thus far of these measures, it is plausible that poaching pressure will continue and 3) there is ongoing, if not growing interest to source the swim bladder of this species for illegal trade.

We suspect a past and future three-generation decline (1993–2029) of at least 30% based on the following: 

1) Estimated annual removals of adult individuals by poaching increased five-fold from approximately 6,000 individuals in the mid-1980s to 30,000 individuals by 2017; although, there is some uncertainty associated with these estimates.
2) The total mortality rate of Totoaba increased from the mid-1980s to 1991–1993 due to a sharp increase in poaching during that period. While declines may have started in the mid-1980s we have a higher level of confidence in the data that indicate declines starting in the early 1990s.
3) In the Upper Gulf spawning grounds where Totoaba aggregate in winter-spring, there has been a 99% decline since 2011 in the sympatric Vaquita Porpoise population due to incidental capture in illegal gillnets targeting Totoaba. Given that gillnet poachers search for and target Totoaba aggregations, it is plausible that a steep decline may have also occurred in the Totoaba population during the same period.
4) Annual average seizures of illegal Totoaba swim bladders have increased by five-fold from just over 500 per year in 2013–2017 to over 2,300 per year in 2018–2020. These numbers represent only a portion of the illegal trade, and are therefore inferred to be underestimates.
5) Targeted poaching of Totoaba is also evident in net removal statistics, with over 1,200 illegal large-mesh gillnets removed from the Upper Gulf spawning area from 2016 to 2020. 
Therefore, primarily based on the level of exploitation, this species is assessed as Vulnerable under criteria A4bcd. Given that there are inconsistencies in the available data, with evidence of increased poaching pressure countered by other indications of population resilience, and no direct measures of population trend, this assessment should be updated when additional data allow for a better understanding of this species’ status, especially since declines are expected to continue in the near future due to the ongoing high poaching rate. The change in status from the previous assessment is non-genuine and reflects an improved application of the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria, as well as improved availability of data.

The most urgent conservation need is to stop illegal fishing and trafficking of swim bladders. Conservation measures that have reduced fishing by the commercial fleet and provided protections of the spawning ground should remain in place. Improvements in fishery data collection are needed as well as research on the efficacy of the released cultivated juveniles to increase wild stock.
habitat:
This demersal species occurs on soft bottoms in coastal areas from brackish to marine waters. Adults have also been reported in in the northern and southeastern Gulf of California in rocky reef areas. Adults migrate to the Colorado River Delta to form spawning aggregations in winter/spring. Early juveniles utilize brackish waters/estuaries as nursery habitat. Immature individuals remain in the delta for up to three years before migrating south and returning to the delta for spawning the following year. Currently, this is the only confirmed spawning site, but additional research is needed to investigate other potential sites (M.A. Cisneros-Mata pers. comm. 2020). 

Variability of the Totoaba population growth rate is very sensitive to survival of pre-adults and adults (i.e. individuals older than five years) (Cisneros-Mata et al. 1997). However, there is no direct evidence that the Totoaba population has been reduced by the damming of the Colorado River. The maximum reported length is about 200 cm and maximum weight is 135 kg, although due to present overfishing, it is now rarely captured at this size (Cisneros-Mata 2020a). It primarily consumes fish and shrimp species. 

Age at first maturity is about six years for males and seven years for females; longevity is 27 years and the estimated natural mortality rate is 0.26/year (Cisneros-Mata et al. 1995, Cisneros-Mata 2020a).  

Generation length for this species is 11.94 years. This was calculated using survivorship and per capita recruitment rate data from Cisneros-Mata et al. (1997) and the following equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: 

G = Σ x lx mx / Σ lx mx
threats:
Overfishing is the primary major threat to this species (Márquez-Farías and Rosales-Juárez 2013, Cisneros-Mata 2020a). A large commercial fishery caused initial historical declines, though this fishery has been banned since 1975. The current threat is increased illegal fishing to supply swim bladders that are in high demand in the illegal Chinese market. Poaching is highest in the Upper Gulf spawning grounds, with the preferred gear being large-mesh (10–12 inch) gillnets, operated both passively and actively and has has extended south to the archipelago during the non-spawning season.

Heavy alteration of the Colorado River delta in the Upper Gulf of California due to upstream freshwater diversion by dams has resulted in its classification as a “negative estuary” (salinity levels are higher, rather than lower as they would be with freshwater inputs), impacting the only known habitat for spawning and growth of early Totoaba juveniles. Adult Totoaba migrate to this area and concentrate there for spawning in winter/spring, and juveniles remain there for up to three years. Totoaba are still able to spawn there, and the effect of increasing salinity on the Totoaba population is unclear, but recent studies indicate the species has been able to adapt to this environmental shift on some level (Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020c, L. Enriquez and C. True pers. comm. 2021).
population:
This species sustained an important commercial fishery from 1924 to 1975 with catches exceeding 2,100 metric tons (t) annually in the 1940s. Fishers captured particularly large amounts by targeting the annual spawning migration in the Colorado River Delta and Upper Gulf of California. Catches declined by over 97% to less than 100 t per year by the 1970s (Rosales-Juárez and Ramírez-González 1987). Annual catch peaked in 1942 at 2,261 t, and despite intensified fishing effort, the annual catch fluctuated erratically and declined to approximately 59 t by 1975. A fishing ban was implemented in 1975 to reduce pressure on the Totoaba (Government of Mexico 1975, Bobadilla et al. 2011). Modelling by Lercari and Chavez (2007) suggests the population was over-exploited during the last 20 years of the legal fishery, and it is likely that a population collapse occurred, although they attribute additional environmental factors.

The commercial Totoaba fishery started in the 1920s to harvest the fish for its swim bladder, which was dried and exported to China as a delicacy, but a commercial meat trade to the United States soon developed and became the primary driver of the legal fishery from the 1940s to the 1970s (Cisneros-Mata et al. 1995). From the 1980s to about 2010, Totoaba poaching was mainly for local meat consumption (Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020a). Cisneros-Mata et al. (1995) estimated that 6,218 adult Totoaba were poached annually in the mid-1980s in the Upper Gulf. Structured interviews with fishermen in the Upper Gulf found that most considered Totoaba biomass medium to high in the 1980s, but low in the early 2000s (Ainsworth 2011). While declines may have started in the 1980s, we have a higher level of confidence in data from Pedrín-Osuna et al. (2001) that indicate declines starting in the 1990s. Age series modeling by Pedrín-Osuna et al. (2001) found the mid-1980s to be a relatively low period of mortality, but it increased sharply from 1991 until by 1993 total mortality (from illegal capture, primarily) was almost quintuple that of natural mortality, and that the stock was over-exploited.

In the early 2010s, the swim bladder trade re-emerged, with Chinese traders willing to pay extremely high prices (see Trade section) for dried Totoaba swim bladders (EIA 2016), which uniquely resemble those of a native sciaenid fish Bahaba taipingensis (Sasaki 1989) fished to the verge of extinction for the swim bladder market (Sadovy and Cheung 2003). This black-market trade is driving the Vaquita Porpoise (Phocoena sinus, CR) rapidly toward extinction due to bycatch in the large-mesh bottom-set gillnets used to poach Totoaba in the Upper Gulf of California (Jaramillo-Legoretta et al. 2019), and is the primary threat to the Totoaba population (Cisneros-Mata 2020b). In the Upper Gulf spawning grounds where Totoaba concentrate in winter-spring, there has been a 99% decline since 2011 in the sympatric Vaquita Porpoise population. The Vaquita is likely more vulnerable to declines caused by these nets, not only because of its very small population (estimated at nine individuals in 2019), but also because the nets likely entangle animals of all ages, whereas only large-sized Totoaba are caught. However, poachers search for and target locations of schooling Totoaba, so it is plausible that their nets are at least half as effective at driving a decline in the Totoaba population over the same period.

Based on Totoaba individuals sampled in the early 2010s, Valenzuela-Quiñonez et al. (2015, 2016) and Rodríguez-García et al. (2020) concluded that the population displayed characteristics of stability based on analysis of age structure, genetic diversity, and presence throughout its historical range with some evident expansion to the south. An ongoing analysis of nearly 3,200 Totoaba swim bladders seized by Mexican authorities from 2013–2020 is yielding similar findings (L. Enriquez and C. True unpublished data 2021). The population may have benefited from the release of nearly 700,000 juveniles from captive breeding facilities in recent years (Jimenez-Esquivel and Domínguez-Sánchez 2020), although this remains to be confirmed by an ongoing genetic traceability study (L. Enriquez and C. True pers. comm. 2021). However, poaching in the Upper Gulf spawning ground represents a significant ongoing threat. Analysis of carcass dumps found onshore in the Upper Gulf during the 2016–2017 spawning period (poachers often slice out the swim bladder and dump the remainder of the carcass in the desert, although the meat is also eaten and sold) showed relatively few of the older, largest sized fish, which are most sought after by poachers. This was also reflected by these researchers’ interviews with poachers, who said that in 2018, catching Totoabas of a size necessary for the prized weight of a swim bladder over 1 kg (fresh weight) had become increasingly rare (Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020a). The presence of older adults in the population is considered important for reproductive viability (Cisernos-Mata 2020b). However, analyses of recently seized swim bladder indicate that the seemingly low occurrence of large individuals may be expected in the age structure of this population (L. Enriquez and C. True unpublished data 2021).

While both larval counts and biomass estimates obtained by insonification of schooling fish can be inaccurate, recent independent surveys in the Upper Gulf both reported steep declines over just one year (2017 to 2018): larval counts declined by 40%, and maximum larval abundance declined by 75% from 15.3 larvae per 10 square metres to 4.1/10 m2, despite increased search effort (Guevara-Aguirre et al. 2020). In addition, estimated biomass declined by 45% over the same period, from 36,429 t in 2017 to 19,294 t in 2018 (Nevárez-Martínez et al. 2020). While the larval decrease could be due to environmental factors (a significant decrease was observed in chlorophyll, suggesting possible reduced primary productivity), poaching pressure on spawners could not be ruled out (Cisneros-Mata 2020b).

Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020a) estimated that 29,680 adult individuals of Totoaba were poached for their swim bladders in 2017, a five-fold increase in estimated poaching over three generations, and noted that this could be an underestimate as subsequent information indicated that more fishing boats were active than originally estimated (the calculation was based on a range of 5 to 50 active boats per month during the spawning season). Cisneros-Mata (2020b) later wrote “In recent confidential communications (2019) we were informed that the number of vessels engaged in the capture of adult Totoaba easily exceeded 100” (moreover, bycatch in abandoned fishing nets was also not taken into account). In addition, an outbreak of Totoaba poaching was reported to the south in 2020 in Bahia de Los Angeles (Anon. 2020 and ProNatura Noroeste pers. comm.); Totoaba poaching in that area was previously noted by Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020a), and it is possible that Totoaba are poached throughout their distributional area, although levels have only been estimated in the spawning grounds. From 2013–2020, nearly 10,000 swim bladders were seized by authorities in Mexico, China and Hong Kong and the United States (EIA 2020, see details in Supplemental Information). The highest totals were in 2018–2020 (average 2,347 annually) compared to the five previous years 2013–2017 (average 521 annually). Almost all these seizures were the result of random inspections. Intelligence-led investigation is more indicative of the true trade volume: in 2019, China indicted 11 men accused of trafficking more than 20,000 swim bladders from Mexico over at least a four-year period (2019–2018, 2018–2017, 2017–2016 and 2016–2015 Totoaba illegal fishing seasons). A public-private programme has removed over 1,200 Totoaba gillnets from the Upper Gulf of California from 2016–2020 (unpublished information from the Programa de Eliminación de Redes en el Alto Golfo de California, see Supplemental Information), totalling over 200,000 m2 of illegal large-mesh gillnets (SSCS 2019a). Although net removals were highest in 2017–2018 (averaging 443 annually), and declined in 2019–2020 to an average of around 150 annually, it is evident that Totoaba poachers have expanded their range of fishing methods: they do not consistently leave their expensive passive gillnets unattended as in the past, but now also sometimes remain near them to defend them from net removal teams. In addition, net removal operations were reduced in these years due to these attacks (2019) as well as withdrawal during the COVID19 pandemic (2020), so the decrease in net removals does not appear to indicate a decline in poaching effort.

Since the closure of the commercial fishery in 1975, there are no reliable estimates of the size and trend of the Totoaba population (Valenzuela-Quiñonez et al. 2014, 2015, Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020b, Rodríguez-García et al. 2020). Two separate studies that were not yet published in peer-reviewed format at the time of this Red List assessment, modelled potential trends in abundance (in tons of biomass) based on estimates of illegal catch of adults and juvenile bycatch in shrimp trawl nets following the methodology of Martell and Froese (2013) as a starting point. Each calculated the Limit Reference Point (LRP) biomass, below which the population is in danger of being over-exploited, differently: Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020b) defined it as 12,136 t and Espino-Leal et al. (2018) as 18,771 t. In 2017, the former predicted that the population would be above LRP, whereas the latter predicted it to be below. Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020a) also estimate potential 2017 biomass from their estimated 2017 poaching rate of approximately 30,000 adults; this has a high level of uncertainty associated with sampling bias (estimates of the size and weight of illegally caught Totoaba). Their catch rate-based biomass estimates were 15,077 t and 8,478 t for 2017 (one above and one below the LRP designated by Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020b), and Cisneros-Mata (2020b) noted biomass could be as low as 4,400 or 6,000 t if the catch rate was underestimated. Reconciling differences between the biomass estimated by different methods is not currently possible (Cisneros-Mata 2020b), nor can they be readily converted to population estimates given uncertainty concerning average weights and age structure.

It should be noted that, in the past, Totoaba population recovery prospects have been predicated upon adequate legal protection from illegal fishing. For example, Cisneros-Mata et al. (1995) wrote that, “The recently declared biosphere reserve, which includes the uppermost region of the Gulf, may give the Totoaba and other endangered species in this unique region another chance, but only if enforcement of the fishing ban is successful.”  Márquez-Farías and Rosales-Juárez (2013) found that the intrinsic rebound potential of the species is low (r2M = 0.055), even assuming complete effectiveness of the fishing ban. Cisneros-Mata (2020b) stated that since 1975 “no measures or instruments have been effective,” and urged that “the most feasible alternative for the viability of Totoaba is to stop the illegal capture of reproductive adults, especially the older or oldest ones.” Given that illegal catch rates are likely underestimated (Cisneros-Mata 2020b), that measures of population status derived independently from catch estimates indicate a worsening trend since 2017, that poaching has resisted all attempts to deter it, and that interest to trade swim bladder is not abating and may be increasing, it is plausible that poaching pressure will continue and may increase beyond the status quo. It is also important to note that while there are recent estimates of effective population size (estimated number of breeding adults) (e.g. 1,900–2,760: Valenzuela-Quinonez et al. 2014; 4,250–11,120: UABC 2015), these cannot be used as an estimate of the number of mature individuals for Red List assessments (IUCN Standards and Petitions Committee 2019).

A secondary threat to the population could be bycatch of juveniles in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery (although other smaller sciaenid species taken as bycatch in this fishery do not appear to have been impacted). In the 1980s, Cisneros-Mata et al. (1995) estimated 120,834 individuals were taken as bycatch annually and some interpreted this relatively high number as an indicator of population abundance (Valenzuela-Quiñonez et al. 2015). Although a scientific observer programme on board this fleet began in 2004, bycatch estimates for Totoaba juveniles are not yet available (Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020b). Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020c) reported that Totoaba juveniles with lengths of 30–40 cm are most vulnerable. Cisneros-Mata (2020b) recommended that authorities fully implement the use of fish excluders in the industrial shrimp trawling fishery as García-Caudillo et al. (2000) estimated that Totoaba bycatch could be reduced by 80% with the full use of such devices.

While it is indisputable that habitat quality in the Colorado River Delta has been degraded by upstream dams which converted the formerly brackish-water habitat in the Upper Gulf of California into a hypersaline environment or negative estuary, the impacts on Totoaba are unclear and difficult to disentangle from impacts of fishing (Brusca et al. 2017). In addition, pre-dam flows were often low or non-existent given the arid landscape upstream in the southwestern U.S. (Brusca et al. 2017). Modelling by Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020b) suggests that population levels were highest before damming in the late 1930s, but this is also the period where fishing pressure was the lowest. The lack of natural variability after the river was dammed may have also caused a reduction of variability in the species itself (Botsford et al. 2011, Ruiz-Berreiro et al. 2019), and there is some evidence that the life history of the species has been altered compared to prehistoric times (Totoaba may have matured more quickly in low saline environments: Rowell et al. 2008). However, Valdéz-Muñoz et al. (2010) sampled Totoaba juveniles in Upper Gulf and Delta waters with salinities between 35.3 and 39.5% and reported that captures of juveniles and salinity had no significant correlation. In 2011, Totoaba larvae were found only in the saltiest part of the Upper Gulf, close to the former mouth of the Colorado River (Garcés-Rodríguez et al. 2018). However, extreme salinity levels were shown to be detrimental to the survival of Totoaba larvae in laboratory conditions (Giffard-Mena et al. 2020).
range: This species is endemic to the Gulf of California in Mexico where it occurs throughout the northern part and south to La Paz, Baja California Sur in the west and Mármol, Sinaloa in the east. Historically, this species’ southern limit was Bahía Concepción in the west and to the mouth of the El Fuerte River, Sinaloa in the east. Recent studies found juveniles in more southern latitudes (De Anda-Montañez et al. 2013, Valenzuela-Quiñonez et al. 2015), which may indicate new spawning grounds and/or positive effects from stock enhancement efforts. The capture of individuals in the Bay of La Paz and off Mármol suggest a possible southward range expansion by about 400 km (Guevara-Aguirre and Cisneros-Mata 2020), although these may represent extralimital records rather than full occupation, or the presence of captive releases. The depth range is 1–70 m (Hernández-Tlapale et al. 2020).
useTrade:
The species formerly supported an important commercial fishing industry and sport fishery in the Upper Gulf of California. Historically, the majority of the commercial catch was exported from Mexico to the United States as “sea bass.” It is also taken illegally by recreational sport fishers. Currently, although it is eaten locally for subsistence, its greatest value is for its swim bladder (“maw”) for the Chinese market, where the organ is cooked in a soup and valued as an investment product (Sadovy de Mitcheson et al. 2019). China has a massive legal maw trade, but Totoaba trade is illegal under Mexican and Chinese national laws as well as international law (CITES Appendix I). See the attached Supplementary Information for details on seizures of swim bladders and specimens from 2013 to 2020 and net removals from 2016 to 2020.

Totoaba maw fetches a premium price in China due to its large size as well as unique resemblance to that of a China endemic, the Critically Endangered Chinese Bahaba (Bahaba taipingensis) (EIA 2016, Sadovy de Mitcheson et al. 2019). Recently, prices for Totoaba swim bladder have been falling. From 2015–2017, the retail price of a dried Totoaba swim bladder sold illegally in China declined from about $60,000 USD to $25,000 per kg (C4ADS 2017, page 63). In 2014, local prices in the Upper Gulf of California were around US$8,000 per kg (fresh weight) (CIRVA 2014). In 2017, Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020a) reported that the price had fallen by half to about US$4,000 for a large, fresh 1 kg swim bladder (whereas small ¼ kg ones fetched just a few hundred dollars). However, after the coronavirus outbreak in February 2020, a Mexican journalist specializing in coverage of the region’s fisheries issues reported being informed by fishermen that “a swim bladder of one kg of weight that was previously bought for US$4,000 is now bought at US$2,200” (Mendez 2020). 

It has been theorized that a falling price paid to poachers could lead to reduction in poaching effort (Castellanos-Rico et al. 2019), but it is also possible that poaching efforts have increased to try to sustain previous income levels. Based on interviews, Cisneros-Mata et al. (2020a) learned that each fishing skiff poaching Totoaba captures between 6–20 individuals per trip, with exceptional catches up to 120 reported, and based on this, it was estimated that nearly 30,000 adult Totoaba were poached for their swim bladders in 2017. However, this could be an underestimate as subsequent information indicated that more fishing boats were active than originally calculated (the calculation was based on a range of 5 to 50 active boats per month during the spawning season), and Cisneros-Mata (2020b) later wrote “In recent confidential communications (2019). we were informed that the number of vessels engaged in the capture of adult Totoaba easily exceeded 100.” Poaching has since continued in a flagrant manner; on December 8th, 2019 it was estimated that at least 500 Totoaba individuals were captured in a single day’s mass poaching incident involving over 80 fishing skiffs (SSCS 2019b).
conservationActions:
Commercial Totoaba fishing bans have been implemented by the Mexican government on three occasions. Seasonal bans were implemented in 1940 and 1955 and a permanent ban was declared in 1975 (Government of Mexico 1975). In 1976, it was placed on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). After an evaluation of its biological status, the Totoaba was added to the U.S. Endangered Species list in May 1979, and consequently, import to the U.S. became illegal. It was later also placed on the Mexican Endangered Species List (SEMARNAT 2010), although Guevara-Aguirre and Cisneros-Mata’s (2020a,b) revisitation of the Mexican listing criteria suggest it should be down-listed to Threatened.

The spawning ground in the Upper Gulf was designated a biosphere reserve in 1993 (DOF 1993). In 2017 and 2020, much of the Upper Gulf was designated as a Gillnet Exclusion Zone (SADER 2017, SEMAR 2020). Although the commercial fishery has been greatly reduced to historic low levels, illegal fishing and poaching continued in the Upper Gulf after these conservation measures were enacted. These illegal activities are now facilitated by organized crime groups in the region and this has sharply increased in the past decade compared to previous years (C4ADS 2017, EAL 2018, Chase 2019, Cisneros-Mata et al. 2020a). There is an urgent need to stop illegal fishing and trafficking of swim bladders. In November 2020, the government of Mexico, for the first time, arrested and charged a group of Mexican nationals under the Organized Crime Law for trafficking Totoaba (FGR 2020).

Although hundreds of adult Totoaba individuals are sampled from illegal nets each year, scientists have not been able to gather basic data about this species that would facilitate effective conservation and management. The status of this species would be better understood if data on age, reproductive status, weight, and genetic samples were collected. 

Aquaculture facilities located in Ensenada in Baja California, La Paz in Baja California Sur and Kino Bay in Sonora are now in operation and facilitate enhancing the wild stock through release of cultivated juveniles. A genetic traceability study (parentage assignment) on juveniles from all supplemented areas within the Gulf is underway and should clarify the contribution of stocking to the wild population (C. True and L. Enriquez pers. comm. 2020).

Recommended conservation measures include eliminating poaching of pre-adults and adults and implementing an observer programme to evaluate juvenile bycatch (Cisneros-Mata 2020b). In December 2020, the Mexican government announced the final development stages of a comprehensive program for the Upper Gulf of California aimed at recovery of the Vaquita population and “eliminating illegal Totoaba capture” (SEMARNAT 2020).

rationale: The Blacktip Shark (Carcharhinus limbatus) is a medium-sized (to 286 cm total length) shark with a circumglobal distribution in tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate seas. It is demersal and pelagic on the continental shelf from inshore to a depth of 140 m, though mostly it occurs close inshore. It also often occurs in large schools near the surface, and it has inshore nursery grounds. The species is captured as target and bycatch in artisanal, industrial, and recreational fisheries and is retained for the high value meat and fins, unless regulations prohibit retention. The Blacktip Shark is estimated to be sustainably fished in areas where management measures are in place, i.e., the United States Gulf of Mexico, North Atlantic, Australia, and South Africa. Species-specific population trend data from these regions reveal population reductions of <20% over the past three generation lengths in the Gulf of Mexico and South Africa (27–45 years). The North Atlantic population reduction in the spawning stock fecundity was not to a level where the stock was overfished, while in Australia, stock assessments on the Blacktip Shark complex indicate stocks have recovered from previous overfishing and are now sustainable. In the Arabian Seas region, a population decline of 30–49% is suspected for the Blacktip Shark. Elsewhere, little data is available, but the species is exposed to intensive and unmanaged fishing effort and due to its preference for inshore habitats, has limited refuge from fishing pressure. There is evidence of declines in general shark catches in many parts of its range where there is a lack of management, despite ongoing high levels of effort; declines in whaler sharks across the regions Large Marine Ecosystems equate to a 54% reduction in the Blacktip Shark over the average past three generation lengths (38 years). This level of reduction is not species-specific and is informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Overall, it is suspected that the Blacktip Shark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (27–49 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Blacktip Shark is demersal and pelagic in tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate seas on the continental shelf from close inshore to a depth of 140 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). It mostly occurs close inshore including off river mouths, in estuaries, shallow muddy bays, mangroves, lagoons, and coral reef drop-offs (Ebert et al. 2013). It often occurs in large schools near the surface and has inshore nursery grounds (Hueter et al. 2007, Ebert et al. 2013, Kajiura and Tellman 2016, Amojil et al. 2018). The species reaches a maximum size of 286 cm total length (TL), males mature at 125–201 cm TL and females mature at 145–207 cm TL, with regional variation in these and age parameters; maximum size and size-at-maturity is smaller in the Northwest Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico than in the Indo-Pacific (Branstetter 1987, Dudley and Cliff 1993, Castro 1996, Carlson et al. 2006, White 2007, Tovar-Ávila et al. 2009, Moore et al. 2012, Smart et al. 2015, Jabado et al. 2016, Harry et al. 2019). Reproduction is viviparous with yolk-sac placenta and litter sizes of 1–11, a biennial-triennial reproductive cycle (varies regionally), and size-at-birth of 38–72 cm (Dudley and Cliff 1993, Castro 1996, Capapé et al. 2004, White 2007, Harry et al. 2019). In Australia and Indonesia, female age-at-maturity is 8.3 and 7.6 years and maximum age is 24 and 17 years; thus, generation length is 16.2 and 12.3 years, respectively (Smart et al. 2015, Harry et al. 2019). In South Africa, female age-at-maturity is 7 years and maximum age is 11 years, resulting in a generation length of 9 years (Winter and Cliff 1996). In the Gulf of Mexico and Northwest Atlantic, female age-at-maturity is 6.5 and 6.7 years and maximum age is 23.5 and 17.5 years; thus, generation length is 15.0 and 12.1 years, respectively (Carlson et al. 2006, Passerotti and Baremore 2012, Baremore and Passerotti 2013, Deacy et al. 2018, SEDAR 2020).
threats:
The Blacktip Shark is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is captured as target and bycatch in artisanal and industrial fisheries with multiple fishing gears including gillnet, longline, and trawl. It is retained for its valuable meat and fins, unless regulations prohibit retention. The species is caught in recreational fishing and mostly released and is also caught in beach protection programs that target large sharks (Dudley and Simpfendorfer 2006, Simpfendorfer et al. 2010, Reid et al. 2011, SEDAR 2020). Post-release mortality of sharks released alive was estimated at 44% and 31% for the United States commercial demersal longlines and gillnets respectively, and 19–23% for recreational line fisheries in the Gulf of Mexico (Mohan et al. 2020, SEDAR 2020).

In the Southwest Atlantic, artisanal fisheries are intense and there are largely unmanaged commercial fisheries in many areas. For e.g., in Venezuela, industrial and artisanal fisheries have exhibited peaks in catches followed by declines, indicative of sequential overfishing (Mendoza 2015). Off western Africa, fishing effort has increased in both efficiency and intensity during the past 50 years. For e.g, effective fishing effort of the small-scale fleet operating off Mauritania is estimated to have increased by a factor of 10 during the past 25 years (Gascuel 2007). The Blacktip Shark is occasionally caught in the Mediterranean Sea driftnet fishery (Walker et al. 2005). Across Southeast Asia, historic and current fishing pressure is high and intensive. For e.g., the South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008).

This species’ preference for inshore coastal waters means it is also threatened by habitat loss and degradation, including pollution and clearing, and climate change. Global climate change has already resulted in large-scale coral bleaching events with increasing frequency causing worldwide reef degradation since 1997. Almost all warm-water coral reefs are projected to suffer significant losses of area and local extinctions, even if global warming is limited to 1.5ºC (IPCC 2019).
population:
Genetic data indicate genetic structuring between ocean basins (western Atlantic, Gulf of Mexico, and Caribbean Sea distinct from eastern Atlantic and Indo-Pacific), potentially within ocean basins, and likely global male-biased dispersal and female philopatry (Keeney and Heist 2006, Sodré et al. 2012, Spaet et al. 2015, Almojil et al. 2018, Johnson et al. 2018, Bester-van der Marewe et al. 2019). Population trend data are available from three sources: stock assessments in (1) the Gulf of Mexico (SEDAR 2018) and (2) the Northwest Atlantic (SEDAR 2020); and standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) in (3) the Western Indian Ocean (M. Dicken and H. Winker unpubl. data 2020). The trend data from each source were analyzed over three generation lengths using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List Category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information).

First, the stock assessment from the northern Gulf of Mexico estimated that in 2016 the stock was not overfished and that overfishing was not occurring; the stock appeared capable of supporting the current fishing pressure (SEDAR 2018). The population declined from 1981 to the early 2000s, and then began to slightly increase, possibly in response to more limited catches in the latter years (SEDAR 2018). The spawning stock fecundity was estimated to have reduced from virgin levels in 1981 by 1–32%, but most likely by <5% (SEDAR 2018). The trend analysis of the northern Gulf of Mexico abundance for 1981–2016 (36 years) revealed annual rates of reduction of 0.2%, consistent with an estimated median reduction of 6.6% over three generation lengths (45 years), with the highest probability of <20% population reduction over three generation lengths.

Second, the stock assessment from the North Atlantic (from Maine to Florida) estimated that in 2018 the stock was not overfished and that overfishing was not occurring, although it had experienced overfishing in some previous years (SEDAR 2020). Although the spawning stock fecundity declined by 54% over 38 years from 1981 to 2018, it did not fall below the minimum stock size threshold (MSST) which is used as a benchmark for stock status (SEDAR 2020). The trend analysis of the spawning stock fecundity for 1981–2018 (38 years) revealed annual rates of reduction of 2.5%, consistent with an estimated median reduction of 59.2% over three generation lengths (36 years), with the highest probability of 50–79% population reduction over three generation lengths.

Thirdly, the standardized CPUE from the Kwazulu-Natal Sharks Board (KZNSB) bather protection program (South Africa) fluctuated but steadily declined from 1981 to 2019 (M. Dicken and H. Winker unpubl. data 2020). The trend analysis of the CPUE for 1981–2019 (39 years) revealed annual rates of reduction of 1.8%, consistent with an estimated median reduction of 20.3% over three generation lengths (27 years), with the highest probability of <20% reduction over three generation lengths. In contrast, both recreational and commercial fishermen as well as SCUBA divers have noticed a marked increase in the abundance of Blacktip Sharks off the KwaZulu-Natal coast since ~2006 (M. Dicken, KZN Sharks Board, unpubl. data 2016). Indeed, the Blacktip Shark is considered a common species off the KwaZulu-Natal coast and is one of the most commonly caught species in both the KZNSB program (Dudley and Simpfendorfer 2006) and competitive shore angling fishery (Pradervand 2004, Pradervand et al. 2007).

Additionally, standardized CPUE is available for combined Blacktip Shark and Australian Blacktip Shark (C. tilstoni) from longline fishery independent surveys in northwest Australia (Braccini et al. 2020). The CPUE for 2003–2017 fluctuated, but overall was mostly stable, although there was a high level of uncertainty as the catches were relatively low. The area of the surveys was closed to commercial fishing from 1993 to 2005 onwards and the fluctuating, but overall stable pattern is suggested to reflect either no major detrimental fishing effects on the population even prior to the closures or naturally low abundance that precludes detecting abundance patterns (Braccini et al. 2020). The lack of targeted fishing or incidental catch since ~2009 means there is no longer a threat in that region. Elsewhere in Australia, stock assessments for the Blacktip Shark species complex that consists of Blacktip Shark, Australian Blacktip Shark, and Spottail Shark (C. sorrah) suggest that while the northern Australian stock was over-exploited in the past, on the North and West Coast and on the East Coast the complex has recovered from previous fishing and is currently sustainable (Bradshaw et al. 2013, Grubert et al. 2013. Johnson et al. 2018). Two of the species in the Blacktip Shark species complex are difficult to visually distinguish which has hampered species-specific stock status determination (Johnson et al. 2018)

In the Arabian Seas region, the Blacktip Shark is a common component of fishery catches (Moore et al. 2012, Moore and Pierce 2013, Jabado et al. 2015, Spaet and Berumen 2015). In some areas, it is the most common species landed, for e.g., in the Gulf of Aden and off the Socotra Islands, Yemen (Shaher 2007).
