Management measures implemented in 2004, as part of the Gulf of Mexico red grouper rebuilding plan, include a reduced aggregate commercial shallow-water grouper quota, a red grouper quota within the aggregate quota, and a recreational bag limit of two red grouper within the five fish aggregate grouper bag limit (GMFMC 2008). The Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council established 16 marine protected areas (MPAs) in the Gulf of Mexico, such as the Flower Garden Banks, the Florida Middle Grounds, the Madison-Swanson and the Steamboat Lumps Marine Reserves and the Tortugas Ecological reserve (Coleman et al. 2004). Conservation of older individuals within some of these areas has been documented (Coleman et al. 2011, Koenig and Coleman 2013).

In Mexico, the grouper fishery is seasonally closed from February 15 to March 15 each year (since 2003) in Yucatan, Campeche and Quintana Roo (SAGARPA 2003). In 2017, the seasonal closure was extended two months from February 1 to March 31 (SAGARPA 2016). Other regulations include limiting commercial fishing permits, gear requirements (hook size), and a minimum size limit (SAGARPA 2009, 2014b). Cuban vessels fishing in Mexican waters operate under a set quota (Fernández et al. 2010, Monroy-García et al. 2014, SAGARPA 2014a). Species-specific grouper landings data would improve estimates of its population status and further reductions in fishing effort to levels prevailing in the 1980s (SAGARPA 2012, 2014a). Fishing by commercial fleets in the Campeche Bank during spawning season should be reduced as well as the capture of juveniles (Caballero-Arango 2013, Albáñez-Lucero and Arreguín-Sánchez 2014, Brulé et al. 2014, Tuz-Sulub and Brulé 2015). It is unclear whether the seasonal fishery closures have provided an opportunity to recover or not. Brulé et al. (2015) concluded that the hook size regulation in the Yucatan artisanal fishery provides little, if any, improvement. Furthermore, the current minimum size limit 36.3 cm total length is not enough and enforcement of this protective measure is currently unknown. Giménez-Hurtado (2005) proposed prohibiting fishing from zero to 20 metres depth to reduce juvenile mortality, extending the annual fishery closure to February-April to include east of the continental shelf to protect spawners, and prohibiting fishing deeper than 70 m to protect large adults and designate protected areas in critical habitats. These recommendations are supported by studies on catchability (López-Rocha and Arreguín-Sánchez 2008, López-Rocha et al. 2009).

In Brazil, marine protected areas (MPAs) are the main conservation tool for populations of this species, including the Abrolhos National Marine Park. Freitas et al. (2017) identified potential additional sites for protection on the Abrolhos Bank that are located outside the current MPA network. Recently, two large MPAs were established within a mosaic of MPAs around the oceanic archipelagos of St. Peter and St. Paul Rocks and Trindade and Martim Vaz. This area covers approximately 900,000 square kilometres, which increased coverage from 1.5% to about 21% of Brazilian waters. A fishing moratorium that included this species was established in 2014 by the Ministry of Environment (MMA 2014), although this has never been effectively implemented.

rationale: This widely distributed, demersal species inhabits deeper rocky to sand-mud bottoms on continental shelves, including the shelf edge and upper slope. It is taken in fisheries throughout its range. This species is especially long-lived, with a documented longevity of up to 85 years; this characteristic, combined with a reproductive strategy of protogynous hermaphroditism, can cause it to be particularly susceptible to rapid population decline from fishing pressure. Fishing caused total and spawning stock biomass declines in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico of 61 and 68% from 1975 to 2009 (end of data time series), and it is inferred that it remains at this low level to the current day. Landings in Brazil have declined due to overfishing since at least 1996 to 2006 by about 84 to 96%. Significant, but unquantified declines are also suspected in Venezuela and possibly Mexico. Conservation measures are in place in a few areas, but overall, protection from fishing remains insufficient. Therefore, it is suspected that at least a 30% global decline has occurred over the past 41 years (1975-2016), which is nearly one past generation length (46.5 years), and this decline is expected to continue in to the future over the next two generation lengths (93 years) due to no anticipated changes in exploitation rates or management efforts. It is listed as Vulnerable A1bd+4bd. Improvements in fishery management and monitoring are needed.
habitat: This demersal, solitary species inhabits rocky areas and sand-mud bottoms often in or near trenches or burrow-like excavations. It inhabits moderately deep waters on the continental shelf near the edge and on the upper slope (Smith 1971, Jones et al. 1989, Heemstra and Randall 1993, Harris and Sedberry 2011). It is often associated with tilefish species due to their similar ecological preferences (Roe 1976, Jones et al. 1989). Juveniles are found shallower and inshore of adults, and have been observed as shallow as 30 metres depth (Smith 1971, Cook et al. 2009, NMFS SEAMAP surveys). Its maximum total length is 125 cm (Haimovici et al. 2004). It consumes a wide variety of invertebrates (mainly brachyuran crabs) and fishes (Heemstra and Randall 1993). This species is a protogynous hermaphrodite and females transition to male at 81 cm total length or 22 years. An individual from Trinidad and Tobago was aged to 35 years (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 2000). It has been aged up to 85 years in the Gulf of Mexico (Cook et al. 2009) and a female size and age at 50% maturity of 54.7 cm total length and eight years (SEDAR 2011). Based on a longevity of 85 years, age of first maturity of eight years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 46.5 years.
threats: Overfishing is a major threat to this species. It is a long-lived, protogynous hermaphrodite, which increases its susceptibility to rapid declines due to fishing pressure. A recent regulatory shift of the U.S. Gulf of Mexico Red Grouper longline fishery to deeper (470 m) water could lead to increased fishing pressure on tilefish and other deep-water species such as H. flavolimbatus (GMFMC 2009, Coleman and Koenig 2010). Its habitat may be negatively impacted by roller-rigged bottom trawl fishing in parts of its range.
population:
This species has declined in many areas due to fishing. Abundance data are limited in many areas and catch is often not species-specific (i.e., lumped with other grouper species). According to stock assessment biomass data, catch and catch per unit effort data, this species is suspected to have undergone at least a 30% global decline or more over the past 41 years (1975-2016), which is nearly one past generation length (46.5 years), and this decline is expected to continue in to the future over the next two generation lengths (93 years) due to no anticipated changes in exploitation rates or management efforts.

United States: In the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, this species has been targeted by the commercial deepwater longline fishery since 1975 (SEDAR22 2011). The most recent stock assessment classified this species as not overfished with overfishing not occurring as of 2009, but model runs indicate it is on the boundaries of these definitions (SEDAR22 2011). Total biomass steeply declined beginning in the early 1980s due to overfishing, levelled off by 1993 at 12,912 metric tonnes, and has been stable at this lower level ever since. Total biomass in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico declined by 61% over 34 years from 33,667 in 1975 to 13,004 metric tonnes in 2009. In addition, spawning biomass declined by 68% over the same time period (30,319 to 9,593 metric tonnes) (SEDAR22 2011). An earlier stock assessment by Cass-Calay and Bahnick (2002) suggested that a decline in longline catch per unit effort (CPUE) had occurred for this species since commercial fishing commenced. A fishery independent survey conducted in the northern Gulf of Mexico since 1972, reported that relative abundance indices of this species significantly declined after 1985 (Pollack and Ingram 2010). This species has also been targeted by both recreational and commercial fisheries in the southeast U.S. Atlantic since at least 1962; commercial landings have been highly variable, and do not have an overall trend from 1962 to 2002; catch per unit effort in the recreational headboat fishery has generally been minimal, but declined by over 90% over 22 years from 0.008 in 1980 to 0.0001 in 2002 (Williams and Dixon 2003; Figure 1 in the Supplementary Information).

Mexico: In Mexico, this species comprises 1% of the mixed-grouper and snapper fishery catch. The grouper fishery, which is typically dominated by catch of Epinephelus morio, has experienced a 50% decline in landings and catch per unit effort over the past 30 years (Instituto de la Pesca 2010).

Cuba: This species is naturally uncommon in Cuba, and is rare in fisheries catch.

Venezuela: Snappers and groupers (including this species) have traditionally been exploited on the continental shelf and slope of Venezuela and Trinidad and Tobago by artisanal fishers, and catch has significantly declined due to overfishing (Mendoza and Larez 2004). The main species exploited by the handline and longline fisheries include the southern red snapper (Lutjanus purpureus) and Hyporthodus flavolimbatus (Mendoza and Larez 1996). Catch and effort of H. flavolimbatus generally increased from 1981 to 1991 when catch peaked at about 2,400 tons. Since then, catch and effort have been declining and historic lows were registered in the last years of the series (Mendoza and Larez 2004).

Brazil: In 1997/1998, a fishery independent survey conducted along the southern Brazilian upper shelf and slope (São Paulo to Rio Grande do Sul) considered this species to be 'rare' (0.5 kg per 1,000 hooks per hour and 1.4% of total catch by weight). It was also considered patchily distributed with the highest concentrations recorded at Santa Catarina around Florianópolis from 120 to 135 metres depth specifically on flat mud bottoms near deep trenches (Revizee-Score 1999, Haimovici et al. 2004, Haimovici pers. comm. 2007). There is no targeted fishery in Brazil, but it is retained as bycatch in longline and gill net fisheries that target Snowy Grouper (H. niveatus) and tilefish (Lopholatilus villarii) (A. Olinto pers. comm. 2007). It also occasionally occurs in bottom trawl fisheries that target angel sharks from 80 to 150 metres depth (M. Peres pers. comm. 2006). In southern Brazil, bottom longline and gill net fisheries targeting mainly wreckfish (Polyprion americanus), snowy grouper and tilefish have dramatically increased over the past decade. It has been recorded in commercial landings in the states of São Paulo, Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul, but statistics are generally lumped with other grouper (cherne) species. Santa Catarina State records commercial landings for H. flavolimbatus under "chene-galha-amarela", because it is a particularly important component of the catch in that area, but it may also be registered under the "cherne" category. In Santa Catarina, annual grouper landings declined by about 96% from 262,500 kg in 2002 to less than 10,000 kg in 2006 (Figure 2 in the Supplementary Information). In São Paulo and Rio Grande do Sul, where this species is apparently less naturally abundant, annual grouper landings declined by 84% from 1998 to 2005 (from about 98,000 to 16,000 kg; Figure 3 in the Supplementary Information) and by 90% from 1996 to 2005 (from about 400,000 to 40,000 kg; Figure 4 in the Supplementary Information), respectively. It is inferred that population trends of H. flavolimbatus mirror the documented overexploitation of the target species within this fishery (Haimovici et al. 2004, BRASIL 2004, Avila-da-Silva and Haimovici 2005). In addition, due the decline in target species, some longline fishers have redirected effort to other grouper species, which likely includes H. flavolimbatus (Peres pers. obs. 2007).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from North Carolina south along the U.S. Atlantic, throughout the Gulf of Mexico except Cuba, in the Caribbean Sea from Puerto Rico to Tobago and from Mexico to French Guiana, and off Brazil from 12°S to Rio Grande do Sul (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015). It may occur in areas between French Guiana and central Brazil. Its depth range is 30 to 370 metres.
useTrade: This species is exploited by commercial and recreational fisheries throughout its range. It is captured using longline, handline and gill net (Heemstra and Randall 1993).
conservationActions: Fishery regulations implemented in U.S. waters apply to the entire snapper-grouper complex, which includes this species. These regulations include a recreational bag limit of five grouper individuals per person per day. The SEDAR22 (2011) stock assessment review panel recommended further research into refining ageing data. Mendoza and Larez (2004) recommend implementing a biomass recovery plan that reduces fishing effort on the population in Venezuela.

rationale: This widely distributed species inhabits rocky and coral reefs and is naturally uncommon. It is heavily exploited by commercial and recreational fisheries through much of its range. Quantified population data are limited due to misreporting and the lack of species-specific reporting in mixed-catch grouper landings in several areas. According to catch per unit effort data, declines on mixed grouper catches of more than 80% over the past two generation lengths (44 years, or since the 1970s) have been reported for some areas in Brazil due to overfishing. Significant declines have also been reported, but are not quantified, in Trinidad and Tobago, Mexico and Cuba, and likely elsewhere in areas with large-scale grouper fisheries. Conservation measures are insufficient, and as a result, declines from fishing pressure are expected to continue in to the future. Therefore, a global-level decline of at least 30% or more is suspected to have occurred over the past two generation lengths and is projected to continue over the next generation length, which causes this species to be listed as Vulnerable A4bd. Improvements in fisheries management and monitoring are needed as well as area protection for spawning aggregation sites.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits rocky and coral reefs (Smith 1978). Small and medium-sized individuals commonly occur in mangrove-lined lagoons. It is more abundant in waters around islands than along continental coasts. It primarily feeds on fishes. Sex-reversal has been reported for this species. Juveniles mimic juveniles of the clown wrasse, Halichoeres maculipinna, which allows it to approach wary prey. Its maximum total length is 85.9 cm. Longevity has been reported as 28 years by Bullock and Murphy (1994) in the Gulf of Mexico, 31 years by Burton et al. (2015) in the southeastern U.S. and 41 years by Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip (2000) in Trinidad and Tobago. Age at first maturity likely occurs between 2-4 years. Based on a longevity of 41 years, age of first maturity of 3 years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 22 years.
threats: In areas where fisheries are developed, rapid population declines have been recorded. The species is slow growing, long-lived and has a presumed low natural mortality rate, which likely increases its susceptibility to overfishing (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 2000).
population:
This species is naturally uncommon throughout its range. In areas where fisheries are developed, rapid population declines have been recorded. Quantified population data are limited due to misreporting and the lack of species-specific reporting in mixed-catch grouper landings in several areas. According to catch per unit effort (CPUE) data, declines of more than 80% over the past two generation lengths (44 years, or since the 1970s) have occurred in Brazil due to overfishing. Significant declines have also been reported, but are not quantified, in Trinidad and Tobago, Mexico and Cuba, and likely elsewhere in areas with large-scale grouper fisheries. Conservation measures are insufficient, and as a result, declines from fishing pressure are expected to continue in to the future. Therefore, a global-level decline of at least 30% or more is suspected to have occurred over the past two generation lengths and is projected to continue over the next generation length.

United States: Landings for this species reported by the U.S. National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) are relatively low, due perhaps to the shallow water grouper closures. From 1999-2015, landings ranged from 800 lbs to 66 lbs (NMFS commercial dataset). Estimated annual landings from headboats in the southeast U.S. averaged 292 kg between 1986 and 2010 (K.J. Brennan NMFS, unpublished data from Burton et al. 2015).

Cuba: This species is naturally uncommon in Cuba and there is no species-specific fishery information, but declines are likely to have occurred.

Mexico: This species forms important spawning aggregations on Alacranes Reef, Campeche Bank, Mexico in the southern Gulf of Mexico that are heavily exploited by fishermen targeting all grouper species. It is not managed, and as a result, there is evidence of serious declines in the spawning aggregations. Species-specific information is not available (Aguilar-Perera and Tuz-Sulub 2011), but according to landings and CPUE data, declines of 50 to 60% in Mycteroperca bonaci over the past 36 years) are suspected in Mexican waters. Data on landings in Yucatan, Mexico indicate this species represented about 0.1% of the total grouper catch in 2014 (7.4 mt) and 2015 (6 mt) (SAGARPA, Delegación Federal en Yucatán, Subdelegación de Pesca, Departamento de Administración de Pesquerías pers. comm. 2016).

Bermuda: In the 1980s, a rapid development of trap fishing on shallow water grouper populations in Bermuda led to a seven year decline in grouper catches from 18.2 to 4.5 mt pounds per year (Bannerot et al. 1987); although, this trap fishery has been banned for a number of years.

Trinidad and Tobago: This species is taken by artisanal fishers off Trinidad and Tobago and declines in catch rates have been reported (Manickchand-Heileman and Phillip 2000, Mendoza and Larez 2004).

Brazil: Fishery independent data from research cruises and underwater surveys confirm a low abundance of this species n Brazil. During four research cruises of the Revizee Program conducted in the Abrolhos to Vitoria region of Brazil from 1996-1998, the CPUE for this species was 0.2 to 2.1 kg per 1,000 hooks, including 1.4 kg per 1,000 hooks in depths above 100 m and 0.3 kg per 1,000 hook in areas between 100 and 300 m. Densities are as low as 0.06 fish/100 m² in Santa Catarina shallow rocky reefs in southern Brazil (A. Bertoncini pers. obs.). Floeter et al. (2007) reported low mean densities of 0.03 fish/40 m² for coastal islands along Espirito Santo, and Pinheiro et al. (2011) reported a mean density of 0.05 fish/40 m² and frequency of occurrence of 3.2% for the oceanic island of Trindade. Hackradt et al. (2011), reported densities of 0.11 fish/28 m² in Paraná, southern Brazil. This species was recorded in Brazilian landings under mixed catch comprised of Mycteroperca species under the name "sirigado" or "badejo" until 2010, when official statistics were discontinued (Boletim Estatístico da Pesca e Aquicultura 2011). Ferreira et al. (1998) estimated that M. interstitialis represents 3% of the total Mycteroperca catches in northeast Brazil, with M. bonaci being the dominant species at 88%. Landings from Bahia (Salvador to Baixo Sul) from 2009 to 2014 indicate the species comprised 0.16% of the total catch in weight in the bottom longline fleet (G. Olavo pers. comm. Pro-Arribada Project 2009-2014). The overall trends for the badejo fishery report a decline in catch per unit effort (CPUE) of 12 kg/day/fisher in the late 1970s to 1.4 kg/fisher/day by 2000, which represents a decline of about 88% over a 25 year period (Costa et al. 2003). In addition, landings of the main target species, Mycteroperca bonaci, have declined by rates exceeding 30% over the past 30 years. No trends are available for this species, however, since this species is reported in the catches, it is likely that the same trend applies for this species. Fisheries operating in the Brazilian oceanic islands, including the Trindade and Martin Vaz insular complex and the Vitoria–Trindade submarine chain, have also heavily exploited this species since at least the 1990s (Martins et al. 2005, Pinheiro et al. 2010b, Pinheiro et al. 2011).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from Cape Hatteras, North Carolina south along the U.S., Bermuda, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from areas with reef habitat, throughout the Caribbean Sea to Brazil from Maranhao to Santa Catarina, including the Trinidade and Fernando de Noronha Islands. Its depth range is 1-150 metres (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).
useTrade: This species supports commercial and artisanal fisheries throughout its range. Its natural rarity prevents it from becoming a major target species, but it is taken along with similar, yet more abundant and more persistent species, such as Mycteroperca phenax and M. bonaci, which are heavily targeted (Ferreira et al. 1998). In the Caribbean, it is caught with hook-and-line, traps and spear (Heemstra and Randall 1993). It is of significant commercial value in Venezuela (Smith 1971, Gonzalez and Celaya 1986 cited in Manickchand-Heilmand and Phillip 2000). It is also commercially exploited in Bermuda (Smith 1971) and the eastern Gulf of Mexico (Bullock and Murphy 1994). In Honduras, the species is caught via handline, speargun, nets and sometimes traps (Gobert et al. 2005). It is of moderate importance to the southeast U.S. reef fish fishery (Burton et al. 2015).
conservationActions: Improvements in grouper fishery monitoring, management and regulation are needed in much of its range. In the U.S., this species is managed by the South Atlantic Fishery Management Council (SAFMC) under the Snapper–Grouper Fishery Management Plan (SAFMC 2013). The establishment of specific regulation for hook-and-line fishing activities around the oceanic islands of Brazil is recommended, as well as the establishment of area-based protection (MPAs or other legal instruments; Pinheiro et al. 2010).

rationale:
This widely distributed species inhabits coastal waters, including estuaries and mangrove habitats. It is commercially valued for its flesh and gasbladder throughout its range. Intrinsic characteristics that include large body size and aggregate spawning behaviour make it particularly susceptible to rapid population decline from overfishing. It is overexploited in Maracaibo Lake, Venezuela and northern Brazil. The population in Guyana is inferred to be in decline based on reduced catch rates and continued fishing effort. Catch per unit effort has significantly declined over the past decade in Suriname and some level of decline is also suspected for French Guiana. Landings in northern Brazil declined by about 30% over the past two generation lengths. In French Guiana, an overseas department of France located between Suriname and Brazil, there are strict limits on fishing licenses, gillnet length, and mesh sizes. However, due to high levels of continuously increasing Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing by boats originating from Brazil, Suriname and Guyana, overfishing is occurring in French Guiana. 

Regulatory measures are not in place or are insufficient in most of its range, and illegal fishing continues to be a major problem that negates efforts to reduce fishing (e.g. Suriname and French Guiana). In addition, mangrove and estuarine habitats, which are important spawning and nursery grounds, are undergoing degradation due to anthropogenic activities. This includes oil extraction activities that occur on and off the continental shelf of the region which have the potential to pollute and degrade these habitats. Based on fisheries dependent data, it is suspected that at least a 30% global decline has occurred over the past 20 years, which is nearly three generation lengths (25 years). Due in part to the lack of anticipated changes in management to discourage illegal fishing, reduce fishing effort or to promote sustainable fishing practices at the regional scale, this decline is expected to continue into the future over the next generation length (8.5 years). It is listed as Vulnerable A2bcd+4bcd. Significant, concerted improvements in regional-scale fisheries management, action to address illegal fishing and monitoring of the gasbladder trade are urgently needed.
habitat: This demersal species occurs along the coast mostly in shallow waters near estuaries (Le Joncour et al. 2020). It is commonly found over mud or sandy mud bottoms near mouths of rivers, estuaries and coastal lagoons. Juveniles and larvae shelter in mangrove swamps as nursery grounds (Carvalho-Filho 1999, Szpilman 2000, Barletta-Bergan et al. 2002, Barletta and Saint-Paul 2010, Rousseau et al. 2017). It forms spawning aggregations in estuaries in the spring and summer in Maracaibo Lake, Venezuela (Carvalho-Filho 1999, Montaño and Morales 2013). In São Marcos Bay, Brazil, spawning peaks twice per year, in November/December and March/April and estimated fecundity ranges between 9,832,960 and 14,340,373 oocytes (Almeida et al. 2016). The maximum length is 120 cm (Chao 2002). Total length at maturity is about 40 cm for males and females. Natural mortality from Maracaibo Lake (Venezuela) is 0.53, but there is a high degree of uncertainty associated with this estimate (Montaño and Morales 2013). Based on FishLife, the natural mortality for French Guiana was estimated to be 0.37 (Thorson et al. 2017, M. Tagliarolo pers. comm. 2020). It attains sexual maturity around 2 years of age and longevity is at least 15 years (Espinosa 1972). When applying an age at first reproduction of 2 years and longevity of 15 years, its estimated generation length is 8.5 years based on the following equation recommended by the IUCN Red List methods: Age at first reproduction + (Age at last reproduction – age at first reproduction)/2.
threats: The primary major threat to this species is overfishing, especially IUU fishing. Targeting of spawning aggregations by fishers contributes to large-scale declines. It is also impacted by degradation of estuarine and mangrove habitats from anthropogenic activities including intense fishing pressure in Guyana and Suriname with the widespread use of static trawls in rivermouths called 'Chinese seines' that capture a large amount of juveniles (Guyana Fisheries Department 2019). IUU fishing has been identified as a major threat by the Western Atlantic Fisheries Commission (WECAFC/FAO) (FAO 2015).
population:
Within its range, this species is most common in northeastern South America, and it is locally abundant in some areas there (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2009). Landings reported in the FAO fisheries statistics database are only available for Brazil beginning in 2002. Venezuela only recently began reporting catch of this species to FAO, beginning in the year 2016 at 2,310 t. Brazil landings declined by 28% over the past two generation lengths from 27,559 t in 2002 to 19,800 t in 2016 (FAO 2019). Reconstructed catch data are available through the Sea Around Us project with a start year of 1950 for the countries of Guyana, Suriname and Brazil. Landings steadily increased from 1950 to the 1980s, steeply increased in the 1990s, peaked at 30,148 t in 2002 and declined thereafter by 29% to 21,281 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). 

Venezuela: In Maracaibo Lake, Venezuela, commercial fishing intensity is high for this species, fish size in landings has declined, immature individuals frequently occur in the landings and the size of spawning aggregations are sharply reduced. Quantitative fisheries data have not been consistently collected in this area, but based on some stock assessment modeling, it is considered growth and recruitment overfished and at high risk of stock collapse (Montaño and Morales 2013).

Guyana: This is one of the most important species targeted by artisanal and trawl fleet fisheries in Guyana. The estimated catch of artisanal fisheries was 891 t in 2016 (Guyana Fisheries Department 2019). Catch and effort data are limited, but the largest and most important stocks are inferred to be declining. Many fishing vessels are unregistered and unlicensed. Catch rates have declined and fisher incomes have declined, particularly as fuel and ice costs increase. Data is currently being compiled to conduct a stock assessment (Guyana Fisheries Department 2019).

Suriname: In Suriname, this species is a primary target of a coastal fishing fleet that uses drift gillnets on open or decked wooden vessels. As in other countries, the high value of the gasbladder of this species constitutes an important incentive for the fishery. Landings statistics for this species are not available. However, there has been a significant decline in catch per unit effort (CPUE) over the last decade, and fishers have increased effort by remaining longer at sea and fishing longer nets. The introduction of the hydraulic winch on many gillnet boats allows for efficient retrieval of the nets, in many cases causing an effective increase in fishing when net length limitations are not enforced (T. Willems pers. comm. 2020). A data-limited method for length-based stock assessment reported a low spawning potential ratio of 15% for the species based on length data for 2017-2018 for Suriname and Guyana combined (T. Willems in prep). Conservation International Suriname is expecting to publish an assessment of catch profiles, CPUE, bycatch and discards in the coastal gillnet fishery in May 2020.

French Guiana: In 2018, this species represented 33% of captures of small scale artisanal fisheries in French Guiana with around 748 t landed (Weiss et al. 2019b). Though roughly estimated in 2012, total catch is not known due to the high level of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing. About 2/3 of the coastal fishing effort in French Guiana was conducted by IUU fishing fleets from Brazil, Guiana and Suriname (Levrel 2012). IUU Brazilian boats fishing in French Guianese waters fish with nets 12 km in length, which is five times the length of a single net on a French Guianese vessel. This level of IUU fishing effort offsets any beneficial management efforts attempted locally. Boats that participate in IUU fisheries are often illegal in their own countries and often operate outside of their own national framework (i.e. boats with no identification number or fishing licenses) (M. Nalovic pers. comm. 2020). The migration of Brazilian fishers to Amapá State has implications for French Guiana as its coast is illegally exploited by Brazilian fisheries (Jimenez et al. in press). Due to this high fishing pressure, this species is overexploited in French Guiana (Levrel 2012). Landings have not declined in French Guiana at the rate they have in neighboring countries. Due to the better condition of the stock in French Guiana, foreign fleets continue to fish illegally in French Guiana despite risking prison time and loss of their boats if caught by local enforcement agencies (F. Blanchard pers. comm. 2020). The planning process to conduct a data-limited stock assessment is underway for French Guiana (M. Tagliarolo pers. comm. 2020).

Brazil: In Brazil, this species has a higher abundance along the northern coast in the states of Amapá, Pará and Maranhão (IBAMA 2007), but can be frequently observed in fish markets of Rio de Janeiro (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020). According to a genetics study, the Amazonian coast extending from Amapá to Pará is considered to represent one stock. Despite improvements in technology, catches have continued to decline along the Amazon coast and illegal fishing is increasing. Low genetic variability may be an additional signal that this population has undergone a bottleneck due to overexploitation (Rodrigues et al. 2008). There is some suspicion that there is a separate subpopulation in the southern part of its range in Brazil, but this requires further genetic study (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020).

In Brazil, annual landings of this species were about 22,000 t in the 1990s, with landings from the Caeté estuary in eastern Amazon at about 122 t (Barletta et al. 1998). Landings in northern Brazil declined from 22,028 t in 2000 to 14,888 t in 2007 (Souza et al. 2003, IBAMA 2007), which represents a 32% decline over a 7-year time period, or nearly one generation length. In Pará State, fishermen reported that the size of individuals in catches has declined over time and that they have had to travel farther to find productive fishing grounds than in previous years. The number of vessel participating in the fishery increased over time and fishing efficiency increased with the introduction of GPS and other technologies (Mourão et al. 2009). In northern Brazil, this species has been considered to be fully exploited for over a decade. It is one of the five most significant fishery resources in the State of Amapá by frequency of capture and by volume. The variability in net mesh sizes used by fishing fleets operating in Amapá, Pará and Maranhão may lead to both growth and recruitment overfishing. Over the last 10-15 years, fishers from Pará and Maranhão have been increasingly fishing in Amapá waters and many fishers have migrated to Amapá over the past decade. This provides a challenge for both the management of fisheries and environmental conservation (Jimenez et al. in press). Fishing effort in the artisanal fisheries that target this species in Pará increased overall and catch declined on average from 1996 to 2007. Where catches did increase, it is presumably due to the increase in effort and the stock has likely declined due to overfishing (Seabra 2019). It is overexploited in Maranhão and immature individuals are frequently landed, which is causing growth overfishing (de Oliveira 2018). Landings from Santos, São Paulo, Brazil declined by about 20% from 2010 to 2019 (~one generation length), landing frequency declined by about 40% over the same time period and catch per unit effort increased from 14.5 to 19.6 (kg/frequency) (Instituto de Pesca 2019).
range: This species is distributed in the western Atlantic from the estuarine area of Maracaibo Lake, Venezuela to southern Brazil (~30ºS) (Cervigón et al. 1993, Aguilera et al. 1998). Records from the Gulf of Venezuela, Caribbean coast of Colombia and Panama require verification (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020). The depth range is 0-45 metres.
useTrade: This species is targeted by commercial and artisanal fisheries throughout its range (Barletta et al. 1998, Chao 2003, Mourão et al. 2009). The flesh is valued in fish markets of French Guiana and Guyana. The gasbladder is highly-valued in the international maw trade (with highest demand from China) and is marketed for supposed nutritional value and medicinal properties and is also used to produce isinglass (Tuuli et al. 2016, Jimenez et al. in press). The high market value of the gasbladder has driven increases in illegal fishing. Reliable data for gasbladder exports from Brazil are not available because much of the trade is illegal and unreported. The Brazil Ministry of Development, Industry, and Foreign Trade (MDIC) recorded a total export of fish by-products of approximately 500 t to Asian markets in 2015, the majority of which was composed of gasbladders with an average price of 38.76 USD/kg (Barone et al. 2017). Fishers interviewed in northern Brazil reported receiving 98.75 USD/kg for gasbladders (Jimenez et al. in press).
conservationActions: Due to the large size and commercial importance of this species, monitoring of its harvest levels and population numbers is needed. Regulatory measures are not in place or are insufficient throughout its range. This species was assessed as Near Threatened on the Brazilian National Red List. There are no known net length or mesh size or license limitations for Brazil or Guyana's gillnet fishery. The fishery in Lake Maracaibo is open access with no fishing regulation. Net mesh size limitations and a minimum landing size are recommended to improve management (Montaño and Morales 2013). The maximum number of boats in the Suriname fleet is defined by the annual Ministerial Fisheries Decree and was set at 468 licenses in 2020 (T. Willems pers. comm. 2020). The number of licenses in Suriname is higher than the national recommendations, though they are working to align the actual number of licenses with the recommendation. There is a mesh size limit and maximum length limitation of 2,000 m per boat (Department of Fisheries 2003), but this is not strongly enforced. The Suriname Fisheries Management Plan (LVV 2013) recommends the introduction of various measures to combat IUU fishing. In French Guiana, strict fishing regulations, including limits on the number of licenses and restrictions on the length and mesh sizes of fishing nets, are in place to control fishing effort. The French Guiana Regional Fisheries Committee (CRPMEM Guyane) is currently conducting a study to characterize the gasbladder market and its economic importance in French Guiana's fishing sector to recommend paths towards a sustainable market (M. Nalovic pers. comm. 2020). Since 2018, regulations have been in place and enforced to manage the gasbladder trade in French Guiana (M. Nalovic pers. comm. 2020). Conservation actions are urgently needed to combat IUU fishing.

rationale: This widely distributed species is common and abundant where it occurs over shallow coral and rocky reef. Coral reef habitat has declined by an overall average of 59% over the past 41 years. Its generation length is short and three generations is inferred as no more than 10 years. It has been documented as susceptible to predation by the invasive lionfish, which now occurs throughout its entire range. An overall 65% decline in prey biomass was directly observed over a period of two years in the Bahamas. However, species-specific declines are not available at this time. Based on this information, a suspected population decline of >30% is projected to occur over the next ten years due to predation by the invasive lionfish. Therefore, it is listed as VU A3ce. We recommend improved monitoring on the effects of habitat degradation and predation by the invasive lionfish.
habitat: Coryphopterus hyalinus is a coral reef-associated species that is found in tropical climates. It is a schooling species that hovers above the substratum mostly in deeper drop-off, and spur-and-groove habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999). It is also found near large coral columns and heads at the edges and slopes of patch reefs (depths of eight to 52 m) and feeds on plankton. It hovers above bottom in caves and shaded areas in reefs (Smith 1997). It is a benthic spawner. Fishes of this genus are sequential protogynous hermaphrodites (Cole and Shapiro 1990, Thacker and Cole 2002). Proxy life history data based on a study of Coryphopterus kuna: Larvae settle around 7-9 mm SL, adults mature at 10–11 mm SL and then only attain about 17 mm SL. It has a 60-day pelagic larval life and matures rapidly. They are sexually active in as few as three weeks and live for about two months after settlement. This is the first reported fish in which the pelagic larval duration is generally longer than the post-settlement lifespan, which indicates that C. kuna may represent the extreme of a bipartite life-history strategy: a relatively slow-growing pelagic larval stage, often with delayed metamorphosis, in combination with a rapidly maturing, high-mortality adult stage (Victor et al. 2010). Based on this information, it is inferred that three generation lengths are almost certainly no more than ten years.
threats:
Coryphopterus hyalinus is occasionally taken for the aquarium trade, however it is unlikely to be collected across its entire range and its short generation length makes it resilient to moderate levels of threats.

Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease (Jackson et al. 2014). Coryphopterus hyalinus has been identified as a prey item of the invasive Lionfish in the Bahamas and Mexican Caribbean and likely in the remainder of its range (Morris and Akins 2009, Cote and Maljkovic 2010, Green et al. 2012, Valdez-Moreno et al. 2012). It is easily targeted by the lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species are likely consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: This species is common. In a survey conducted in the western Caribbean, Coryphopterus hyalinus was one of the most dominant goby species in coral drop-off habitats (Greenfield and Johnson 1999).
range: Coryphopterus hyalinus is distributed in the western Atlantic from Bermuda, the Bahamas, in the Gulf of Mexico from the Florida Keys, the Flower Garden Banks, and Veracruz, Mexico along the northern Yucatan to northwestern Cuba, and throughout the Caribbean to Trinidad (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014).
useTrade: Coryphopterus hyalinus is harvested for the aquarium trade, however, it may also be bred in captivity.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale:
Global Assessment: This extremely shallow-water species has a restricted range which could easily be impacted by oil spills. Surveys and monitoring are needed to determine the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.

The Persian Gulf Regional Assessment: This species is known from only two specimens (one record) in the Gulf (Manifa, Saudi Arabia). Oceanographic data suggests that a rescue effect through the Strait of Hormuz is negligible. Therefore, Omobranchus mekranensis is listed as Vulnerable D2.
habitat:
Omobranchus mekranensis is a marine, demersal species that occurs in tropical climates. It is typically found in areas with rocks, sand, and sparse corals (Springer and Gomon 1975). Maximum total length for this species is 6.0 cm or 60 mm male/unsexed (Randall 1995).  

This species has an oviparous life cycle, exhibits distinct pairing, and produces demersal, adhesive eggs (Breder and Rosen 1966).
threats: Substantial sea bottom dredging, resulting in changes of water flow and sedimentation rates, for industrial, infrastructure-based, and residential and tourism development along the coast have caused deterioration in most benthic habitats (Sheppard et al. 2010). For example, large number of desalination plants on the coast of the Persian Gulf leads to localized increases in temperature and salinity (Q. Alghawzi, D. Feary, and S. Hartmann pers. comm. 2014). It is not known whether or not this species is directly affected by this coastal development, but due to the large-scale of coastal development throughout the Persian Gulf and given this species' habitat preferences, it's likely it is impacted negatively in some parts of the region.
population:
There is no known population information for this species.

Oceanographic data suggests that a rescue effect through the Strait of Hormuz is negligible.
range: Omobranchus mekranensis is know from one record at the Manifa Oil Fields off Saudi Arabia in the Persian Gulf. Ghanbarifardi and Malek (2009) recorded three records of this species off three Iranian Islands (Chabahar, Ramin and Gwater Islands) in the Gulf of Oman. It is also known from three isolated records off Pakistan.
useTrade: This species isn't utilized.
conservationActions: Currently, there are no known species-specific conservation measures in place for Omobranchus mekranensis. However, its range overlaps with several marine protected areas (World Database on Protected Areas 2010).

rationale: This species has a restricted range (extent of occurrence of less than 20,000 km²) and is only known from one location (based on coral reef loss and degradation across its entire known range). This species is threatened by coral reef degradation, and due to its small range there is the possibility that a change in human activities could impact seriously. Therefore this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B .
habitat: This species inhabits holes in live coral reefs. Microhabitat is partitioned by age and sex. Females, non-breeding males, and juveniles are found on Gorgonia ventalina seafans, while nuptial males are found in Spirobranchus holes in live corals (several different species). Females lay their eggs in these holes and males fertilize brood them. Mature females have 21-27 eggs with tubes containing an average of 300 eggs at various stages of development. This indicates spawning deposits by multiple females. Breeding males range from 17.5 to 28.6 mm SL. Mature females are up to 19.6 mm SL (Tyler and Tyler 1999).
threats: Coral reef degradation is a threat for this species across its entire range.
population: This species is common, but with low abundance (Greenfield and Johnson 1990).
range: This species is distributed in the Caribbean Sea from Belize to Roatan Island, Honduras (Tyler and Tyler 1999). It has a relatively restricted range.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place. However, this species' distribution includes Marine Protected Areas.

rationale: This species is known only from three locations, possibly present in other similar places. Because it inhabits a heavily impacted estuarine environment, the species is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species is found in shallow bays and estuaries.
threats: This species may be threatened by sedimentation and agricultural/industrial pollution (Allen pers comm.).
population: There is no known population information for this species as it is known only from a few localities.
range: This species occurs from Godavari Estuary on west coast of  India to the Gulf of Thailand (mouth of river at Chantabun) (Eschmeyer 2001) and Nha Trang Bay, Vietnam (Nguyen and Nguyen 2006).
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps some marine protected areas within its range.

rationale: This species is known from only one locality, and is a very remote area and is inaccessible. It is also a designated marine park. There is a potential threat of oil and gas exploration at this site. It is recommended that surveys and monitoring be done on the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat:
This species is found on lagoon coral reefs at depths between about 3-5 m.

Meiacanthus are distinguished by having grooved dentary canines and associated glands. They are unique among fishes in having highly specialized toxic buccal glands. Species have a well-developed swim bladder and reduced vulnerability to predation that allows them to feed in the water column and forage over a wide area (Smith-Vaniz 1976).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. Potential threats exist from oil and gas exploration.
population: This species is known from one remote locality.
range: This species is known only from Rowley Shoals, Western Australia.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Rowley Shoals is a designated marine park with a total area of 876.7 km² (Wood 2007).

rationale: This species is only known from Norfolk Island and has an area of occupancy of less than 20 km².  There is no population information. Given its very restricted range and shallow water habitat, this species is subject to stochastic threats. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: This species is found near rocky shores in 1-10 m depth.
threats: This species is only known from one location (Norfolk Island), and has an area of occupancy of less than 20 km². It is vulnerable to a number of threats, including by-catch from resource extraction, marine debris and ghost fishing entanglement, and severe tropical storms and cyclones (DNP 2010).
population: This species is common (Allen pers comm.), and is locally abundant (J. Williams pers comm.). There is no other population information available for this species.
range: This species endemic to Norfolk Island, Australia.
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for this species. There are no protected areas within its restricted range, although Norfolk Island is not heavily populated.

rationale: This species is only found around the Easter Island, and has an area of occupancy of less than 1 km². Given that this species has a very shallow near-shore habitat, it is threatened by increasing tourism and coastal development throughout its restricted range. Coastal development and tourism has more than doubled in the past 10 years (since 2002), and is expected to substantially increase in the next 10 years. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species is found in shallow rocky shores and in tide pools to a depth of 2 m (J.T. Williams pers comm).
threats: This species has a very restricted range and shallow near-shore habitat. Easter Island has a circumference of 56 km, and given that this species is only found to 2 m depth, it has an area of occupancy of less than 1 km². Coastal development and tourism in Easter Island have more than doubled in the past 10 years, from 22,000 visitors in 2002 to over 50,000 in 2006. With the planned expansion of the airport in 2011, tourists visiting the island may number 200,000 by 2020 (Chile National Tourism Service 2008). Additionally, historical local extinctions at Easter Island on the sub-tropical fringe of the southern Pacific also suggest the possibility of climate-related species loss (Hawkins 2000).
population: This species is locally common and abundant (J.T. Williams pers comm.).
range: This species is known only from Easter Island.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps three designated marine protected areas in Easter Island (Wood 2007).

rationale: This species is known only from one reef (less than 20 square kilometres), at Raroia, Tuamoto archipelago. There are no known major threats, however, the restricted range makes this species vulnerable to extirpation from habitat degradation or a catastrophic pollution event (oil spill). It is recommended that surveys and monitoring be done on the status of the population of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: This species is known only from surge channels on a reef flat.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. Potential threats would be habitat degradation if it is really restricted to one reef  in the Tuamoto archipelago.
population: There is no known population information for this species. It is only known from two specimens.
range: The holotype and paratype were collected in Raroia, Tuamotu archipelago in 1955.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: Although not currently traded by marine aquarists, this species is potentially threatened by over collection for the marine aquarium trade because it occurs only at three reefs off the Coral Sea, which are popular tourist diving sites. It is recommended that surveys and monitoring be done on the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: Most species of Ecsenius are found on coastal fringing reefs and lagoons to 10 m; solitary or in small groups on coral outcroppings. For most Ecsenius species, juveniles and adults are almost entirely restricted to subtidal habitats with living coral. Little information is available on the reproductive habits and the early life history of species of this genus (Springer 1988).
threats: This species has characteristics that could potentially make it moderately vulnerable to over collection by the Queensland marine aquarium trade (Roelofs and Silcock 2008). This species is found only in three small reef systems that are popular tourist diving sites and for aquarium trade collectors.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is known only from 3 small reef systems in the western Coral Sea - Osprey, Bougainville, and Holmes Reefs.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Osprey and Holmes reefs are found within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

rationale: This species is not rare but apparently has an extremely restricted range and could easily be impacted by oil spills. It is recommended that survey and monitoring be done on the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species occurs on rocky bottom and is nearly always seen under the ledges swimming upside down (Randall 1995).
threats: No known threats but apparently has an extremely restricted range and could easily be impacted by oil spills.
population: This species is known from only four specimens from the type locality but has been observed at another location in southern Oman (Randall 1995).
range: This species is known only from Oman.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps some marine protected areas within its range.

rationale: This species is  known from very few localities. The environment where the species is found  is known to be affected by habitat degradation such as pollution associated with large human population. Survey and monitoring is needed to determine the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species is found in shallow brackish water in oyster beds (Springer and Gomon 1975).
threats: The environment where the species is found  is known to be affected by habitat degradation such as pollution associated with large human population.
population: There is no known population information for this species.
range: This species is only known from the South China Sea in a single oyster bed locality in southern shore of Deep Bay between Hong Kong and Macau (Sadovy and Cornish 2000).
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps some marine protected areas within its range.

rationale: This species is only known from one location (Revillagidedos Islands), with an area of occupancy estimated to be less than 2,000 km². Regional experts support the plausible threat of the increased duration and frequency of El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events that can cause severe and rapid declines for restricted-range, shallow-water species. This species qualifies for Vulnerable under Criterion D2. However, more research is needed on this phenomenon, and this species should be reassessed when new information is available.
habitat: Based on information from Dactyloscopus pectoralis, this benthic species is found on sandy substrate near reefs, and also in tidepools (De La Cruz Agüero 1997).
threats: This species has a very restricted range, with an area of occupancy estimated to be less than 2,000 km². In the Eastern Tropical Pacific, severe localized fish species declines have occurred after strong ENSO events that result in shallow waters that are too warm and nutrient poor for extended periods of time (Edgar et al. 2009). The frequency and duration of ENSO events in this region of the Eastern Tropical Pacific appears to be increasing (Glynn and Ault 2000, Soto 2001, Chen et al. 2004). Given this species' restricted distribution and relatively shallow water habitat, oceanographic environmental changes, such as those associated with future ENSO events, may have detrimental effects on the survival of this species.
population: There is no population information available for this species.
range: This species is only known from the Revillagigedos Islands in the Eastern Pacific, including Isla San Benedicto, Isla Socorro and Isla Clarion.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures for this species.

rationale: This species is apparently rare being found only in two isolated localities which may be impacted by habitat degradation. Surveys and monitoring are needed to determine the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species likely occurs in mangrove and brackish habitats and possibly rocky subtidal.
threats: This species' limited distribution may be impacted by general habitat degradation. Mangrove habitat is being removed in Bali and Sri Lanka for land-conversion to agriculture, oil palm plantations and fish farms (Gunawardena and Rowan 2005, Hamilton 2013).
population: There is no known population information for this species but is apparently rare, being found only in two isolated localities.
range: This species is known from two isolated localities in Sri Lanka and Bali (Bath and Patzner 1991).
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas within its range.

rationale: This species is only known from Christmas Island and has an area of occupancy of less than 20 km<sup>2</sup>.  There is no population information. Given its very restricted range and shallow water habitat, this species is subject to several stochastic threats. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: This species inhabits the intertidal zone of rocky shorelines (Myers 1991) to depths of 3 m.
threats: This species has a very restricted range and is subject to stochastic events including severe storms, disease and invasive species (Burbidge et al. 2010).
population: This species is common (Allen pers. comm.).
range: This species is known from Christmas Island, Australia in the eastern Indian Ocean.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. However, Christmas Island has one designated marine park with a total area of 87.26 km<sup>2</sup> (Wood 2007).

rationale: This species is found only in two locations in Halmahera Island, Indonesia, and it is threatened  by environmental degradation (mining). It is recommended that surveys and monitoring be done on the status of the populations of this species. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat:
This species is found in the lagoon side of the reef at 5 m.

For most species of Ecsenius, juveniles and adults are almost entirely restricted to subtidal habitats with living coral. Little information is available on the reproductive habits and the early life history of species of this genus (Springer 1988).
threats: Large areas around Halmahera are threatened by environmental degradation, including pollution from mining (K.E. Carpenter pers comm.).
population: This species is relatively uncommon (Allen pers comm.)
range: This species is known from at least two localities in Indonesia at Halmahera.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species.

rationale: This species is only known from a few locations (<5) in the Calamianes and Palawan Islands. A single record from Borneo may be an as yet undescribed species. Based on its restricted distribution and the likelihood of being heavily collected for the aquarium trade, it is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: This species is demersal and occurs in coral rich habitats at about 10 m depth, usually among Acropora branches (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001).
threats: This species is very likely threatened by collection for the aquarium trade, especially given the increasing evidence for species declines due to intensive collection in the nearby Visayas region (Nanola et al. 2010).
population: This species can be common where found (Allen pers comm.).
range: This species is known only from a few locations in the Calamianes and Palawan Islands, Philippines. A single record based on a colour photograph from Derawan, Borneo could be an undescribed new species.
useTrade: This species may be collected for the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas within its range.

rationale: This species is only known from Delagoa Bay, Mozambique, and has an area of occupancy of less than 20 km².  There is no population information. Given its very restricted range and shallow water habitat, this species is subject to a several threats, including periodic dredging, pollution and coastal development. It is listed as Vulnerable under criterion D2.
habitat: This species is found along shallow rocky shores, to depths of 5 m (J. Williams pers comm).
threats: This species is found in near-shore shallow waters (<5 m) and has a very restricted range in Delagoa Bay which surrounds Maputo in Mozambique. The bay and coastal zone area are threatened by degradation from periodic dredging, pollution and coastal development.
population: There is no known population information for this species.
range: This species is known only from Delagoa Bay, Mozambique and has an area of occupancy less than 20 km².
conservationActions: There are no species specific conservation measures in place for this species. This species likely occurs within the Inhaca Island Marine Protected Area, but it is unknown if this offers effective protection.

rationale: This species is only known from Reunion and has an area of occupancy less than 20 km².  It is recommended that surveys and monitoring be done on its population status, as this species is subject to stochastic threats. It is listed as Vulnerable under D2.
habitat: This species is found in rocks covered with algae in heavy surf at depths of 0-2 m.
threats: There are no major threats known for this species. However, this species has very restricted range, occurs in very shallow, littoral habitats, and is subject to a number of stochastic threats including severe tropical storms associated with cyclones and episodic high pollution (eutrophication) events (Harmelin-Vivien 1992, Chabanet et al. 1995, Naim 1993).
population: There is no known population information for this species.
range: This species is known only from Reunion Island.
conservationActions: There are no specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps several marine protected areas within its range.

rationale:
Shagreen Skate (Leucoraja fullonica) is an offshore species, usually occurring on the outer parts of the continental shelf, at depths of 30–550 m, and it has occasionally been recorded beyond 550 m in the Mediterranean Sea. In the Northeast Atlantic this skate is taken as bycatch in demersal trawl and longline fisheries throughout much of its range. Reported French landings were more than 370 tonnes in 1983, but since 1984 annual landings have been more stable and averaged about 75–150 tonnes. Recent captures of this species in Scottish surveys have been made in waters > 200 m deep, suggesting that its range has been constricted to deeper waters. However, accurate trends in abundance are hard to determine due to changes in survey techniques, as well as some uncertainty in the taxonomic identification in earlier surveys. It is suspected that there have been continuing population declines of 30-50% over three generations for the Northeast Atlantic subpopulation. 

Few data are available on this skate in the Mediterranean Sea, where it was recorded in only seven of 6,336 tows between 1994 and 1999 at depths ranging from 10–800 m during the International Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean. More recent records from 2008–2009 identified ten specimens in the southern Adriatic Sea, an area that this species was previously suspected to be absent from, although these records could be misidentifications. This species is rare in Mediterranean trawl surveys. However, this skate likely has a low intrinsic rate of increase suggested by its large body size and large size at maturity. Therefore, further analyses of survey data and close monitoring are needed to elucidate the long-term distribution and relative abundance of this species.

It is assumed that the rate of decline in the Mediterranean Sea is at least the same or worse than the NEA due to near absence of effective fisheries management there. Therefore it is inferred that this species meets the threshold for Vulnerable, given an estimated 30-50% overall decline in a three generation span from the NEA (from ICES 2012) and suspected 30-50% decline throughout European waters overall in a three generation span. This species potentially meets the threshold for Endangered and thus should be monitored, particularly in the Mediterranean.
habitat:
This benthic skate is found in offshore shelf and upper slope waters on sandy and coarse bottoms, predominantly found around 200 m depth but ranging from 30–800 m (Stehmann and Bürkel 1984, Ellis et al. 2005). In the Mediterranean Sea, it occurs in relatively cold coastal waters and on upper parts of continental slopes in about 30–550 m, but has also been captured in deeper water down to 800 m (Stehmann and Bürkel 1987, Bertrand et al. 2000, Baino et al. 2001).

Little is known about the biology and reproductive cycle of this relatively large-bodied skate. It is an egg laying species, producing egg cases that measure about 8 by 5 cm (Stehmann and Bürkel 1984). Specimens caught in the Celtic Seas and North Sea between 1992 and 2011 ranged from 21 to 96 cm and 24 to 70 cm total length (TL) in males and females, respectively (McCully et al. 2012). All female specimens were immature, while only two males at 75 and 96 cm TL were mature. The largest immature male caught was 82 cm TL. This species reaches a maximum size of 100–110 cm (Bauchot 1987). Based on the information available for its congener, L. naevus, the species has an estimated generation length of 9.7 years.
threats: The relatively large body size of this skate suggests that it is sensitive to exploitation. It is taken as bycatch in mixed demersal fisheries through much of its range, including mixed trawl fisheries operating in the outer parts and edge of the continental shelf in both the Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean Sea. In the Mediterranean Sea it is also caught as bycatch by both bottom trawl and longline fisheries (Stehmann and Bürkel 1984, Serena 2005). In the Northeast Atlantic it may also be taken as a bycatch in gillnet fisheries targeting anglerfish and longline fisheries targeting hake, though information on the catches in these fisheries are poor.
population:
It is likely that there is poor connection between the two deepwater subpopulations of the Northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea. The overall population trend of this species is of a decrease.

Northeast Atlantic

Accurate determination of abundance trends in the Northeast Atlantic is not possible, in the absence of long-term, standardised surveys sampling off the edge of the continental shelf. Historically, this species may have been more widely distributed in shelf areas in the Northeast Atlantic. Reported French landings for this species were more than 370 tonnes (t) in 1983, but since 1984 annual landings have been more stable and averaged about 75–150 t. English surveys in the North Sea have not recorded this species since 1998, though occasional specimens are taken in the Celtic Sea. It is now encountered only infrequently in surveys on the inner continental shelf, though is still present in deeper waters along the edge of the continental shelf, suggesting that the main part of the range has contracted to deeper water. Indeed, most recent catches in Scottish surveys have been made in waters deeper than 200 m.

Catches of this skate around Iceland and eastern Greenland has been relatively stable overall, ranging from two tonnes in 1993 to 17 t in 2011, with the highest catch of 37 t recorded in 2001 (ICES 2012). While these catch volumes are low, confusion with Sailray (Rajella lintea) is believed to still occur, suggesting that true catch volumes may be even lower. The French Evaluation Halieutique Ouest Européen (EVHOE) Groundfish survey suggested an overall declining trend in abundance and biomass in waters west of Scotland and Ireland between 1997 and 2011, although this decline appeared to be stabilizing in 2010–2011 (ICES 2012). French landings from the Bay of Biscay and Iberian waters have increased from three tonnes in 2000 to 32 t in 2011 (ICES 2012). Spanish landings from this region have been consistently low and stable, ranging from four tonnes in 2000 to eight tonnes in 2008. Purported Scottish landings of White Skate (Rostroraja alba) from these waters may also refer to Shagreen Skate (Leucoraja fullonica) because White Skate is considered depleted in this area (ICES 2013). Although levels of exploitation are unknown for this subpopulation, it is inferred to be declining due to a decrease in survey catch rates and landings.

Mediterranean Sea

This species was captured at depths ranging from 200–800 m in only seven of 6,336 tows during the International Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) performed throughout the northern Mediterranean Sea from 1994–1999 in depths ranging from 10–800 m (Baino et al. 2001). It was absent from multiple trawl survey time series data that ran from 1957–1995 and consisted of eight separate surveys conducted by four different survey vessels in the Gulf of Lions in the eastern Mediterranean Sea (Aldebert 1997). Additionally, it was was absent from both recent and historical surveys in the Adriatic Sea (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). While further MEDITS surveys from 2008–2009 found ten specimens of the species in the southern Adriatic Sea (Zupa et al. 2010), an area it was previously thought to be absent from, it is possible that these specimens may have been incorrectly identified Sandy Skate (Leucoraja circularis). Trawl surveys in the south Ligurian Sea and north Tyrrhenian Sea suggest that the species is rare there, with few specimens captured between 1985 and 2004 at depths of 366–549 m (Serena et al. 2005). The trajectory of the Mediterranean Sea subpopulation is currently unknown.
range: In the Northeast Atlantic this skate occurs in the offshore waters of the continental shelf from Madeira and northern Morocco. Northwards it is present but sparse in the Norwegian Sea including the Skagerrak, Icelandic waters, the Faroe Islands and east of Greenland (Stehmann and Bürkel 1984, ICES 2012). It occurs in low numbers west of Scotland at Rockall Bank, in the Bay of Biscay region, in Iberian waters and around the Azores and mid-Atlantic ridge (ICES 2012). In the Mediterranean Sea it is known from the western and eastern central areas to Tunisia and western coasts of Greece, including the southern Adriatic Sea (Stehmann and Bürkel 1984, Bauchot 1987, Bertrand et al. 2000, Relini et al. 2000, Marano et al. 2003, Tinti et al. 2003, Serena et al. 2011).
useTrade: There is no information on the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions:
In 1999, the European Union (EU) introduced a Total Allowable Catch (TAC) for skates and rays of 6,060 t for fisheries operating in the Norwegian Sea (International Council for the Exploration of the Sea [ICES] Division IIa) and North Sea (ICES sub-area IV) based on landing statistics from the previous five years. This TAC has been progressively reduced by 8−25% annually to the current level of 1,256 t. As part of the TAC, the bycatch quota for vessels over 15 metres was set at 25% of live weight of catch retained on board per trip. For much of this period (1999−2014), the TAC was higher than reported landings and therefore not effectively constraining catches. Additional management measures, including a 2006 permanent ban on all deepwater gillnet fisheries at depths of > 600 m imposed by the European Commission (EC), may help to protect the deeper range of this species. The EC also imposed maximum limits on the length of nets deployed and the soak time in the remaining fisheries at depths of < 600 m (EC Regulation No. 41/2006).

Skate and ray TACs were established for other EU waters in 2009, including the Skagerrak and Kattegat (ICES Division IIIa) and from the northwest coast of Scotland and Northern Ireland to Portuguese waters (ICES sub-areas VI−IX). These TACs have also been gradually reduced since then. In 2013, the TAC for all skate and ray species grouped was 21,800 t (regulations are available online at http://faolex.fao.org). Since 2008, the European Commission has obliged member states to provide species-specific landings data for the major North Sea species, including this species, in order to improve understanding of skate stocks in the area (CEC 2008). In 2009, this obligation was extended to other ICES divisions, including the Celtic Seas (CEC 2009), and has been ongoing since 2008 (CEC 2013). Additional management measures, including non-trawling areas in the Mediterranean Sea, could benefit this species as a fraction of the adult population and eggs are often found in trawl cod-ends (Ragonese et al. 2003).

rationale: Madeira Skate (Raja maderensis) is endemic to Madeira (Portugal) and the Azores (Portugal) in the Eastern Central Atlantic. It is found on the upper shelf and slope down to at least 150 m depth. The species attains 70-80 cm total length but its biology is poorly known. The continental shelf and slope off Madeira and the Azores is too rough for trawling, but this species is taken as regular bycatch in bottom longline fisheries and is mostly discarded, survival from which is unknown. In the Azores, skate landings have increased recently. The species has a restricted number of locations (less than five), and discard survival after bycatch is unknown; it therefore qualifies as Vulnerable under criterion D2. Research is required on taxonomy, distribution, population size, life-history and fisheries related mortality.
habitat: This species is found on the upper shelf and slope at depths down to 150 m on both soft and hard substrates (Stehmann 1971, Stehmann and Bürkel 1984). Like other skates, reproduction is oviparous. It attains a maximum size of 70-80 cm total length (TL) and probably matures at > 50 cm TL, but no other information is available on its biology (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).
threats: The continental shelf and slope off Madeira is too rough for trawling and this species is caught as bycatch in line fisheries and mainly discarded (Ebert and Stehmann 2013). However, discard survival is unknown and skate catches are increasingly reported, particularly from the Azores Islands. No catches are reported from Madeira (SAUP 2014).
population:
This skate is relatively common in the Azores, although it has very restricted local populations (Ebert and Stehmann 2013). It is likely to have an extent of occurrence (EOO) of < 5,000 km² as the combined shelf area of the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of Madeira (333 km²) and the Azores (1,955 km²) is 2,288 km² (EEZ estimate from the See Around Us Project website). The species is currently known to exist in only two locations, and is subject to unregulated fishing mortality in both, albeit a non-target species. The combination of a small EOO (< 5,000 km²) and presence in only two locations with largely unmonitored, unregulated fisheries in operation leads to suspicion of a decline in the number of mature individuals. While species with no commercial value can generally be considered less susceptible to fishing, and there are no catch or landings data available for this species, there is also no information to suggest its post-release survival rate. For this reason, it is necessary to assess the situation precautionarily under the assumption that it may not survive after being discarded.

This skate is considered very rare, or perhaps absent from waters southwest of the Azores (Bloomfield et al. 2011). Additionally, the Azorean Spring Demersal Longline survey confirmed very low numbers of the species (Pinho 2006).
range: This skate is apparently only found on the shelf and upper slope of Madeira (Portugal) (Stehmann 1971, 1973, 1979; Stehmann and Bürkel 1984). Reports of this species elsewhere in the Eastern Central Atlantic are misidentifications, and the identity of a similar form in the Azores still needs to be clarified (see ‘Taxonomic Notes’ section). It may also occur on submarine banks, such as Great Meteor Bank (Ebert and Stehmann 2013).
useTrade: The species is very rarely marketed. There is no target fishery in Madeira (P. Wirtz pers. comm. 2008).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place, and the European Union total allowable catch limitations for skates and rays do not extend to the Azores or Madeira. Further information is required on the taxonomy, population size and trends, life history and fisheries related mortality, including post-release survival.

rationale: This species has been fished in large areas of its range (northern Namibia to southeastern South Africa) over the last 150 years. It is a large species, reaching a maximum total length of 145 cm, and is exposed to a wide variety of fishing gear and fisheries sectors as it occurs in relatively shallow water. The distribution of the species along the coast suggests about 60% of the population is in South African waters with the remaining 40% in Namibian waters. Stock assessments in the mid-1990s showed the three stocks/ subpopulations in South Africa were all heavily over-exploited, while the Namibian stock/subpopulation was also over-exploited. Despite enforced effort reduction in the South African commercial linefishing sector, trends in standardized catch-per-unit-effort from the linefishery from 1986 to 2017 projected forward to 2022 show an overall decline of the South African population of 41% over three generations (36 years). For the other putative 40% of the population in Namibia, declines in spawner biomass to between 14-47% (depending on method) of the pristine (unfished) level were estimated in the mid-1990s. It is not apparent when wide-scale fishing of the Namibian population commenced – although considerable catches were already being made in in the mid-1960s - so it is uncertain over what time period the decline of this population occurred. Furthermore, much of the Namibian coast is not accessible to recreational shore fishers who catch this species in considerable numbers, and the recreational fishing effort there apparently declined markedly in 2010. There has been no formal monitoring of catches since the late 1990s.
