Deep-water dogfishes, including a number of Centrophorus spp, are targeted and/or retained as bycatch throughout Indonesia for their high value liver oil (White et al. 2006, Blaber et al. 2009, Gunawan 2013, Samusamu and Dharmadi 2017). Fisheries occur at depths of 200–800 m (Samusamu and Dharmadi, 2017), but have also been reported near shore at depths <100 m (Gunawan 2013). There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across Indonesia, and demersal coastal fisheries resources have been severely depleted in many areas across the Indo-West Pacific (Stobutzki et al. 2006). Catches of sharks and rays in Southeast Asia are very high, but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Targeting gulper shark fishing has also occurred off the Andaman Islands since the 1980s (Soundararajan and Roy 2004).

A number of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries, some dating back to 1968, operate in the Southwest Indian Ocean (Groeneveld and Everett 2015). These fisheries target a mixture of high-value crustaceans (deep-water prawns, lobsters, crabs) at depths of 300–700 m (Groeneveld and Everett 2015). Fishing pressure in this region is expected to continue; in 2017, the fishery in Madagascar intensified from 2 to 12 Chinese deep-water trawlers in 2017 without any known management measures (R. Bennett pers. comm. 25/4/2018). Bycatch is recognised as making up a considerable amount of the catch, with sharks, fish, and cephalopods comprising ~85% of catch by weight (Doherty et al. 2015).
population:
Population size and trends for this species across its entire range are unknown. Taxonomic uncertainty and identification issues have led to some confusion over the occurrence of gulper sharks, often leading to this group reported under a generic category (e.g. Centrophorus spp). Species-specific population trend data of relative abundance is available from southeast Australia (Walker and Gason 2007). The trend data was analysed over three generation lengths (89 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).
The trend analysis of standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) estimates from research trawl surveys between 1998–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007), revealed an annual rate decline of 2.4%, consistent with an estimated reduction of 88.5% over three generation lengths (89 years), with the highest probability (58%) of >80% reduction in population over three generation lengths. This accounts for only a small proportion (<10%) of the species known range. In addition, significant reductions (>95%) in the catch of the Endeavour Dogfish from 1976 to 77 to 1996–97 on the upper slope trawl fishery off New South Wales (NSW), Australia, were documented by fishery-independent surveys (Graham et al. 2001). Catches of the species were reported from the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), with a mean annual catch estimate of 30 t between 2000–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). 

Elsewhere in the Indo-Pacific, the species was the most recorded Centrophorus spp from fishing landing site across Indonesia between 2001–2006 (White and Dharmadi 2010). Total catch of dogfishes, a mixed category for more than 10 species, reported to the Indonesian National Shark Data Collection program decreased from 16,536 t in 2005 to 4,820 t in 2016 (DGCF, 2017). This equates to >80% reduction in population over three generation lengths. Off the southwest coast of the South Andaman Islands, the hooking rate of Centrophorus spp was found to decline from 18% to 1–14% between 1984 and 2004 (Soundararajan and Roy 2004).

In the Northwest Pacific, annual exports of shark liver oil from the Philippines peaked at 336 t in 1980 to 45 t in 1993. The fishery includes a number of shark species, including unidentified Centrophorus spp (BFAR 2017). In Japan, the Endeavour Dogfish CPUE (numbers of sharks/100 hooks) in Okinawa waters ranged from 0.04–1.48 from 1983 to 1986 (Yano and Kugai 1993), indicating a stable population during that time. Research surveys in 2006–2012 reported a slightly higher average CPUE (numbers of sharks/100 hooks) for the Endeavour Dogfish of 0.04 (Uehara et al. 2013), suggesting little change in the population abundance from 1983 to 2012.

Across the regions, the Endeavour Dogfish was estimated and suspected to be declining in parts of its range (southeast Australia, Indonesia, Philippines, Andaman Islands) and suspected to be stable in Japan. The species has refuge across part of Western Australia and off Northeast Australia, and off the west Pacific Islands where there are no known deep-water fisheries. Due to inferred declines in parts of the Indo-Pacific and high levels of exploitation balanced with refuge in other parts of its distribution, a global population reduction of 30–49% was estimated over three generation lengths (89 years). Therefore, the Endeavour Dogfish is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Endeavour Dogfish is known from a patchy distribution in the Indo-Pacific Ocean (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: Gulper shark liver oil, rich in squalene, is considered the most valuable of shark liver oil and is an important marine resource for local communities (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019). Oil may be processed locally or shipped overseas (e.g. Dubai) for processing before sold on the international market. High grade oil is exported to Japan and the European Union (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2019, K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019, A. Tanna pers. comm., 21/11/2019). Flesh is sold to local markets (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019), while waste products from liver oil production is utilized as aquaculture and poultry feed (A. Tanna pers. comm. 21/11/2019). Gulper shark fins are of low value (Jaiteh et al. 2016), but have been reported in the international fin trade in low quantities (Fields et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on population size and trends of the Endeavour Dogfish, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range. 

In Australia, gulper sharks are assessed and managed as a multi-species stock, comprising several Centrophorus spp, and Harrisson’s dogfish (C. harrissoni) and the Southern Dogfish (C. uyato) are listed as Conservation-Dependent under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) (Patterson et al. 2018). Species are subject to recovery plans that specify management actions to halt fishing mortality and support recovery, including gulper shark protection areas off New South Wales and eastern Bass Strait. A combination of trawling closures in most of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) waters deeper than 700 m since 2005, as well as the closure of the South Tasman Rise Fishery in 2007 (Patterson et al. 2018), may indirectly offer this species some refuge in this region.

rationale:
The Roughskin Dogfish (Centroscymnus owstonii) is a small deepwater shark (to 120 cm total length), with a patchy yet widespread distribution in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans. It occurs on continental slopes, oceanic ridges, and seamounts at depths of 150-1,458 m, but is most common at depths >600 m.

Population size and trends for this species are unknown across most of its range, however, documented declines have been reported in parts of its range. The Roughskin Dogfish is taken incidentally in benthic trawl and longline (surface and benthic) fisheries across its range. The species has been reported under a generic code in many regions, or misidentified with other Centroscymnus species, including the Portuguese Dogfish (C. coelolepis). At this time, there are some species-specific management actions in place for the Roughskin Dogfish in part of its range. Fisheries closures and restrictions in the Tasman Sea may indirectly offer this species some refuge, but mitigation for deepwater dogfish in the Northeast Atlantic, where fishing effort is high, do not cease the capture of this species as bycatch.

This is a low productivity species, and based on current levels of exploitation, it is inferred that the global population has declined by at least 30% over the past three generations (90 years) given actual levels of exploitation in core areas of its range, particularly the Northeast Atlantic, New Zealand and Australia. This species is therefore assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Roughskin Dogfish is recorded on continental slopes, oceanic ridges, and seamounts at depths of 150-1,458 m, but is most common at depths >600 m (Blackwell 2010, Ebert et al. 2013). It reaches a maximum size of 120 cm total length (TL); males mature at 67-84 cm TL; females mature at 95-104 cm TL; size at birth 25-30 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous and is presumed to be asynchronous; litter size is 5-34 pups (Daley et al. 2002, Ebert et al. 2013). Generation length is estimated to be 30 years (Irvine 2004).
threats:
The Roughskin Dogfish is taken incidentally in benthic trawl and longline (surface and benthic) fisheries across its range (Walker and Gason 2007, Francis 2015, Compagno 2016). This species is strongly associated with seamounts (Tracey et al. 2004), potentially increasing its susceptibility to capture.

In the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), most catches are from depths >600 m (Walker and Gason 2007). This species, and other smallspine sharks (Centroscymnus spp) were previously targeted in mid-slope (650-1,200 m) deepwater shark fisheries (Daley et al. 2002). In the Northeast Atlantic, deepwater dogfish are taken as bycatch in multi-species deepwater trawl, hook, and gillnet fisheries that target other species with high Total Allowable Catches (TACs) (Dureuil and Jung 2015), and it is likely that this species is also captured. A qualitative risk assessment for New Zealand's chondrichthyans ranked this species moderate risk from commercial fishing (Ford et al. 2015), and a semi-quantitative risk assessment for chondrichthyan bycatch species taken in the SESSF ranked this species with low risk from commercial fishing (Walker et al. 2008).

Across its range, it has been documented that the Roughskin Dogfish has been reported under a generic code (Blackwell 2010), or misidentified with other Centroscymnus species, including the Portuguese Dogfish (C. coelolepis) (Daley et al. 2002, Moura et al. 2008, Ebert 2015). The Portguese Dogfish represented the majority of deepwater shark in some European fisheries, including Portugal (Figueiredo and Machado 2005), before targeted deepwater shark fishing was prohibited in the EU (ICES 2016). These factors are likely to underestimate catches of the Roughskin Dogfish. Any discard mortality is unknown, but presumed to be high (Brooks et al. 2015).

The Roughskin Dogfish is also reported from Eastern Central Atlantic benthic trawl and tuna longline fisheries, however, further information is not available for catches of this species (Compagno 2016). As fisheries expand further into deeper water, it is likely that the Roughskin Dogfish will be at risk of future population declines in other parts of its distribution.
population:
Population size and trends for this species are unknown across most of its range. Some of its known range is confirmed only from a few reported specimens, and thus, any estimation of population trends from these areas cannot be reported at this time. There is however some information from Australia and New Zealand in the Southwest Pacific and from the Northeast Atlantic.

Southwest Pacific
In New Zealand, the species is considered to have a large population size (based on the number of records in commercial, observer and research trawl databases in the New Zealand EEZ; Ford et al. 2015). Abundance indices for New Zealand on Chatham Rise (1992-2010) and the Sub-Antarctic (1991-1993, 2000-2009) are poorly estimated and show no clear trends (O’Driscoll et al. 2011, Bagley et al. 2013).

In Australia, the Roughskin Dogfish has been considered to be common in abundance (Walker and Gason 2007). However, over a 20 year period (1976/77-1996/97), substantial declines (in some cases >90%) of relative abundance of deepwater chondrichthyans in the Australian South East Fishery trawl grounds have been documented (Graham et al. 2001). Roughskin Dogfish declined by ~90% over 11 years (1996-2006, standardized CPUE) (Walker and Gason 2007), which would equate to a decline of >99% over three generations (90 years).

Northeast Atlantic
In the Northeast Atlantic, other deepwater dogfish have been estimated to have undergone population declines of >80% over three generations (Dureuil and Jung 2015, Guallart et al. 2015). Where survey catch data are available, data have shown patterns of high initial catch rates, followed by rapid declines (Dureuil and Jung 2015), highlighting the susceptibility of deepwater dogfish to over-exploitation.

With the information provided, it is inferred that the Roughskin Dogfish has sustained population declines of at least 30% over three generations (90 years) based on levels of exploitation (i.e. bycatch).
range: The Roughskin Dogfish is known from a patchy yet widespread distribution in the Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific Oceans (Last and Stevens 2009, Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016).
useTrade: The Roughskin Dogfish is utilized for its flesh and squalene oil, and is also used for fishmeal (Roberts et al. 2015, Compagno 2016). In Australia and New Zealand, >90% of catches have historically been retained (Walker and Gason 2007, Ministry of Fisheries 2008).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on population size and trends of the Roughskin Dogfish, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range. Some management arrangements in New Zealand, Australia, and the Northeast Atlantic are relevant to this species.

Southwest Pacific
New Zealand has had a Quota Management System (QMS) in place since 1986 to provide for the sustainable management of its fisheries. The Roughskin Dogfish is a non-QMS species, meaning that there is no species-specific management in place for the species (MPI 2013). New Zealand has a system of Benthic Protected Areas (BPAs), however they are unlikely to provide any major refuge for this species given the spatial occurrence of the BPAs (see Black and Tilney 2015). In Australia, catches of Roughskin Dogfish are controlled by basket trip limits to prevent targeted fishing (Walker and Gason 2007). A combination of trawling closures in most of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) waters deeper than 700 m since 2005, as well as the closure of the South Tasman Rise Fishery in 2007 (Patterson et al. 2016), may indirectly offer this species some refuge in this region.

Northeast Atlantic
Since 2010, the European Union Fisheries Council prohibited direct fishing for deepwater sharks in European Community and international waters, and in 2012, no allowances for bycatch were implemented (ICES 2016). Additional management actions for this region include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); banned use of gillnets by EU vessels at depths >600 m; maximum bycatch limits of deepwater shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and Monkfish (Lophius spp.) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear), and a network of closed areas in Azorean waters; closure of the Condor seamount to deepwater fishing in 2010 (ICES 2016).

rationale: The Silver Chimaera (Chimaera phantasma) is a large-sized deep-water chimaera (to at least 110 cm total length) known from a widespread distribution in the Northwest and Western Central Pacific, from Japan and Russia to the Philippines and Borneo. It has been recorded from the continental shelf and slope at depths of 20–962 m, but is generally recorded at depths <500 m. The Silver Chimaera is not known to be targeted but is caught as bycatch in artisanal and commercial fisheries. Much of the species' distribution has been subject to extensive fishing pressure, although the population should have some refuge in deeper waters. Landings data of all sharks combined from the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates, and rays from Japan, China, South Korea, and Viet Nam EEZs indicate declines of 50–99% over the last three generation lengths (56 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline of chondrichthyans in the region. Given the balance of heavy fishing pressure with some refuge in deeper waters, a population reduction of 30–49% is suspected over the last three generation lengths (56 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, thus meeting Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Silver Chimaera has been recorded from the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 20–962 m, but is generally recorded at depths <500 m. It reaches a maximum size of at least 110 cm total length (TL). Maturity occurs at >65 cm total length (TL) in males and females. A generation length of 18.6 years can be estimated from the Rabbitfish (Chimaera monstrosa), which reaches a similar maximum size (Calis et al. 2005). Like other chimaeras, it is oviparous.
threats:
The Silver Chimaera is not known to be targeted but is caught as bycatch in subsistence and commercial fisheries. Fishing pressure is intense across most of the species' range.

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, declined in the 1980–1990s, and have since remained relatively stable in recent years (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, FAO 2019). Bottom trawl fishing effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (FAO 2019, S. Tanaka pers. obs.). Chimaeras are caught by set net, dropline, or demersal trawl and are often discarded at sea or landed. The Silver Chimaera is commonly observed as landed catch from trawl fisheries in the East China Sea (A. Yamaguchi, unpubl. data), where fishing intensity is high (Szuwalski et al. 2017). If the species is caught in a high enough quantity to fill catch boxes it is often retained and landed; if smaller numbers are caught it is more regularly discarded. Retention also depends on catches of other species as meat of the Silver Chimaera is considered of lower quality than other chondrichthyans such as skates.

In Taiwan, by the 1950s coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and into distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989 at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics, unpubl. data 2019). Seine nets and bottom trawls are the main gear types, accounting for 46% and 19% of the total coastal and offshore fisheries catch respectively, followed by longline (7%) and gillnet (4%) (Fisheries Agency 2019).

The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly-valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture where demand is high (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

In the Philippines, fishing of other deep-water chondrichthyans dates back to the 1960s (Flores 2004). Chimaeras (also referred to as 'silversharks') have been collected from local landing sites in the region, but catches are not reported (BFAR 2017).
population:
No data are available on population size, trends, and structure of the Silver Chimaera. The species' distribution includes areas subject to extensive fishing pressure since the 1950s (e.g. Anticamara et al. 2011, Teh et al. 2017). 

In Taiwan, landings data on all combined shark species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) showed a 52% decline for all shark species combined over 63 years from 1953–2015 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019, Liao et al. 2019). The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019, Liao et al. 2019).

Reconstructed catches of sharks, rays, and skates between 1950–2014 for the Japan and China EEZs have shown declines of 98% (1,300 t to 14 t annually) and 67% (90,000 t to 30,000 t annually), respectively (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In South Korea, reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates from 1969–2014 (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catches were minimal during 1950, then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t, followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014. In Viet Nam, there were minimal catches from 1950–1980; catches then rose steeply during the mid-1980s to a peak of 1,515 t in 1990, followed by a steady decline to 182 t in 2014 (Zeller and Pauly 2016). 

Municipal and commercial shark fisheries production in the Philippines peaked around 1990 (19,049 mt reported collectively); between 1996–2005, municipal fisheries declined at a rate of ~50% and between 1997–2006, commercial fisheries declined ~90% (BFAR 2017). 

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Silver Chimaera (56 years) they represent declines of 46%, 98%, 62%, 98%, and 98%, in Taiwan, Japan, China, South Korea, and Viet Nam, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline for chondrichthyans in the region. Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Silver Chimaera, although the population should have some refuge at depth, and therefore will not have declined to the degree that inshore species have. Overall, it is suspected that the Silver Chimaera has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (56 years).
range: The Silver Chimaera is known from a widespread distribution in the Northwest and Western Central Pacific, from Japan and Russia to the Philippines and Borneo (Last et al. 2010). Records from New Caledonia require further investigation to confirm species presence there.
useTrade: This species is utilized for local consumption.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Silver Chimaera. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology, and life history, and interactions with regional fisheries. Monitoring of species-specific catch landings is needed.

rationale: The Longsnout Dogfish (Deania quadrispinosa) is a small (to 118 cm total length) deep-water shark known from the Southeast Atlantic (southern Africa) and the Indo-Pacific (Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan, and west Pacific Islands) Oceans. It occurs on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 150–1,360 m, and usually at depths >400 m. The species is caught as both targeted and incidental catch in midwater and demersal trawl, demersal longline, and gillnet fisheries operating across most its known range, but the species may find some refuge at depth. There has been a number of management measures implemented in recent years, both species-specific and more generally, for deep-water sharks. There is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, reported declines in part of its range but stable population in others, and a lack of species-specific management across its entire range. The Longsnout Dogfish is infered to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (90 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Longsnout Dogfish is demersal on from continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 150–1,360 m, and usually at depths >400 m (Ebert et al. 2013). It reaches a maximum size of 118 cm total length (TL); males mature at 87 cm TL and females mature at 110 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of 8–18 pups (Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a closely related species, the Birdbeak Dogfish (Deania calcea) that has a female age-at-maturity of 21.5 years and a maximum age of 37 years, resulting in a generation length of 30 years (Irvine et al. 2012).
threats:
The Longsnout Dogfish has been taken as both targeted and incidental catch across its range in midwater and demersal trawl, demersal longline, and gillnet fisheries. It is likely to be misreported with similar looking Deania spp.

Between 1950–1998, there was an apparent increase in reported landings of deep-water sharks and dogfishes across the east central Atlantic region (e.g. Vasconcellos and Watson 2004). In Namibia, deep-water sharks have been reported as bycatch from hake (Merluccius capensis) fisheries (Kainge et al. 2010) Species-specific catches are difficult to determine and likely underestimated; on-board processing as deep-water sharks are rarely landed whole (Fernández et al. 2005). Deania spp are occasionally reported in logbooks (annual catch of <1 t between 2010–12) in demersal inshore and offshore hake trawl fisheries off South Africa (da Silva et al. 2015). In the South African Hake fishery, Deania spp made up <0.2% of the total catch with a reported 126 t landed between 2010–2018 (MSC 2020).

A number of deep-water demersal trawl fisheries, some dating back to 1968, operate in the Southwest Indian Ocean (Groeneveld and Everett 2015). These fisheries target a mixture of high-value crustaceans (deep-water prawns, lobsters, crabs) at depths of 300–700 m (Groeneveld and Everett 2015). Fishing pressure in this region is expected to continue; in 2017, the fishery in Madagascar intensified from 2 to 12 Chinese deep-water trawlers in 2017 without any known management measures (R. Bennett unpubl. data 2018). Bycatch is recognized as making up a considerable amount of the catch, with sharks, fish, and cephalopods comprising ~85% of catch by weight (Doherty et al. 2015).

Deep-water sharks have also been targeted in demersal longline and gillnet fisheries operating in areas managed under the Southern Indian Ocean Fisheries Agreement (SIOFA); the latter of these fisheries ceased in 2015 (Georgeson et al. 2019). An ecological risk assessment framework for deep-water sharks found the Longsnout Dogfish to have high to extreme vulnerability to demersal trawl and demersal longline fisheries in South Pacific Ocean fisheries (Georgeson et al. 2019).

In the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), total shark catches from the eastern and western deep-water shark fisheries peaked in 1998 at 330 t and 400 t, respectively, before declining to <25 t in each zone by 2007 (Patterson et al. 2018). A semi-quantitative risk assessment for chondrichthyan bycatch species taken in the SESSF ranked this species with low risk from current commercial fishing as fishing effort has reduced and the species likely has refuge at depth (T. Walker unpubl. data 2019). In New Zealand, the Birdbeak Dogfish (Deania calcea) is one of the most reported deep-water shark species from offshore deep-water fisheries, however, the Longsnout Dogfish is very infrequently reported (Francis 2015). It is likely to be more abundant than currently reported but taxonomic resolution of Deania spp is required (Roberts et al. 2015).

Over the past 30 years in Taiwan, the deep-water trawl fishery has moved to deeper waters of 300–700 m for most of the year and would encounter this species. However, there is some refuge at depths beyond 700 m and during the monsoon season when the fishery effort is directed at shallow depths. There has been a noted increase in landing rates in Taiwan since 2013, that could partly be accounted for by the increased fishing depth, although that has been occurring for the past 30 years with the increase in landings only noted in the past six years, and improvements in reporting can not be ruled out. Any Deania spp caught in Taiwanese fisheries is likely retained and sold locally (Liu et al. 2013).
population:
Population size and trends for this species across its entire range are unknown. In Australia, from 1976 to 77 to 1996–97, catches of the species by fishery-independent surveys declined from 11.0 to 1.4 kg/h on the upper slope trawl fishery off New South Wales (NSW), Australia (Graham et al. 2001), equating to a reduction of ~87% over the past three generations (90 years). Catches of Longsnout Dogfish were occasionally reported from the Australian Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), with a mean annual catch estimate of ~4 t between 2000–2006 (Walker and Gason 2007). In New Zealand, an indicator analysis for the related Birdbeak Dogfish (Deania calcea) showed no trends in abundance (Francis et al. 2016).

In Taiwan, landings data showed a 52% decline of all combined shark species over 63 years from 1953 to 2015. The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t annually in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s (Kuo and Booth 2011, Liao et al. 2019). Industrial effort did decline after the 1990s, however, there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort. These long-term declines in abundance of sharks can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. This represents a 65% decline when scaled to the past three generation lengths (90 years) for the Longsnout Dogfish, and although not species-specific, is informative for inferring the possible levels of reduction of this species in Taiwan. There are no known deep-water fisheries off the west Pacific Islands.

In southern Africa, the species occurs in areas where deep-water trawl fishing is intensifying with no known management measures in place, but the species is infrequently reported (da Silva et al. 2015).

Across the regions, the Longsnout Dogfish was estimated and inferred to have declined in Australia and Taiwan and remained stable in New Zealand. Due to estimated and inferred declines in part of its range, high levels of exploitation, a global population reduction of 30–49% was inferred over three generation lengths (90 years). Therefore, the Longsnout Dogfish is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Longsnout Dogfish is known from the Southeast Atlantic (southern Africa) and the Indo-Pacific (Australia, New Zealand, Taiwan, and west Pacific Islands) Oceans (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species has historically been utilized for its flesh and liver oil. Fins from Deania spp have been reported in the international fin trade in low quantities (Fields et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on population size and trends of the Longsnout Dogfish, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range, particularly around Africa. There are some species-specific and general management arrangements of relevance in place in the Northeast Atlantic and the Southwest Pacific. Targeted deep-water shark fishing is not permitted in the South East Atlantic Fisheries Organization (SEAFO) Convention Area or under the Southern Indian Ocean Fisheries Agreement (SIOFA) (SIOFA 2019, SEAFO 2016). Conservation measures are generally lacking elsewhere in the species' patchy range.

In Australia, deep-water sharks, including the Birdbeak Dogfish, are assessed and managed as a multi-species stock, divided into eastern and western zone fisheries (Patterson et al. 2018). These fisheries are subject to a multi-species Total Allowable Catches (TACs). A combination of fishery closures and reduced TACs, trawling closures to protect benthic habitat >700 m in waters of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) since 2005, as well as the closure of the South Tasman Rise Fishery in 2007 (Patterson et al. 2018), may indirectly offer this species some refuge in this region.

rationale: The Northern River Shark (Glyphis garricki) is a medium-sized (to 251 cm total length) shark with a patchy and relatively restricted distribution in northern Australia and southern Papua New Guinea (PNG). It is a euryhaline species that inhabits tropical macrotidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal waters. Previously thought to be very rare, recent surveys in Australia and Papua New Guinea have revealed that the species occurs in higher abundance and in a greater number of rivers and estuaries than previously thought. All life stages from neonates to adults have been recorded in tropical macrotidal rivers and adults have also been recorded in coastal marine waters. It displays a high degree of population structuring, with each of five regions of the species’ range representing a genetically distinct subpopulation. This increases the vulnerability of subpopulations to local threats. The application of close-kin mark-recapture to the core part of the species’ range, rivers of the Van Diemen Gulf (Northern Territory, Australia), has revealed a low adult population size. Accounting for the remainder of the species' distribution, including newly discovered parts of its range in the western Top End (Northern Territory) and the Kimberley region of Western Australia, along with its recently rediscovered range in PNG, the adult population size is estimated to be >2,500 but <10,000 mature individuals. Although a protected species in Australian waters, it is subject to incidental capture in commercial fisheries and some illegal recreational retention. In PNG, it is retained for its meat and fins in largely unregulated fisheries. Based on current and future levels of threat, a continuing decline of at least 10% is projected over the next three generation lengths (54 years) and the Northern River Shark is assessed as Vulnerable C1.
habitat:
The Northern River Shark is a euryhaline species found in freshwater, estuarine, and coastal marine habitats (Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015, Grant et al. 2019). All life stages from neonates, juveniles, subadults to adults have been recorded in tropical macrotidal rivers with high turbidity (Feutry et al. 2020, P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Adults have also been recorded in coastal marine waters (Pillans et al. 2009). Within the riverine environment, the species is however restricted to tidal reaches and does not penetrate upstream into clear water like the sympatric Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Capture depths in Northern Territory and Western Australian rivers has ranged from 0.7 m to 23 m (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). The exact location of pupping is not known, although it may be in the estuary. Riverine movement patterns are complex, driven daily by the tidal cycle and seasonally by freshwater flow and salinity (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021).

Maximum size is 251 cm total length; male size-at-maturity is 141 cm total length; a female of 177 cm TL was mature although female size-at-maturity is likely smaller than this (Pillans et al. 2009, Feutry et al. 2020). Reproduction is viviparous with yolk-sac placenta, a litter size of 9 pups (based on one gravid female; Pillans et al. 2009), a possible biennial reproductive cycle, and a size-at-birth of 50–65 cm TL (Pillans et al. 2009). Kyne et al. (2021) used a generation length of 18 years based on age-at-length data for the Speartooth Shark (Glyphis glyphis) and this is followed here. This is further supported by consideration of age data from northern Australia for the euryhaline and sympatric Bull Shark where female age-at-maturity is 9.5 years and maximum age is 26 years, resulting in a generation length of 18 years (Tillet et al. 2011).
threats:
This species is caught as bycatch in subsistence, small-scale, commercial, and recreational fisheries and although retention is prohibited in Australia, it is retained in Papua New Guinea for its meat and fins by small-scale fishers. The Northern River Shark occupies large tidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal waters. This habitat specificity increases the susceptibility to the impacts of human activities, particularly fishing and habitat modification (Grant et al. 2019). In Australia, the species is incidentally caught in commercial inshore gillnet, line, and pot fisheries, and is subject to minor levels of Indigenous harvest, and illegal recreational take (Field et al. 2013, DoE 2015b, Kyne and Feutry 2017, Kyne et al. 2021). The Northern River Shark was assessed as at high-risk in a cumulative risk assessment of all fisheries across northern Australia, mainly due to its susceptibility to capture in gill nets and suspected low productivity (Salini et al. 2007). The level of illegal recreational take is unknown; however, it is of concern due to the low population size and restricted distribution of the species including reliance on riverine habitat by juveniles (Kyne and Feutry 2017). The species is known to have a high mortality rate when captured in gillnets (Pillans et al. 2009) and juveniles are susceptible to capture in pots targeting Mud Crab (Scylla serrata). Post-release mortality rate when discarded from other commercial fisheries is unknown; however, adoption of best handling guidelines may improve survival (Kyne and Pillans 2014, DoE 2015b). Habitat modification such as water extraction and barriers in rivers, such as dams, barrages, weirs, and poorly constructed road crossings, may affect habitat quality and impede movement patterns of the Northern River Shark (DoE 2015b).

In Papua New Guinea, this species is caught in small-scale riverine and inshore fisheries and may be subject to habitat degradation in the Gulf of Papua and South Fly District associated with mining and logging activities (White et al. 2017b, M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021). It is incidentally captured in a relatively recently developed high-value fishery for swim bladder (also known as fish maw) that targets mainly Barramundi (Lates calcarifer) and Scaly Croaker (Nibea squamosa) in estuarine and coastal habitats (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021).
population:
The Northern River Shark shows a high degree of population structuring. Molecular analysis revealed genetically distinct subpopulations in each of the five known regions of its range: southern Papua New Guinea, Van Diemen Gulf (Northern Territory; NT), Daly River (NT), Cambridge Gulf (Western Australia; WA), and King Sound (WA) (Feutry et al. 2020). The King Sound subpopulation is particularly distinct and isolated (Feutry et al. 2020). The rates of movement between these subpopulations was estimated to be very low, indicating that replenishment of any depleted subpopulations by immigration is unlikely (Feutry et al. 2020).

Historically, the Northern River Shark has been considered a very rare species with only a limited number of records from a restricted number of locations (Pogonoski and Pollard 2003). Pillans et al. (2009) catalogued only 32 records. Since then, dedicated surveys in the NT and WA extending across 12 rivers and estuaries have recorded >600 individuals (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Neonates, juveniles, subadults, and adults have all been recorded in these rivers and estuaries and immature animals are particularly common in the rivers flowing into Van Diemen Gulf (NT) with >500 individuals documented during surveys (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Unlike the congener Speartooth Shark (Glyphis glyphis), adults have regularly been caught in Van Diemen Gulf rivers (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021).

The application of close-kin mark-recapture estimated an adult population size in Van Diemen Gulf in 2015 of 520–1,116, although when considering all models and 90% confidence intervals this estimate was 320–2,050 individuals (Bravington et al. 2019). The estimates have low precision due to limited age information and a limited range of sampled cohorts (Bravington et al. 2019). The number of mature individuals in the Daly River, Cambridge Gulf, and King Sound is suspected to be smaller than that of Van Diemen Gulf due to the lower catch rates of Northern River Shark in these other systems as well as the smaller geographic area (i.e. a smaller area of available habitat) (Bravington et al. 2019, P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Kyne et al. (2021) used the Van Diemen Gulf population size estimate to derive an Australian population size estimate of >2,500 but <10,000. This took into account the relative proportion of the species' known range that is represented by Van Diemen Gulf and then accounted for the subpopulations where population size estimates are not available and placed the total in the context of the Criteria C thresholds (Kyne et al. 2021).

In Papua New Guinea (PNG), surveys of artisanal fishers on the South Fly District, southern PNG in 2014 recorded two individual Northern River Sharks (White et al. 2015, White et al. 2017a). Subsequent surveys of small-scale fishers in riverine and inshore habitats in the Gulf of Papua and South Fly Coast, southern PNG over three years from 2017 to 2020 recorded a total of 140 Northern River Sharks, which were all juveniles (White et al. 2017a, M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021). These juvenile Northern River Sharks were noted to be commonly caught by fishers in the Fly and Kikori River Deltas relative to other elasmobranchs (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021) with the Northern River Shark being more abundant than the Speartooth Shark. This pattern, where the Northern River Shark is the more common species, is mirrored in Australia (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021).  

Based on the estimated small adult population size in Australia (despite relatively common juveniles), it is suspected that the adult population size in PNG is also quite small. The global population size is estimated to be >2,500 but <10,000 mature individuals when accounting for the species' PNG range in addition to the Australian range. Threats are ongoing, particularly incidental and illegal capture in Australian fisheries (see Kyne and Feutry 2017, Kyne et al. 2021) and largely unregulated fishing pressure in PNG. Habitat degradation in PNG and habitat modification in Australia may also be a threat to this species. Based on current and future levels of threat, a continuing decline of at least 10% is projected over the next three generation lengths (54 years) and the Northern River Shark is assessed as Vulnerable C1.
range: The Northern River Shark has a patchy distribution across northern Australia and southern Papua New Guinea (PNG) in macrotidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal marine waters (Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015, Feutry et al. 2020, Kyne et al. 2021). In Australia, it was previously known from a marine record off the Wessel Islands (Northern Territory; NT), rivers flowing into Van Diemen Gulf (NT), Cambridge Gulf (Western Australia; WA), and King Sound (WA) (Pillans et al. 2009). Recent surveys have however revealed a wider range including additional rivers of Van Diemen Gulf, the Daly River (NT), and additional rivers of the Kimberley region of WA (Feutry et al. 2020, Kyne et al. 2021, A.V. Harry pers. comm. 4 May 2021). Species distribution models suggest that the species occurs more-widely than presently known based on habitat suitability (Udyawer et al. 2021). In Papua New Guinea, the species is known from jaws collected off the Gulf of Papua off Port Romilly in 1966 and Baimuru in 1975, and more recently from additional individuals recorded across the western Gulf of Papua (White et al. 2015, White et al. 2017a, M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021).
useTrade: Retention of this species is prohibited in Australia, although there is some illegal recreational take with Glyphis spp. being used as bait (Kyne and Feutry 2017) as well as some legal Indigenous harvest. In Papua New Guinea, the meat is used for local consumption and the fins are sold to local buyers through both legal and illegal markets for export (White et al. 2017a, Busilacchi et al. 2021). Glyphis spp. fins have been reported in the international trade, occurring in Hong Kong and China (Cardeñosa et al. 2020a, Cardeñosa et al. 2020b).
conservationActions:
In Australia, the species is listed as Critically Endangered on the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). However, this listing was undertaken when the species was known from few records and was considered be to extremely rare. A recent reassessment demonstrates that the species does not meet the criteria for listing as Critically Endangered and recommends a down-listing to Vulnerable (Kyne et al. 2021). Listing on the EPBC Act means the species is a 'Matter of National Environmental Significance' and is protected under the Act. The species is subject to a national multi-species Recovery Plan which aims to improve the population status and ensure anthropogenic activities do not hinder recovery (DoE 2015a).

In the Northern Territory, the Northern River Shark is listed as an Endangered species under the Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 2000, and a no-take species under the Fisheries Act 1998 and Fisheries Regulations. In Western Australia, it is protected from commercial and recreational catch under the Fisheries Resource Management Act 1994 and the Wildlife Conservation Act 1950. Most Northern Territory rivers are closed to commercial net fishing and a core part of the species' distribution, the Alligator rivers, is within Kakadu National Park and World Heritage Area, providing a significant conservation benefit to the subpopulation there. In Papua New Guinea (PNG), there is currently no species-specific regulation for the Northern River Shark (White et al. 2015).

Species distribution models have suggested the species occurs in other unsurveyed locations (Udyawer et al. 2021). These areas are priorities for surveys; these surveys should utilize appropriate methods and target the species' preferred salinity and turbidity ranges (Pillans et al. 2009, Kyne and Pillans 2014). More urgent is the implementation of effective management measures in PNG.

rationale: The Speartooth Shark (Glyphis glyphis) is a medium-sized (to at least 260 cm total length) shark with a patchy and relatively restricted distribution in northern Australia and southern Papua New Guinea (PNG). It is a euryhaline species that inhabits tropical macrotidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal waters. Previously thought to be very rare, recent surveys in Australia and PNG have revealed that the species occurs in higher abundance and in a greater number of rivers and estuaries than previously thought. The vast majority of records are neonates and juveniles from within rivers while adults are known from only a handful of records. It displays a high degree of population structuring, increasing the vulnerability of subpopulations to local threats. The application of close-kin mark-recapture to the Wenlock River (Queensland, Australia) and rivers of the Van Diemen Gulf (Northern Territory, Australia) have revealed a low adult population size. Accounting for the remainder of the species' distribution, including newly discovered parts of its range in the western Top End (Northern Territory) and the Kimberley region of Western Australia, along with its recently rediscovered range in PNG, the adult population size is estimated to be >2,500 but <10,000 mature individuals. Although a protected species in Australian waters, it is subject to incidental capture in commercial fisheries and some illegal recreational retention. In PNG, it is retained for its meat and fins in largely unregulated fisheries. Based on current levels of threat, a continuing decline of at least 10% is projected over the next three generation lengths (54 years) and the Speartooth Shark is assessed as Vulnerable C1.
habitat:
The Speartooth Shark is a euryhaline species found in freshwater, estuarine, and coastal marine habitats (Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015, Grant et al. 2019). Juveniles and subadults occupy tropical macrotidal rivers with high turbidity. Within the riverine environment, the species is however restricted to tidal reaches and does not penetrate upstream into clear water like the sympatric Bull Shark (Carcharhinus leucas) (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). Capture depths in Northern Territory and Western Australian rivers has ranged from 0.4 m to 23 m (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). The exact location of pupping is not known, although it may be in the estuary and habitat use and occurrence of adults is very poorly-known (Last and Stevens 2009, Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015). Riverine movement patterns are complex, driven daily by the tidal cycle and seasonally by freshwater flow and salinity (Pillans et al. 2009, Lyon et al. 2017, Dwyer et al. 2020). 

Maximum size is unknown but is at least 260 cm total length (TL); size-at-maturity is also unknown with a 157 cm TL male being subadult, suggesting a large size-at-maturity (Compagno et al. 2008, White et al. 2015). One gravid female was estimated at 237–260 cm TL (size calculated from fin measurements; White et al. 2015). Reproduction is viviparous with yolk-sac placenta, possible litter size of 6–7 pups (based on anecdotal reports from PNG fishers), a possible biennial reproductive cycle as suggested for the Northern River Shark, and a size-at-birth of 50–65 cm TL (Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015, White et al. 2017a). Age-at-length is under investigation in this species (P.M. Kyne and M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021) and Kyne et al. (2021) used a generation length of 18 years which is followed here. This is further supported by consideration of age data from northern Australia for the euryhaline and sympatric Bull Shark where female age-at-maturity is 9.5 years and maximum age is 26 years, resulting in a generation length of 18 years (Tillet et al. 2011).
threats:
The species is caught as bycatch in subsistence, small-scale, commercial, and recreational fisheries and although retention is prohibited in Australia, it is retained in Papua New Guinea for its meat and fins by small-scale fishers. The Speartooth Shark occupies large tidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal waters. This habitat specificity increases the susceptibility to the impacts of human activities, particularly fishing and habitat modification (Grant et al. 2019). In Australia, the species is incidentally caught in commercial inshore gillnet, line, and pot fisheries, and is subject to minor levels of Indigenous harvest, and illegal recreational take (Field et al. 2013, DoE 2015b, Kyne and Feutry 2017, Lyon et al. 2017, Dwyer et al. 2019, Kyne et al. 2021). The Speartooth Shark was assessed as at high-risk in a cumulative risk assessment of all fisheries across northern Australia, mainly due to its susceptibility to capture in gill nets and suspected low productivity (Salini et al. 2007). The level of illegal recreational take is unknown; however, it is of concern due to the low population size and restricted distribution of the species including reliance on riverine habitat by juveniles (Kyne and Feutry 2017). The species is known to have a high mortality rate when captured in gillnets (Pillans et al. 2009) and juveniles are susceptible to capture in pots targeting Mud Crab (Scylla serrata) (Dwyer et al. 2019). Post-release mortality rate when discarded from other commercial fisheries is unknown; however, adoption of best handling guidelines may improve survival (Kyne and Pillans 2014, DoE 2015b). Habitat modification such as water extraction and barriers in rivers, such as dams, barrages, weirs, and poorly constructed road crossings, may affect habitat quality and impede movement patterns of the Speartooth Shark (DoE 2015b, Dwyer et al. 2020).

In Papua New Guinea, this species is caught in small-scale riverine and inshore fisheries and may be subject to habitat degradation in the Gulf of Papua and South Fly District associated with mining and logging activities (White et al. 2017b, M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021). It is incidentally captured in a relatively recently developed high-value fishery for swim bladder (also known as fish maw) that targets mainly Barramundi (Lates calcarifer) and Scaly Croaker (Nibea squamosa) in estuarine and coastal habitats (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021).
population:
The Speartooth Shark shows a high degree of population structuring. Molecular analysis from northern Australia show two genetically distinct units which might be considered to be subpopulations: Wenlock River, Queensland, and Van Diemen Gulf, Northern Territory (NT) (Feutry et al. 2014, Feutry et al. 2017). At the time of these analyses, the work covered the species' entire known extant Australian range, i.e. Wenlock River of Queensland, and the Adelaide River and Alligator rivers of Van Diemen Gulf. The species displays strong female philopatry to each of these rivers with males likely moving between rivers less than 150 km apart in the Van Diemen Gulf (Feutry et al. 2014, Feutry et al. 2017). There is not yet information available on the genetic relationship of the Papua New Guinea (PNG) population, but further analyses are underway to assess genetic structuring of newly-discovered populations in the western Top End of the NT and the Kimberley region of Western Australia (WA) along with the Kikori River, PNG (P.M. Kyne, M.I. Grant et al., unpubl. data 2021).

The Speartooth Shark has historically been considered a very rare species with only a limited number of records from a restricted number of locations (Compagno et al. 2009). Pillans et al. (2009) cataloged 106 records from Australia, most of which (n=84) were from the Adelaide River, NT. Since then, dedicated surveys in the NT and WA extending across eight rivers, but primarily focused on the Adelaide and South Alligator Rivers, have recorded >400 individuals (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021). All have, however, been neonate, juvenile, or subadult with adults never recorded in the NT or WA (and only very limited numbers recorded from Queensland and PNG). In Queensland, Pillans et al. (2009) documented 11 records from the Wenlock River-Ducie River-Port Musgrave system and two records from the Bizant River. There are no further records from the Bizant River and given that the historical records were collected prior to 1983, it has been speculated that the species may be extinct there (Pillans et al. 2009). We caution that such a conclusion cannot be reached without dedicated surveys targeting the preferred salinity and turbidity ranges of the species with appropriate sampling methods (Kyne and Pillans 2014). The Wenlock River has been the focus of research into the species' ecology (e.g., Lyon et al. 2017, Dwyer et al. 2019, Dwyer et al. 2020), and similar to the Van Diemen Gulf rivers, juveniles are relatively common there (e.g., Feutry et al. 2017 included 125 samples from the Wenlock River). 

In PNG, surveys of artisanal fishers on the South Fly District, southern PNG in 2014 recorded three adult Speartooth Sharks from coastal waters (White et al. 2015). Subsequent surveys of small-scale fishers in riverine and inshore habitats in the Gulf of Papua and South Fly District, southern PNG over three years from 2017 to 2020 recorded a total of 38 Speartooth Sharks, which were all juveniles (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021). In the same survey, 140 Northern River Shark (G. garricki) were recorded and together, these Glyphis spp. were noted to be commonly caught by the fishers relative to other elasmobranchs (M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021), although the survey suggests that Speartooth Shark are less abundant than the Northern River Shark. This pattern, where the Speartooth Shark is the less common species, is mirrored in Australia (P.M. Kyne unpubl. data 2021).   

Close-kin mark-recapture has been applied to the Wenlock River and Van Diemen Gulf subpopulation to produce adult population sizes (see Bravington et al. 2019 for methodology). Although these estimates are not yet published, they were used by Kyne et al. (2021) to derive an Australian population size estimate of >2,500 but <10,000. This took into account the estimates from the Wenlock River and Van Diemen Gulf and the relative proportion of the species' known range that these subpopulations represented. The total population size accounted for the subpopulations where population size estimates are not available and placed the total in the context of the Criteria C thresholds (see Kyne et al. 2021 for further details).

Based on the estimated small adult population in Australia (despite relatively common juveniles), it is suspected that the adult population size in PNG is also quite small. The global population size is estimated to be >2,500 but <10,000 mature individuals when accounting for the species' PNG range in addition to the Australian range. Threats are ongoing, particularly incidental and illegal capture in Australian fisheries (see Kyne and Feutry 2017, Kyne et al. 2021) and largely unregulated fishing pressure in PNG. Habitat degradation in PNG and habitat modification in Australia may also be a threat to this species. Based on current and future levels of threat, a continuing decline of at least 10% is projected over the next three generation lengths (54 years) and the Speartooth Shark is assessed as Vulnerable C1.
range: The Speartooth Shark has a patchy distribution across northern Australia and southern Papua New Guinea in macrotidal rivers, estuaries, and coastal marine waters (Pillans et al. 2009, White et al. 2015, Kyne et al. 2021). In Australia, previously it had been documented from the Bizant River, eastern Cape York, Queensland (but has not been reported there since 1982 although further dedicated surveys are needed), the Wenlock River-Ducie River-Port Musgrave system on western Cape York, and various rivers flowing into Van Diemen Gulf in the Northern Territory (NT) (Pillans et al. 2009). Recent surveys have however revealed a wider range including rivers of the western Top End (NT) and the Kimberley region of Western Australia (Kyne et al. 2021, A.V. Harry pers. comm. 4 May 2021). Species distribution models suggest that the species occurs more-widely than presently known based on habitat suitability (Udyawer et al. 2021). In Papua New Guinea, it was first known from jaws collected close to Port Romilly in 1966 and from jaws collected from the Fly River (Compagno et al. 2008) and has been more recently recorded from the Kikori and Fly Rivers, and Daru region of the South Fly District (White et al. 2015, M.I. Grant unpubl. data 2021).
useTrade: Retention of this species is prohibited in Australia, although there is some illegal recreational take with Glyphis spp. being used as bait (Kyne and Feutry 2017) as well as some legal Indigenous harvest. In Papua New Guinea, the meat is used for local consumption and the fins are sold to local buyers through both legal and illegal markets for export (White et al. 2017a, Busilacchi et al. 2021). Glyphis spp. fins have been reported in the international trade, occurring in Hong Kong and China (Cardeñosa et al. 2020a, Cardeñosa et al. 2020b).
conservationActions:
In Australia, the species is listed as Critically Endangered on the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). However, this listing was undertaken when the species was considered be to extremely rare and possibly thought to be extinct in part of its historic Australian range (the Bizant River, Queensland). A recent reassessment demonstrates that the species does not meet the criteria for listing as Critically Endangered and recommends a down-listing to Vulnerable (Kyne et al. 2021). Listing on the EPBC Act means the species is a 'Matter of National Environmental Significance' and is protected under the Act. The species is subject to a national multi-species Recovery Plan which aims to improve the population status and ensure anthropogenic activities do not hinder recovery (DoE 2015a). 

In the Northern Territory, the Speartooth Shark is listed as a Vulnerable species under the Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 2000, and a no-take species under the Fisheries Act 1998 and Fisheries Regulations. In Queensland, it is listed as a no-take species under the Queensland Fisheries Act 1994 and Fisheries Regulations 2008. Most Northern Territory rivers are closed to commercial net fishing and a core part of the species' distribution, the Alligator rivers, is within Kakadu National Park and World Heritage Area, providing a significant conservation benefit to the juvenile population there. In Papua New Guinea (PNG), there is currently no species-specific regulation for the Speartooth Shark (White et al. 2015).

Given its recent documentation in Western Australia (P.M. Kyne and A.V. Harry, unpubl. data 2021), there is a need for legislative protection in that jurisdiction. There is also a need for targeted surveys in the Bizant River, Queensland, to confirm its presence/absence there since the last records are prior to 1983 (Pillans et al. 2009). Species distribution models have suggested the species also occurs in other unsurveyed locations (Udyawer et al. 2021). Surveys should utilize appropriate methods and target the species' preferred salinity and turbidity ranges (Pillans et al. 2009, Kyne and Pillans 2014). More urgent is the implementation of effective management measures in PNG.

rationale:
The Fossil Shark (Hemipristis elongata) is commonly landed in coastal fisheries throughout its shallow (down to 130 m) tropical Indo-West Pacific range (to a lesser extent in Australia) since the flesh is considered of very high quality, as are the fins and liver.

Life history data demonstrate that it grows and matures rapidly, suggesting a relatively high ability to sustain fishing. Despite this, the intensive and largely unmanaged net and trawl fisheries that occur throughout most of its range (with the exception of Australia) fish heavily in its known habitat and are likely to catch this species when present. Many shark stocks in the region are known to be over-exploited, with catches declining, and market surveys indicate that this species has declined in areas where it was once considered common. This species has not been reported in surveys of the South China Sea where it has previously been recorded.

This declining trend is likely to continue in future in the absence of management and because of continued, if not increasing, fishing effort. Based on global declines in chondrichthyan landings of at least 20% over the past 12 years, and the fact that the Indo-Pacific region is a region with some of the most poorly managed and intensely fished waters, a population reduction of greater than 30% over the past three generations (27 years) is inferred for the Fossil Shark, and a decline at a similar rate is expected to occur over the next three generations; hence the species is assessed as Vulnerable.

In Australian waters, this species is suspected to be Least Concern as a result of well-managed fisheries and low catches.
habitat: The Fossil Shark occurs on the continental shelf, inshore to a depth of 130 m (Compagno 1998). This viviparous species has a seasonal reproductive cycle, producing 2 to 11 (mean = 6) young per litter, ranging in size from 45 to 52 cm total length (TL; Compagno 1984, Last and Stevens 2009). Mating appears to take place around June, ovulation in September and birth in about April, with a gestation period of about 7 to 8 months. The pregnancy rate among mature females off Australia is about 30%, which suggests that individual females may breed every other year (Stevens and McLoughlin 1991). This species attains 240 cm TL, with females and males maturing at approximately 120 and 110 cm TL, respectively. Smart et al. (2013) provided age and growth data for specimens caught off the east coast of Queensland. Growth appears to be quite rapid, with maturity reached in 2–3 years. Maximum observed age was 15 years. Generation length is estimated to be 9 years, based on age data from Smart et al. (2013).
threats:
The gillnet and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) are very extensive and as a result, many shark species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Globally, shark and ray landings have declined by at least 20% since 2003, but the Indo-Pacific is amongst the regions where this decline has been more severe (Dulvy et al. 2014). Catches of sharks in Southeast Asia are very high but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Trawl and gillnet fisheries are moving further away, for example, in Jakarta the gillnet fishery at Muara Baru travels to waters around Kalimantan due to the decline in local shark populations (W.T. White, unpubl. data). In the Gulf of Thailand, this species was once considered common, however, surveys in recent years have observed very few specimens (L.J.V Compagno, pers. comm. 2003). Similarly, in the waters of the South China Sea (including Hong Kong and parts of mainland China) this species has been recorded in historic surveys, but has been absent from all recent surveys (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2010) indicating that it may have become locally extinct in some parts of Asia. The numbers observed in market surveys in Indonesia are likely to provide a relatively good representation of a likely depleted population although no baseline information exists (White 2007). It is taken in very small quantities in fisheries throughout the Arabian/Persian Gulf and Red Sea (Moore and Peirce 2013, Spaet and Berumen 2015, Jabado et al. 2015) but its status there is unknown.

The Fossil Shark is a minor component of the northern Australian gillnet and trawl (prawn and fish) fisheries (Last and Stevens 2009, Stobutzki et al. 2002, Zhou and Griffiths 2008). In the inshore gillnet fishery on the east coast of Queensland it makes up about 0.1% of the catch. It makes up similar proportions in other coastal fisheries across northern Australia. The catch (which is discarded) in the Australian Northern Prawn Fishery is small, and estimates of fishing mortality indicate that the level of take is sufficiently low to ensure sustainability (Zhou and Griffiths 2008).
population: The Fossil Shark appears to be naturally rare in most places where it occurs. There are no data available on population structure, but the population is inferred to be declining based on heavy exploitation of coastal and shelf fishes across most of its range.
range: The Fossil Shark has a wide range in the Indo-West Pacific including South Africa, Madagascar, Mozambique, Tanzania, Yemen (Aden), the Red Sea, the Arabian/Persian Gulf, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Malaysia, Viet Nam, China, Indonesia, the Philippines, southern Papua New Guinea, and northern and western Australia (Last and Stevens 2009, Jaiteh and Momigliano 2015). In Australian waters, the species is known from Bunbury, Western Australia, to Moreton Bay, Queensland (Compagno 1998, Last and Stevens 2009, Taylor and Bennett 2013).
useTrade: The Fossil Shark is taken for its flesh, fins, liver oil and skin. In India and Indonesia, among other countries, the flesh is considered of high quality (White et al. 2006, Last and Stevens 2009).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific management measures for the Fossil Shark. Fisheries that take this species in northern Australia are well managed, having limited entry, catch or effort limits, gear restrictions and finning regulations. Throughout most of the rest of the distribution, coastal fisheries lack sufficient management or enforcement to achieve sustainability.

rationale:
The Leopard Whipray (Himantura leoparda) is possibly widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific in mainly coastal inshore waters. It is currently known to range from Southeast Asia to the Japanese Archipelago and south to northern Australia, however there are ongoing taxonomic issues that are being investigated, the outcomes of which may affect the known range.

Its biology is poorly known, partly due to confusion with other members of the ‘uarnak’ species-complex. This species is commercially valuable throughout Southeast Asia where it is taken as utilised bycatch in a range of commercial and artisanal fisheries including demersal trawl and tangle/gill nets, dropline and longline fisheries, and Danish seine fisheries. In recent decades, demersal fishing pressure has increased in both capacity and effort and is intense throughout this species’ inshore range in Southeast Asia. Fishing pressure is also very heavy in the Arafura Sea region; previously more than 600 trawlers operated and although the numbers of currently active trawlers is unclear, there are still high levels of Indonesian trawl fishing in the area. This level of exploitation is of great concern to the sustainability of Leopard Whipray populations in the Arafura Sea outside the Australian Fishing Zone.

This species’ preference for inshore coastal waters means it is also threatened by extensive habitat degradation and destructive fishing practices throughout a large part of its range. Although species-specific data are not available, given the species’ high levels of exploitation, extensive habitat degradation and its large size, significant population declines are inferred to have occurred and are likely to be ongoing in Southeast Asia. Conversely, this species has refuge from fishing pressure in northern Australia, where fishing pressure is light, bycatch mitigation measures are in place and it is not commercially utilised and consequently is considered at low risk.

Given the continuation of high levels of exploitation throughout its range in Southeast Asia where the species is caught in multiple types of fisheries, along with evidence for declines in catches of rays, the level of decline (>30% over the last three generations) and exploitation can be inferred from overall declines in fish catches in the region, as well as from habitat loss. The Leopard Whipray is assessed as Vulnerable globally based on inferred levels of decline and exploitation across a large part of its range, but is considered to be Least Concern in Australia.
habitat:
The Leopard Whipray is demersal on soft substrates and is mainly inshore and coastal though it also occurs on the continental shelf to at least 70 m depth (White et al. 2006, Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2008). The biology of this species is poorly known, partly due to confusion with other species of the ‘uarnak’ species-complex, especially the Reticulate Whipray (H. uarnak) and the Honeycomb Whipray (H. undulata) (Last and Stevens 2009). It attains about 140 cm disc width (DW); born at about 20 cm DW; males mature at 70–94 cm DW (White and Dharmadi 2007, Last and Stevens 2009). Reproduction is viviparous (White et al. 2006).

As there is no information on this species’ maximum age and age at maturity, generation length was inferred as 20 years based on data for the congener, the Blackspotted Whipray (Himantura astra). Female Blackspotted Whiprays are reported to have a maximum age of 29 years and an age at maturity of nine years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2011). These were used to calculate a generation length of 19 years based on the equation: generation length = 9+((29-9)/2). The maximum size of the Leopard Whipray is considerably larger (~140 cm DW) than that of the Blackspotted Whipray (80 cm DW) so it is possible the generation length of the Leopard Whipray could be greater than 20 years.
threats:
The threats to the Leopard Whipray are many of those faced by other Himantura species within its range. However, the Leopard Whipray may be more vulnerable than some of its congeners due to its large size at maturity and maximum size and its preference for inshore coastal waters that are heavily fished and degraded in many parts of its range outside Australian waters (Manjaji and White 2004).

In Indonesia and across large parts of its distribution, the Leopard Whipray is caught by demersal trawl and tangle/gill nets, dropline and longline fishing, Danish seine fishing gear, and coastal artisanal fisheries (Manjaji and White 2004, White et al. 2006). In Southeast Asia, this species is commercially valuable, with most specimens caught as bycatch landed and sold. The Leopard Whipray is important in the gill and tangle net fisheries in Indonesian waters, which likely also includes adjacent waters. These fisheries, along with trawl fishing are particularly intensive in the Arafura Sea region (W. White pers. comm. 2010). In 2004, it was reported that more than 600 trawlers operated in the Arafura Sea and that catches in inshore waters had declined with vessels travelling further south to maintain catches (Manjaji and White 2004). Although the numbers of trawlers currently operating is unclear, this intensive fishing pressure still continues; high levels of Indonesian trawl fishing in the Arafura Sea adjacent to the Australian Fishing Zone have recently been reported (Heazle and Butcher 2007, Northern Territory Government 2009) and thus the level of exploitation of this species could be extremely high.

In recent decades, demersal fishing pressure has increased in both capacity and effort in many areas of this species’ inshore range. For example, demersal resources in the Gulf of Thailand went from being lightly exploited to severely over-exploited between 1973 and 1994 (Pauly et al. 2005). On standardized trawl surveys conducted over this 20 year period in the Gulf of Thailand, the abundance (biomass) of the major trawl bycatch groups was recorded. The group ‘rays’ showed a large reduction in biomass over this period and an ecosystem model fitted to the bycatch data indicated that ‘rays’ were one of the groups most severely impacted by the initial increase in fishing pressure (Pauly et al. 2005). Species-specific catch data are not available, but Indonesian landings of ‘Rays, stingrays, mantas, nei’ (nei = not elsewhere included) increased from ~10,000 t in 1975 to 58,000 t in 2004 (FAO 2009).

This species’ preference for inshore coastal waters means it is also threatened by extensive habitat degradation, including pollution and clearing, and destructive fishing practices. Large coastal areas, in particular mangroves, have been lost in Indonesia and Malaysia through land conversion for urban development, shrimp farms and agriculture. Across Indonesia and Malaysia from 1980 to 2005, the area of mangroves was reduced by >30% (FAO 2007).

Although data are available mostly only for grouped ‘rays’ and not specifically for the Leopard Whipray and/or other Himantura species, given that the Leopard Whipray is a large species with a preference for shallow waters where threats from coastal fisheries and habitat degradation are highest, significant declines are suspected to have occurred in Southeast Asia.

Conversely, this species has refuge from fishing pressure across its range in northern Australia where there is much less fishing pressure and bycatch mitigation measures are enacted. Large specimens were previously occasionally caught as bycatch in the Australian Northern Prawn Fishery (NPF), a trawl fishery across northern Australia, but the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) in 2000 significantly reduced the bycatch of this species, particularly those individuals >1 m DW (Brewer et al. 2004). In the NPF, this species was considered to have a moderate to high sustainability to the impacts of trawling (Stobutzki et al. 2002, Zhou and Griffiths 2008). It has also been recorded as a minor component of the bycatch in the banana prawn and scallop sectors of the Queensland East Coast Otter Trawl Fishery (Stobutzki et al. 2001, Courtney et al. 2007), but again the use of TEDs in this fishery should limit bycatch (particularly of larger specimens).
population:
Globally, shark and ray landings have declined by at least 20% since 2003, but the Indo-Pacific is amongst the regions where this decline has been more severe (Dulvy et al. 2014). Catches of sharks and rays in Southeast Asia are very high but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Batoids are heavily exploited (White and Dharmadi 2007) and datasets from as early as 1963–1972 show the considerable decline in batoids in the Gulf of Thailand (Pauly 1979). Trawl and gill net fisheries are also moving further afield. For example, in Jakarta the gillnet fishery at Muara Baru travels to waters around Kalimantan due to the decline in local populations (W.T. White, unpubl. data). While species-specific data on long-term declines in elasmobranchs in the Southeast Asian region are lacking, declines of the Leopard Whipray in Southeast Asia are inferred given the widespread historical and continuing declines of demersal fisheries in this region (Stobutzki et al. 2006). Furthermore, the extensive loss and degradation of habitats such as coastal mangroves are another key threat to coastal and inshore species; Southeast Asia has seen an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2010).

It is not possible to estimate the proportion of the global population occurring within the Australian region as there is little information on the population structure of this species, however an estimated 15% of the Leopard Whipray’s known distributional range is in the Australian region.
range: The Leopard Whipray is possibly widespread in the Indo-West Pacific. Its range is based on current knowledge, however there are ongoing taxonomic issues that are being investigated and the outcomes of these may affect the known range. It is currently known from Southeast Asia to the Japanese Archipelago and south to northern Australia, where it occurs from Coral Bay, Western Australia to the Torres Strait, Queensland (Manjaji-Matsumoto and Last 2008, Last and Stevens 2009). It is currently considered absent from the Western Indian Ocean.
