Overall, further study is needed to accurately determine the distributional range, abundance and biology (including possible migrations, sex ratios, fecundity, genetic connectivity, etc.) of this species. Any dead specimens landed by commercial fishing operations should be retained and delivered to the nearest relevant research organisation, so that more biological and genetic information can be obtained.

rationale: The Pacific Eagle Ray (Aetobatus laticeps) is a large (to 230 cm disc width) coastal and offshore ray that inhabits bays, estuaries, and open ocean near the surface in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California to Ecuador, including the Galápagos Islands. It is caught in artisanal gillnet and longline, purse seine, and industrial shrimp trawl fisheries, which operate throughout most of its range. Where eagle rays have been targeted, fishers have reported declines in catches indicating local depletion. Fisheries are intensive in parts of its range, are noted for overcapacity, recent declines in catch, and poor or no management. This eagle ray may have limited refuge in the Galápagos Marine Reserve, but illegal fishing is ongoing there. Overall, due to the level of intense and unmanaged fisheries operating throughout most of its range and noted declines in catch in some areas, but some refuge in marine parks, the Pacific Eagle Ray is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (43.5 years) based on levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: This eagle ray inhabits coastal inshore waters in bays and estuaries. It reaches a maximum size of 230 cm DW or 283 cm total length but is usually smaller than 130 cm DW (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). These rays can be solitary or form large aggregations. Reproduction is viviparous, but little else is known of its biology. The generation length for the Pacific Eagle Ray is suspected to be 14.5 years, close to that of the related Bat Ray (Myliobatis californicus), which has an age at maturity of 5 years and a longevity of 24 years (Martin and Cailliet 1988).
threats: Pacific Eagle Rays are caught in artisanal gillnet and longline, purse seine, and industrial shrimp trawl fisheries. In Mexico, gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and other eagle rays are targeted and caught in this fishery (Ehemann et al. 2017). Where eagle rays have been targeted elsewhere, fishers have reported declines in catch (Cuevas-Zimbrón et al. 2011). Shrimp trawling is prevalent in Mexico south of the Gulf of California, and management issues such as overcapacity and declining catches have been cited in that fishery (Foster and Vincent 2010). This ray is caught on longlines in Guatemala, where it is now rare (C. Avalos unpubl. data 2019). In El Salvador, this species was formerly not retained but is now being utilized and has become increasingly rare (A. Gonzalez unpubl. data 2019). Gillnets capture them in Costa Rica but they are not retained (M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2019). Data are sparse in Nicaragua and from Panama to Ecuador, but artisanal fisheries in this part of its range are sparsely managed and inadequately enforced (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). In the Gulf of Panama, this ray is caught as bycatch in purse seine fishery targeting small pelagic fish (Morales-Saldaña unpubl. data 2019). In Colombia, this species is mainly caught in small-scale fisheries with gillnets and longlines, as well as in industrial shrimp trawl fisheries, and is consumed or sold locally (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017, Mejía-Falla et al. 2017). Overall, Pacific Eagle Rays are caught as bycatch in intensive and inadequately managed fisheries through most of their range, with very little refuge.
population: Gillnet, trawl, and longline fisheries (both small- and large-scale) capture this species throughout much of its range; these fisheries are intensive in many places along the Eastern Pacific coast, and in most cases management is inadequately enforced or completely lacking. In Mexico, gillnetting in the Gulf of California has caused substantial declines in several species such as pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and other eagle rays are targeted and caught in this fishery (Ehemann et al. 2017); these are suspected to have also declined. Where eagle rays have been targeted elsewhere, fishers have reported declines in catch (Cuevas-Zimbrón et al. 2011). The Pacific Eagle Ray is now considered to be rare in Guatemala (C. Avalos unpubl. data 2019) and El Salvador (A. Gonzalez unpubl. data 2019). Overall, due to the presence of intensive fisheries throughout most of its range and increased rarity in some areas, it is suspected that the Pacific Eagle Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (43.5 years) based on levels of exploitation.
range: The Pacific Eagle Ray occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California to Ecuador, including the Galápagos Islands (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Eagle rays are typically valued for their meat, and this species is likely dried or salted and consumed or sold locally when caught. Offal is used for fishmeal (Mejía-Falla et al. 2017, A. Cevallos unpublished data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this eagle ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. This ray may have some refuge in the Galápagos Marine Reserve, although illegal fishing is ongoing there (Jacquet et al. 2008, Schiller et al. 2015, Alava and Paladines 2017). Further research is needed on life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend.

rationale:
The Naru Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narutobiei) is a medium-sized (to 150 cm disc width) ray that is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean, where it occurs from Japan to Viet Nam. It is benthopelagic at depths of 0–60 m, and possibly to a depth of 90 m. The species is a bycatch of industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple demersal fishing gears, including trawl, gillnet, and set net, and is retained for human consumption or fish meal.

It has undergone a localised population reduction of 81% over the past three generation lengths (36 years) in Ariake Bay, Japan, due to a predator control program. Elsewhere, there are no species-specific time series, although catches of skates and rays from across the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates, and rays from the China, South Korea, and Viet Nam EEZs indicate declines of 46–96% over the past three generation lengths (36 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical fishing pressure was high, and it remains high in China, and to a lesser extent in South Korea, but has declined in Japan over the past 30 years. Across its range the species is still considered common and the inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species some refuge. It is suspected that the Naru Eagle Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Naru Eagle Ray is benthopelagic and semi-oceanic over the continental shelf from the surface to 60 m depth, and possibly to 90 m depth (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). It enters estuarine waters to breed and use as nursery grounds, and in southern Japan, schools move inshore in summer months and move offshore in winter (Yamaguchi et al. 2005, White et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 150 cm disc width (DW), males are mature by ~ 80 cm DW and female size-at-maturity is estimated as ~95 cm DW (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is matrotrophic viviparous with a litter size of 1–7 embryos reported and a size-at-birth of 33–35 cm DW (White et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016, A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). Female age-at-maturity is 7 years and maximum age is 19 years, thus generation length is 12 years (Yamaguchi et al. 2005).
threats:
The Naru Eagle Ray is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as target and bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple demersal fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, set net, and longline, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

In Japan, this species is targeted in a predator control program implemented in Ariake Bay in 2001 to protect commercially important bivalves as the Longnose Eagle Ray (Aetobatus flagellum), and presumably the Naru Eagle Ray, feeds on these bivalves (Yamaguchi et al. 2005). Up to 10,000 individual eagle rays (which includes this species, Longnose Eagle Ray and the Japanese Eagle Ray, Myliobatis tobijei) have been targeted in gillnets annually as part of the program. Across Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a there is a lack of younger people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013 (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019). In South Korea, the Naru Eagle Ray is occasionally captured (C.-H. Jeong unpubl. data 2019). Fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation with dramatic levels of habitat loss evident in the region. In the Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s with 65% loss of tidal flats since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In the East China Sea, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands (Heileman and Tang 2009). In Viet Nam, large areas of the coast are used for brackish-water aquaculture, which may have contributed to the dramatic loss of 45% of mangroves in Viet Nam from 1945 to 1995 (Jameson et al. 1995).
population:
The Naru Eagle Ray is common in coastal habitats over shallow tidal flats (Last et al. 2016). In Japan, this species' abundance has declined by 50% in Ariake Bay over the past 15 years, where it is targeted in a predator control program (Yamaguchi et al. 2005). This represents a decline of 81% over the past three generation lengths (36 years). Prior to the implementation of the program, the population of eagle rays (which also includes the Eagle Ray (Myliobatis tobiei)), had been increasing in Ariake Bay (Yamaguchi et al. 2005). The average maximum size of Naru Eagle Ray individuals in Ariake Bay appears to be decreasing (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019) and in the Seto Inland Sea, research from 2004 to 2012 found the abundance of larger Naru Eagle Rays (>120 cm disc width) decreased after 2008 (Shimamoto et al. 2019).

In Japan, the catch of all skates and rays combined from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some of the decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea, China, and Viet Nam EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). In Viet Nam, there were minimal catches from 1950 to 1980 that then rose steeply during the mid-1980s to a peak of 1,515 t in 1990 followed by a steady decline to 182 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). There is no specific effort information from Viet Nam but as the human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with some of the highest increases in the Asian region (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (36 years), they represent declines of 75%, 94%, 46%, and 96% in Japan, South Korea, China, and Viet Nam respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Significant localised depletion of the Naru Eagle Ray in Ariake Bay is evident with a population reduction of 84% over the past three generation lengths (36 years) due to the predator control program. Historical fishing pressure was high across the spatial and depth range of the Naru Eagle Ray, and it remains high in China, and to a lesser extent South Korea, but has declined in Japan over the past 30 years. Across its range the species is still considered common and the inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years).
range: The Naru Eagle Ray is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean where it occurs from Japan to Viet Nam, including North and South Korea, and China (White et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The meat is used for human consumption and fish meal. In China, the use may be similar to that of the Mottled Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus maculatus), whose fins are consumed and the rest of the animal used for fish meal (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial bottom trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). Trawling is banned all year round in the Bohai Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). Some of the species range may be protected along the China coastline as it is estimated that ~20% of the coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Brown Stingray (Bathytoshia lata) is a large (to 260 cm disc width) ray that has a widespread but patchy distribution in the Mediterranean Sea, east Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, and the west and Eastern Central Pacific Ocean. It is demersal on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 0–800 m. This species is taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple demersal fishing gears, including trawl, line gear, gillnet, and set net and is retained for its meat. Recent changes to the taxonomy of this species, and reporting of the species under different names (e.g., Cow Stingray, Dasyatis ushiei or Black Stingray, D. thetidis) may have precluded its accurate identification in the past. Little data are available to determine population trends although the very large size of the Brown Stingray makes it intrinsically susceptible to population depletion. There is no reason to infer or suspect a reduction in population size across its range in Australia, New Zealand, or the United States given the levels of fishing effort across its known range in these countries. However, there are largely unmanaged fisheries that operate across the remaining regions where it has been recorded (e.g., West Africa, India, and Indonesia) and the intense fishing pressure is a cause of concern. While declines in rays have been noted in these regions, this species also occurs deeper than most stingrays and this may offer it some refuge from fishing in deeper waters. Overall, it is suspected that the Brown Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (65 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Brown Stingray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates and sometimes around coral reefs on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 0–800 m (Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 260 cm disc width (DW), males mature at 80–150 cm DW and females mature at 110–160 cm DW (Ebert and Stehmann 2013, Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is viviparous with litter sizes of 2–6 pups, a gestation length of ~ 4 months, and size-at-birth of 34–37 cm DW (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016b). The Brown Stingray has an age-at-maturity of 15 years and a maximum age of 28 years; generation length is therefore 21.5 years (Dale and Holland 2012).
threats:
The Brown Stingray is taken as bycatch in artisanal and industrial fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. In the Mediterranean Sea, demersal trawl effort has increased in both effort and efficiency in the shelf and slope areas over the last 50 years. This region has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide depth range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Following two centuries of fisheries development, target shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008). 

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades and reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977­ to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 - these were mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018). Furthermore, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed the reported legal catch by more than 40% (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

In Pakistan, about 2,000 trawlers operate in shelf waters, targeting shrimp in shallow waters and fish in outer shelf waters (Moazzam Khan pers. comm. 6 February 2017). In India, there are intense coastal fisheries with a significant increase in coastal fishing effort and power over the past 30 years. For example, about 6,600 trawlers were operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). Furthermore, there are over 13,400 gill netters operating along the west coast, with many other types of net gear also deployed in coastal areas (CMFRI 2010). In the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, there is a targeted fishery for rays that began two years ago and consists of 20–40 boats and catch up to 6 tonnes of rays per trip (K.K. Bineesh pers. comm. 14 April 2020). In Thailand, most fisheries are overexploited. Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased dramatically from 5,900 vessels in 1950 to a peak of 82,900 vessels in 2004 and then declined steadily to 54,700 vessels in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of Thai trawlers peaked in 1989 at ~13,100 boats (Poonnachit-Korsieporn 2000), which was reflected in the catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) which declined from >300 kg per hour in 1963 to 20–30 kg per hour in the 1990s (Poonnachit-Korsieporn 2000). Fisheries in Thailand have been moving to deeper water for decades due to the overexploitation of the coastal region (Sylwester 2014).

In Indonesia, effort across all sectors has been increasing since the 1950s with steep increases in effort since the 1980s. Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Sharks and rays are an important resource and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Indonesia catches the highest number of chondrichthyans in the world with batoid contribution to rising catches. Batoids comprised over 50% of chondrichthyan landings in 2003, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006). In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019).
population:
There are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally (e.g., Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, the Brown Stingray is considered rare with few records over the last few decades (Capapé 1993, Serena et al. 2020). This species was recorded in one of 6,336 hauls conducted during the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) program in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, from 1994 to 1999 at depths of 10–800 m (Baino et al. 2001). In similar MEDITS surveys in the western Mediterranean (Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands) from 1994 to 2015, one individual was recorded in the Balearic Islands at 58 m depth (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). Analysis of various trawl datasets from the Adriatic Sea between 1948 and 2005 indicate that only four individuals were captured (Ferretti et al. 2013). The Italian survey program Gruppo Nazionale Risorse Demersali (GRUND) carried out over 22 surveys in Italian waters between 198 and 1998. The percentage presence of this species was one of the lowest recorded (0.83%) and it was only captured in the South Ligurian Sea and Sardinian waters (Relini et al. 2000). Off the coast of Turkey, this species is considered rare with only five surveys having recorded fewer than five individuals each between 2000 and 2017 in Iskenderun Bay, the Gulf of Antalya, and the Aegean Sea (Akyol et al. 2017). It is more common along the North African coast, especially off Tunisia, but records there are also limited (Capapé 1993).

Second, in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, both overall catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark and ray fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana. Population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but do indicate rising fishing pressure. Since the 1970s, the greatest African fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries were located in Nigeria, Senegal, and Ghana (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Across West Africa, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) decreased by 71% between 1970 and 2015 from 0.68 t/kW (tons per kilowatts) to 0.20 t/kw (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings increased by more than 2.5 times from 1970 to 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020), implying an increase in fishing effort. Within countries, landings have begun to decline in recent years. For example, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates increased from 1950 to 1972 then declined by 80% from 1972 to 1981. Landings increased again until 2001 followed by a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline from 2001 to 2016. These declines in landings can be inferred to represent population reductions as the fishing effort has remained stable during the decline (Pauly et al. 2020). Overall, in the northwest Africa region (Morocco to Guinea-Bissau), total elasmobranch catch in the industrial sector increased by a factor of ten between 1970 and 2015 while total industrial fishing effort increased by 45% (Pauly et al. 2020). The industrial elasmobranch CPUE of the region more than doubled during this time frame (Pauly et al. 2020). While these levels of change are not species-specific, they are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks and rays in the region. 

Third, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that the Brown Stingray is sometimes landed across its range in the Eastern Central Atlantic region. It was reported in small quantities between 2010 and 2014 during regular monitoring of fisheries landings between 2006 and 2018 undertaken by the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches (IMROP) along the coast of Mauritania (as Roughtail Stingray (D. centroura)) (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). However, it has not been recorded since. During extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004 and 2011 (Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including the Cape Verde Archipelago), this species was only recorded in Guinea and was reported as very rare (as Roughtail Stingray) (Diop and Dossa 2011). It was also recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985 to 2012 (Camara et al. 2016). In the Gambia, one individual was recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010 and 2018, although other species of rays with similar catchability were reported in large quantities (Moore et al. 2019). It was also listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" surveys as (Roughtail Stingray) with two individuals captured in one trawl haul in Cape Verde in 2011; 13 individuals captured off Gabon and Congo in 2008; and 54 individuals captured between Morocco and Guinea in 2011 (Krakstad et al. 2008, Krakstad et al. 2011a, Krakstad et al. 2011b). The species was also reported during baited remote underwater surveys in eastern Cape Verde with three sightings in 220 hours of underwater video footage between 2015 and 2017 (S. Pires unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, one individual has been recorded over two years of landing site surveys representing 0.05% of all shark and ray records (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). Across the rest of the Eastern Central Atlantic region, this species was not detected in recent landing site surveys in the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau, Côte d'Ivoire, Western Ghana, Nigeria, Gabon and the Republic of the Congo (E. Chartrain, G. De Bruyne, P. Doherty, G.H.L. Leurs, K. Metcalfe, I. Seidu, A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).

Fourth, in South Africa, this species is reported as a resident of canyons along the north coast of KwaZulu-Natal (Sodwana Bay) (as Black Stingray) (Heemstra et al. 2006). Twelve individuals were captured between 1989 and 1992 in commercial prawn trawls off Tugela Bank in 169 hauls (Fennessy 1994). It was also reported from recreational angling catches in False Bay in 1989 and 2010 but its status there is unknown (Best 2012).

Fifth, this species has rarely been recorded in the Indian Ocean and several records require verification. In Oman, genetic analysis of tissue from an unidentified ray recorded during landing site surveys revealed that it clustered with records of Cow Stingray (Henderson et al. 2016). However, this species was not reported from other landing site surveys undertaken in the region (e.g., Henderson et al. 2004). In Pakistan, while this species is considered rare, there has been a change in area of operation of fish trawlers from less than 40 m depth to about 150 m on the continental shelf area which has increased the frequency of landings for this species (Moazzam Khan pers. comm. 26 January 2021). In India, one individual (as Roughtail Stingray) was reported from exploratory trawl surveys undertaken in 1972 off Quilon, west coast of India at a depth of 250 m (Silas and Selvaraj 1985). In 2012, another individual (as Roughtail Stingray) was recorded during surveys of landings from vessels operating in the the Gulf of Mannar (Theivasigamani and Subbiah 2014). Furthermore, this species is listed on the national fish checklist for the Andaman and Nicobar Islands (as Black Stingray) (Rajan et al. 2012). All records of Roughtail Stingray and Black Stingray from India are reported as questionable and requiring verification (Akhilesh et al. 2014). However, if this species does occur in India, although rarely reported, the population is suspected to have declined due to overall declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing. The annual average catch of rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990 and 2004 was 502 t. During this period trawler hours doubled, and consequently, in 1990 the catch rate declined by 60% from 0.65 kg/hr to 0.24 in 2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009). In Thailand, nine individuals were recorded during landing site surveys undertaken in 2013–2014 (BOBLME 2014). There are no species-specific ray landings data but data are available on all combined ray species from the Thailand Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) for 1998–2018 (Krajangdara 2019). Ray landings peaked in 2003 with over 18,000 t reported but rapidly decreased and have been under 4,000 t since 2011, a decrease of ~78% in eight years (Krajangdara 2019).  

Sixth, in Southeast Asia, catches of sharks and rays are very high but are declining and fishers are traveling much further from port to increase catches (Chen 1996). Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). While species-specific data on long-term declines in sharks and rays in the Southeast Asia region are lacking, declines of the Brown Stingray in this region and elsewhere in the Indo-West Pacific are inferred given the widespread historical and continuing declines of demersal fisheries in this region (Stobutzki et al. 2006). For example, the catch of whiprays increased throughout Indonesia starting in the 1960s. In Eastern Indonesia, catch has since decreased by 45% between 1998–2014 from 300 t to an estimated 167 t (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Central Indonesia, whipray catch increased by 550% throughout the early-1970s to 2000, from 30 t to >200 t per year (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch decreased by 45% since the early 2000s (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catches are still increasing in western Sumatra and Java; however, this increase may be related to increasing fishing effort and demand for rays in the area and likely does not reflect the actual population trend (Blaber et al. 2009). These rising catches are unsustainable and instead arise from shifts in fishing effort into deeper waters due to decreased catch closer to shore (Dharmadi pers. comm. 14 April 2020). Research surveys from 1976 to 1997 shows more than a 90% decline in ray catch per unit effort throughout the Java Sea in 20 years (one generation length) (Blaber et al. 2009). With the increased catch through parts of Indonesia, there has also been increased effort and therefore, CPUE is likely decreasing, suggesting an overall decrease in the population of chondrichthyans (White and Dharmadi 2007). Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort have increased substantially since the 1950s. Since the 1990s, industrial effort has declined, however there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort. In Taiwan, this species is only occasionally observed at fish markets (Ebert et al. 2013). Landings data are available on the combined catch of all ray species taken by bottom trawl in Da-xi, Yilan County. The landings increased by 98% over 14 years from 1993 to 2006 (Lee 2008). That is, from ~1 t in 1993 to ~50 t in 2006. There is no detailed concurrent effort data, however the number of trawl vessels operating in the Yilan County area during the latter part of the time-series (1999–2008) were relatively stable (H. Hsu pers. comm. Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics 2019). This marked increase in rays caught by trawlers in the Yilan County from 1993 to 2006 is likely a reflection of an increase in reporting of the ray catch over that period, rather than an actual increase in abundance (H. Hans and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28 August 2019).

Seventh, in Australia, this species is considered common inshore (Last and Stevens 2009). Standardized CPUE data from the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF) between 1998 and 2006 showed no trend in CPUE (Walker and Gason 2007). There is no reason to infer or suspect a reduction in population size in Australia given levels of fishing effort. In New Zealand, the species is occasionally reported (as Black Stingray) in demersal longline, trawl, set net, and Danish seine fisheries (Francis 2015). Between 2008 and 2013, 32.9 t of the species was reported from commercial fisheries (Francis 2015). The species was ranked with relatively high risk from current fishing activities, but it also exists at depths of <100 m where many commercial fisheries closures exist (Ford et al. 2018). The species is listed as Not Threatened by the New Zealand Threat Classification System (NZTCS) (Duffy et al. 2018) and was regionally assessed as Least Concern using the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Finucci et al. 2019).

Eighth, in the United States, this species is considered common in nearshore waters of Hawaii and is the most common species in Kaneohe Bay, Oahu (Cartamil et al. 2002). There are no commercial or recreational fisheries for this species (Dale and Holland 2012).

The Brown Stingray has a patchy distribution and little data are available to determine population trends. There is no reason to infer or suspect a reduction in population size across its range in Australia, New Zealand, or the United States given distribution overlap with/or the levels of fishing effort. However, there are largely unmanaged fisheries that operate across the remaining regions where it has been recorded (e.g., West Africa, India, and Indonesia) and the intense fishing pressure is a cause of concern. While declines in rays have been noted in these regions, this species is likely to have some refuge at depth. Overall, it is suspected that the Brown Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (65 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Brown Stingray is found in the Mediterranean Sea (but absent from the Black Sea), east Atlantic Ocean, Indian Ocean, the west Pacific, and Eastern Central Pacific Ocean (Last et al. 2016b). It has a widespread but patchy distribution and recent changes to the taxonomy of this species, and its reporting under different names (e.g., Cow Stingray or Black Stingray) may have precluded its accurate identification in the past. Furthermore, many records of this species are old and require verification.
useTrade: The Brown Stingray is used for its meat. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of rays is consumed fresh in many coastal communities across its range as an important source of protein (e.g., Eastern Central Atlantic region: Walker et al. 2005; India: K. K. Bineesh pers. comm. 07 February 2017).
conservationActions:
There are no known conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Brown Stingray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts its range, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

In West Africa, a number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing one (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure, and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Whilst Gabon have recently expanded marine protected area coverage to 26% of their Exclusive Economic Zone, other countries such as the Republic of the Congo and Côte d'Ivoire are still in the process of expanding their marine protected area networks, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020).

Oman has banned trawling in its waters since 2011 and India has a seasonal trawl ban that might benefit the species. However, incidental catches are likely to occur in other fisheries (e.g., gillnetting). In Thailand, all commercial fishing vessels greater than 10 gross tonnage are prohibited to fish within three nautical miles from the shore (DoF 2015).

In Indonesia in 1980, trawls were banned, however, large numbers of mini or baby trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). There are currently plans in place to lift both this ban in the near future, where the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) plan will allow the operation of the fishing gear with restrictions on the area of fishing pressure (Dharmadi pers. comm. 14 April 2020). Throughout Indonesia there are 196 Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) making up 239,428 km² that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020).

In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within three nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). This species may be protected in some of the ~32 Protected Areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In Australia, the use of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) and other bycatch reduction devices has significantly reduced the bycatch of rays, especially for large individuals with >100 cm total length such as the Brown Whipray (Brewer et al. 2004). State and Commonwealth marine protected areas may provide some refuge for this species. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray (Telatrygon zugei) is a small (to 29 cm disc width) ray endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific from southern Japan to Viet Nam. It is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 0–100 m. The species is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and seine nets, and is retained for human consumption and possibly fish meal. Landings of this species in some areas have appeared stable in China over the past 10 years, although concurrent effort data for those areas is lacking. The catch-per-unit effort of all rays has remained stable in Taiwan over 17 years, and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the Japan, China, and Viet Nam Exclusive Economic Zones indicate declines of 46–85% over the past three generation lengths (26 years). Historic and current fishing pressure are high across most of the species’ range, yet is likely to have a stable population in Taiwan over 17 years (two generation lengths) which indicates that the species likely has some resilience to fishing pressure, possibly due to a short generation length. Fishing pressure has been in decline in Japan over the past three generation lengths (26 years). Dramatic levels of habitat loss across its China range is a threat to the species. It is suspected that the Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (26 years) due to levels of exploitation and a decline in quality of habitat, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cd.
habitat: The Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 0–100 m (Last et al. 2016a, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of ~29 cm disc width (DW) (~80 cm total length), male and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is oviparous with litter sizes of 1–3 and size-at-birth of ~8 cm DW (Last et al. 2016b). Nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from the related and similar-sized Plain Maskray (Neotrygon annotata) that has a verified female age-at-maturity of 4 years and a maximum age of 13 years, resulting in a generation length of 8.5 years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010).
threats:
The Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including trawl, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption and possibly fish meal.

There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017). The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding 30 years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly-valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

In response to fish stock depletions, the Chinese national government introduced measures in the 1980s and 1990s, that have since been modified, to reduce inshore fishing effort, including a ban on motorized trawling in close inshore waters, annual closed seasons, gear regulations such as a minimum mesh size, vessel buybacks, and fishing vessel scrapping (Yu and Yu 2008, Rueter et al. 2019). However, non-compliance with these measures is high and fishing effort continues to increase, and in some areas, move offshore in response to declining inshore catches (Yu and Yu 2008, Villasante et al. 2013, FAO 2019a, Pauly and Liang 2019). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989 at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283 to 239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273 to 12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Fabinyi and Liu 2014, Helgil 2019a).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980s–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile EEZ (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000 to 232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019b). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019b, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (Fabinya and Liu 2014, FAO 2019b, Helgil 2019b).

Dramatic levels of habitat loss in the region pose a threat. In the Yellow Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s and 65% loss of tidal flats (one type of intertidal habitat) since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In both the East and South China Seas, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands, with a loss of 70% of mangroves in the last 70 years in the South China Sea, where there has also been modification of up to 50% of seagrass beds and degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009).
population:
In China, the observed species abundance at some fish markets has remained stable over the past 10 years, although trends prior to that are unknown (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Fishing pressure has increased in China over the past decade and the lack of change in landings may indicate a decline in catch rates, however there is no concurrent effort data at the area of the fish markets to infer population trends. In Taiwan, although there is no species-specific data, the catch-per-unit effort for all rays has remained stable over 17 years, that is, 1997–2013 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Japan, China, and Viet Nam Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs), based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Japan and China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 98% and 67% decline respectively in landings over the 65-year period (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Japan, this decline was from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ. In China, the decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller-sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Viet Nam, there were minimal catches from 1950 to 1980 that then rose steeply during the mid-1980s to a peak of 1,515 t in 1990 followed by a steady decline to 182 t in 2014 (Zeller and Pauly 2016). There is no specific effort information from Viet Nam but as the human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with some of the highest increases in the Asian region (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray (26 years), they represent declines of 84%, 46%, and 85% in Japan, China, and Viet Nam, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region.

Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the spatial and depth range of the Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray. Yet, a stable population is reported from Taiwan over 17 years (two generation lengths). This indicates that the species likely has some resilience to fishing pressure. Fishing pressure has been in decline in Japan over the past three generation lengths. Inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China and Taiwan may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (26 years).
range: The Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray is endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific from southern Japan to Viet Nam, including China and Taiwan; the presence of the species in Thailand and the Philippines is uncertain (Last et al. 2016b).
useTrade: This species is used for human consumption and possibly fish meal. In China, this species is preferred for consumption, as it is small with good quality flesh (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place. In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the Yellow Sea, East China Sea, and in the South China Sea to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019).

This species may be protected in parts of China where there are approximately 124 coastal marine protected areas in the southern China provinces, although only a few are documented internationally (McCook 2019). Fifty-four national marine reserves are reported by FAO (2019a) and five marine protected areas, all each less than 20 km², are reported in the World Database of Protected Areas (UNEP-WCMC and IUCN 2019). All protected areas across China have recently been nationalized (McCook 2019). It is estimated that ~20% of the Chinese coastline is included in protected areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). It may also be protected in some of the ~32 protected areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019).

In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015).

Research is required on the species' life history and catches, and population size and trends of the Pale-edge Sharpnose Stingray should be closely monitored.

rationale: Bennett's Stingray (Hemitrygon bennetti) is a medium-sized (to at least 61 cm disc width) ray endemic to the Northwest and Western Central Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans from northern China to Java, Indonesia. It is also recently reported from east India. The species is demersal on the continental shelf in rocky, coral, and soft-sediment habitats at depths of 25–36 m. An isolated, entirely freshwater population occurs in the Zuojiang River, China. The species is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and seine nets, and is retained for human consumption. The freshwater population, which is subject to commercial fishing pressure, is suspected to have declined by 80–90% over the past 20 years. There are no species-specific time-series from elsewhere, although catch-per-unit effort of all rays has remained stable in Taiwan over 17 years, and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the China, Viet Nam, Cambodia, Malaysia Exclusive Economic Zones, and catch rates in Indonesia and India indicate declines of 46%–99% over the past three generation lengths (36 years). Historic and current fishing pressure are high across the species’ entire range, yet in China and Taiwan this is an abundant and common species with a stable population in Taiwan, which suggests that the species has some resilience to fishing pressure and it may have refuge in rocky habitat. It is suspected that Bennett's Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: Bennett's Stingray is demersal across rocky, coral, and soft-sediment habitats, and occurs inshore on the continental shelf at depths of 25–36 m (Last et al. 2016b, Weigmann 2016, H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). In China, a local population occurs entirely in freshwater in the Zuojiang River, more than 1,500 km inland (Zhang et al. 2010). The inland population is isolated from the South China Sea due to dams in the Pearl River Basin, and is breeding in the freshwater habitat (Zhang et al. 2010). The species reaches a maximum size of 61 cm disc width (DW), males mature at ~32 cm DW with female size-at-maturity unknown. Reproduction is viviparous and size-at-birth is ~13 cm DW (Last et al. 2016b). Nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from the related Kuhl's Maskray (Neotrygon kuhlii) that has a verified female age-at-maturity of 6.5 years and a maximum age of 17 years, resulting in a generation length of 12 years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010).
threats:
Bennett's Stingray is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, likely including trawl, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption. The freshwater population in the Zuojiang River is subject to commercial fishing pressure (Zhang et al. 2010). There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of Bennett's Stingray.

In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017). The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). In response to fish stock depletions, the Chinese national government introduced measures in the 1980s and 1990s, that have since been modified, to reduce inshore fishing effort, including a ban on motorized trawling in close inshore waters, annual closed seasons, gear regulations such as a minimum mesh size, vessel buybacks, and fishing vessel scrapping (Yu and Yu 2008, Rueter et al. 2019). However, non-compliance with these measures is high and fishing effort continues to increase, and in some areas, move offshore in response to declining inshore catches (Yu and Yu 2008, Villasante et al. 2013, FAO 2019, Pauly and Liang 2019). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6 percent annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s Exclusive Economic Zone significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283–239 from 1956–2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273–12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Fabinyi and Liu 2014, Helgil 2019).

Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020). The fleet is dominated by small-scale artisanal and subsistence fisheries that have accounted for 60–85% of the fleet since the 1950s (Teh et al. 2014b, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal and subsistence motorized fleet has tripled from 1950 (~24,280 vessels) to 2014 (~ 78,000 vessels) but has also substantially increased in effort in terms of engine power, particularly over the last two decades (Pauly et al. 2020). This fleet tends to operate in inshore waters at depths less than 50 m, and within 4–5 nautical miles from shore, and mostly use small trawl, gillnet, longline, lift-net, push net, and traps (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020). Approximately 33% of the total marine captures in Viet Nam consists of ‘trash’ fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry and also to manufacture fish sauce (FAO 2020). The demand for seafood is also high in Viet Nam, with per capita fish consumption steeply increasing over the last two decades to 36.3 kg per capita in 2017 (FAO 2020, Helgil 2020). Illegal fishing by foreign vessels is an additional threat in Viet Nam waters (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020).

Coastal fisheries in Cambodia are considered overexploited (Teh et al. 2014a). Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 26,180 vessels in 1950 to 108,490 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since the 1980s and most of the fleet artisanal fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The marine fisheries are mostly inshore and small-scale within 10 km of the shore and occur across all habitats, including coral reefs, seagrass, mangroves, and estuaries. Motorized vessels increased during the 1980s and trawlers are the dominant fishery accounting for one-quarter to one-third of the Cambodian fishing fleet (Teh et al. 2014a, Pauly et al. 2020).

Most fisheries in Thailand are overexploited. By 2007, over 40% of the trawler catch in the Gulf of Thailand consisted of small, low-value fish (Derrick et al. 2017). Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased dramatically from 5,900 vessels in 1950 to a peak of 82,900 vessels in 2004 and then declined steadily to 54,700 vessels in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Malaysia, unrestrained fisheries expansion from the mid-1960s to the 70s meant that inshore fisheries were fully exploited by the late 1970s (Teh and Teh 2014). Fishing effort in Malaysia has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has more than doubled from 22,800 vessels in 1950 to 50,150 vessels in 2014. However, the substantial increase over this period has been in engine power, which has dramatically increased by ~30 fold (Pauly et al. 2020). There has been, and still is, a currently rising trend in fish consumption throughout the country and ~85% of this comes from within the Malaysian EEZ (Fowler et al. 2002, A. Ali unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, effort across all sectors has been increasing since the 1950s with steep increases in effort since the 1980s. Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Sharks and rays are an important resource and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Indonesia catches the highest number of chondrichthyans in the world with batoid contribution to rising catches. Batoids comprised over 50% of chondrichthyan landings in 2003, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006).
population:
There are no species-specific time-series for Bennett's Stingray. In China, the isolated freshwater population is now rare with less than 20 individuals captured annually (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Based on anecdotal information, it is suspected that this isolated population has declined by 80–90% over the past 20 years (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Elsewhere in China, this is species is abundant and common with small to large individuals noted at fish markets; anecdotally there is a slight decrease in landings in the past 10 years (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019).

In Taiwan, this species is considered very common (H. Hsu unpubl. data 2019). Although there is no species-specific data, the catch-per-unit effort for all rays has remained stable over 17 years (1997–2013) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). Landings data are available on all combined ray species from the Thailand Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) for 1998–2018 (Krajangdara 2019). The landings data showed an 89% reduction over 16 years from 2003 to 2018. Catches rose steadily from 1998 to a peak catch of 18,131 t in 2003 followed by a steady decline in catches to ~2000 t in 2018 (Krajangdara 2019). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the decline in catches from 2003 to 2018 coincided with a decline in fishing effort.

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for China, Viet Nam, Cambodia, and Malaysia EEZs, based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline in landings over the 65 years (Zeller and Pauly 2016). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Viet Nam, reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates in the EEZ over 29 years from 1986 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 1,560 t in 1950 to ~44,000 t per year in the mid-1960s, fluctuated and then rose steeply during the early-1980s to a peak of 466,445 t in 1986 followed by a fairly steady decline to 14,750 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cambodia, the reconstructed catch data showed a 91% reduction decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates in the EEZ over 12 years from 2003 to 2014. Catches sharply rose from 1950 to a peak of 4,550 t in 1970, dropped sharply then rose over two decades to another peak catch of 3,914 t in 2003 followed by a sharp decline in catches to 335 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in populations of sharks, rays, and skates in both countries can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort was increasing during the period of a decline in landings (Teh et al. 2014a, Pauly et al. 2020).

In Peninsular Malaysia, reconstructed catch data showed declines in landings of sharks, rays, and skates. On the east coast, there was a 30% decline from a peak of 17,604 t in 1999 to 12,314 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). On the west coast, the decline was 54% decline from a peak of 19,308 t in 1979 to 8,902 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing pressure has been increasing since the 1950s on both coasts and thus these declines infer reductions in these populations in Peninsular Malaysia. In Indonesia, research survey data shows an ~ 50% decline in ray catch-per-unit effort 1976–1997 throughout the Java Sea in the areas of the Bennett's Stingray distribution (Blaber et al. 2009). In India, there is no information on ray catches from the east coast, however, the annual average catch rate of demersal rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990–2004 declined by 63%, despite a doubling of trawl effort (Raje and Zacharia 2009). This provides an indication of overall batoid declines as a result of heavy (and increasing) fishing pressure on the Indian continental shelf.

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of Bennett's Stingray (36 years), they represent declines of 46%, 99%, 99%, 58%, 55%, 70%, and 92% in China, Viet Nam, Cambodia, east and west coast Peninsular Malaysia, Indonesia, and India, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. A population trend cannot be inferred for Thailand. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the spatial and depth range of Bennett's Stingray. The isolated freshwater population in China is suspected to have undergone dramatic declines of 80–90% over the past 20 years. The inshore distribution provides little refuge from fishing pressure, yet in China and Taiwan this is an abundant and common species, which suggests that it has some resilience to fishing pressure. The inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China and Taiwan may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years).
