Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a there is a lack of younger people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013 (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019). 

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation with dramatic levels of habitat loss evident in the region. In the Yellow Sea and Bohai Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s with 65% loss of tidal flats since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In the East China Sea, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands (Heileman and Tang 2009).
population:
In Japan, this species abundance has declined by 90% in Ariake Bay over the past 15 years, where it is captured as part of a predator control program (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). This represents a decline of 94% over the past three generation lengths (18 years). In South Korea, this species is seen at fishing ports from Incheon to the south coast, where it is more frequently observed (C.-H. Jeong unpubl. data 2019).

In Japan, the catch of all skates and rays combined from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species. Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea and China EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (18 years), they represent declines of 50%, 75%, and 27% in Japan, South Korea, and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Significant localised depletion of the Japanese Eagle Ray in Ariake Bay is evident with a population reduction of 94% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) due to the predator control program. Historical fishing pressure was high across the spatial and depth range of the Japanese Eagle Ray, and it remains high in China, and to a lesser extent South Korea, but has declined in Japan over the past 30 years. Inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (18 years).
range: The Japanese Eagle Ray is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean where it occurs off Sakhalin Island, Russia, and off Japan, North and South Korea, and China (Last et al. 2016, Dyldin and Orlov 2018). The species was previously thought to occur from Japan south to Indonesia, but its range is now known to be restricted to the Northwest Pacific (White et al. 2015). A record in the Bering Sea requires further verification (Dyldin and Orlov 2018)
useTrade: The meat is used for human consumption and fish meal. In China, the use may be similar to that of the Mottled Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus maculatus), whose fins are consumed and the rest of the animal used for fish meal (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The species is used for aquarium displays.
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015).

In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial bottom trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). Trawling is banned all year round in the Bohai Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). Some of the species range may be protected along the China coastline as it is estimated that ~20% of the coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Sailfin Roughshark (Oxynotus paradoxus) is a small (to at least 118 cm total length) deep-water shark endemic to the Northeast and Eastern Central Atlantic, from Scotland to Senegal and possibly southwards to the Gulf of Guinea. It occurs on the continental slope at depths of 265–1,104 m. The Sailfin Roughshark is very infrequently reported as bycatch in demersal trawl fisheries across its range and may inhabit depths beyond the reach of some regional fishing activities. Off West Africa, there are a number of European distant-water vessels using demersal trawl and longline to target demersal fish and shrimp species that reach the depth limit of the species. The Sailfin Roughshark is listed as a deep-water shark species in European Union regulations, and various management actions apply to such listed deep-water sharks, including a prohibited on targeted fisheries, a Total Allowable Catch (TAC) for shark bycatch in longline fisheries targeting Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp), and depth limits beyond which gillnets and demersal trawl fisheries are prohibited in some areas. Oxynotus species are highly susceptible to population decline from fishing with estimated population reductions of 80% over three generation lengths (60 years) in areas with high fishing effort. There is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, reported declines of deep-water sharks in part of its range, some relevant management across part of its range, and possible refuge at depth. The Sailfin Roughshark is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (60 years) based on actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Sailfin Roughshark is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 265–1,104 m (Pajuelo et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 118 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous and size-at-birth is ~25 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown and are inferred from another species in the family Squalidae, the Shortnose Spurdog (Squalus megalops) which has a female age-at-maturity of 19 years and a maximum age of 25 years, resulting in a generation length of 19.5 years (Rigby et al. 2016). This is similar to the generation length of 20 years that has been used for other Oxynotus spp. (Soldo and Guallart 2015).
threats:
The Sailfin Roughshark is very infrequently reported as bycatch across its range in demersal trawl fisheries (Ebert et al. 2013, O'Hea et al. 2020, Santos et al. 2020). The species may inhabit depths beyond the reach of some regional fishing activities; a large number of Sailfin Roughshark were reported from trawl surveys operating at depths >800 m off northwest Africa (Pajuelo et al. 2016). 

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, there are a number of European distant-water industrial vessels using demersal trawls to capture deep-water shrimps at depths of 150–850 m in Guinea-Bissau (Sobrino et al. 2017) and at 400–950 m in Mauritania (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In Mauritania, there are also demersal longline fisheries for Ray's Bream (Brama brama) operating to depths >1,500 m and demersal trawl fisheries for black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and Merluccius polli) operating mainly at depths of 500–700 m (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In the Mauritanian trawl fisheries, unidentified deep-water sharks and rays have accounted for approximately 10% of landings (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). Demersal trawl and longline fisheries in southern Morocco target a number of demersal fish, including black hake and scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Trawl fishing there occurs mostly at depths of 500–800 m and longline fishing occurs at 100–400 m (Cervantes et al. 2018). Further information on bycatch species in these fisheries is largely unknown. 

There are also an estimated 518 Chinese distant-water vessels registered in Africa; most (480) vessels fly flags from West Africa between Morocco and Gabon and most (426) are trawlers (Gutiérrez et al. 2020). Fishing effort is widespread, often takes place in deep offshore areas, and some “high intensity” areas have been identified off Guinea to Sierra Leone and off the Congo (Gutiérrez et al. 2020). Virtually nothing is known about these fishing activities. 

West Africa has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and IUU fishing by large industrial trawlers has contributed to depleted fish stocks across the region (Daniels et al. 2016). Of the stocks assessed in the Eastern Central Atlantic, most are either overexploited or are fully exploited and are fished at levels that are not sustainable in the short term (FAO 2020).
population:
There are no species-specific population trends for the Sailfin Roughshark. Despite the lack of species-specific data, there are a number of relevant datasets for fish and elasmobranch landings and catch rates that are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. In the east Atlantic, reported fish landings from distant water fleets increased from 600,000 t to 4.5 million t between 1950 and 2000 (Alder and Sumaila 2004). Between 1984–2001, landings of the most reported squalid sharks in the Mauritania hake fishery declined steadily from 158 t to 37 t, with a minimum catch of 3.5 t reported in 1999 (Fernández et al. 2005), amounting to a reduction in squalid landings of >99% over three generation lengths (60 years). Causes of these declines have been attributed to changes in the fishing fleet, economics, and likely over-exploitation of both the target species and bycatch (Fernández et al. 2005). Across West Africa, total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold between 1950–2010, while the catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) of artisanal and industrial vessels declined by 34% over this period (Belhabib et al. 2018). In the northwest Africa region (Morocco to Guinea-Bissau), total elasmobranch catch in the industrial sector increased by a factor of ten between 1950–2015, from 6,031 t to 60,822 t (Pauly et al. 2020). Many regional fisheries are now characterised by severe over-exploitation and declines in abundance of marine resources (e.g. Gascuel et al. 2007).

Oxynotus species are highly susceptible to population decline from fishing, and populations in the Mediterranean and Northeast Atlantic have declined by an estimated 80% over three generation lengths (60 years), or disappeared altogether, in areas with high fishing effort (Soldo and Guallart 2015, Soldo and Guallart 2016). The Sailfin Roughshark is suspected to be declining across its distribution where historic and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high (Fernández et al. 2005, Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019) and previous declines in deep-water sharks have been documented (for example, see Finucci et al. 2018). It may have refuge at depth. Overall, it is suspected that the Sailfin Roughshark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (60 years) and is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Sailfin Roughshark is endemic to the Northeast and Eastern Central Atlantic, from Scotland to Senegal, and possibly southwards to the Gulf of Guinea (Ebert et al. 2013). The species has also been reported from the Mid-Atlantic Ridge (Hareide and Garnes 2001).
useTrade: The species may be used for fishmeal (Ebert et al. 2013).
conservationActions: Further information is required on population size and trends of the Sailfin Roughshark, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range, particularly around Africa. There are some general management arrangements of relevance in place in the Northeast Atlantic. In 2010, the European Union Fisheries Council prohibited direct fishing for deep-water sharks, including the Sailfin Roughshark, in European Community and international waters, and in 2012, no allowances for bycatch were implemented (ICES-WGEF 2019). Since 2017, a restrictive bycatch allowance (10 t) was trialled, permitting limited landings of unavoidable catches of deep-water sharks in directed artisanal demersal longline fisheries for Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Additional management actions for this region include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m depth in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); banned use of gillnets by European Union vessels at depths >600 m; maximum bycatch limits of deep-water shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and monkfish (Lophius spp) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear), and a network of closed areas in Azorean waters; closure of the Condor seamount to deep-water fishing in 2010 (ICES-WGEF 2019).

rationale:
The Japanese Velvet Dogfish (Scymnodon ichiharai) is a medium-sized (to at least 151 cm total length) deep-water shark with a disjunct distribution in the Northwest Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans where it is known from southern Japan, southeast Taiwan, and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India. It is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 450–830 m. The species is only currently known from ~20 specimens. It is taken as bycatch and possibly targeted in demersal line fisheries and likely retained for its meat and liver oil.

There are no species-specific population trends although landings data of all sharks, skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and catches of all sharks combined from the Taiwan EEZ infer declines of 99% and 70%, respectively over the past three generation lengths (102 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region.

Shark populations are anecdotally reported to have declined in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands since the target shark fishery commenced in the 1980s. A recent strategy to further develop deep-water fishing in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands is of concern for this species. The Japanese Velvet Dogfish has a likely low biological productivity, is subject to intense fishing pressure in some parts of its distribution, and has little refuge from fishing pressure in its known range. It is a rare species, but it is not known if this is due to a naturally low population size or to overfishing.

A precautionary approach leads to a suspected population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (102 years) due to levels of exploitation, and the Japanese Velvet Dogfish is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Japanese Velvet Dogfish is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 450–830 m (White et al. 2015, Weigmann 2016). The depth range is based on type specimens from Japan with no depth information available for the Taiwan specimens (White et al. 2015). It reaches a maximum size of at least 151 cm total length (TL), males mature at 89 cm TL and females mature at 126 cm TL (Yano and Tanaka 1984, White et al. 2015). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology (Ebert et al. 2013b, White et al. 2015). Age parameters are inferred from the closely related Plunket's Shark (Scymnodon plunketi) that has a female age-at-maturity of 29 years and estimated maximum age of 39 years, thus generation length is estimated at 34 years (Daley et al. 2002, Irvine 2004).
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. The known specimens were caught in Japan by deepset line surveys and fisheries (Yana and Tanaka 1984, Compagno et al. 2005). A localised fishery targeting deep-water sharks previously operated in Suruga Bay, Honshu, using demersal longlines (McCormack and Tanaka 2009). It is unknown whether this species comprised part of the catch in that fishery (McCormack and Tanaka 2009). A deep-water dropline fishery for Splendid Alfonsino (Beryx splendens) currently operates around the islands and seamounts south of Sagami Bay at depths of 400–800 m (S. Tanaka pers. comm. 28/08/2019) and may capture this species. If susceptible to capture in gillnets, it may be taken in Suruga Bay by demersal gillnets that target fish and crustaceans at depths of 100–500 m (S. Tanaka pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

Fisheries developed rapidly in Japan during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980s–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000 to 232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019).

In Taiwan, this species was captured and retained by commercial longlines operating off Cheong-gong, Taitung, southeast Taiwan. Deep-water longlines operate on the east coast of Taiwan, targeting mostly tuna with all incidental shark catch retained and marketed. The longline fishery likely began during the 1980s, and mostly operated at depths of 100–300 m, though catches of this species and other deep-water species indicate that the fishery has moved into deeper waters (Ebert et al. 2013a, H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Kuo and Booth 2011, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

There is no information on the capture of this species in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India (Kumar et al. 2018). A target fishery for elasmobranchs has operated in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands since the 1980s and there is a deep-water target shark fishery for shark liver oil (Bineesh et al. 2020, Tyabji et al. 2020). A recent strategy has been developed in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to expand fisheries and increase development of deep-water mechanised vessels and associated fisheries infrastructure (Tyabji et al. 2020). This is of concern as it further increases the likelihood of capture of the Japanese Velvet Dogfish.
population:
There are no species-specific trend data for this species. It is currently only known from ~20 specimens: the holotype, 6 paratypes, and a recently collected specimen from Suruga Bay and adjacent waters in Japan; 11 specimens from southeast Taiwan; and a single record from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India (White et al. 2015, Kumar et al. 2018). The species is considered very rare in Japan (McCormack and Tanaka 2009).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Japanese Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Across Japan, fishing effort has declined by about one third since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). The reconstructed catch data showed a 98% decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ over 65 years, that is from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort, which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ.

In Taiwan, landings data are available on all combined shark species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). The landings data showed a 52% decline of all combined shark species over 63 years from 1953 to 2015. The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t annually in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). These long-term declines in abundance of sharks and skates can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort.

In the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, anecdotal information from fishers indicates that shark and ray populations have declined since targeted fishing commenced in the 1980s (Tyabji et al. 2020). Reconstructed sharks, rays, and skates landings indicate declining catches from 1980 to 2014; the catches peaked at nearly 8,000 t in 1998 then fluctuated and declined to around 4,000 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). No concurrent information on effort in the area is available, and thus a shark population trend cannot be inferred.

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Japanese Velvet Dogfish (102 years) they represent declines of 99% and 70% in Japan and Taiwan, respectively. These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. This species is subject to intense fishing pressure in some parts of its distribution and has little refuge from fishing pressure in its known range. It is highly likely to have low biological productivity, based on other sleeper sharks, which reduces its ability to recover from fishing pressure. It is a rare species, but it is not known if this is due to a naturally low population size or to overfishing. Other deep-water shark populations have declined dramatically in response to intense fishing pressure (Clark et al. 2000, Graham et al. 2001, Tyabji et al. 2020). Based on the levels of fishing pressure, declines in all shark species in its range, and the suspected declines in other deep-water sharks exposed to such fishing pressure, a precautionary approach leads to a suspected population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (102 years).
range: The Japanese Velvet Dogfish has a patchy distribution in the Northwest Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans where it is known from Suruga Bay and adjacent waters in Japan, Cheng-gong, Taitung, in southeast Taiwan, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India (Ebert et al. 2013a, White et al. 2015, Kumar et al. 2018).
useTrade: Based on other sleeper sharks (Somniosidae), this species is likely used for its meat at local markets and processed for liver oil (Akhilesh et al. 2011, Ebert et al. 2013b).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In Taiwan, since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nautical miles (nm) in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a 45-day closed season for target shark fishing was declared in 2009 (Tyabji et al. 2020). Research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Ocellate Topeshark (Hemitriakis complicofasciata) is a small (to 96 cm total length) shark endemic to the Northwest Pacific from the Ryukyu Islands, Japan to Taiwan. It is a demersal inshore species that occurs at depths of 90–100 m. The species is a bycatch of demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet fisheries and is retained for human consumption and fish meal. Landings data of all sharks combined from the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates and rays from the Japan EEZ indicate declines of 30% and 88%, respectively over the past three generation lengths (30 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Fishing pressure is high across the spatial and depth range of the Ocellate Topeshark in Taiwan, but may be less intense in its range across the Ryukyu Islands of Japan. The inshore trawl bans in Taiwan may afford the species some refuge from fishing pressure. Fishing pressure and bottom trawl effort in Japan is decreasing and continuing to decline. Overall, it is inferred that the Ocellate Topeshark  has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (30 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Ocellate Topeshark is demersal and occurs inshore on the continental shelf at depths of 90–100 m (Takahashi and Nakaya 2004, Ebert et al. 2013a). It reaches a maximum size of 95.5 cm total length (TL); males mature at 76 cm TL and females mature at 81 cm TL (Takahashi and Nakaya 2004, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is viviparous with litters of 5–8 and size-at-birth of 24 cm TL (Takahashi and Nakaya 2004, Ebert et al. 2013a). Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a closely-related species, the Japanese Topeshark (Hemitriakis japanica) that has a female age-at-maturity of 4–6 years and a maximum age of >15 years, resulting in a generation length of 10 years (Yamada 1986, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 28 August 2019).
threats:
The Ocellate Topeshark is subject to fishing pressure on its inshore shelf habitats. It is likely taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, longline, and gillnet. All incidental catch in Taiwan is retained for the meat for human consumption or for fish meal production for aquaculture. In Japan, it is likely this species is retained as its relative, the Japanese Topeshark (Hemitriakis japanica) is retained for its meat.

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s Exclusive Economic Zone significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989 at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283 to 239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273 to 12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). Seine nets and demersal trawls are the main gear types, accounting for 46% and 19% of the total coastal and offshore fisheries catch, respectively, followed by longline (7%) and gillnet (4%) (Fisheries Agency 2019). Demersal trawling operates to depths of 700 m, depending on the location. In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Fabinyi and Liu et al. 2014, Helgil 2019a). Fish too small for human consumption are in demand for processing into fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry that produces double the quantity of seafood taken from wild capture fisheries in Taiwan waters (NDC 2016).

 In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980s–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000 to 232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (Fabinya and Liu 2014, FAO 2019, Helgil 2019b).
population:
The Ocellate Topeshark appears to be rare in Taiwan as it is only known from three specimens, one of which was an embryo (Ebert et al. 2013b, H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). However, adults may be mistaken for the Japanese Topeshark (Hemitriakis japanica) which was one of the most abundant sharks in Taiwan coastal fisheries (Ebert et al. 2013b, H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).

Despite the lack of species-specific data, landings data are available on all combined shark species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort have increased substantially since the 1950s, despite attempts by the Taiwan government to restrict effort in response to depletion of fisheries resources. Since the 1990s, industrial effort has declined, however there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort.

The landings data showed a 52% decline of all combined shark species over 63 years from 1953 to 2015. The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t annually in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The landings of all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries decreased by 80% over 49 years from 1953 to 2001. The annual landings rose from 560 t tonne in 1953 to a peak of 1,800 t in 1973, then declined steadily to the 114 t in 2001 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). These long-term declines in abundance of sharks and skates can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. Additionally, there are anecdotal reports of catch declines during 1967–1997 of some demersal shark species that were previously considered common, with some species difficult to find by 1997 (Chen 1997). Unfortunately, this information is not species-specific.

In Japan, catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the EEZ, based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016). The reconstructed catch data showed a 98% decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates over 65 years, that is from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some of the decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ.

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (30 years) they represent declines of 30% and 88% in Taiwan and Japan, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the spatial and depth range of the Ocellate Topeshark in Taiwan but in Japan, the range of the Ocellate Topeshark is the Ryukyu Islands that are likely not as heavily fished as the waters of mainland Japan. The inshore trawl bans in Taiwan may afford the species some refuge from fishing pressure. Fishing pressure and bottom trawl effort in Japan is decreasing and continuing to decline. Overall, it is inferred that the species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (30 years).
range: The Ocellate Topeshark is endemic to the Northwest Pacific from the Ryukyu Islands of Japan to Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013a).
useTrade: No information is available on use and trade; however, it is likely used for human consumption as its closely-related relative, the Japanese Topeshark (Hemitriakis japanica) is valued for its meat (A. Yamaguchi pers. comm. 28 August 2019). Smaller individuals may be used for fish meal in Taiwan. The fins may be traded, as fins from other topesharks are reported in the fin trade (Fields et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within three nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since 2005, shark fins must be naturally attached on vessels that use ice to preserve the catch (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). This species may have some refuge in the ~32 protected areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). 

Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Velvet Belly Lanternshark (Etmopterus spinax) is a small (to at least 55 cm total length) deep-water shark found in the Eastern Atlantic Ocean (from Iceland to Gabon) and in the Western Mediterranean Sea. It occurs on the outer continental shelves and upper slopes at depths of 70–2,000 m, and mostly from 200 to 500 m. The species is frequently reported as incidental catch in deep-water demersal trawl, longline, and handline fisheries across its known spatial range in the Northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea. Off West Africa, there are a number of European distant-water vessels using demersal trawl and longline to target demersal fish and shrimp species that likely interact with this species. The Velvet Belly Lanternshark is listed as a deep-water shark species in European Union regulations, and various management actions apply to such listed deep-water sharks, including a prohibited on targeted fisheries, a Total Allowable Catch (TAC) for shark bycatch in longline fisheries targeting Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp,) and depth limits beyond which gillnets and demersal trawl fisheries are prohibited in some areas. Overall, there is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, some refuge at depth, and deep-water shark management across part of its range. The Velvet Belly Lanternshark is estimated to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (23 years) based on abundance indices and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Velvet Belly Lanternshark is demersal on the outer continental shelves and upper slopes at depths of 70–2,000 m, and mostly at 200–500 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 55 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Males mature at 24–34 cm TL and females mature at 30–41 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with a litter size of 1–21 pups and size-at-birth is 9–14 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Female age-at-maturity is 4.7 years and maximum age is 11 years, resulting in a generation length of 7.8 years (Coelho and Erzini 2008).
threats:
The Velvet Belly Lanternshark is reported as incidental catch in deep-water demersal trawl, longline, and handline fisheries across its range (Fauconnet et al. 2019, ICES-WGEF 2019). The Northeast Atlantic and the Mediterranean have been subject to extensive and intensive deep-water fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution (Coelho et al. 2009). Relative abundance of the Velvet Belly Lanternshark was highest at depths of 400–750 m (Ragonese et al. 2013, Neat et al. 2015, ICES-WGEF 2019). In the Northeast Atlantic, there were a number of demersal trawl and longline fisheries targeting mixed deep-water sharks along the continental slope (Gordon 1999, ICES-WGEF 2019). Despite a number of management measures to reduce deep-water shark fishing mortality, the species is still captured in demersal fisheries (e.g. Moura et al. 2018). Discard mortality is unknown, but is likely to be high based on severe injuries obtained when individuals are captured (Coelho et al. 2009).

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). 

There are currently three active mixed fishery bilateral agreements between the European Union and the West African nations of Morocco, Mauritania, and Guinea-Bissau (European Commission 2020). These agreements, known as Sustainable Fisheries Partnership Agreements (SFPAs) involve payments to third party countries in exchange for access to marine resources and sectorial support aimed at promoting sustainable fisheries development in the partner countries. Under SFPAs, there are a number of European distant-water industrial vessels using demersal trawls to capture deep-water shrimps at depths of 150–850 m in Guinea-Bissau (Sobrino et al. 2017) and at 400–950 m in Mauritania (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In Mauritania, there demersal trawl fisheries for black hake (Merluccius senegalensis and Merluccius polli) that operate mainly at depths of 500–700 m (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). In the Mauritanian trawl fisheries, unidentified deep-water sharks and rays have accounted for approximately 10% of landings (Fernandez Peralta et al. 2019). Demersal trawl and longline fisheries in southern Morocco target a number of demersal fish, including black hake and scabbardfish. Trawl fishing here occurs mostly at depths of 500–800 m and longline fishing occurs at depths of 100–400 m (Cervantes et al. 2018). Further information on bycatch species in these fisheries is largely unknown.  

There are also an estimated 518 Chinese distant-water vessels registered in Africa; most (480) vessels fly flags from West Africa between Morocco and Gabon and most (426) are trawlers (Gutiérrez et al. 2020). Fishing effort is widespread, often takes place in deep offshore areas, and some “high intensity” areas have been identified off Guinea to Sierra Leone and off the Congo (Gutiérrez et al. 2020). Virtually nothing is known about these fishing activities. 

West Africa has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and IUU fishing by large industrial trawlers has contributed to depleted fish stocks across the region (Daniels et al. 2016). Of the stocks assessed in the Eastern Central Atlantic, most are either overexploited or are fully exploited and are fished at levels that are not sustainable in the short term (FAO 2020).
population:
In the Northeast Atlantic, the Velvet Belly Lanternshark appears to have distinct regional populations (McMillan et al. 2016). Species-specific population trend data are available from standardised catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) indices and relative abundance in the Northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea (Serena 2014, Moura et al. 2018, ICES-WGEF 2019, Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (23 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis of the standardised CPUE from commercial fisheries off Portugal (1997–2016), relative abundance estimates from the Spanish Porcupine Bank scientific survey time-series (2001–2018), and relative abundance estimates from the Mediterranean International Trawl Survey (MEDITS) in the Western Mediterranean Sea (Northern Alboran Sea, off the Balearic Islands and Northern Spain, 1994–2015), and Central Mediterranean Sea and Adriatic Sea (1994–2011) revealed an annual rate of decline of 3.3%, consistent with an estimated population reduction of 67% over three generation lengths (23 years).

The trend analysis of the standardised CPUE from commercial fisheries off Portugal (1997–2016) and relative abundance estimates from the Spanish Porcupine Bank scientific survey time-series (2001–2018) revealed an annual rate of decline of 2.2%, consistent with an estimated population reduction of 35% over three generation lengths (23 years), although the highest probability is a <20% population reduction over three generation lengths (Supplementary Information). The relative abundance estimates from the Mediterranean International Trawl Survey (MEDITS) in the Western Mediterranean Sea (Northern Alboran Sea, off the Balearic Islands and Northern Spain, 1994–2015), and Central Mediterranean Sea and Adriatic Sea (1994–2011) revealed an annual rate of decline of 3.3%, consistent with an estimated population reduction of 67% over three generation lengths (23 years). The global weighted trend estimated a 52% population reduction over three generation lengths (23 years). The data were estimated to represent 80% of the species' known spatial distribution.

Across West Africa, total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold between 1950–2010, while the CPUE of artisanal and industrial vessels declined by 34% over this period (Belhabib et al. 2018). Reconstructed catches of sharks, rays, and skates data are available across the Velvet Belly Lanternshark's range and while these levels of declines are not species-specific, they are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Using these reconstructed data, the regional West Africa elasmobranch CPUE is inferred to have decreased by 74%, from 0.27 t/kW to 0.07 t/kW from 1950 to 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020).

The Velvet Belly Lanternshark has declined across its range (based on estimated and inferred reductions summarised above). The species is thought to have some refuge from fishing pressure at depth in parts of its range and there is deep-water shark management across part of its range. A global population reduction of 30–49% was estimated over three generation lengths (23 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation and the Velvet Belly Lanternshark is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Velvet Belly Lanternshark is found in the Eastern Atlantic Ocean (from Iceland to Gabon) and in the Mediterranean Sea (excluding the north Adriatic and Black Seas) (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is not known to be utilized and is often discarded (Ragonese et al. 2013). Off Mauritania, a number of deep-water sharks, including Etmopterus spp., are used for their liver oil (M. Dia unpub. data 2020).
conservationActions:
Further information is required on population size and trends of the Velvet Belly Lanternshark, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range, particularly around Africa. There are some general management arrangements of relevance in place in the Northeast Atlantic. In 2010, the European Union Fisheries Council prohibited directed fishing for deep-water sharks, including the Velvet Belly Lanternshark, in European Community and international waters, and in 2012, no allowances for bycatch were implemented (ICES-WGEF 2019). Since 2017, a restrictive bycatch allowance has been trialled, permitting limited landings of unavoidable catches of deep-water sharks in directed artisanal demersal longline fisheries for Black Scabbardfish (Aphanopus spp). Additional management actions for this region include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); banned use of gillnets by European Union vessels at depths >600 m; maximum bycatch limits of deep-water shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and Monkfish (Lophius spp) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear), and a network of closed areas in Azorean waters; closure of the Condor seamount to deep-water fishing in 2010 (ICES-WGEF 2019).

In the Mediterranean, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) banned demersal trawling below depths of >1,000 m in the Mediterranean Sea in 2005, but this is unlikely to provide considerable refuge for the species.

rationale: The Fake Round Ray (Urotrygon simulatrix) is a small (to ~27 cm total length) ray with a poorly-defined range in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific where it has been recorded from Mexico, Costa Rica, Panama, and possibly Colombia (records from the latter require validation). It inhabits shallow coastal waters at depths of 2–18 m. This is a very rare and poorly-known species with some uncertainty regarding its population status. Information on catches in large-scale and small-scale fisheries are generally lacking, although shrimp trawl fisheries and a variety of other artisanal fisheries that are likely to catch it operate across its range. Round rays are generally discarded although they may be used as bait or fishmeal by artisanal fishers. Tropical Eastern Pacific round rays have life history parameters including very early age-at-maturity (1–4 years) that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality. The Fake Round Ray is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure throughout most of its range, with little refuge. Overall, due levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, its apparently restricted and patchy range, rarity, and lack of recent records in Panama, balanced with the high biological productivity of tropical Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that the Fake Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Fake Round Ray inhabits shallow coastal waters at depths of 2–18 m (Last et al. 2016, Fishnet 2 Portal 2020). It reaches a maximum size of ~27 cm total length (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Age data are not available for this species, but generation length is estimated to be 5 years based on Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) and the Spinytail Round Ray (Urotrygon aspidura) (Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019). These species are larger (46 and 42 cm TL, respectively) than the Fake Round Ray, and therefore this is likely to be an overestimate of generation length.
threats:
This species is likely to be taken as bycatch of large-scale and small-scale shrimp trawl fisheries across its range. 

In Panama, the entire known range of the Fake Round Ray overlaps with both large-scale (industrial) and small-scale (artisanal) fisheries. Coastal industrial shrimp trawling commenced in the 1950s with eight small fishing boats (D’Croz et al. 1979) and currently there are around 190 licensed vessels in the industrial fleet off Panama, using beam trawls targeting shrimp (FAO 2018). Due to high fishing pressure on the zone, the shrimp landings have decreased in recent decades (CGR 2019). Within the Gulf of Panama there are fisheries for small pelagic fishes (anchovies, herrings etc.) that operate on soft-benthic coastal habitats and which catch several species of ray as bycatch, including Rogers’ Round Ray (Urotrygon rogersi) (CeDePesca 2016). This indicates that the Fake Round Ray would also be susceptible to capture in these fisheries. A variety of small-scale fisheries also operate within the Gulf of Panama with little management (~1,500 registered artisanal vessels in the Province of Panama alone; ARAP 2015). There are no recent records of the species in Panama, and given its shallow depth range, it likely has little refuge from fishing.

Overall, there is high spatial overlap with fisheries (which generally lack management or effective enforcement of regulations across most of its range), and given the geographic and depth range of the species, it has no refuge from fishing activities that operate across its range.
population:
There are no data available on population trend of the Fake Round Ray. It is a rare species, with very few records. During 2019, a concerted effort was made to search for new records of this species in Panama through engagement with fishers, fisheries observers, and seafood markets, however no records or information on its contemporary occurrence could be ascertained (J.M. Morales-Saldaña unpubl. data). 

In the Tehuantepec Gulf, Mexico, demographic models suggest population declines of the related Chilean Round Ray (Urotyrgon chilensis) under some scenarios, but not under other scenarios; overall the model results were not conclusive to ascertain population trend (Guzmán-Castellanos 2015).

Biological data from tropical Eastern Pacific round rays show life history parameters, including very early ages-at-maturity (1–4 years; Mejía-Falla et al. 2014, Guzmán-Castellanos 2015, Torres-Palacios et al. 2019), that demonstrate high biological productivity and therefore resilience to fishing mortality.

Overall, due to levels of exploitation from its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, its apparently restricted and patchy range, rarity, and lack of recent records in Panama, balanced with the high biological productivity of Eastern Pacific round rays, it is suspected that the Fake Round Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generations (15 years).
range: The Fake Round Ray was originally recorded from the Gulf of Panama (Panama) (Miyake and McEachran 1988, McEachran 1995) and this range is shown by Last et al. (2016). In addition to Panama, museum records include specimens from Mexico, Costa Rica, and Colombia (Fishnet 2 Portal 2020, iDigBio 2020). However, Mejía-Falla and Navia (2019) suggest that records of this species for Colombia could be misidentifications and these records need to be reviewed. The species' full distribution is poorly-defined and it may be more wide-ranging than presently known (i.e., possibly from Mexico to Colombia).
useTrade: Round rays are of little commercial value due to their small size. They are often discarded when caught, although there may be some retention in small-scale (artisanal) fisheries for meat, fish meal, or bait.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Fake Round Ray. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki pers. comm. 2019). <span class="msoins0">A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Although some marine protected areas exist in the Gulf of Panama (e.g. The Special Management Zone of the Archipiélago de Las Perlas), surveillance and enforcement are a challenge. Further research is needed to define its contemporary occurrence, life history, the level of mortality due to fisheries, and population size and trend. Both small- and large-scale fisheries should be monitored for bycatch at the species level.

rationale:
The Ocellate Torpedo (Torpedo torpedo) is a small (to 60 cm total length) torpedo ray that occurs in the Eastern and Central Atlantic Oceans, and the Mediterranean Sea (absent from the Black Sea). It is demersal on the continental shelf and slope from nearshore to a depth of 320 m.

This species is taken as incidental catch in bottom trawl, longline, set net, and trammel net fisheries across its range. Torpedo rays (Torpedo spp.) have low economic value and while retained in some countries (e.g., Senegal), they are discarded in others (e.g., across the Mediterranean Sea and Gabon). If released alive, post-release survival is likely to be high.

There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species. In the Mediterranean Sea, trend analyses of standardized catch-per-unit effort estimates from trawl surveys in the upper Tyrrhenian Sea reveal an increasing population over the past three generation lengths (30 years). However, in other locations such as the Adriatic Sea, records of this species have become rare over the last two decades. In the Eastern Central Atlantic region, which comprises most of the species' range, there are a number of distant water vessels using demersal trawl and longline to target demersal fish and shrimp species within the depth limit of this species. In Mauritania, catch data from research surveys indicate a decline equivalent to a 73% population reduction over the past three generation lengths (30 years). Across the rest of this region, there are few recent records from most countries, likely reflecting a high level of discards in both industrial and artisanal fisheries. However, populations may also have already been reduced prior to recent studies in the area. The Ocellate Torpedo is estimated to be stable and increasing in some areas of the Mediterranean Sea. It is suspected to be declining across West Africa where historic and current fishing pressure is high, although it might have some refuge from artisanal fisheries with depth across some of its range. It is suspected that the Ocellate Torpedo has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (30 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Ocellate Torpedo is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates on the continental shelf and slope from nearshore to a depth of 320 m (Gulyugin et al. 2006). It reaches a maximum size of 60 cm total length (TL), males mature at 18 cm TL and females mature at 22 cm TL(Abdel-Aziz 1994). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous, like other torpedo rays, with litter sizes of 3–21 pups and size-at-birth of 8–10 cm TL (Serena 2005). There is no information on this species' maximum age and age-at-maturity, hence, generation length was inferred based on data for the Marbled Torpedo (Torpedo marmorata). The Marbled Torpedo has an age-at-maturity of 12 years and a maximum age of 20 years and, thus, a generation length of 16 years (Mellinger 1971). The Ocellate Torpedo has a smaller maximum size than the Marbled Torpedo (60 cm vs 100 cm TL), and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length was inferred to be 10 years for the Ocellate Torpedo.
threats:
The Ocellate Torpedo is taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is discarded or retained for human consumption. Information on post-release survival is limited, but it is suspected to be high (Tsagarakis et al. 2018).

In the Mediterranean Sea, the Ocellate Torpedo is sometimes landed in fisheries as bycatch. This water body has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide bathymetric range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Following two centuries of fisheries development, shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008).

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020).

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutiérrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats, which are part of this species range, are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., for rice and salt production) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture, and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural run-off, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). For example, in West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years with the highest loses recorded from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance in the Mediterranean Sea (Ferretti et al. 2005). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (30 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE ) estimates from trawl surveys (1985–2004) in the upper Tyrrhenian Sea (central region of the Mediterranean Sea) revealed an annual rate of increase of 5%, consistent with an estimated increasing population over the past three generation lengths (30 years).

There are a number of other relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Mediterranean Sea, Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, surveys indicate that the Ocellate Torpedo is generally uncommon and less abundant than the Marbled Torpedo (Torpedo marmorata). It was recorded in 28 of 6,336 hauls conducted during the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) programme in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, from 1994–1999 at depths of 10-800 m (Baino et al. 2001). In similar MEDITS surveys in the western Mediterranean (Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands) from 1994–2017, 11 specimens were recorded in the Northern Alboran Sea (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). MEDITS catch data was also compared from the Adriatic Sea in 1998 with that the Hvar survey in 1948 and indicated that although this species was rarely recorded in the past, it was not recorded in the 1998 trawl surveys (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). Further investigation of these datasets and additional trawl surveys in the Adriatic Sea (to 2005) indicates that only two individuals were captured in this region in 1996 and 2003 (Ferretti et al. 2013). There are no other data to indicate population size, although the lack of recent records could be an indication of decline.
 
Second, both catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana, and consequently population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but this does indicate rising fishing pressure. There are no other estimates of population reduction available from this region. The greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t), and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch CPUE has decreased by 71% over 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch catch has increased by more than 2.5 times (250%) from 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch catch in the region was 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch catch volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, catches have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001–2016. Catches gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981 (80% decline), then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch catch then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be used to infer reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase in landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 44% reduction in elasmobranch CPUE from 0.107 t/kW in 1981–1983 to 0.060 t/kW in 2013–2015.

Third, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that while there are limited records of this species in the past decade from across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, it appears to be more common than other torpedo rays occurring in the region (e.g., Rosette Torpedo (Torpedo bauchotae)). The pattern of retention and discarding of torpedo rays varies between countries across this region and therefore species occurrence or absence in landings need to be carefully considered at the national scale. In a study investigating discards in Mauritanian shrimp fisheries between 2004–2006, this species was present in 24.8% of the total catches and contributed 0.5% in weight (Goudswaard and Meissa 2006). Twenty-seven individuals were also recorded during research trawl surveys carried out between 2007–2010 in Mauritanian waters, representing 0.12% of the total number of fishing hauls in which the species occurred (Pascual-Alayon et al. 2017). This was species has not been reported in regular monitoring of fisheries landings between 2006–2018 undertaken by the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches in the Parc National du Banc d'Arguin which could, however, indicate that it is discarded by fishers (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). However, in research trawl fishing surveys, CPUE peaked at 24.6 kg/tow in 1988 and declined to 7.2 kg/tow in 2018 (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). This decrease is the equivalent of 73% population reduction over the last three generation lengths of the Ocellate Torpedo (30 years).

During extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004–2011, this species was recorded across all countries except Cape Verde (where it does not occur) and Sierra Leone (Diop and Dossa 2011). However, historical data from Sierra Leone indicates that this species was considered common and abundant (Litvinov 1993) and a lack of records in landings could indicate that they are discarded there. In Senegal, it was also recorded in the fisheries monitoring program by the Centre de Recherche Océographique Dakar-Thiaroye (CRODT) between 1985–1988 (Mar 2008). Cruise reports from trawl surveys in Togo indicate that 42 individuals were caught in 1984 (Lhomme 1984). It was also recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985–2012 (Camara et al. 2016). On the other hand, it has not been detected in recent surveys in of the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau; in Côte d'Ivoire during landing site surveys in 2019; in Nigerian research surveys (although likely to be retained here despite its low economic value); in Cameroon in over two years of landing site surveys (although often discarded here); in the Republic of the Congo from surveys between January and December 2019 (although if caught it would likely be directly processed for fish meal especially in industrial fisheries); and from Angola during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 although fishers were able to identify torpedo rays during interviews (P. Doherty, G.H.L. Leurs, K. Metcalfe, A.L. Soares, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). Landing sites surveys in Western Ghana in 2019 and 2020 indicate that this species represents 7% of ray landings (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). All torpedo rays there are landed for local consumption or for utilization as chicken feed. In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species is still captured but discarded alive and it is also recorded in artisanal fisheries landings operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets and is also usually discarded (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). This species was listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" surveys and represented up to 10.9% of catches and up to 30 individuals in one trawl haul in surveys between Guinea and Morocco in 2011 (Krakstad et al. 2011), up to 7.2% of catches and up to 65 individuals per trawl haul, and up to 2.1% of catches and up to eight individuals per trawl haul in Gabon and Congo, in 2008 and 2010 respectively (Krakstad et al. 2008, Mehl et al. 2010).  However, it was not listed in more recent cruise reports in Angola and northern Namibia in 2012 (Krakstad et al. 2012) and in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana in 2017 (Staby et al. 2017).

The Ocellate Torpedo is estimated to be stable and increasing in some areas of the Mediterranean Sea although in other regions of this basin, there has been a long history of fisheries overexploitation across its range which is ongoing. It is suspected to be declining across West Africa where historic and current fishing pressure is high although it might have some refuge from artisanal fisheries with depth across some of its range. Overall, it is suspected that the Ocellate Torpedo has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (30 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation.
range: The Ocellate Torpedo is found in the Eastern Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea (although absent from the Black Sea) and occurs from the southern Bay of Biscay to Angola (Last et al. 2016). It has not been recorded from the Cape Verde Archipelago but is found around São Tomé and Príncipe (Afonso et al. 1999, Wirtz et al. 2013).
useTrade: Torpedo rays (Torpedo spp.) have low economic value and have generally been discarded in the Mediterranean Sea and West Africa or used for human consumption (fresh or dried and smoked) and animal feed (e.g., Diop and Dossa 2011, Tiralongo et al. 2018; E. Chartrain, I. Seidu and A. B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). The Ocellate Torpedo may be used for fish oil production in the future (Ayas et al. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Although countries across the range of the Ocellate Torpedo have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking this species are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of its range, and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future.
