In West Africa, a number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing one (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Whilst Gabon have recently expanded marine protected area coverage to 26% of their Exclusive Economic Zone, other countries such as the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are still in the process of expanding their marine protected area networks, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020).

Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog (Squalus hemipinnis) is a small (to 78 cm total length) deep-water dogfish recorded off Indonesia (Java, Bali, Lombok, and possibly Sumatra) and the Andaman Islands in the Eastern Indian Ocean. It has been reported from continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 40–500 m. The species is caught as target and incidental catch in demersal longline and gill net fisheries operating across Indonesia, and is regularly caught and discarded live in demersal longline fisheries targeting gulper sharks (Centrophorus spp). There is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, reported declines in part of its range, and a lack of species-specific management across its entire range. The Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog is estimated to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (72 years) based actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog is demersal on continental and insular shelves and slopes at depths of 40–500 m (Dharmadi and Fahmi 2007, K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a maximum size of at least 78 cm total length (TL) (White et al. 2006). Females mature at ~60 cm TL and size-at-birth is 14–17.5 cm TL (White et al. 2007, White and Dharmadi 2010). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous. Generation length for this species is estimated at 24 years, based on life history parameters of the Shortnose Spurdog (Squalus megalops) (Braccini 2006).
threats:
Squaloid sharks (Squalus spp) are some of the most commonly reported deep-water sharks in Indonesian fisheries. They are caught as target and incidental catch with a number of fishing gears including deep-water demersal longline and gill net fisheries (White et al. 2006, Dharmadi and Fahmi 2007, Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). The Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog accounts for 13% of squaloid sharks landed at Tanjung Luar-West Nusa Tenggara (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2019). Indonesian deep-water fisheries operate throughout most of the depth range at which this species occurs (White et al. 2006). Species-specific catch data in Indonesian fisheries are unavailable as all squaloid sharks are currently recorded together (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). 

In the Andaman Islands, the Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog is one of the most commonly caught species in demersal longline fisheries targeting gulper sharks (Centrophorus spp) (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019). The species is not retained and is often discarded live, however, post-release mortality is unknown (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019).
population:
Catch landings of Squalus spp at Tanjung Luar-West Nusa Tenggara have indicated that catch rates are exceeding the maximum exploitation level, suggesting the regional population is being over-fished (Fahmi and Sentosa 2017). Total catches of "dogfish" (representing at least ten species, including several Squalus spp) reported to the National Shark Data Collection program under the Directorate General of Capture Fisheries (DGCF) declined from 16,536 t in 2005 to 4,820 t in 2016 (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2019). Such a decline would amount to a population reduction of >99% over three generations (72 years). There is no information available from the Andaman Islands, but the species is thought to be relatively common (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019).

Based on high levels of exploitation, it is estimated that the Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog has been subject to population decline in part of its range (Indonesia) over the past three generations (72 years). A global population reduction of 30–49% was estimated over three generation lengths (72 years). Therefore, the Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog has been recorded off Indonesia (Java, Bali, Lombok, and possibly Sumatra) and the Andaman Islands (White et al. 2007, K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019) in the Eastern Indian Ocean.
useTrade: In Indonesia, the species is utilised for its flesh, fins, and high value liver oil (White et al. 2006). It is discarded in the Andaman Islands (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place for the Indonesian Shortsnout Spurdog. Further information is required on its distribution, ecology and life history, as well species’ interactions with fisheries.

rationale: The Common Stingray (Dasyatis pastinaca) is a medium-sized (to 140 cm disc width) ray that occurs in the east Atlantic and the Mediterranean and Black Sea ranging from the North Sea to Angola. It is demersal on the continental shelf from the surface to a depth of 200 m, but is more commonly found in shallow waters less than 50 m. This species is taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries across its range with multiple demersal fishing gears, including trawl, line gear, gillnet, and set net. The meat is generally consumed locally and in the Eastern Central Atlantic it is traded regionally salted-dried or dried and smoked. There is a high-level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across most of the range of this species. In the Mediterranean and Black Sea, data from comparative trawl surveys (1948 and 1998) conducted in the Adriatic Sea suggest that this species may have decreased in abundance during this period. However, standardized catch-per-unit effort estimates from demersal trawl surveys in Sardinia show no major reductions in population over the past three generation lengths (23 years). In the Northeast Atlantic, it is a less common species, generally showing a low abundance index in comparison to the Mediterranean Sea but may have disappeared from areas where it was previously recorded (e.g., the south of the Bay of Biscay). In the Eastern Central Atlantic region, there are few recent records from most countries, however, it is suspected to be declining due to the high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure which are a cause for concern. Overall, considering the scale and intensity of unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its preference for shallow waters, its susceptibility to fisheries pressure, and noted declines in rays in general across its range, it is suspected that the Common Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (23 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Common Stingray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates on the continental shelf at depths of 0–200 m, but is more commonly found in shallow waters less than 50 m (Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 140 cm disc width (DW), males mature at 26–31 cm DW and females mature at 28–41 cm DW (Ismen 2003, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of 3–9 pups, a gestation length of 4 months, and size-at-birth of ~ 8–12 cm DW (Ismen 2003, Ebert and Stehmann 2013, Last et al. 2016). The Common Stingray has an age-at-maturity of 7 years and a maximum age of 16 years; resulting in a generation length of 7.5 years (Yigin and Ismen 2012).
threats:
The Common Stingray is taken as bycatch in artisanal and industrial fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption. 

In the Mediterranean Sea, the Common Stingray is landed in artisanal and industrial fisheries as bycatch and is sometimes targeted in semi-industrial, small-scale and commercial bottom trawl, gillnet, beach seine, bottom longline and trammel net fisheries. This water body has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide bathymetric range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Following two centuries of fisheries development, shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008).

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat for export to Ghana and fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and likely resulted in increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (e.g., False Shark Ray (Rhynchorhina mauritaniensis) from the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin and the African Wedgefish (Rhynchobatus luebberti) from the Sine-Saloum Delta) (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977 to 2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 - these were mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region and which covers most the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world, and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed the reported legal catch by more than 40% (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats preferred by rays are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016). In West Africa, mangroves are harvested for fuel wood, construction timber, and charcoal with an overall mangrove forest area decline of up to 70% in some countries over the last 20 years. The highest loses recorded from are from Côte d'Ivoire (67%), Liberia (65%), Guinea (60%), Sierra Leone (40%), and Ghana (30%) (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016, CCLME 2016).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance in the Mediterranean Sea (Serena 2014). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (23 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List Category based on percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) estimates from demersal trawl surveys (1994–2010; 16 years) in Sardinia revealed an annual rate of decrease of 0.9%, although in recent years the trend was increasing and when measured over the longer three generation period (23 years), there was an estimated increase of 0.5% over three generation lengths with the highest probability of no major reductions in population over three generation lengths.

There are a number of relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Mediterranean Sea, Eastern Central Atlantic, and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, the Common Stingray was recorded in 49 of 6,336 hauls (0.5% of total hauls) conducted during the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) program in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, from 1994 to 1999 at depths of 50–800 m (Baino et al. 2001). In similar MEDITS surveys in the western Mediterranean (Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands) from 1994 to 2017, 365 individuals were recorded in the Balearic Islands and five individuals were reported from Northern Spain (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). MEDITS catch data using the same survey methods were also compared from the Adriatic Sea in 1998 with the Hvar survey in 1948 and indicated the abundance of this species may have decreased during this period (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). The frequency of occurrence (frequency log transformed data) of the Common Stingray on the shelf according to the 1948 survey was ~ 0.5, whereas frequency of occurrence on the shelf in the 1998 survey was <0.1, indicating a 36% population reduction over the past three generation lengths (23 years) (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). This species was not recorded in experimental fishing trials in 1999–2000 using trammel nets and conducted within several parts of this species' known distribution and depth ranges in the Mediterranean and northeast Atlantic (Stergiou et al. 2006). In Lebanon and Syria, this species is reported as one of the most common rays (Bariche 2012). In Tunisia, it is also considered relatively abundant and 17 individuals were captured during fisheries surveys between 2006–2007 in the Lagoon of Bizerte (Bradai et al. 2004, El Kamel et al. 2009). Off the coast of Turkey, between 2009–2010, 391 individuals were captured in 116 hauls by commercial demersal trawl in the Gulf of Antalya, representing a 56% frequency of occurrence; and 72 individuals were captured between 2014–2015 in commercial trawl operations in Iskenderun Bay (Özgür Özbek et al. 2015, Yeldan and Gundogdu 2018). However, CPUE comparisons with a previous survey in the Gulf of Antalya suggest declines in abundance over 17 years (Özgür Özbek et al. 2015). An experimental trawl fishery in the Aegean Sea (Izmir Bay, Turkey) revealed that this species was a relatively prevalent non-commercial species, representing up to 1.89% of the total catch by weight during the winter months, 1.78% in the spring, 1.18% in the autumn but was not recorded in the summer (Gurbet et al. 2013). In Russian waters of the Black Sea, pressure from fisheries has declined in recent years due to the lack of demand at fish markets (A. Orlov pers. comm. 11 December 2020). Annual average catches between 1976–1980 were 367 t which decreased to 10–15 t between 2001–2003 due to reduced fishing pressure and the Common Stingray is reportedly still abundant in the Azov Sea (Vasil'eva and Luzhnyak 2013). The species is also considered common in the Azores based on data from experimental fishing surveys and underwater visual surveys (Das and Afonso 2017). Furthermore, it is reported in the most abundant group of sharks and rays sampled during landing site surveys carried out between May 2018 and August 2018 in Tangier, Morocco and caught in longlines and trawl nets (Darasi and Aksissou 2019). Overall, in the Mediterranean Sea, the Common Stingray appears to have declined in certain regions but is still relatively abundant in others, especially along the North African coast and southern central region.

Second, in the Northeast Atlantic, this species is less abundant than in the Mediterranean Sea and it has reportedly disappeared from the south of the Bay of Biscay, as observed for other demersal elasmobranch species (Quero 1998). However, the species has appeared in very low quantities in French landings from this area and Iberian waters between 1999 and 2012, ranging from 0 to 3 t per year. The average catch rate (number per hour) during the first quarter of the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the North Sea, Skagerrak and Kattegat (1977–2004) was 0.0006 (ICES 2005). In United Kingdom groundfish surveys, it was only recorded occasionally in the western English Channel at depths of 17–160 m (Ellis et al. 2005). 

Third, in the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, both overall catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark and ray fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana. Population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but do indicate rising fishing pressure. Since the 1970s, the greatest African fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries were located in Nigeria, Senegal, and Ghana (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Across West Africa, the average elasmobranch catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) decreased by 71% between 1970–2015 from 0.68 t/kW (ton per kilowatts) to 0.20 t/kW (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch landings increased by more than 2.5 times from 1970 to 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020), implying an increase in fishing effort. Within countries, landings have begun to decline in recent years. For example, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates increased from 1950 to 1972 then declined by 80% from 1972 to 1981. Landings increased again until 2001 followed by a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline from 2001–2016. These declines in landings can be inferred to represent population reductions as the fishing effort has remained stable during the decline (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch catch then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be used to infer reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase in landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 44% reduction in elasmobranch CPUE from 0.107 t/kW in 1981–1983 to 0.060 t/kW in 2013–2015.

Fourth, contemporary patterns of landings indicate that the Common Stingray is still landed across most of its Eastern Central Atlantic region range but in relatively low numbers. During extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region between 2004–2011, this species was considered uncommon but recorded in Cape Verde, Guinea, and Sierra Leone and was absent from Mauritania, Senegal, The Gambia and Guinea-Bissau (Diop and Dossa 2011). This species has been reported in regular monitoring of fisheries landings between 2006–2018 undertaken by the Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches in the Parc National du Banc d'Arguin but has become increasingly rare (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). This species was listed in cruise reports from the "Dr. Fridtjof Nansen" surveys and two individuals in one trawl haul in surveys in Cape Verde in 2011 (Krakstad et al. 2011). In the Gambia, only three individuals were recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010 and 2018 although other species of rays with similar catchability were reported in large quantities (Moore et al. 2019). It was also recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985–2012 (Camara et al. 2016). In Cameroon, two individuals have been recorded over two years of landing site surveys representing 0.13% of all shark and ray records (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species along with other dasyatids (Brown Stingray (Bathytoshia lata), Marbled Stingray (Dasyatis marmorata), Pearl Whipray (Fontitrygon margaritella), Daisy Whipray (Fontitrygon margarita), and Round Stingray (Taeniurops grabatus)) were considered common and represented 18.5% of rays captured in 2018 (99.9% mortality rate) and 26.5% in 2019 (100% mortality rate) (E. Chartrain, G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). Overall, dasyatids in trawl fisheries represented 4.6% of trawl production in 2018 and 3.6% in 2019. This species was infrequently recorded throughout the year from the artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba using demersal-set gillnets (E. Chartrain, G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). In Angola, five individuals were recorded during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). On the other hand, it has not been detected in recent fisheries monitoring surveys in the Bijagos Archipelago in Guinea-Bissau (2019); in Côte d'Ivoire in 2019; in Nigerian research surveys from 2002–2016 (although listed on the national species checklist); in Western Ghana in 2019–2020; and in the Republic of the Congo from surveys between January and December 2019 (P. Doherty, G.H.L. Leurs, K. Metcalfe, I. Seidu, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In summary, the Common Stingray is estimated to be stable and increasing in some areas of the Mediterranean Sea, although in other regions of this basin there has been a long history of fisheries overexploitation across its range which is ongoing. It is suspected to be declining across West Africa where historic and current fishing pressure is high although it might have some refuge from artisanal fisheries with depth across some of its range. Overall, it is suspected that the Common Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (23 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation.
range: The Common Stingray is found in the east Atlantic and the Mediterranean and Black Sea (Last et al. 2016, Ebert and Dando 2021). It occurs from the North Sea, across the Canary Islands, Madeira Islands, and the Azores, to Angola (Ebert and Stehmann 2013, Last et al. 2016; A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: The Common Stingray is utilized for its meat. While little-species specific information is available, the meat of rays is consumed fresh across many coastal communities in the region as an important source of protein (Walker et al. 2005). It is also dried or dried and smoked and exported across West Africa to supply countries such as Ghana, Guinea, Nigeria, Mali, and Burkina Faso. It may also be used as fish meal.
conservationActions:
Across its Mediterranean Sea range, the Common Stingray is protected within five of the six existing Balearic Island marine reserves. Although artisanal fishing is allowed within these marine protected areas (MPAs), this species must be released alive if caught. 

The first European Union (EU) total allowable catch (TAC) for skates and rays (all species falling within the order Rajiformes) was established for the North and Norwegian Sea for 1999 at 6,060 t, cut to 4,848 t for 2001–2002, and since reduced annually in most years by 8–25% to 1,256 t in 2014 - bycatch quota for up to 25% of live weight per trip for vessels over 15 m fishing in International Council for the Exploration of the Sea [ICES] subareas IIa and IV in 2014. For much of this period (1999–2014), the TAC was higher than reported landings. Skate and ray TACs were established for other EU waters (ICES Divisions IIIa, VI-IX) in 2009 and have also been gradually reduced since. Separate TACs are now in place for ICES subareas III (Skagerrak, entrance to the Baltic Sea), Via and b, VII a-c, VII c-k (West of Scotland, Irish and Celtic Seas), VIId (Eastern English Channel), and VIII and IX (Bay of Biscay and Iberian waters).

There are no known conservation measures in place for this species across the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic region. Although countries across the region have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters). Fisheries taking the Common Stingray are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future.

In West Africa, a number of countries - Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde - have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks or are currently working on developing one (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

The Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries - Mauritania to Sierra Leone - to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure, and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but both are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Whilst Gabon has recently expanded MPA coverage to 26% of their Exclusive Economic Zone, other countries such as the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are still in the process of expanding their marine protected area networks. However, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Speckled Guitarfish (Pseudobatos glaucostigmus) is a small (to 91 cm total length) shark-like ray that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from Magdalena Bay, Mexico to Ecuador, including the Gulf of California. It inhabits soft substrates over the continental shelf to a depth of 110 m. This guitarfish is captured in commercial demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries and by artisanal gillnets and longlines. Artisanal fisheries operate without management throughout most of its range (or with inadequate enforcement of regulations), and shrimp trawling occurs in the Gulf of California, off Mazatlan, Costa Rica, Colombia, and Ecuador. In the Gulf of California artisanal gillnet fishery, annual landings of the Speckled Guitarfish have been steadily increasing from approximately 200 t in 1997 to 700 t in 2014. In Costa Rica, it was historically recorded in the Gulf of Nicoya which is fished intensely by industrial and artisanal fisheries, but recent records are sparse. There is very little refuge from fishing for this species. Overall, given the intensity of fishing pressure throughout its range, it is suspected that the Speckled Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (15 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Speckled Guitarfish is a benthic shark-like ray that inhabits soft substrates over the continental shelf to a depth of 110 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 91 cm total length (TL) (Rodrigues-Romero et al. 2008); females mature at 71–75 cm TL and males at 57–60 cm TL. Reproduction is viviparous and females give birth to 3–9 pups (Pérez Jiménez 2001). Generation length is suspected to be about 5 years, based on data available for the larger congeneric Shovelnose Guitarfish (Pseudobatos productus), which has an age-at-maturity of 7 years, a longevity of 11 years, and a generation length of 9 years (Timmons and Bray 1997).
threats: The Speckled Guitarfish is captured in commercial demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries and in artisanal gillnets and longlines. Artisanal fisheries are intense and unmanaged throughout its range, and there are trawl fisheries in many areas. It is caught in the Gulf of California artisanal gillnet fisheries especially during spring and summer months in association with reproductive aggregations in shallow nearshore and insular waters (Bizzarro et al. 2007). These fisheries have driven declines in turtles, marine mammals, and pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004). In San Felipe, Mexico, guitarfish species made up over 22% of elasmobranch bycatch in a study on the industrial teleost trawl fishery (Godinez-Padilla and Castillo-Geniz 2016). It makes up a small percentage of the bycatch in industrial shrimp trawls in Guatemala (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010). Shrimp trawl fisheries operate in Costa Rica, Colombia, and Ecuador, but there are no data regarding catches of this species. Artisanal fisheries operate without management throughout the southern portion of its range. This species does not have any refuge at depth.
population: In the Gulf of California artisanal fishery, annual landings of the Speckled Guitarfish have been steadily increasing from approximately 200 t in 1997 to 700 t in 2014 (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016), and there is no management in place. Declines in other species including turtles, marine mammals, and pelagic sharks and rays have been recorded in the southern Gulf of California multi-species artisanal gillnet fishery (Sala et al. 2004), and declines in guitarfishes are also likely. In Costa Rica, it was historically recorded in the Gulf of Nicoya which is heavily fished by industrial and artisanal trawl fisheries, but recent records are sparse. In Panama, Del Cid (2011) recorded only two individuals during nearly two years of monitoring the catch of artisanal fisheries in the Gulf of Chiriquí. There is also a lack of confirmed recent records in Colombia. It is unclear if this contemporary rarity reflects a reduced population or if the species has always been rarer in the southern part of its range. The species' range throughout Panama, Colombia, and Ecuador is however, subjected to high fishing pressure. Overall, given the intensity of unmanaged fishing pressure throughout its range and the increase in landings in the Gulf of California, it is suspected that the Speckled Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (15 years).
range: The Speckled Guitarfish occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from Magdalena Bay, Mexico to Ecuador, including the Gulf of California (Godinez-Padilla and Castillo-Geniz 2016, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This guitarfish is retained in multi-species fisheries and the meat is dried and sold locally.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in   place for this guitarfish. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted   elasmobranch fishing   from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is   inadequate (O.   Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. Management measures are needed in order to ensure that this ray does not become threatened in the near future. Further research is   needed on life   history and population size and trends, and species-specific monitoring of   catch is  needed in industrial trawl and    artisanal gillnet and longline  fisheries.

rationale: The Smooth Skate (Malacoraja senta) is a small (to 71 cm total length) skate that is endemic to the Northwest Atlantic waters of the USA and Canada ranging from New Jersey, USA to northern Labrador, Canada, including the Grand Banks, Southeast Shoal, and Flemish Cap. It is demersal on the continental shelves and slopes from 25 to 1,435 m, but is most common from 70 to 480 m deep. It is captured in mainly in demersal trawl, longline, gillnet, and dredge fisheries. Historically, this species underwent very steep declines coinciding with high levels of demersal fishing from international fleets targeting shelf and slope groundfish. The extension of Exclusive Economic Zones out to 200 nautical miles in 1977 restricted fishing access to the USA and Canadian vessels. Effort was renewed on skates with the encouragement of directed skate fisheries as other groundfish fisheries collapsed in the USA and Canadian waters in the late 1980s and 1990s, and as international demand for skate wings increased. Population trends vary with latitude with very steep reductions in the northern (Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf, 2J3K) and central (Scotian Shelf and Bay of Fundy, Canada, 4VWX) parts of its range. There have been increases in the easternmost part of the range (Grand Banks, 3LNOPs) and signs of recovery in the southern part of is range in the USA. The overall index suggests a steep decline in abundance from the mid-1960s until the mid-1990s, followed by increasing abundance to the present day. The overall annual rate of decrease of 1.08% is consistent with an estimated median decline of 36.1% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (62%) of >30% reduction over three generation lengths. Predation from recovering populations of Grey Seal (Halichoerus grypus) is estimated to have caused high levels of adult mortality in the Gulf of St Lawrence and which may be inhibiting recovery there. Overall, while the population trend is currently increasing, there have been substantial declines in the past and only limited recovery in some areas of its range. Mortality is ongoing from both bycatch and predation from Grey Seals in the Gulf of St Lawrence, and overall, this skate is estimated to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations. Therefore, the Smooth Skate is assessed as Vulnerable (A2bd).
habitat: The Smooth Skate is demersal on continental shelves and slopes at depths of  25–1,435 m and is most common at 70–480 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 71 cm total length (TL); females mature at 47–57 cm TL and males at 41–54 cm TL (Kulka et al. 2006, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous and size-at-hatch is 8–10 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). There are considerable differences in life history between the warmer southern part of this species' distribution and the more northern part of the distribution. In the USA Gulf of Maine female age-at-maturity is 9.5 years and maximum observed age is 14 years (Sulikowski et al. 2009). Female age-at-maturity is 10.7–14.7 years on the Scotian Shelf, Canada (McPhie and Campana 2009). A conservative generation length of 16 years was chosen based on GL = age at 50% maturity + 1/M, where M was assumed to be 0.2 (Simon et al. 2012).
threats:
The Smooth Skate is captured in demersal trawl, longline, pot, seine, gillnet, and dredge fisheries.

In the USA, landings of the Northeast skate complex (comprising 7 species) have been reported since the late 1800s. However, commercial fishery landings never exceeded several hundred metric tons until the advent of distant-water fleets during the 1960s (Packer et al. 2003). Skate landings (of all species combined) reached 9,500 mt in 1969, but declined quickly during the 1970s, falling to 800 mt in 1981 (Packer et al. 2003). While most skates were discarded between 1983–2002, in the USA, but the increasing value of skate wings and demand for lobster bait in recent years has resulted in increased retention and landings, with discard rates declining from 90% to 40% over time and landings have increasing from 883 to 16,283 t per year (Curtis and Sosebee 2015). Overall fishing effort in the region’s trawl and gillnet fisheries declined during the 2000s due to changing groundfish regulations (Curtis and Sosebee 2015). Smooth Skates are too small to be marketable in the USA skate wing fishery (NEFMC 2003). Possession and landing have been prohibited in the bulk of the species' USA range since 2003 due to their low levels of relative abundance (NEFMC 2003). Any live discards have moderate post-release survival; from the USA New England otter trawl fishery the 72-hour post-release mortality is 60% (Mandelman et al. 2013). Smooth Skate was overfished up to the 2000, but soon after was classified as no longer overfished (Packer et al. 2003). This stock is currently classified as not overfished, it is rebuilt, and overfishing is not occurring (Sosebee 2018).

Historically in the northwest Atlantic, skates were taken as incidental catch of groundfish fisheries with high fishing effort, particularly distant water fleets on Georges Bank and Scotian Shelf, Grand Banks and Labrador Shelf in the 1960s and 1970s. The extension of the USA and Canadian 200-mile exclusive economic zones in 1977 excluded vessels from other countries. The steep decline in the Smooth Skate was coincident with the sharp increase in landings in the 1970s and 1980s (COSEWIC 2012). A targeted skate fishery (primarily for Thorny Skate, Amblyraja radiata) was initiated in 1994 on the Grand Banks and Scotian Shelf, following the closure of groundfish fisheries (as a result of the collapse of Atlantic Cod, Gadus morhua) combined with the rising international demand for skate wings (Kulka and Mowbray 1999). Target fisheries for Smooth Skate are not currently allowed, but it continues to be taken as discarded bycatch of trawl fisheries for Atlantic Cod, Redfish (Sebastes spp.), and Greenland Halibut (Reinhardtius hippoglossoides) (COSEWIC 2012).

Groundfishes, including skates, have been heavily fished historically in the southern Gulf of St Lawrence. The low abundance of prey species has meant that Grey Seal (Halichoerus grypus) predation poses a significant source of mortality on adult classes of skate, including Smooth Skate (Benoît and Swain 2011).
population:
There are no data available on the absolute global population size of Smooth Skate. Population trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

Population trend data are available from seven sources: (1) catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) data from the USA NEFSC Fall survey (1963–2018), (2) Georges Banks, Canada/Gulf of Maine, USA (5Z) relative abundance index (mature individuals) for 1986–2017, (3) Scotian Shelf and Bay of Fundy (4VWX) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1970–2017, (4) Southern Gulf of St. Lawrence (4T) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1971–2018, (5) Northern Gulf of St. Lawrence (4RS) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1991–2018, (6) Grand Banks (3LNOPs) spring survey CPUE for 1973–2017, and (7) Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3K) Fall CPUE (1977–2017).

The population trend data for surveys 1 through to 6 above correspond to the most southerly subpopulations specified as the Laurentian-Scotian Designatable Unit (DU) by COSEWIC (2012). There are no trend data for the minor areas Hopedale, Nose and Flemish DUs (COSEWIC 2012).

First, from south to north, the trend analysis of the US NEFSC Fall survey 1963–2018 (55 years) revealed annual rates of decrease of 0.77%, consistent with an estimated median decrease of 8.5% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (66%) of Least Concern and 20% probability of being in a threatened category. Overall, the time-series shows decline from the early 1960s to the early 1980s, followed by stabilization and a more recent increase since the late 1990s.

Second, the trend analysis of the Georges Bank, Canada/Gulf of Maine, USA (5Z) relative abundance index (mature individuals) for 1986–2017 (31 years) revealed annual rates of decrease of 1.8%, consistent with an estimated median decline of 56% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (54%) of >50% reduction over three generation lengths. This time-series corresponds to a very small portion of the population and is short and very noisy.

Third, the trend analysis of the Scotian Shelf and Bay of Fundy (4VWX) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1970–2017 (47 years) revealed annual rates of decrease of 2.8%, consistent with an estimated median decline of 74.9% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (99%) of >50% reduction over three generation lengths. Overall, this time-series shows steep decline from the early 1960s until around 1990 and little increase in abundance index since then.

Fourth, the trend analysis of the Southern Gulf of St. Lawrence (4T) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1971–2018 (47 years) revealed annual rates of decrease of 0.72%, consistent with an estimated median decline of 32.2% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (53%) of >30% reduction over three generation lengths and a substantial probability (24%) of >50% reduction. This time-series shows decline from the early 1960s and slow increase in abundance index since 2000.

Fifth, the trend analysis of the Northern Gulf of St. Lawrence (4RS) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1991–2018 (27 years) revealed annual rates of increase of 4.02 %, consistent with an estimated median increase of 316.3% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (87%) of Least Concern.

Sixth, the trend analysis of the Grand Banks (3LNOPs) survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1975–2017 (42 years) revealed annual rates of increase of 0.54%, consistent with a median increase of 16.4% over three generation lengths (48 years) and a probability (69%) of Least Concern, but a 25% probability of a population reduction >30%. The population trajectory has been flat with some variability since the mid-1970s.

Seventh, the trend analysis of the Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf (2J3K) Fall CPUE survey index of abundance (mature individuals) for 1977–2017 (40 years) revealed annual rates of decrease of 0.69%, consistent with a median decrease of 58.4% over three generation lengths (48 years) and the highest probability (56%) of >50% reduction over three generation lengths. The population index peaked in the early 1980s then collapsed over the next decade. The population has shown signs of recovery over the most recent generation span, with annual rates of increase of 16.28%. This time series (in 2J3K) corresponds to the subpopulation described as the Funk Designatable Unit (COSEWIC 2012).

Taken together there have been very steep population reductions in the central (Scotian Shelf and Bay of Fundy, Canada, 4VWX) and northern part (Newfoundland and Labrador Shelf, 2J3K) of this species' range. There have been steep increases in the easternmost part of the range (Grand Banks, 3LNOPs) and signs of recovery in the southern USA part of the range.

The overall index suggests a steep decline in abundance from the mid-1960s until the mid-1990s followed by increasing abundance to the present day. The overall annual rate of decrease of 1.08% is consistent with an estimated median decline of 36.1% over three generation lengths (48 years), with the highest probability (62%) of >30% reduction over three generation lengths and a 23% probability of population reduction greater than 50% over three generation lengths (Supplementary Information).
range: The Smooth Skate is endemic to the Northwest Atlantic and occurs from New Jersey, USA to northern Labrador, Canada, including the Grand Banks, Southeast Shoal, and Flemish Cap (Last et al. 2016). It forms geographically distinct subpopulations where there is little demographic or genetic exchange (Kulka et al. 2006).
useTrade: There are no target fisheries for Smooth Skate in Canada or USA. It is taken as incidental bycatch of other trawl and gillnet fisheries (COSEWIC 2012).
conservationActions: The possession of Smooth Skate has been prohibited since 2003 in the USA (NEFMC, 2003). There are currently no specific fisheries measures for this species in Canada, as it is only incidentally captured and discarded at sea (DFO 2017). However, t<span lang="EN-US">his species may have benefited from the 2004 closure of the directed commercial skate fishery on the Grand Banks and Scotian Shelf due to large declines in Winter and Thorny skates there. The   Laurentian Channel was designated as the   Laurentian Channel Marine Protected Area in April 2019. This MPA is in place,   in part, to protect Smooth Skate from bycatch in the commercial fishery.                   In Canada, the COSEWIC (2012) designated status is as follows: Hopedale Channel population - Data Deficient; Funk Island Deep population – Endangered; Nose of the Grand Bank population - Data Deficient; Laurentian-Scotian population - Special Concern. It was not placed on the Canadian Species at Risk Act schedule for protection.

rationale: The Nursehound (Scyliorhinus stellaris) is a medium-sized (to 162 cm total length) catshark known from the Northeast Atlantic Ocean (from Norway to Portugal) and the Mediterranean Sea. It occurs on the continental and insular shelf, mostly from nearshore to about 60 m, with occasional specimens reported from deeper water (to a depth of 380 m). The species is caught incidentally in artisanal and industrial demersal trawl, gill net, demersal set long line, handline and fixed demersal net fisheries operating across all its known range. There is high distribution overlap with intensive fishing pressure, reported declines in part of its range but an increasing population in others, possible local extinctions in the Mediterranean Sea, and a lack of species-specific management across its range. Population recovery may be affected by low levels of interconnectivity between isolated populations around those island groups far from the continental coast. The Nursehound is suspected to have undergone a global population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (48 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Nursehound is demersal on the insular and continental shelf and upper slope from nearshore to a depth of 380 m, and mostly occurs at depths of 20–63 m in rocky and seagrass habitats (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). It is reported to reach a maximum size of 162 cm total length (TL), but mostly attains a length of ~125 cm TL (Ebert and Stehmann 2013, Weigmann 2016). Males mature at 77 cm TL and females mature at 79 cm TL in the Mediterranean Sea (Bauchot 1987). Reproduction is oviparous and size-at-birth is ~11 cm TL (Soares and de Carvalho 2019). Nothing else is known of its biology. Maximum age and age-at-maturity are unknown; maximum age is inferred from a congener, the Smallspotted Catshark (Scyliorhinus canicula), with female age-at-maturity of 9 years and a maximum age of 17 years (Rodríguez-Cabello et al. 2005). This results in a generation length of 13 years. The Nursehound is larger than the Small Spotted Catshark (125 cm vs 100 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 16 years for Nursehound.
threats: The Nursehound is caught incidentally in artisanal and industrial demersal trawl, gill net, demersal set long line, handline and fixed bottom net fisheries (Ellis et al. 2009). In some parts of its range, the preferred inshore, rocky habitats are fished by pots (for crab and lobster), which would reduce local fishing pressure on Nursehound. It is difficult to assess the true impact of fisheries on this species throughout its range because it is often reported under a generic "elasmobranch" category or together with its congener, the Smallspotted Catshark (S. canicula). The species appears to still be commonly captured in Tunisia and Malta (Ragonese et al. 2013).
population:
The Nursehound is sometimes confused with the similar looking and very abundant Smallspotted Catshark (S. canicula), which may impact reported landings of the Nursehound. Species-specific population trend data are available from standardized catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) in the Northeast Atlantic (ICES-WGEF 2019). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (48 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List Category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of the CPUE indices from trawl survey in the Irish Sea and Bristol Channel revealed an annual rate of increase of 4.7%, consistent an increasing population over three generation lengths (48 years). Around the British Isles, the Nursehound is considered locally abundant (ICES-WGEF 2019).

In the Mediterranean Sea, the Nursehound was previously considered a commonly observed species in trawl fishing grounds off the Balearic Islands and Adriatic Sea. However, the species is infrequently reported in research surveys and commercial fisheries and may be locally extinct in some areas (Aldebert 1997, Ragonese et al. 2013, Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). Steep declines (>90%) or the complete disappearance of neritic and slope species have been documented across the Mediterranean Sea between the 1940–50s and 1990s (Aldebert 1997, Maynou et al. 2011, Colloca et al. 2017). These declines equate to >90% reduction in population over three generation lengths (48 years) of the Nursehound. Population recovery may be affected by low levels of interconnectivity between isolated populations around islands far from the continental coast (Ellis et al. 2009). 

Across the regions, the Nursehound was estimated to have increased in the Northeast Atlantic and suspected to have declined in the Mediterranean Sea. With high levels of exploitation across most of its known range, a global population reduction of 30–49% was suspected over three generation lengths (48 years). Therefore, the Nursehound is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Nursehound is found in the Northeast and Eastern Central Atlantic Oceans (from Norway to Portugal) and the Mediterranean Sea, but does not occur in the Black Sea. Records from northwest Africa were likely confused with the West African Catshark (Scyliorhinus cervigoni) (Soares and de Carvalho 2019).
useTrade: The species is used for human consumption, and occasionally for bait in pot traps (ICES-WGEF 2019).
conservationActions: Further information is required on population size and trends of the Nursehound, as well as interactions with fisheries across its range. There are some general management arrangements of relevance in place in the Northeast Atlantic, including minimum mesh sizes for targeting Scyliorhinus spp. (EC Reg 850/98 of 30 March 1998). Management measures for deep-water sharks in European Community waters may offer some refuge for the Nursehound at the deeper end of its bathymetric distribution. These management measures include banned use of trawls and gillnets in waters >200 m depth in Azores, Madeira and Canary Islands and international waters regulated by ICES (NEAFC regulatory Area); maximum bycatch limits of deep-water shark in Hake (Merluccius merluccius) and monkfish (Lophius spp) gillnet catches; area restrictions by vessel size and gear, and gear restrictions (hook size, maximum number of hooks on longline gear) (ICES-WGEF 2019).

rationale:
The Blackspotted Smoothhound (Mustelus punctulatus) is a small (to 122 cm total length) shark found in the Mediterranean Sea and to the Western Sahara in the Eastern Central Atlantic. It is demersal on the continental shelf and slope from the surface to a depth of 300 m. This species is frequently mistaken with other more abundant smoothhound (Mustelus spp.) species, particularly the Common Smoothhound (M. mustelus).

The Blackspotted Smoothhound appears to be very rare in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, but more common along the North African coast, especially on the coasts of Tunisia and Libya. Like other smoothhound species in this region, it is taken as bycatch in demersal trawls as well as gillnet, trammel net and line gear. Landings data are often grouped and therefore species-specific information is not currently available. Smoothhounds are valued for human consumption in many areas of the Mediterranean Sea and northwest Africa and are often retained and marketed. This species is apparently rare, but it may be unknowingly fished throughout its range. There is evidence that other smoothhound species have declined, making further investigation a priority. Considering that the fishing effort in the Mediterranean Sea has either remained the same or increased, catch data suggest declining trends from 2008 to 2012. These declines in the Mediterranean combined with its more common abundance elsewhere lead to a suspected population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (54 years) due to levels of exploitation, and the Blackspotted Smoothhound  is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Blackspotted Smoothhound is demersal on the continental shelf and slope on sandy and gravelly substrates and sea grass beds, from the surface to a depth of 300 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Serena et al. 2014). It reaches a maximum size of 122 cm total length (TL), males mature at 81cm TL and females mature at 96 cm TL (Saïdi et al. 2009). Reproduction is placental viviparous with a uterine fecundity of 12–27, an annual reproductive cycle and size-at-birth of 25 cm TL (Saïdi et al. 2009). The generation length is inferred from a regional congener Common Smoothhound (Mustelus mustelus) to be 18 years (Goosen and Smale 1997, da Silva 2007).
threats:
The Blackspotted Smoothhound occurs in coastal waters where fishing pressure is substantial through most of its range. It is caught by demersal trawl and coastal small-scale fisheries in the Mediterranean Sea (STECF 2003) and probably off the northwestern coast of Africa (Morocco and Western Sahara). Although Bradaï (2000) observed that this species is common in the Gulf of Gabès, it seems to be scarce at least in the northern Mediterranean Sea. In the Mediterranean Sea, there is a high level of exploitation on the continental shelf and upper slope to about 800 m depth (Massuti and Moranta 2003, Ferretti et al. 2005). Smoothhounds are captured by demersal trawls, trammel nets, gillnets and longlines in this region (Bauchot 1987). Semi-industrial fisheries in the Adriatic Sea, off Sicily, Spain and Cyprus are known to take these species, and also artisanal fisheries elsewhere. Smoothhounds are retained and used in the Mediterranean Sea, where they are regularly sold for human consumption in many areas (Fischer et al. 1987).

Smoothhounds have shown signs of depletion in the Mediterranean Sea, although they may be locally abundant in some areas (STECF 2003). Landings of smoothhounds are often grouped as “smoothhounds nei” in landing statistics and therefore no species-specific data are available from the region. Furthermore, at least for Italian catches, reported catches do not correspond with the taxonomic group, but an aggregation of small demersal sharks, including true smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.), spurdogs (Squalus spp.), gulper sharks (Centrophorus spp.), the Kitefin Shark (Dalatias licha), catsharks (Scyliorhinus spp.), and the Blackmouth Catshark (Galeus melastomus). This is because these species are usually marketed headless, skinned, and eviscerated, and sold under the commercial name of “palombo”: the Italian name for smoothhounds. Direct observations by experts are required to collect species-specific data for catches of true smoothhounds, as these sharks can be difficult to identify for non-biologist observers.
population:
Very little information is available on the population trend of the Blackspotted Smoothhound, partly due to confusion with the more common species of smoothhound within its range. It seems to be very rare in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea where surveys have been undertaken. It was recorded in only one of 6,336 hauls during the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) programme (at depths of 50−800 m) from 1994−1999 (Baino et al. 2001). Jukic-Peladic (2001) compared MEDITS catch data from the Adriatic Sea in 1998 with that from the Hvar survey in 1948. The Blackspotted Smoothhound was not reported from either survey, whereas the Common Smoothhound (M. mustelus) and Starry Smoothhound (M. asterias) were present in both. The Blackspotted Smoothhound was also absent from bottom trawl surveys conducted off the Balearic Islands between 1998−2001, at depths of 40−1,800 m (Massutí and Moranta 2003).

The Italian survey programme "Gruppo Nazionale Risorse Demersali" (GRUND) carried out over 22 surveys in Italian waters between 1985−1998. The percentage presence of this species was low (2.48%) and very few specimens were caught in the northern Tyrrhenian Sea, northern central Adriatic Sea, and south of Sicily (Relini et al. 2000). Scientific trawl surveys caught this species mostly in the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) Geographical Sub-areas 16 (Strait of Sicily) and 17 (northern Adriatic Sea) with the average catch rate per hour ranging between 0.6 and 1.7, respectively. From 2008 to 2012, the catch of this species progressively declined, especially in the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations (FAO) Division 37.1.3 (Sardinia) and 37.2.2 (Ionian Sea) areas where catches declined by 75% (from 1.43–0.36 t per year) and 37% (from 33.32–20.87 t per year), respectively. In FAO Division 37.2.1 (Adriatic Sea), the landings remained relatively consistent (between 172 and 311 t per year; Serena et al. 2014).

This species is apparently more common in parts of the North African coast of the Mediterranean Sea. It is common along the Tunisian coasts and seems to be most abundant towards the south in the Gulf of Gabès and along the coast of Libya (Bradaï et al. 2002). Its status in northwest Africa remains unknown.

Considering the population decline data available from the Mediterranean for the period 2008−2012, and its more common abundance elsewhere, it is suspected that the Blackspotted Smoothhound has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over three past three generation lengths (54 years) due to actual or potential levels of exploitation.
range: The Blackspotted Smoothhound occurs throughout coastal and continental shelf waters of the Mediterranean Sea (but is absent from the Black Sea) with its range extending to the Eastern Central Atlantic (Western Sahara) (Serena 2005, Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: Smoothhounds are commercially valuable in the Mediterranean Sea and northwestern Africa, where they are retained and marketed for human consumption of the meat either fresh, frozen, or salted and dried.
conservationActions: No species-specific management or conservation measures are currently in place in the Mediterranean Sea or northwestern Africa. Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Bigeye Skate (Okamejei meerdervoortii) is a small (to 38 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan to China. It is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 30–150 m, though mainly at 80–90 m. This skate is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and set nets, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal.

No species-specific population trend data are available. Catches of skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the South Korea and China EEZs indicate declines of 30–91% over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species’ entire range. Regional congeners have been reported as common in some areas and to have high biological productivity, which would provide some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Bigeye Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Bigeye Skate is demersal on sand and mud habitats of the continental shelf at depths of 30–150 m, though mainly at 80–90 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 38 cm total length (TL), males are mature by 31 cm TL and females size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Two congeners of similar size and depth ranges, the Spiny Skate (O. kenojei) and the Sharpspine Skate (O. acutispina) have female ages-at-maturity of 3.4 and 7.2 years and maximum ages of 10.5 and 13.2 years (Ishihara et al. 2002, Joung et al. 2011), resulting in generation lengths of 6.9 and 10.2 years, respectively. It is thus inferred that the generation length of the Bigeye Skate is on the lower side of 7–10 years.
threats:
The Bigeye Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its entire spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch, and is possibly targeted in South Korea, in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including demersal trawl, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption or fish meal. There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Bigeye Skate. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however, they began to decline in the 1980s–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a there is a lack of younger people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019). 

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China one of the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).
population:
There are no species-specific trend data for this species. In the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), the catch of skates and rays from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some of the decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort, which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan EEZ.

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea and China EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (21 years), they represent declines of 56–70%, 80–91%, and 30–41% in Japan, South Korea, and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the entire spatial and depth range of the Spiny Skate. Congeners of similar size, depth, and range have been reported as common in some areas and to have high biological productivity, which would provide some resilience to fishing pressure (see Red List assessments of Spiny Skate (O. kenojei) and the Sharpspine Skate (O. acutispina)). Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years).
range: The Bigeye Skate is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan, South Korea, and China (Last et al. 2016). It was previously reported from Taiwan; however, all records have since been found to be misidentifications (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The species is used for human consumption and fish meal.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that includes total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Yellowspotted Skate (Leucoraja wallacei) is a medium-sized (to 96 cm total length) skate endemic to southern Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans, occurring from southern Namibia to southern Mozambique. It inhabits the outer continental shelf and upper slope on soft substrates at depths of 73–515 m. It has relatively fast growth rates and matures at a moderate age of 9 years. The Yellowspotted Skate is captured and retained in demersal trawl and line fisheries that operate throughout most of its range, although some remote parts of southern Namibia may offer refuge from fishing pressure. Trend analysis of research trawl data in South African commercially fished areas estimated a population reduction of 46% over the past three generation lengths (36 years). The species has exhibited a southwest range shift with some potential loss of habitat area during 1981–2016, likely due to climate change. Overall, due to an estimated reduction in population size over part of its range, combined with some areas of its range with low fishing pressure that may offer refuge, it is suspected that the Yellowspotted Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Yellowspotted Skate is demersal on the outer continental shelf and upper slope on soft substrates at depths of 73–515 m, but is most common at 150–300 m (Smale 2009, Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 96 cm total length (TL); males mature at 64 cm TL, and females mature at 73 cm TL off the west coast, and 75 cm TL off the south coast of South Africa (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous, with the number of egg cases laid unknown, but the reproductive cycle is possibly annual as egg cases are laid only in March-May; size-at-birth is 16 cm TL (Walmsley-Hart et al. 1999, Last et al. 2016). The species has relatively fast growth rates, at k=0.27 for males and k=0.26 for females (Walmsley-Hart et al. 1999). Female age-at-maturity is 9 years and maximum age is 15 years; generation length is therefore 12 years (Walmsley-Hart et al. 1999).
threats: The Yellowspotted Skate is mainly captured by deep-water trawl fisheries targeting hake (Merluccius spp) and crustaceans in South Africa and Mozambique, respectively, and is sometimes retained. It is also likely taken in commercial line fisheries in South Africa (da Silva et al. 2015). Trawl fisheries operate throughout most of its range but in South Africa, trawl effort has decreased over the past two decades (S. Fennessy pers. comm. 20 April 2018). The crustacean trawl fishery from Durban into southern Mozambique operates at 100–600 m depth (Fennessy and Groenveld 1997). Effort in that fishery, however, has been declining substantially since 2007; the 2016 effort level was half the 2012 level, which in-turn was only 30% of that in the early 1990s. Currently there are 2–3 vessels operating at any one time, for a total of around 1,000 trawls per year (S. Fennessy pers. comm. 24 April 2018). Intense small-scale trawl fishing in southern Mozambique (Jacquet et al. 2010, Benkenstein 2013) may threaten this species. Some parts of southern Namibia are remote and may offer refuge from fishing pressure (Belhabib et al. 2015). The Yellowspotted Skate has exhibited a southwest range shift and a loss of habitat area over three decades from 1981–2016 in South Africa, possibly as a result of climate change (Currie et al. 2019). This may represent a loss of habitat for this species.
population:
There are no estimates of population size for the Yellowspotted Skate. Population trend data of annual density estimates (kg per nm² area swept) were available from demersal research trawl surveys conducted over 26 years (1991–2016) in commercially fished areas of South Africa during autumn and spring along the south coast by the Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF unpubl. data 2018). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (36 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker and Sherley 2019). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 1.7% over the trawl grounds, consistent with an estimated reduction of 46.3% over the past three generation lengths (36 years), with the highest probability (41.6%) of a reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths. The research trawl survey gear was modified in recent years and is now very inefficient at catching skates, which could account for some recent decline in research catch rates (R. Leslie unpubl. data 2018). This species is abundant along the west and south coast of South Africa, but less prevalent on the east coast of South Africa and Mozambique: individuals were observed in only two of 508 research trawls in Mozambique and 11 of 749 trawls in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa from 2003 to 2012 (S.
