Landings slowly increased from the 1950s to the peak catch in 1979 then have been fluctuating considerably since then. Fishing pressure has been increasing since the 1950s and thus these declines infer reductions in these populations in west coast, Peninsular Malaysia. In Myanmar, reconstructed landings from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t annually with no substantial trend. From the late 1990s to 2014 landings increased to around 40,000 t per year which was concurrent with an increase in fishing effort (Pauly et al. 2020). This infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased. However, surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations (San San Khine 2010, Krakstad et al. 2014).

In Bangladesh, reconstructed landings data showed a 34% decline over 15 years from 2000 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 195 t in 1950 to 7,540 t in 1973 the declined to the 3,500 t in the mid -1980s, then rose steeply to a peak of 10,909 t in 2000 followed by a fluctuating decline to 7,163 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). In Sri Lanka, reconstructed landings data showed a five-fold increase over the 65 years from 1950 to 2014. Total catches have fluctuated greatly but continued to rise overall (Pauly et al. 2020). A population trend cannot be inferred as effort has also increased during this period.

In Taiwan, it is difficult to separate this species from the Chinese Numbfish (N. lingula), and all specimens from Taiwan are currently provisionally identified as the Chinese Numbfish (Ebert et al. 2013). Although there is no species-specific data, the catch-per-unit effort for all rays in Taiwan has remained stable over 17 years, that is, 1997–2013 (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). In the Philippines, from 1976 to 2006, the landings of all combined ray species from municipal and commercial fisheries decreased by 76% over 16 years from 1991 to 2006. The annual landings rose from 4,160 t in 1976 to a peak of 10,990 t in 1991, then declined to 2,600 t in 2006 (NFRDI 2017). These declines in landings of sharks and rays can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort was increasing during the period of the declines in landings (Palomares and Pauly 2014). In Thailand, landings data are available on all combined ray species from the EEZ for 1998–2018 (Krajangdara 2019). The landings data showed an 89% reduction over 16 years from 2003 to 2018. Catches rose steadily from 1998 to a peak catch of 18,131 t in 2003 followed by a steady decline in catches to ~2000 t in 2018 (Krajangdara 2019). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the decline in catches from 2003 to 2018 coincided with a decline in fishing effort.

The population of the Smallspot Numbfish is suspected to have declined off India due to overall declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing pressure. For example, the annual average catch of rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990–2004 was 502 t. During this period trawler hours doubled, and consequently, the catch rate declined by 60% from 0.65 kg/hr in 1990 to 0.24 kg/hr in 2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009). Across India, landings of elasmobranchs have declined by 44% from 1998 to 2018, this is despite increasing effort which infers a decline in their populations (Gupta et al. 2020).

When these inferred and suspected declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Smallspot Numbfish (15 years), they represent declines of 23%, 84%, 76%, 28%, 89%, 36%, 66% and 30% in China, Viet Nam, Philippines, Malaysia, Thailand, Bangladesh, Mumbai and across India, respectively. Trends cannot be determined for Sri Lanka and Myanmar, though declines of ray populations are suspected in recent years in Myanmar. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. The declines range from 23–89%, although across most of its range the declines are 23–39%. Historic and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Smallspot Numbfish. Overall, based on inferred declines across most of its range, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (15 years).
range: The Smallspot Numbfish is found from the South China Sea to the Bay of Bengal in the Northwest and Western Central Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans. It occurs from China to India, including Taiwan, Viet Nam (Gulf of Tonkin), the Philippines (Sibuyan and Visayan Seas), Thailand (Gulf of Thailand), Indonesia (Sumatra), Malaysia (Peninsular), Singapore, Myanmar, and Bangladesh (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Based on cogeneric and sympatric Narcine species, the Smallspot Numbfish is likely not used for human consumption as there is very little meat on the animal (A. Bin Ali pers. comm. 05/05/2020). In Indonesia and Bangladesh, Narcine species are generally discarded at sea as fishers fear being electrocuted by them and they are low value in Indonesia and Myanamr (Fahmi, A. Haque and A. Maung unpubl. data 2020). In China and Taiwan, it is retained but discarded at the markets as it is unsuitable for fish meal in those countries; it may sometimes be consumed by fishers at sea in Taiwan (H. Hsu unpubl. data 2019). In Malaysia, it is likely used for 'trash fish' (A. Bin Ali pers. comm. 05/05/2020), that is, fish meal and other products.
conservationActions:
No specific conservation measures are in place. In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the South China Seas to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019).

In Malaysia, large mesh gillnets (>24.5 cm) were banned in 1990 (A. Bin Ali pers. comm. 05/05 2020). In Indonesia, trawls were banned in 1980, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country and the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries permits Danish seine (Cantrang) to operate but they are spatially restricted (Chong et al. 1987). In the Philippines, active fishing gears, including trawlers, were prohibited in 1998 within municipal marine waters (<3 nautical miles from shore). Trawlers within commercial waters have been required since 2010 to use Juvenile and Trashfish Excluder Devices under the Fisheries Administrative Order 237 series of 2010. (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020), which may reduce the retention of rays (Brewer et al. 2006). In Myanmar, two shark reserves were designated in the Myeik Archipelago in 2004 where targeting sharks and rays is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of the ban in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 02/04/2020). Research is required to better define the population size and trends, and life history of the Smallspot Numbfish, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Whitefin Smooth-hound (Mustelus widodoi) is a small (to 120 cm total length) shark that occurs in the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific Oceans off Indonesia and Malaysia (Sabah, Borneo). It is demersal on the inner continental shelf at depths of 60–120 m. In Indonesia, this species is of low commercial value, and it is caught occasionally by demersal longliners off Bali, and possibly Lombok, but it possibly occurs deeper than the majority of fisheries. It is retained for local consumption of its meat and its fins are retained for trade. Reconstructed landings data of all carcharhinid sharks combined from the Central Indonesia indicate declines of 42% over the past three generation lengths (33 years) of the Whitefin Smoothhound. These catch trends are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Fishing pressure is high across the geographic distribution of this species, but there may be some refuge at depth. Overall, it is suspected that the Whitefin Smoothhound has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (33 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Whitefin Smoothhound is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 60–120 m (Ebert et al. 2013). It reaches a maximum size of 110 cm total length (TL), males mature at 83 cm TL and females mature at 92 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is presumably lecithotrophic viviparous and size-at-birth is < 31 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Generation length is inferred from a similar-sized congener, the Starspotted Smoothhound (Mustelus manazo), which has a female age-at-maturity of 3–7 years and maximum age is 17 years; generation length is therefore 11 years (Yamaguchi et al. 2000).
threats:
The Whitefin Smoothhound is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, longline, and gillnet. All incidental catch is retained for the meat and fins. In Indonesia, this species is of low commercial value, and it is caught occasionally by demersal longliners off Bali and possibly Lombok. It possibly occurs deeper than the majority of fisheries, though more information is required. Trawl fishing is particularly intensive in Indonesia, for example, in the nearby Arafura Sea region (W.T. White pers. comm. 28 June 2010). In 2009, it was reported that 680 trawlers operated in the Arafura Sea and that catches in inshore waters had declined with vessels travelling further to maintain catches (Blaber et al. 2009).

Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). The number of fishers increased by 165% from 1951 to 1967, beginning the dramatic and ongoing increase in Indonesian fisheries production (Tull 2014). Small-scale fisheries comprise most (~90%) of fisheries production in Indonesia (Tull 2014). In some regions, effort by these small-scale fisheries has tripled when taking population into account (Ramenzoni 2017). Indonesia has been the top shark fishing nation for over 20 years, with average landings reported to be over 100,000 t (Jaiteh et al. 2017) and worth an estimated $125 million USD in export (Booth et al. 2018). Carcharhinids are commonly caught by demersal trawl and inshore demersal gillnet fisheries and commonly landed in local fish markets (White et al. 2006). Carcharhinids are landed in 90% of fisheries operating in Indonesia (Booth et al. 2018) and in some areas, over 50% of sharks landed are juveniles (Nawawi et al. 2020).

Significant fishing activity also occurs off the southwest coast of Sumatra, in the Indian Ocean. Aceh Province in Sumatra is thought to be Indonesia’s largest shark fishing province, in terms of the total number of fisheries taking sharks (Booth et al. 2018). Smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) are occasionally recorded in fisheries on the southwestern coast of Aceh, which may be the Whitefin Smoothhound. Some specialized shark longlines operate in Aceh province, with demersal longliners potentially overlapping with Whitefin Smoothhound geographic range. Smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) are also recorded in elasmobranch fisheries in Muncar (East Java), which operate in the Bali strait (Winter et al. 2019). Tuna longlines, specialised shark longlines and gillnets all operate in this fishery; Mustelus spp are likely caught in specialised shark longlines (H. Booth Wildlife Conservation Society unpubl. data 2020). Thus, the level of exploitation of this species could be extremely high throughout the Indonesian portion of its range.

In Sabah, Malaysia this species is caught in trawl fisheries in the South China Sea. The trawlers fishing out of Kota Kinabalu typically fish at 60–70 m depth and hence this species may have some refuge at depth (A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). In Sabah, due to the high number of unlicensed local and migrant small-scale fishers, fisheries landings are underreported by an estimated 2.5 times (Teh et al. 2009). Similarly, the number of small-scale fishers may be three times higher than the reported number, thus exploitation levels are far higher than reported.

There is a large amount of Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the region with reported catch estimated to represent only 0.9–19.4% of the true catch (Tull et al. 2014). In some areas, including near Marine Protected Areas, IUU catch of sharks was estimated to equal 77% of the reported catch, indicating much higher levels of depletion (Varkey et al. 2010).
population:
This species is captured infrequently in Indonesia, but the true catch rates remain uncertain due to taxonomic uncertainty as catches are reported as Starspotted Smoothhound (Mustelus manazo) and separately as M. cf manazo. There were moderate catches of 1–2 individuals of Starspotted Smoothhound per demersal-set longline trip in 2016 and 2019 and catches of 1–8 individuals of M. cf manazo per demersal-set longline trip in 2014, 2016, 2018 and 2019 (H. Booth Wildlife Conservation Society unpubl. data 2020). These episodic and low levels of catch may indicate that any overlap of fisheries with depth range may require clarification as the Whitefin Smoothhound possibly occurs deeper than the majority of current fisheries.

Fishermen have reported decreased catches and smaller sizes of sharks in Indonesia. Decreases were reported in more recent years of commonly caught species (e.g. Whitetip Reef Shark (Triaenodon obesus), Snaggletooth Shark (Hemipristis elongata), and Blacktip Reef Shark (Carcharhinus melanopterus)) and decreases starting 20 years ago in other species (e.g. hammerhead sharks (Sphyrna spp.), wedgefishes (Rhynchobatus spp.), and Sandbar Shark (C. plumbeus)) with no species having increased in abundance over the past two decades (Jaiteh et al. 2017).

In Indonesia, reconstructed catch data shows catches of carcharhinids increased throughout the mid to late 1900s. In Eastern Indonesia, carcharhinid catch increased 5,640% from 1970 to the late 1980s before it rapidly decreased ~325% in the mid 1990s to 11,500 t, where catch has since remained relatively stable (Zeller and Pauly 2016). In Central Indonesia, catch of carcharhinids began increasing in the early 1960s before reaching a peak in 1983 and remaining stable between 15,000 and 17,500 t until 2004. After which, carcharhinid catch was between 5,600 and 14,000 t until 2014 (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch of carcharhinids in the Indonesian Exclusive Economic Zone of the Eastern Indian Ocean began increasing in the 1960 and steadily increased until 1994 at ~47,500 t. Catch has since decreased to ~33,000 t per year despite continually increasing effort.

Fishing pressure ('actual levels of exploitation') is high across the geographic distribution of this species, but there may be some refuge at depth for this species. Declines in reconstructed catch of carcharhinids from Indonesia are consistent with a population reduction of 42% over three generation lengths (33 years). Overall, it is suspected that the Whitefin Smoothhound has undergone a reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (33 years) based on actual levels of fishing pressure, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
range: The Whitefin Smoothhound occurs in the Eastern Indian and Western Central Pacific off Indonesia and Malaysia (Sabah, Borneo) (Last et al. 2010, Ebert et al. 2013, A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, this species occurs on the south coast of Sumatra, Java, and the Lesser Sunda islands in central Indonesia (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). There are records of Starspotted Smoothhound‘Mustelus manazo’ and ‘Mustelus cf manazo’ from Tanjung Luar, Lombok which could be Whitefin Smoothhound (Yulianto et al. 2018, H. Booth Wildlife Conservation Society unpubl. data 2020). Fisheries land catches at Tanjung Luar, Lombok from the Lesser Sunda Islands (around Flores, Sumba and Sumbawa) which suggests, if the identity is confirmed, this species may have a more eastward range (H. Booth Wildlife Conservation Society unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: This species is used for its meat and fins, with the fins likely internationally trade, as Mustelus spp. fins comprised 0.39 and 0.76% of fins sampled in Guangzhou and Hong Kong, respectively (Last et al. 2010, Cardeñosa et al. 2020).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific measures in place. In 1980, trawls were banned from use, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In 2015, an additional ban on seine nets (Cantrang) was put in place and set to be fully implemented in February 2020 (Ambari 2019). There are currently plans in place to lift both these bans in the near future (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2020). Throughout Indonesia there are 196 Marine Protected Areas making up 239,428 km2 that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Spottail Sleeper Ray (Narke dipterygia) is a small (to 35 cm total length) ray found in the Indian, Western Central, and Northwest Pacific Oceans ranging from Oman to Japan. It is demersal on the continental shelf to a depth of at least 100 m. The species is a bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and longline and is mostly discarded due to its small size with a likely low post-release survival rate but is retained in some areas for fishmeal. There are no species-specific population trends, though landings data of all rays and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates combined from Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ) across the species' range infer declines of 23–97% over the past three generation lengths (15 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in rays in the region. Fishing pressure is high across most of the range of the Spottail Sleeper Ray, yet the abundance of a regional congener, the Japanese Sleeper Ray, has changed little in Taiwan over the past 10–15 years suggesting these sleeper rays may have some resilience to fishing pressure. Trawl, inshore, and seasonal fishing bans in parts of its range may provide some refuge from fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Spottail Sleeper Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (15 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Spottail Sleeper Ray occurs on the continental shelf on sandy and muddy habitats from nearshore to at least 100 m depth (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 35 cm total length (TL), with Arabian Seas populations attaining this larger size and elsewhere more commonly to a maximum size of 20 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Males and females mature at 15 cm TL (Yamada et al. 2007, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of 4–6 pups and size-at-birth of ~10 cm TL (Yamada et al. 2007). Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown and lacking for all sleeper rays. Ages are inferred from the Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor) that has a female age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 15 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). The Cortez Numbfish is larger than the Spottail Sleeper Ray (75 cm vs 35 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 5 years for the Spottail Sleeper Ray.
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and longline. Electric rays are not targeted in any part of this species’ region and are often discarded at sea with low survivorship. In some areas, the species is retained as bycatch for fish meal production. Sleeper rays are caught as a minor component of the bycatch at least in Taiwan and Japan (Last et al. 2016).

In the Western Indian Ocean region, the Spottail Sleeper Ray occurs in some areas of intense demersal trawl activity. No specific information is available on catches of the Spottail Sleeper Ray as species-specific data are not recorded, however, the high level of exploitation on its habitat is of concern. For example, there were about 6,600 trawlers operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). The Spottail Sleeper Ray is occasionally recorded at landing sites in India as trawl bycatch (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020), although most electric rays are discarded at sea. In Pakistan waters, about 2,000 trawlers operate in shelf waters, targeting shrimp in shallow waters and fish in outer shelf waters (M. Khan pers. comm. 6 February 2017).

In Malaysia, unrestrained fisheries expansion from the mid-1960s to the 70s led to fully exploited inshore fisheries by the late 1970s (Teh and Teh 2014). Fishing effort in Malaysia has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has more than doubled from 22,800 vessels in 1950 to 50,150 vessels in 2014. However, the substantial increase over this period has been in engine power which has dramatically increased by ~30 fold (Pauly et al. 2020). Most fisheries in Thailand are overexploited. Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased dramatically from 5,900 vessels in 1950 to a peak of 82,900 vessels in 2004 and then declined steadily to 54,700 vessels in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Indonesia, small-scale fisheries comprise most (~90%) of fisheries production (Tull 2014). In some regions, effort by these small-scale fisheries has tripled when taking population growth into account (Ramenzoni 2017). Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Fishing pressure in Indonesia is intense with the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally and the country has been among the top shark fishing nations for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019). The catch of rays is rising as shark fisheries collapse; in 2003, rays comprised over 50% of chondrichthyan landings, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006, White and Dharmadi 2007).

Coastal fisheries in Cambodia are considered overexploited (Teh et al. 2014a). Fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 26,180 vessels in 1950 to 108,490 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since the 1980s and most of the fleet artisanal fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The marine fisheries are mostly inshore and small-scale within 10 km of the shore. Motorized vessels increased during the 1980s and trawlers are the dominant fishery accounting for one-quarter to one-third of the Cambodian fishing fleet (Teh et al. 2014a, Pauly et al. 2020). Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020). The fleet is dominated by small-scale artisanal and subsistence fisheries that have accounted for 60–85% of the fleet since the 1950s (Teh et al. 2014b, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal and subsistence motorized fleet has tripled from 1950 (~24,280 vessels) to 2014 (~78,000 vessels) but has also substantially increased in effort in terms of engine power, particularly over the last two decades (Pauly et al. 2020). Approximately 33% of the total marine captures in Viet Nam consists of ‘trash’ fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry and also to manufacture fish sauce (FAO 2020). Illegal fishing by foreign vessels is an additional threat in Viet Nam waters (Teh et al. 2014b, FAO 2020).

The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019). Since the 1980s, demersal trawls are the dominant gear followed by purse seines and small-scale gear (Pauly and Liang 2019). In China, the number of powered fishing vessels increased from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28 August 2019). Fish too small for human consumption are in demand for processing into fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry that produces double the quantity of seafood taken from wild capture fisheries in Taiwan waters (NDC 2016). In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile EEZ (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 1 September 2019).

Dramatic levels of habitat loss in parts of its region may pose a threat. In both the East and South China Seas, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands, with a loss of 70% of mangroves in the last 70 years in the South China Sea, where there has also been modification of up to 50% of seagrass beds and degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009).
population:
There is limited species-specific population trend information for this species. In Oman, trawling was banned in 2011 and as this is the main gear that captures this species in that area, the population is suspected to have been stable for at least the past two generation lengths (10 years). In Pakistan, the use of demersal-set gillnets targeting rays has almost doubled in the last five years due to increasing demand for stingray wings in Thailand and Malaysia. Annual landings of rays was reported to be 42,000 t in 1979, 41,230 t in 1980, and 20,780 t in 1999 which reduced to 3,723 t in 2019; landings were mainly from targeted gillnet fisheries and bycatch of other fisheries, primarily trawls (M. Khan pers. comm. 18 August 2020). There has been a ~30% decrease in trawl catches of the Spottail Sleeper Ray over the past 15 years (three generation lengths) (M. Khan pers. comm. 12 December 2020).

The population is suspected to have declined off India due to overall declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing. For example, the annual average catch of rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990–2004 was 502 t. During this period trawler hours doubled, and consequently, the catch rate declined by 63% from 0.65 kg/hr in 1990 to 0.24 kg/hr in 2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009). This is approximately a 66% decline over a period of three generation lengths of the Spottail Sleeper Ray (15 years). Although this information is not species-specific, and electric rays are generally discarded at sea (with low survivorship), this provides an indication of overall batoid declines as a result of heavy and increasing fishing pressure on the continental shelf in India.

In Thailand, landings data are available on all combined ray species from the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) for 1998–2018 (Krajangdara 2019). The landings data showed an 89% reduction over 16 years from 2003 to 2018. Catches rose steadily from 1998 to a peak catch of 18,131 t in 2003 followed by a steady decline in catches to ~2000 t in 2018 (Krajangdara 2019). It is difficult to infer a population trend as the decline in catches from 2003 to 2018 coincided with a decline in fishing effort. In Taiwan, a regional congener, the Japanese Sleeper Ray (Narke japonica) has changed little in abundance at landing sites over the past 10–15 years (see the Japanese Sleeper Ray Red List assessment). Landings data on all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan EEZ indicate an 80% decrease over 49 years from 1953 to 2001. The annual landings rose from 560 t in 1953 to a peak of 1,800 t in 1973, then declined steadily to the 114 t in 2001 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/8/2019). Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort have increased substantially since the 1950s, and these declines can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations.

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Malaysia, Cambodia, Viet Nam, China, South Korea, and Japan EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In west coast Peninsular Malaysia, reconstructed landings showed a 54% decline from a peak of 19,308 t in 1979 to 8,902 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing pressure has been increasing since the 1950s and thus these declines infer reductions in these populations in west coast of Peninsular Malaysia. In Cambodia, reconstructed landings showed a 91% reduction over 12 years from 2003 to 2014. Catches rose steeply from 1950 to a peak of 4,550 t in 1970, dropped sharply then rose over two decades to another peak catch of 3,914 t in 2003 followed by a sharp decline in catches to 335 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings of sharks and rays can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort was increasing during the period of a decline in landings (Teh et al. 2014a, Pauly et al. 2020). In Viet Nam, reconstructed landings data showed a 97% decline in landings over 29 years from 1986 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 1,560 t in 1950 to ~44,000 t per year in the mid-1960s, fluctuated and then rose steeply during the early-1980s to a peak of 466,445 t in 1986 followed by a fairly steady decline to 14,750 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and was increasing during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

In China, the reconstructed landings showed a 67% decline in landings over the 65 years (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite attempts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort has increased during this period (Anticamara et al. 2011). In Japan, the reconstructed catch data showed a 98% decline in landings from 1950 to 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Japan, this decline was from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ.

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (15 years) of the Spottail Sleeper Ray they represent declines of 30%, 66%, 28%, 97%, 84%, 39%, 23%, 68% and 65% in Pakistan, India, Malaysia, Cambodia, Viet Nam, Taiwan, China, South Korea, and Japan, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in rays in the region. Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Spottail Sleeper Ray, yet the abundance of a regional congener, the Japanese Sleeper Ray, has changed little in Taiwan over the past 10–15 years suggesting these sleeper rays may have some resilience to fishing pressure. Trawl, inshore, and seasonal fishing bans in Oman, Taiwan, and China may provide some refuge from fishing pressure. Overall, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (15 years).
range: The Spottail Sleeper Ray occurs in the Indian, Western Central, and Northwest Pacific Oceans from Oman to Japan including Pakistan, India, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, Cambodia, Viet Nam, China, Taiwan, and North and South Korea (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Sleeper rays in general, and also this species, are usually not used for human consumption as there is very little meat on the animals (Last et al. 2016). In China and Taiwan, this species is retained and sometimes discarded at the markets and sometimes used for fish meal (J. Zhang and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28 August 2019). In Malaysia, and for small individuals in Cambodia, the species is used for 'trash fish' (A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020), that is, for fish meal and other products. In Viet Nam, this species is likely used to produce fish meal and fish sauce (FAO 2020).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. Oman has banned trawling in its waters since 2011. In Indonesia in 1980, trawls were banned, however, large numbers of mini or baby trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In 2015, an additional ban on seine nets (Cantrang) was to be fully implemented in February 2020 (Ambari 2019). There are currently plans in place to lift both these bans in the near future, where the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) plan will allow the operation of the fishing gear with restrictions on the area of fishing pressure (Dharmadi pers. comm. 6 May 2020). Throughout Indonesia there are 196 Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) making up 239,428 km2 and in Malaysia there are 51 MPAs making up 5,462 km². Although these areas may provide some refuge to the inshore component of this species range (CTI 2020), most MPAs in the region are not well enforced and unlikely to provide any tangible relief from fishing pressure.

In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the South China Sea to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28 August 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28 August 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). It is estimated that ~20% of the Chinese coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). In Taiwan, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In Taiwan, there are ~32 Protected Areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Burmese Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium burmensis) is a small (to 58 cm total length) shark that occurs in the Eastern Indian Ocean from Odisha, India to Myanmar. It inhabits shallow coastal inshore and rocky habitats from the surface to 30 m. The species is taken as a bycatch of a range of artisanal and industrial gears including demersal trawl, longline, and gillnet and is retained for human consumption. Reconstructed catch data of all sharks, skates, and rays from the Bangladesh Exclusive Economic Zone indicate a decline of 41% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) of the Burmese Bambooshark. Further, a population reduction of 31% was inferred for the Burmese Bambooshark based on a 50% decrease in fisheries-independent research survey catch rate of elasmobranchs (all species combined) between 1978–80 and 2013 in Myanmar. These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline of elasmobranchs in the region. This species occurs regularly in landings in West Bengal, however, it is an inshore species subject to intense fishing pressure across its range though it may have some possible refuge in rocky reef habitats. The relative proportion of bamboosharks in shark landings has increased over recent decades in the region, which may be in response to the overfishing of large sharks resulting in meso-predator release of the Burmese Bambooshark. Alternatively, the increase in landings may imply some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Burmese Bambooshark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (18 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Burmese Bambooshark occurs in shallow inshore habitats including intertidal pools, rocky and coral reefs, and on soft sediments from the surface to depths of 30 m, with most of the distribution between 5–15 m (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). This species reaches a maximum size of 57.5 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is presumed to be oviparous. Bamboosharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Whitespotted Bambooshark (Chiloscyllium plagiosum) which has an age-at-maturity of 4.5 years and maximum age of 14, resulting in a generation length of 9 years (Chen et al. 2007). The Whitespotted Bambooshark is larger than the Burmese Bambooshark (95 cm vs 57.5 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 6 years for the Burmese Bambooshark.
threats:
The Burmese Bambooshark is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is regularly taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including by demersal inshore trawl, gillnet and line, and retained for human consumption (SEAFDEC 2016, Psomadakis et al. 2020). Fishing effort and power has been increasing in the Asian region and is generally unregulated and unmanaged (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013).

In India, this species is commonly found in landings in West Bengal (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). In the Bay of Bengal, India has an intensive fishing fleet of trawlers and gillnetters throughout the region (>23,000; K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). In India, shark fisheries peaked in the 1980s as the demand for meat and fins grew across southeast Asia (Karnad et al. 2019). There is high level of fisheries exploitation with most stocks fully exploited (FAO 2020). There were about 6,600 trawlers operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). Trawling is also intense elsewhere with 3,678 trawlers in Kerala and 5,767 trawlers in Tamil Nadu waters, with severe declines in fish stocks, including elasmobranchs (Raje et al. 2002, Mohanraj et al. 2009, CMFRI 2010, Karnad et al. 2014).

Bangladesh has a substantial artisanal fishing fleet that has been increasing in recent decades with 67,669 vessels reported to be operating in 2017–2018 (DoF 2018, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal fishing fleet operates at depths of 0–40 m on average (Hoq et al. 2014). Artisanal shark landings have increased from 2,000 t in 1986 to 6,234 t in 2001 (Ullah et al. 2014). Industrial shark landings have increased three-fold from 400 t in 1986 to 1,247 in 2001 (Ullah et al. 2014). Sharks and rays are captured by a wide range of gears in Myanmar. Since 2004 sharks are largely taken as incidental catch in coastal gillnets, trawls (for fish or shrimp), longlines targeting mackerels, and hookah divers spearing at night (mostly catching rays and carpet sharks) (Howard et al. 2015, Mizrahi et al. 2020). The International Labour Organisation (2015) estimated of the number of vessels participating in the small-scale inshore fishery to be about 26,000 in 2013, with about 50% of them unpowered. The number of locally operated larger offshore vessels numbered 2,846 in 2013, having increased nearly 30% since 2009. Foreign fishing vessels numbered 153 in 2013, but had historically been much higher. Foreign vessels were banned in 2014. An indirect threat is the loss and degradation of habitats such as coastal mangroves. Southeast Asia has seen an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2010).
population:
There is no species-specific trend information for the Burmese Bambooshark. Monitoring of fish landing sites in Southeast Asia revealed that the relative proportion of bamboosharks in shark landings has increased significantly over recent decades due to declines in large sharks and increased targeting and retention of the remaining smaller species (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011, Lack and Sant 2012, Arunrugstichai et al. 2018). In India, market surveys during 2009–2019 in West Bengal recorded a range of 8–52 individuals in a single day of landings (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020). Population declines are inferred from intensive trawling in shallow depth areas in the eastern Indian Ocean. 

Despite the lack of species-specific trend data elsewhere, catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Bangladesh Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In Bangladesh, reconstructed landings data showed a 34% decline over 15 years from 2000 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 195 t in 1950 to 7,540 t in 1973 then declined to 3,500 t in the mid-1980s, then rose steeply to a peak of 10,909 t in 2000 followed by a fluctuating decline to 7,163 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent population declines, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This decline in landings is equivalent to a population reduction of 41% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) of the Burmese Bambooshark. This level of decline is not species-specific but is informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region.

In Myanmar, estimates of shark and ray landings, from 1950 to the late 1990s, varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t annually with no substantial trend. From the late 1990s to 2014 landings increased to around 40,000 t per year which was concurrent with an increase in fishing effort (Pauly et al. 2020). This infers there has been no significant reduction in the shark and ray populations as landings have increased as effort has increased. However, surveys in recent years have revealed reductions in some shark and ray populations (San San Khine 2010, Krakstad et al. 2014). Trawl surveys by the Norwegian research vessel Dr Fridtjof Nansen revealed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs over the 33 years between surveys in 1978–80 and 2013 and a shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species (Krakstad et al. 2014). This equates to a population reduction of 31% over the past three generations (18 years). Market surveys reveal a decline in landings 49% over a four-year period (2006–2010) despite no reduction in fishing effort and increasing domination by small short-lived species (San San Khine 2010).

Reconstructed catch data scaled to three generation lengths (18 years) from Bangladesh and scaled survey data from Myanmar, represent population reductions of 41% and 31%, respectively. The relative proportion of bamboosharks in shark landings has increased significantly over recent decades in the region and the Burmese Bambooshark may have benefited from meso-predator release due to the overfishing of large sharks. It is occurring regularly in landings in West Bengal. However, it is an inshore species subject to intense fishing pressure across its range with some possible refuge in rocky reef habitats. Overall, it is suspected that the Burmese Bambooshark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (18 years).
range: The Burmese Bambooshark occurs in the Eastern Indian Ocean from India to Myanmar (Ebert et al. 2013, Haque et al. 2019, K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: The species is used for its low-value meat for local consumption (SEAFDEC 2016). In Bangladesh, species of the genus Chiloscyllium are often landed and sold to crocodile farmers as animal feed (A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures currently in place. In Myanmar, two shark reserves were designated in the Myeik Archipelago in 2004 where targeting sharks and rays is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban, sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of the ban in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 02/04/2020). Research is required to better define the population size and trends, and life history of the Burmese Bambooshark, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Yantai Stingray (Hemitrygon laevigata) is a small (37 cm disc width) ray endemic to the Northwest Pacific in southern Japan and China; its presence in Taiwan is uncertain. It is an inshore species on the continental shelf to a depth of 60 m. The species is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and seine nets, and is retained for human consumption and probably fish meal. It was considered common in Japan and China prior to the 2000s and landings data based on reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the Japan and China Exclusive Economic Zones indicate declines of 92% and 46%, respectively over the past three generation lengths (36 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the Chinese range of the species, and it has possibly become extinct or at least severely depleted over the past one generation length (12 years) in the northern part of its Chinese distribution. Dramatic levels of habitat loss across the Chinese range are a threat to the species. The level of fisheries threat in Japan has significantly decreased and continuing to decline since the early 2000s when this species was still considered common in southern Japan, and it is possibly still common in southern Japan which accounts for a large part of its distribution. Overall, it is inferred that the Yantai Stingray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years) due levels of exploitation and a decline in quality of habitat, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cd.
habitat: The Yantai Stingray is demersal on soft-sediment habitats and occurs inshore on the continental shelf to depths of 60 m (Last et al. 2016b). Juveniles are present in estuaries and coastal shallow waters in summer (Last et al. 2016b). It reaches a maximum size of 37 cm disc width (DW) (~76 cm total length; TL), males mature at 21.8 cm DW (42.9 cm TL) and females mature at~30 cm DW (~59 cm TL) (Furumitsu et al. 2010, Last et al. 2016b). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from the related and similar-sized maskray complex (Neotrygon spp.) that have a verified female age-at-maturity of 6.5 years and a maximum age of 17 years, resulting in a generation length of 12 years (Jacobsen and Bennett 2010; as 'Neotrygon kuhlii').
threats:
The Yantai Stingray is subject to fishing pressure across its spatial range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including trawl, and probably set net and gillnet, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal (Zhu and Meng 2001, Ishihara et al. 2016).

There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the Chinese range of the Yantai Stingray. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, MacKinnon et al. 2012, Liang and Pauly 2017). The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019).

Inshore coastal fisheries resources across China have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding 30 years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear.

In response to fish stock depletions, the Chinese national government introduced measures in the 1980s and 1990s, that have since been modified, to reduce inshore fishing effort, including a ban on motorized trawling in close inshore waters, annual closed seasons, gear regulations such as a minimum mesh size, vessel buybacks, and fishing vessel scrapping (Yu and Yu 2008, Rueter et al. 2019). However, non-compliance with these measures is high and fishing effort continues to increase, and in some areas, move offshore in response to declining inshore catches (Yu and Yu 2008, Villasante et al. 2013, FAO 2019a, Pauly and Liang 2019). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China as one of the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6 percent annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however they began to decline in the 1980s–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000 to 232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019b). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013 it is higher than that of neighbouring China (Helgil 2019).

In Japan, demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people move into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019b, S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka pers. comm. 01 September 2019).

Dramatic levels of habitat loss in the Chinese part of the distribution pose a threat. In the Yellow Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s and 65% loss of tidal flats (one type of intertidal habitat) since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In both the East and South China Seas, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands, with a loss of 70% of mangroves in the last 70 years in the South China Sea, where there has also been modification of up to 50% of seagrass beds and degradation of significant areas of coral reef habitat (Heileman and Tang 2009, Heileman 2009).
population:
The Yantai Stingray was noted as common in southern Japan and China in the early 2000s (Zhu and Meng 2001, Furumitsu et al. 2006). In Japan, the species has been confused with Red Stingray (Hemitrygon akajei), making it difficult to assess population trends (Ishihara et al. 2016). In China, by the mid-2000s it was noted that it was infrequently observed and as it had been historically common in fish markets, a population decline was suspected (Ishihara et al. 2016). It has not been observed in recent genetic sampling of rays from fish markets in Chinese waters of the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019), which raises the possibility of local extinction or at least severe population decline.

Despite the lack of species-specific data, catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Japan and China Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs), based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Japan, the reconstructed catch data showed a 98% decline in landings of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ over 65 years, that is from around 1,300 t annually in the early 1950s to around 14 t annually from 2010 to 2014. Some of the decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of sharks, rays, and skates in the Japan EEZ.


In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline in landings over 65 years (Zeller and Pauly 2016). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller-sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Yantai Stingray (36 years), they represent declines of 92% and 46% in Japan and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline of batoids in the region.

Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the Chinese spatial and depth range of the Yantai Stingray, and habitat loss in China is a threat to the species. It has possibly become extinct or at least been severely depleted over the past one generation length (12 years) in the northern part of its Chinese distribution, although if still present, seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species some refuge. The level of fisheries threat in Japan has markedly decreased and continues to decline since the early 2000s when this species was still considered common in southern Japan. Overall, the species is inferred to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (36 years). Further research is required across its northern China distribution to confirm or refute the possibility of local extinction in that area.
range: The Yantai Stingray is endemic to the Northwest Pacific, occurring in southern Japan and China from Yantai in the north to central China; its presence in Taiwan is uncertain (Zhu and Meng 2001, Last et al. 2016b, D. Ebert and H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).
useTrade: The species is used for human consumption and possibly fish meal.
conservationActions:
This species is regionally listed as Vulnerable in China (Wang and Xie 2004). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the Yellow Sea, East China Sea, and in the South China Sea to 12⁰N (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). Some of the species' range may be protected along the China coastline as it is estimated that ~20% of the coastline is included in protected areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012). 

In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). 

Research is required on the species' current presence and status in northern Chinese waters and life history, and catches and population trends of the Yantai Stingray should be closely monitored.

rationale: The Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray (Benthobatis yangi) is a small (to 37 cm total length) numbfish endemic to southwest Taiwan in the Northwest Pacific. It is demersal on the upper continental slope at depths of 300–500 m. The species is a bycatch of demersal trawl fisheries and is discarded due to its small size and flesh that is unsuitable for human consumption or fish meal. Post-release survival is not known for any numbfish species. The trawl fisheries use small mesh sizes and have been intensive for a considerable time. Standardised catch rates of all rays have fluctuated greatly but remained fairly stable in southwest Taiwan over 17 years from 1997–2013. Landings of all skates combined across the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone have declined by 39% over the past three generation lengths (15 years). The Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray has a restricted distribution that is intensively fished across its entire spatial and depth range. This is of concern and with a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the population has declined rather than remained stable due to the high levels of intensive fishing to which the species is exposed. It is inferred that the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (15 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray is demersal on the upper continental slope at depths of 300–500 m (Last et al. 2016, H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). It reaches a maximum size of 37.1 cm total length (TL); males mature at 16–22 cm TL and female first size-at-maturity is unknown but a 25.7 cm female TL was assumed to be mature (Carvalho et al. 2003, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology (Last et al. 2016). Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from the only species of numbfish with age data, the Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor) that has a female age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 15 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). The Cortez Numbfish is larger than the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray (75 vs 37 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 5 years for the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray. This is an estimate only and research is required on the age parameters of this species.
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch by demersal trawl fisheries but discarded due to its small size and high water content in the flesh that make it unsuitable for human consumption or fish meal (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). Post-release survival is unknown for numbfish (Ellis et al. 2017). Fisheries on the Taiwan southwest coast are mainly shallow and coastal, but may range down to 700 m depth (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). The deeper water trawl fishery targets multiple species of deep-water shrimp, uses small mesh sizes, and has been intensive for a considerable time (D. Ebert and H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989 at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283 to 239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273 to 12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The demand for seafood has always been high and is suspected to continue to be high in Taiwan with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Fabinyi and Liu 2014, Helgil 2019).
population:
In southwest Taiwan, an average of 10–20 Taiwanese Blind Electric Rays are observed in some trawls (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). There is no information on whether this level of catch has changed over time.

There is no species-specific catch data for this species. However, there is data from southwest Taiwan on the combined standardised catch rate of all ray species taken by bottom trawl. This catch rate fluctuated greatly but was fairly stable over 17 years from 1997 to 2013 (H. Hsu, Taiwan Fisheries Institute unpubl. data 2019). Landings data are also available on all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort have increased substantially since the 1950s, despite attempts by the Taiwan government to restrict effort in response to depletion of fisheries resources. Since the 1990s, industrial effort has declined, however there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort.

The landings of all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries decreased by 80% over 49 years from 1953 to 2001. The annual landings rose from 560 t tonne in 1953 to a peak of 1,800 t in 1973, then declined steadily to the 114 t in 2001 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). These long-term declines in abundance of skates can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. When the level of decline is scaled to three generation lengths (15 years) of the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray, it represents a 39% decline in abundance. This decline is not species-specific but is informative for understanding the broader levels of population trends of skates in the area.

Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the entire range of the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray. It is not abundant in trawls and there is no species-specific information on changes in abundance over time. Catches of all species of rays combined have been relatively stable over the past 17 years (slightly more than three generation lengths), yet there has been an overall decline of 39% in skates over three generation lengths (15 years). The Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray has a restricted distribution that is intensively fished across its entire spatial and depth range. This is of concern and with a precautionary approach, it is suspected that the population has declined rather than remained stable due to the high levels of intensive fishing to which the species is exposed. Thus, it is inferred that the species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (15 years).
range: The Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray is endemic to southwest Taiwan in the Northwest Pacific (Zhu and Meng 2001, Last et al. 2016). It may occur in the Philippines, where one specimen has been reported, although confirmation of identification is required (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019).
useTrade: The species is sometimes consumed by fishers at sea, but is not retained or brought ashore to trade for human consumption (H. Hsu unpubl. data 2019). It is not suitable for fish meal as the flesh has a high water content (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. However, since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within three nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Research is required to better define the life history of the Taiwanese Blind Electric Ray, and population size and trends, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Japanese Butterfly Ray (Gymnura japonica) is a medium-sized (to at least 145 cm disc width, and possibly to 180 cm DW) ray endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Japan to Taiwan. It is demersal, inshore and shallow water species, occurring at depths of 0–27 m, and possibly to 108 m. The species is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and set net, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal in Taiwan and China and discarded in Japan, and possibly South Korea.

Catches of skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), landings data of all skates combined from the Taiwan EEZ, and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the South Korea and China EEZs indicate declines of 49–95% over the past three generation lengths (39 years). These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species’ entire range. The population is stable in parts of Japan, which indicates some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Japanese Butterfly Ray has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (39 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Japanese Butterfly Ray is demersal on sandy and muddy substrates inshore at depths of 0–27 m (Weigmann 2016), possibly to 180 m depth in Japan (Nakabo 2013). It reaches a maximum size of at least 145 cm disc width (DW), and possibly to 180 cm DW, male and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Nakabo 2013, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is viviparous with litter sizes of 2–8 pups and size-at-birth of 12 cm total length (Yamada et al. 2007, Last et al. 2016). Nothing else is known of its biology. The generation length is inferred from the two butterfly ray species with age parameters, the Backwater Butterfly Ray (G. natalensis) and Spiny Butterfly Ray (G. altavela) which have female ages-at-maturity of 6 years and 5 years and maximum ages of 24 years and 18 years, resulting in generation lengths of 15 years and 11.5 years, respectively (van der Elst 1988, Parsons et al. 2017). Thus, the generation length of the Japanese Butterfly Ray is inferred as 13 years. This should be used with caution as the two butterfly rays are much larger (250 cm DW and 260 cm DW) than the Japanese Butterfly Ray (145 cm DW).
threats:
The Japanese Butterfly Ray is subject to fishing pressure across its entire spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including demersal trawl, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption or fish meal in Taiwan and China, and discarded in Japan and possibly South Korea. At-vessel mortality of butterfly rays is 41–46% in trawl fisheries with post-release mortality unknown (Ellis et al. 2017).

There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Japanese Butterfly Ray. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however, they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people moving into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019a). 

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China one of the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Helgil 2019b).

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation with dramatic levels of habitat loss evident in the region. In the Yellow Sea and the Bohai Sea, intensive coastal development, that includes ongoing land reclamation, has led to widespread and significant loss of 35% of all intertidal habitat since the 1980s with 65% loss of tidal flats since the 1950s (Murray et al. 2014). In the East China Sea, reclamation has contributed to a dramatic reduction in coastal and mangrove wetlands (Heileman and Tang 2009).
population:
There are no species-specific population trend data for this species. It was previously reported as locally common with population declines in Japan and China (Ishihara et al. 2009). In Japan, set net catches of this species in Suruga Bay and trawl catches in Ariake Bay showed low but stable catches, that is, 100 individuals were captured over 40 years in Suruga Bay and from 1993 to 2007 the catch rates were stable (S. Tanaka and A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). It is infrequently captured in Taiwan and South Korea (Ebert et al. 2013, C.-H. Jeong unpubl. data 2019).

In Japan, the catch of all skates and rays combined from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ).
