In Taiwan, landings data are available on all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the EEZ. The landings decreased by 80% over 49 years from 1953 to 2001. The annual landings rose from 560 t in 1953 to a peak of 1,800 t in 1973, then declined steadily to the 114 t in 2001 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). These long-term declines in abundance of skates can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. In southwest Taiwan, the combined standardised catch rate of all ray species taken by bottom trawl fluctuated greatly but was fairly stable over 17 years from 1997 to 2013 (H. Hsu Taiwan Fisheries Institute pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea and China EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (39 years), they represent declines of 78%, 73%, 95%, and 49% in Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, and China, respectively. These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the spatial and depth range of the Japanese Butterfly Ray. Yet, the catches were stable in parts of Japan over 14 years, which indicates that the species likely has some resilience to fishing pressure. Inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China and Taiwan may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (39 years).
range: The Japanese Butterfly Ray is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from Japan to Taiwan, including North and South Korea, and China (Yamada et al. 2007, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The low-value meat is used for human consumption and fish meal.
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that includes total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial bottom trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). Trawling is banned all year round in the Bohai Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). It may receive some protection in marine protected areas, as it is estimated that ~20% of the Chinese coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). This species may be protected in the ~32 Protected Areas which cover ~38% of the Taiwan coastline and ~47% of Taiwan territorial seas, with no-entry and no-take areas accounting for 0.9% and 4.6% of the territorial seas, respectively (MacKinnon et al. 2012, Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Sharpspine Skate (Okamejei acutispina) is a small (to 45 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan to Taiwan. It is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 20–175 m. This skate is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and set nets, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal.

Catches of skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), landings data of all skates combined from the Taiwan EEZ, and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the South Korea and China EEZs indicate declines of 41–95% over the past three generation lengths (31 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species’ entire range. It is common and abundant in Taiwan, which indicates some resilience to fishing pressure, although it was considered to be at the optimal margin of exploitation in northeast Taiwan ten years ago. It is suspected that the Sharpspine Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (31 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Sharpspine Skate is demersal on sand and mud habitats of the continental shelf at depths of 20–175 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 45 cm total length, males mature at 24 cm TL and females mature at 38 cm TL (Chang 2008, Joung et al. 2011, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous and egg cases are laid year-round with the peak from October to March (Chang 2008). Female age-at-maturity is 7.2 years and maximum age is 13.2 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.2 years (Joung et al. 2011).
threats:
The Sharpspine Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its entire spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including trawl, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption or fish meal. There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Sharpspine Skate. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however, fishing effort began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people moving into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019a). 

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s, when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China one of the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the EEZ, and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28 August 2019). In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Helgil 2019b).
population:
This is one of the most abundant and common bycatch species of skate from the trawl fisheries in northeast and southwest Taiwan (Joung et al. 2011, Ebert et al. 2013). However, it was considered at the margin of optimal exploitation ten years ago in northeast Taiwan based on its life history and exploitation rate (Joung et al. 2011). Elsewhere, there are no species-specific data on this species.

In Japan, the catch of skates and rays from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea, which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some of the decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort, which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone.

In Taiwan, landings data are available on all combined skate species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the EEZ. The landings decreased by 80% over 49 years from 1953 to 2001. The annual landings rose from 560 t in 1953 to a peak of 1,800 t in 1973, then declined steadily to the 114 t in 2001 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics pers. comm. 28/08/2019). These long-term declines in abundance of skates can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. An increase in ray landings from trawl catches in Da-Xi, northeast Taiwan from 1993 to 2006 (Lee 2008) is likely a reflection of an increase in reporting of the ray catch over that period, rather than an actual increase in abundance (H. Hans and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019).

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea and China EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (31 years), they represent declines of 70%, 95%, 91%, and 41% in Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the entire spatial and depth range of the Sharpspine Skate. Yet, the species is reported as common and abundant in Taiwan. This indicates that this skate likely has some resilience to fishing pressure, although it was considered at the optimal margin of exploitation ten years ago in northeast Taiwan. Inshore and seasonal trawl bans in China and Taiwan may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the Sharpspine Skate is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (31 years).
range: The Sharpspine Skate is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Japan to Taiwan, including North and South Korea, and China (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is of low value in Taiwan where it is used for fishmeal (Joung et al. 2011). The dried 'wings' are eaten and processed into fishcakes in Japan (Ishihara et al. 2009).
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that include total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28 August 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28 August 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable, as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019).

In Taiwan, there is a prohibition on using any net fishing gear (e.g. trawls, seine nets) in 68 reef areas (Fisheries Agency 2019). Since 1999, all demersal trawling is prohibited within 3 nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Since the mid–2000s, gillnets have been banned within 3 nm in parts of five counties with a policy of gradual removal of gillnets from within 3 nm of the entire coast and government assistance to transition to line and troll fishing (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Whitetip Weasel Shark (Paragaleus leucolomatus) is a small (to 96 cm total length) slender coastal shark that occurs in the Western Indian Ocean and is known from South Africa (records from the 1980s), Mozambique (recorded in 2007), Madagascar (records from the 1960s), and Yemen (a recent record which may represent an outlier). It has a limited depth range from the surface down to 20 m. With only two pups per litter, it is suspected to have limited biological productivity. This species is known from very few specimens and there are no population trend estimates. Similar to other weasel sharks, this species may be targeted and taken as bycatch in artisanal and commercial inshore fisheries, and retained for human consumption. Despite considerable fisheries research surveys in the region and the distinctive markings of the species, it has rarely been recorded. Its limited South African range is within the iSimangaliso Marine Protected Area (MPA), and although extremely rare, it is suspected that the South African portion of the range offers some refuge (although there is an urgent need to confirm its status there). In contrast, the extensive inshore artisanal fisheries elsewhere (e.g. Mozambique, Madagascar) are suspected to have driven a population reduction (particularly given the species' restricted depth range and low biological productivity). Balancing these contrasting situations, it is suspected that the Whitetip Weasel Shark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (26 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Whitetip Weasel Shark is a slender shark that inhabits shallow coastal waters to a depth of 20 m (Weigmann 2016). The largest known specimen is 96 cm total length (TL) (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is placental viviparous with litter sizes of 2 pups (Ebert et al. 2013). The small litter size infers this species may have limited biological productivity. Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown and there is no such data from a congener, but it is available from a member of the same family, the Snaggletooth Shark (Hemipristis elongata) that also occurs along the east African coastline with an age-at-maturity of 2.5 years and maximum age of 14.7 years (Last and Stevens 2009, Smart et al. 2013), resulting in a generation length of 8.6 years. However, the Snaggletooth Shark reaches a considerably larger size than the Whitetip Weasel Shark (240 cm vs 96 cm TL) and therefore the generation length of the Whitetip Weasel Shark is likely to be shorter in reality.
threats: Similar to other weasel sharks, the Whitetip Weasel Shark is possibly targeted and taken as bycatch in artisanal and small commercial inshore fisheries within its range, and retained for human consumption (White et al. 2006, Ebert et al. 2013). While the full extent of this species' distribution is currently unknown, extensive artisanal fisheries operate in coastal waters of the southwestern Indian Ocean (Le Manach et al. 2012, Benkenstein 2013, da Silva et al. 2015, Cripps et al. 2015). Data are needed on the level of fisheries interactions with this species.
population: The Whitetip Weasel Shark is known from very few specimens and there are no population size or trend estimates. Although its previous abundance is unknown, the rarity of specimens of a species inhabiting shallow, coastal waters to 20 m depth is cause for concern, particularly with the presence of heavy fishing pressure over most of its range. It has been noted in the Gulf of Aden in recent years, Mozambique in 2007, South Africa in the 1980s, and Madagascar in the 1960s. This species may be overlooked in landings and recorded as other similar-looking shark species in commercial fisheries data. However, it is unlikely that this species would be misidentified in the extensive fisheries research surveys in the region during which this species was not found (da Silva et al. 2015, Le Manach and Pauly 2015), as it has distinctive fin markings (Compagno and Smale 1985). Reports indicate that shark resources in the Gulf of Aden, particularly off Yemen (including the Socotra Archipelago) were already showing signs of depletion over 15 years ago (PERSGA 2002). Overall, due to heavy fishing pressure across much of its range and few records of its occurrence, along with potentially low biological productivity and inferred high susceptibility to fisheries, balanced with some potential refuge in South Africa, it is suspected that this species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (26 years).
range: The Whitetip Weasel Shark occurs in the Western Indian Ocean; known specimens are from Kosi Bay, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa (Compagno and Smale 1985), Nosy Be and Nosy Iranja, Madagascar (Fourmanoir 1961 cited in Compagno and Smale 1985), central Mozambique (D. Ebert and E. Heemstra, unpubl. data based on photographs, 2007), and the Gulf of Aden (Yemen) (I. Elhassan, pers. comm., 4 July 2019). The occurrence of this species between Mozambique and Yemen is uncertain.
useTrade: The utilization of the Whitetip Weasel Shark is not known, but similar to other weasel sharks, it is likely retained for subsistence use locally if taken in artisanal fisheries (e.g. White et al. 2006).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species. Recreational anglers in South Africa are restricted to one shark per species per day (maximum of 10 individuals per day) (da Silva et al. 2015), although enforcement is an ongoing issue. Its limited South African range is within the iSimangaliso Marine Protected Area (MPA), and it possibly occurs in other reserves, such as South Africa's uThukela MPA to the south, and Mozambique's Ponta do Ouro Partial Marine Reserve to the north. Further research is required on distribution, population size and trends, life history, and catch rates.

rationale:
The Spiny Skate (Okamejei kenojei) is a small (to 55 cm total length) skate endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Russia to China. It is demersal on the continental shelf at depths of 20–230 m, mainly at 30–100 m. The species is a bycatch of multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and set nets, and is retained for human consumption and fish meal.

Previously, this species was reported as common across its range with one local disappearance reported since then, from Ariake Bay in Japan. Catches of skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and reconstructed catches of all sharks, rays, and skates from the South Korea and China EEZs indicate declines of 30–80% over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species’ entire range. It is a highly productive species in captivity which may be similar in the wild and would provide some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Spiny Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Spiny Skate is demersal on sand and mud habitats of the continental shelf at depths of 20–230 m, though mainly at 30–100 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 55 cm total length (TL), males mature at 35 cm TL and females mature at 39 cm TL (Ishihara et al. 2002, Ishihara et al. 2009, Nakabo 2013, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous and egg cases are laid year-round with size-at-birth of 8.2 cm TL (Ishihara et al. 2002). In captivity, the observed fecundity of three females was high at 42–103 egg capsules laid per year (Ishihara et al. 2002). In captivity, female age-at-maturity is 3.2–3.5 years and maximum age is ~10–11 years (Ishihara et al. 2002), resulting in a generation length of 6.9 years.
threats:
The Spiny Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its entire spatial and depth range. It is taken as target in South Korea and bycatch elsewhere in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including demersal trawl, longline, set net, and gillnet, and retained for human consumption or fish meal (Ishihara et al. 2009). There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Spiny Skate. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017).

In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however, they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and a lack of young people moving into the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high; at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013, the demand is higher than that of neighbouring China (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019). 

In South Korea, fishing effort has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). It increased markedly from the 1970s and in the 1990s when the number of fishing boats increased to 75,000 in 1996 and 81,000 in 1997, of which 70% were operating within Korean EEZ (Shon et al. 2014). Many commercially important stocks rapidly became overfished and in response, the government decommissioned 16,800 boats by 2008, of which 10,400 were coastal boats (Shon et al. 2014).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive bottom trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding thirty years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for seafood in China is high and increasing, with China one of the largest consumers of seafood products globally; a 6% annual increase per capita fish consumption was evident from 1990 to 2010 (Fabinyi and Liu 2014).
population:
The Spiny Skate was previously reported as common (Ishihara et al. 2009), though there are no species-specific trend data prior to or post-2009 other than in Japan, where this species is no longer captured in Ariake Bay (A. Yamaguchi unpubl. data 2019). The catch of skates and rays in the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea, which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort, which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan EEZ.

Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the South Korea and China EEZs, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). In South Korea, the reconstructed catch data showed a 97% decline in landings over 46 years from 1969 to 2014. There were minimal catches during 1950 that then rose steeply during the mid-1960s to a peak of 8,900 t followed by a steady decline to 294 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing effort in South Korea has increased by about one-quarter since the 1950s (Anticamara et al. 2011). In China, the reconstructed catch data showed a 67% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to demersal trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths (21 years), they represent declines of 56%, 80%, and 30% in Japan, South Korea, and China, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the entire spatial and depth range of the Spiny Skate. The species has high biological productivity in captivity that may be similar in the wild, which would provide some resilience to fishing pressure. Seasonal trawl bans in China may afford the species some refuge. Overall, the species is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years).
range: The Spiny Skate is endemic to the Northwest Pacific Ocean from southern Russia (Sakhalin Island), Japan, North and South Korea, and China. Records from Taiwan need confirmation (Ebert et al. 2013, Last et al. 2016, Dyldin and Orlov 2018).
useTrade: This species is of low value in China and Taiwan where it is used for fishmeal. The dried 'wings' are eaten and processed into fishcakes in Japan (Ishihara et al. 2009).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that includes total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015). In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the Yellow Sea and East China Sea (Yu and Yu 2008). In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen pers. comm. 28/08/2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate (Bathyraja irrasa) is a medium-sized (to 140 cm total length) deep-water skate that occurs in the Southern Indian Ocean, and is likely endemic to the Kerguelen Islands (France) and Heard and McDonald Islands (Australia). It is reported from insular slopes at depths of 300–1,220 m. The species is caught incidentally in demersal trawl and longline fisheries off Heard Island and McDonald Islands, and in demersal longline fisheries targeting Patagonian Toothfish (Dissostichus eleginoides) on the Kerguelen Plateau. The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is managed collectively with all other skates and rays in longline and trawl fisheries operating within the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) Convention Area. Fishing is only permitted below 500 m in CCAMLR waters, offering the species some refuge in the shallow part of its depth range. There is high distribution overlap with fishing pressure, decline in part of its range and species-specific management across its entire range. The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate was estimated to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (42 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is demersal on insular slopes at depths of 300–1,220 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 140 cm total length (TL) (Duhamel et al. 2005, Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous. Nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a related species, the Broadnose Skate (Bathyraja brachyurops), which has a female age-at-maturity of 8.2 years and a maximum age of 20 years, resulting in a generation length of 14 years (Arkhipkin et al. 2008).
threats: The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is caught incidentally in demersal trawl and longline fisheries off Heard Island and McDonald Islands, as well as demersal longline fisheries targeting Patagonian Toothfish (Dissostichus eleginoides) on the Kerguelen Plateau (Nowara et al. 2017). These fisheries operate to depths of ~1,800 m; the species accounts for 2–12.5% of the skate trawl catch and 62–97% of the skate longline catch (Nowara et al. 2017). Fisheries on the Kerguelen Plateau were effectively unregulated until 2003, and illegal fisheries were estimated to be three times more abundant than legal fisheries between 1997–2001 (Shust and Koslov 2006, Palomares and Pauly 2011). Management was introduced in 2003 and enforcement of the fisheries reduced Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing from thousands of tonnes to hundreds of tonnes (CCAMLR 2018). Skate catches prior to this enforcement were probably underestimated. There is still some evidence of IUU fishing of the edges of the Kerguelen–Heard Exclusive Economic Zone (Weimerskirch et al. 2020). Previous tagging studies have suggested post-release mortality of sub-Antarctic demersal trawl skates is high (Daley et al. 2008), however, recent risk assessments have indicated skates in the Heard and McDonald Islands fisheries were at low risk of unsustainable fishing (Dell et al. 2017).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from standardized longline catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) in Antarctica (Kerguelen Plateau and Heard and McDonald Islands) between 2006–2014 (Nowara et al. 2017). The trend data were analysed over three generation lengths (42 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of decrease of 1.1% consistent with an estimated decline of 37.4% over three generation lengths (42 years), with the highest probability of no population reduction over the three generation lengths. However, trend analysis also estimated a 28% probability of >50% decline over three generation lengths. Due to estimated declines in the Kerguelen part of its range, high levels of exploitation across all its known distribution, and refuge in the shallow part of its depth range, a global population reduction of 30–49% was estimated over three generation lengths (42 years). Therefore, the Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
range: The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is found in the Antarctic Indian Ocean, and is possibly endemic to the Kerguelen Islands (France) and Heard and McDonald Islands (Australia) (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The species is not known to be utilised.
conservationActions: The Kerguelen Sandpaper Skate is managed collectively with all other skates and rays in longline and trawl fisheries operating within the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR) Convention Area (Sporcic et al. 2018). Fisheries are regulated by a multi-species bycatch limit of 120 t for all "skates and rays" and species-specific bycatch is recorded. Additionally, a move-on-rule is applied if a total of 2 t of skate/ray are caught in one haul and vessels are not permitted to fish within five nautical miles of the location for at least five days. Fishing is only permitted below depths of 500 m in CCAMLR waters, offering the species some refuge in the shallow part of its depth range. When possible, all skates must be released alive, and may only be retained if hauled dead.

rationale: The Pacific Sharpnose Shark (Rhizoprionodon longurio) is a small (to 110 cm total length) requiem shark that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from southern California, USA, to Peru from inshore to 100 m depth. This shark is captured as bycatch in demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries and in teleost traps, and is targeted by artisanal gillnets and longlines throughout much of its range. These fisheries are generally intense in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. There is evidence of a population reduction including an increasing rarity of landings and anecdotal evidence from fishers. Gillnet pressure in the Gulf of California, Mexico, is high and has led to declines in pelagic sharks, and smaller coastal sharks are increasingly targeted without management (or inadequate enforcement of regulations). Shrimp trawling is substantial off southwest Baja California Sur and also off Mazatlan, where declines in catches in other species, overcapacity, and poor governance have been highlighted. Throughout its Central and South American range, the species is subjected to intense fishing pressure. Recent landings surveys in Costa Rica have recorded relatively few individuals, and anecdotal evidence from fishers indicates that they were previously much more common. In Colombia, this species is recorded in artisanal fisheries at lower frequency than the 1990s. Mangrove habitats, which often serve as nursery areas for coastal sharks such as this, have been degraded with the development of shrimp aquaculture in many areas of the Eastern Central Pacific. Although this species has a relativity high biological productivity, a lack of management and enforcement throughout most of its range precludes sustainability. This shark may have some refuge from fishing in southern California and the relatively remote Pacific coast of Baja California. Overall, due to the level of intense and largely unmanaged fisheries operating in its range, its increasing rarity in some areas, and the degradation of coastal mangrove habitats, balanced with some areas of refuge, it is suspected that the Pacific Sharpnose Shark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (15 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2cd.
habitat: The Pacific Sharpnose Shark inhabits the continental shelf from the intertidal zone to 100 m (Amezcua-Linares 1996), and it may utilize mangroves as other sharpnose sharks tend to (Gallo et al. 2010). It reaches a maximum size of 154 cm total length (TL) but is more commonly observed at sizes <120 cm TL (Franke and Acero 1991, Márquez-Farías et al. 2005); females mature at 103 cm TL and males at 58–69 cm TL (Hildebrand 1946, Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is placental viviparous and females give birth to litters of 2–5 young that are 33–34 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Generation length is suspected to be similar to that of the congeneric Atlantic Sharpnose Shark (Rhizoprionodon terranovae) in the Gulf of Mexico at about 5 years (Carlson and Baremore 2003, Loefer and Sedberry 2003).
threats:
The Pacific Sharpnose Shark is captured as bycatch in demersal shrimp and hake trawl fisheries and in teleost traps, and is targeted by artisanal gillnets and longlines. These fisheries are generally intense in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific. Gillnet pressure in the Gulf of California is high and has led to declines in various marine species including pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004). There is a hake trawl fishery in the northeastern Gulf of California that likely captures this species. Shrimp trawling is substantial off southwest Baja California Sur and also off Mazatlan, where declines in catches, overcapacity, and poor governance have been highlighted (Foster and Vincent 2010). In Guatemala, this species is landed commonly with a peak in November that includes neonates (C. Avalos unpubl. data 2019). In Costa Rica and Colombia, shrimp trawl fisheries have declined to the point of being unprofitable, indicating overfishing. In a vulnerability analysis of elasmobranchs in the Costa Rica shrimp trawl fishery, this species was determined to be highly vulnerable (Clarke et al. 2018). These sharks are caught frequently on bottom longlines in Costa Rica. Artisanal net fisheries operate across the species' South American range, and there is little management in place. Mangrove habitats, which often serve as nursery areas for coastal sharks, have been degraded as a result of coastal development and shrimp aquaculture in many areas of the Eastern Central Pacific (López-Angarita et al. 2016).

Although this species is relatively productive and could probably withstand some fishing pressure, a lack of management and enforcement throughout most of its range precludes sustainability, and there is no refuge at depth. This shark may have some refuge from fishing in southern California and the relatively remote Pacific coast of Baja California.
population: In the Gulf of California, this coastal shark was the second most important shark in artisanal landings between 1960 and 2014, with peaks of 3,000 t in the late 1970s and early 1980s and of over 2,000 t in the early 1990s. Since the mid-1990s landings have been between 1,000 and 2,000 t (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2017). Artisanal fisheries there began targeting large predatory sharks in the 1960s, and in the 1970s and 1980s the use of gillnets increased rapidly. After depleting the large predatory sharks, these fisheries shifted to targeting smaller coastal sharks in the 1990s (Sala et al. 2004). Records from the northern Gulf of California hake fishery are rare. This shark is subjected to intense fishing pressure in Guatemala, and a population reduction is suspected there. In Costa Rica, recent landings surveys have recorded relatively few individuals, and anecdotal evidence from fishers indicates that the species was previously much more common. In Colombia, this species is recorded in artisanal fisheries at lower frequency than the 1990s (P.A. Mejía-Falla and A.F. Navia, unpubl. data 2019). Although data are sparse further south, gillnet and trawl fishing pressure is intense and largely unmanaged. Furthermore, mangroves in the region have declined (López-Angarita et al. 2016). Overall, due to the level of intense and largely unmanaged fisheries operating in its range, its increasing rarity in some areas, its lack of refuge from fishing at depth, and the degradation of coastal mangrove habitats, it is suspected that this shark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (15 years).
range: The Pacific Sharpnose Shark occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from southern California, USA to Peru (Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: This shark is targeted and/or caught as retained bycatch through most of its range. It is sold fresh or dried and salted. In Costa Rica, this species is often served as ceviche (M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this shark. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. Management measures are needed to ensure that this species does not become more threatened in the near future. Further research is needed on life history and population size and trends. Species-specific monitoring of catch is needed in artisanal and commercial fisheries.

rationale: The Natal Shyshark (Haploblepharus kistnasamyi) is a small (to at least 50 cm total length) demersal catshark that inhabits inshore rocky and coral reefs and sandy areas from the intertidal to a depth of 30 m. It is endemic to South Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans, and ranges along ~1,000 km of coastline where it is known from five locations with an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of ~2,000 km². Its range overlaps with trawl and line fisheries, and a lack of recent records despite surveys leads to inference of a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals. The Natal Shyshark is therefore assessed as Vulnerable B2ab(v). The previous assessment of Critically Endangered B1ab(iii) published in 2009 miscalculated the species' extent of occurrence (EOO). This reassessment to Vulnerable represents a non-genuine change in status based on new information, and that fact that incorrect data were used previously.
habitat: The Natal Shyshark inhabits inshore rocky and coral reefs and sandy areas, with a depth range from the intertidal to 30 m depth (Human and Compagno 2006, Human 2007). Maximum size is unknown, but is at least 50 cm total length (TL) (Human and Compagno 2006, Human 2007). Reproduction is oviparous.
threats: The Natal Shyshark is captured in demersal trawl and recreational and commercial line fisheries (Booth and Hecht 1996, Smith et al. 2007, Walmsley et al. 2007). Although not retained in trawl fisheries, catsharks are frequently not alive when discarded due to injuries from fishing gear or neglect on deck (Peterson et al. 2008). The commercial and recreational line fisheries in Plettenberg Bay where the Natal Shyshark has been documented in Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF) research trawl surveys (Human and Compagno 2006, Human 2007) have been assessed as unsustainable (Smith et al. 2007). The inshore habitat of the species may be subject to degradation from coastal development activities.
population: This species is known to be extremely rare. Although previously it was caught in research trawl surveys by the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), it has not been caught recently (C. da Silva, unpubl. data, 2018). Only one specimen has been seen during Oceanographic Research Institute (ORI) annual surveys in the Pondoland Marine Protected Area over a 10-year period between 2006 and 2016 (B. Mann, pers. comm., 2018). The former presence of this species in historical surveys and lack thereof in recent surveys, combined with fisher interviews that indicate no sign of this species, leads to an inferred continuing decline in mature individuals of the Natal Shyshark.
range: The Natal Shyshark occurs in the Western Indian Ocean off the coast of South Africa from Mossel Bay, Western Cape, to KwaDukuza, KwaZulu-Natal (Human 2007, K. Gledhill, unpubl. data, 2018). This species occurs along ~1,000 km of coastline and is restricted to shallow waters to 30 m depth only, which is within ~2 km of coast; placing a 2 x 2 km grid along the full 1,000 km of coastline gives an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of ~2,000 km².
useTrade: This rare species is not known to be utilized or traded.
conservationActions: The Natal Shyshark is protected in South Africa. Catching, possession, or harassment of the this species is not legal without a valid exemption permit. Further research is needed on distribution, life history, population size and trend, and threats. Population and habitat monitoring should be prioritized.

rationale: The Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark (Cirrhoscyllium formosanum) is a small (to 43 cm total length) carpetshark endemic to southwest Taiwan in the Northwest Pacific. It is demersal on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–320 m. The first estimates of age lead to a very short generation length of 2.7 years, which should be treated with caution, as it is extremely short compared to most other small sharks. The species is a bycatch of bottom trawl fisheries that operate across its entire depth range, use small mesh sizes, and have been intensive for a considerable time. Standardised catch rates of all sharks taken by trawl in southwest Taiwan have declined by 64% over 17 years from 1997–2013. This represents a 41% decline when scaled to three generation lengths (8 years). The species has a highly restricted distribution, with a relatively narrow depth range entirely exposed to intense trawl fishing. The inshore trawl ban in Taiwan waters may afford the species some refuge from fishing pressure. It is inferred that the Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (8 years) due to levels of exploitation (bycatch), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark is demersal on the outer continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 110–320 m (Weigmann 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 43 cm total length; males mature at 30.5 cm TL and females mature at 34.1 cm TL (Huang 2017). Reproduction is oviparous with size-at-birth is 11 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013a, Huang 2017). Female age-at-maturity is estimated at 2.4 years and maximum age is estimated at 3 years; generation length is therefore estimated at 2.7 years (Huang 2017). The estimated growth rate is very rapid with a von Bertalanffy rate of k=0.520 for females (Huang 2017). These first age and growth estimates for this species should be treated with caution; they are not validated, carpetsharks are difficult to age, and the age parameters seem very low compared to sharks in general (Carrier et al. 2010). The only other carpetshark age information is for a larger species, the Whitespotted Bamboo Shark (Chiloscyllium plagiosum) (95 cm vs 43 cm TL) that had an age-at-maturity of 4.5 years and maximum age of 12.6 years, and thus a generation length of 8.6 years (Chen et al. 2007).
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch by demersal trawl fisheries but discarded due to its small size and thick skin that make it unsuitable for human consumption or fish meal (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). Fisheries on the Taiwan southwest coast are mainly shallow and coastal, but may range down to 700 m depth (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). The deeper water trawl fishery targets multiple species of deep-water shrimp, uses small mesh sizes that would likely capture juveniles and adults, and has been intensive for a considerable time (D. Ebert and H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). Juveniles are still seasonally observed, despite the intense and ongoing fishing pressure (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). Post release survival is unknown, but is high for other carpetsharks taken by gillnet and trawl (Ellis et al. 2017, C. Rigby unpubl. data 2019).

In Taiwan, by the 1950s the coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating in Taiwan’s EEZ significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989 at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283 to 239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273 to 12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The demand for seafood has always been high and is suspected to continue to be high in Taiwan with per capita fish consumption similar to the high levels in China (Fabinyi and Liu 2014, Helgil 2019).
population:
The Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark is infrequently but regularly observed in southwest Taiwan with little observed change to the abundance in landing rates over the past 10 years, however this is based on low numbers that make changes difficult to ascertain (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019). There is no specific information on effort in southwest Taiwan but industrial fishing effort has been slowly declining across the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone since the 1980s (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019). Despite the slow decline, fishing pressure remains high in Taiwan and is considered intense in southwest Taiwan (D. Ebert and H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).

In southwest Taiwan, the combined standardised catch rate of all shark species taken by bottom trawls has fluctuated with an overall decline of 64% over 17 years from 1997 to 2013. The catch-per-unit-effort was ~28 kg/hour in 1997 and declined to ~10 kg/hour in 2013 (H. Hsu, Taiwan Fisheries Institute unpubl. data 2019). When the level of decline is scaled to three generation lengths (8 years) it represents a 41% decline in abundance of sharks in southwest Taiwan. This decline is not species-specific but is informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the area.

Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the entire range of the Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark and there has been an overall decline of 41% in shark catch rates in the area over three generation lengths (8 years). The species has a highly restricted distribution, with a relatively narrow depth range that is intensively trawled. The inshore trawl ban in Taiwan waters may afford the species some spatial refuge from fishing pressure. Overall, it is inferred that the species has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (8 years).
range: The Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark is endemic to southwest Taiwan in the Northwest Pacific (Ebert et al. 2013b, Huang 2017).
useTrade: This species is not utilised; it is considered too small for human consumption and the thick skin renders it unsuitable to process for fish meal (H. Ho unpubl. data 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. However, since 1999, all demersal trawling in Taiwan is prohibited within three nautical miles (nm) of the coast and within 12 nm for trawlers larger than 50 Gross Registered Tonnage (Fisheries Agency 2019, Liao et al. 2019). Research is required to better define the life history, population size and trend of the Taiwan Saddled Carpetshark, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Equatorial Skate (Rostroraja equatorialis) is a medium-sized (to 88 cm TL) skate that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California, Mexico to northern Peru. It is demersal on continental and insular shelves at depths of 20–200 m. It is captured in commercial demersal trawl and in artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries, which are intense and largely unmanaged across much of its range. Trawl fisheries are intense in parts of the Gulf of California, and gillnets have been responsible for depletion of various marine species. Further south in Mexico, longline and trawl fisheries have been in operation since at least the 1960s with little effective management in place. Artisanal fisheries are intense and unmanaged throughout the Central and South American portions of its range, and there are unmanaged trawl fisheries in many areas. Overall, due to the level of intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure across much of its range and its known susceptibility to capture in these fisheries, it is suspected that the Equatorial Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (30 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Equatorial Skate is demersal on continental and insular shelves at depths of 20–200 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 88 cm total length (TL); female maturity is unknown and males are mature at 36 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous, and generation length is suspected to be 10 years, based on data from the similar but smaller Roundel Skate (Rostroraja texana) which has an age at maturity of 5.8 years, a longevity of nine years, and a generation length of 7.4 years (Sulikowski et al. 2007).
threats: The Equatorial Skate is captured in demersal trawl fisheries and artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries, which are intense and largely unmanaged through much of its range. In the Gulf of California, hake trawl fisheries capture this skate (Lara-Mendoza et al. 2016). Gillnet fisheries in the Gulf of California have caused declines in other species such as turtles, marine mammals, and pelagic sharks (Sala et al. 2004), and declines are also likely in this skate. Shrimp trawl fisheries operate in the southern Gulf of California and off Mazatlan, shrimp trawling is intense and this fishery is reported to suffer from overcapacity, poor governance, and declines in catches (Foster and Vincent 2010). In Costa Rica, this skate is susceptible to being caught in shrimp trawl fisheries (Clarke et al. 2018), however these fisheries are declining and the last permits expire in 2019 (M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2019). In Colombia, shrimp trawl fisheries are declining but do catch this species. In Ecuador, this species is caught in artisanal longlines and gillnets that lack management. There are shrimp and hake trawl fisheries in Ecuador and Peru that fish throughout this skate's depth range. In 2014 there were 60 hake trawlers in Peru. Overall, this skate is subjected to intense fishing pressure across much of its range, and there is not likely to be refuge at deeper waters.
population: This skate is subjected to intense and largely unmanaged fishing pressure through most of its range. Data from the northern Gulf of California indicate that this skate was caught at low levels between 1997 and 2014 (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). Although there are no further data available, it inhabits shallow waters and has little refuge from fishing across its range. Given the intense fishing pressure across most of its range, its known susceptibility to capture in fisheries, lack of refuge at depth, it is suspected that the Equatorial Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (30 years).
range: The Equatorial Skate occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California, Mexico to northern Peru (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This skate is salted and dried for local consumption when caught in artisanal fisheries. In the Gulf of California it is caught in the hake trawl fishery and exported to Korea (Santana-Morales et al. 2004).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in  place for this skate. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted  elasmobranch fishing   from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is  inadequate (O.   Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. Management measures are needed to ensure that this skate does not become endangered in the near future. Further research is  needed on life   history and population size and trends.  Species-specific monitoring of   catch is needed in industrial trawl and  artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries.

rationale: The Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor) is a small (to 93 cm total length) benthic electric ray that inhabits bays and estuaries in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from Baja California Sur, Mexico to northern Peru, including the Gulf of California and the Revillagigedo Islands. It has a preference for sandy substrates from shore to a depth of 100 m. It is captured in industrial demersal trawl fisheries, trammel nets, and in artisanal gillnets. In the Gulf of California artisanal fishery, landings of Cortez Numbfish between 1997 and 2014 declined before returning to levels similar to the start of the time-series. In Guatemala between 1996 and 1998, this electric ray represented 15% of batoid bycatch in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery, but in 2006 it only represented 3.6%, suggesting a decline. In Colombia, relative abundance increased between 2001 and 2007, but average size decreased considerably. Overall, due to its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, apparent reductions in some areas but stable landings elsewhere, it is suspected that the Cortez Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (31.5 years), and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2bd.
habitat: The Cortez Numbfish is a benthic electric ray that inhabits continental and insular shelves and estuaries from inshore to 100 m depth (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016). It is associated primarily with sandy substrates (including carbonate sands) (Breder 1928, Valadez-González et al. 2000). It reaches a maximum size of 93 cm TL; females mature at 65 cm TL (at six years of age) and males at 43 cm TL (at four years of age) (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). Reproduction is viviparous and females give birth after 10–12 months to up to 15 pups that are born at 11 cm TL (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000, Last et al. 2016). This species sexually segregates, with females much more common in shallow embayments than males, especially during late spring and early summer (Bizzarro 2005). Maximum age is 11 years for males and 15 years for females (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000), and generation length is estimated to be 10.5 years.
threats: The Cortez Numbfish is captured in industrial demersal trawl fisheries, trammel nets, and in artisanal gillnets. In the Gulf of California, gillnets are prevalent, lack management, and have been noted to have caused declines in teleosts, pelagic sharks, and rays (Sala et al. 2004). Artisanal gillnet fisheries are intense and increasing and lack management further south. This species has been shown to have a moderate to high susceptibility to capture in trawl fisheries (Clarke et al. 2018). Shrimp trawling is widespread in the southern Gulf of California. Trawling is intense off Mazatlan, and this fishery is noted for its overcapacity, poor governance and declining catches (Foster and Vincent 2010).
population: In the Gulf of California artisanal fishery, landings of Cortez Numbfish between 1997 and 2014 declined before returning to levels similar to the start of the time-series (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2016). In the Gulf of Tehuantepec, this species was caught in low numbers in research trawls in 2011. In Guatemala between 1996 and 1998, this electric ray represented 15% of batoid bycatch in the industrial shrimp trawl fishery, and in 2006 it only represented 3.6% (Ixquiac-Cabrera et al. 2010), equivalent to a >85% population reduction over three generations (31.5 years). In Costa Rica from 2008 to 2012, this species was captured in 100% of trawls in one study (Clarke et al. 2016). Data the industrial shrimp trawl fishery between 2001 and 2007 showed increase in the relative abundance of Cortez Numbfish (0.14 individuals/hour to 0.86 ind/hr) but a decrease in the average size (58 cm total length (TL) to 37.8 cm TL; Navia and Mejía-Falla 2016). Overall, due to its exposure to inadequately managed fisheries throughout its range, reductions in catches in some areas despite increased effort, and its continued presence in other areas, it is suspected that the Cortez Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generations (31.5 years).
range: The Cortez Numbfish occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from Baja California Sur, Mexico to northern Peru, including the Gulf of California and the Revillagigedo Islands (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: This species is utilized for local consumption in Mexico. Only the trunk and tail are used, as the disc is electrified. It is discarded elsewhere.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for the Cortez Numbfish. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O. Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. Management measures are needed to ensure that this species does not become endangered in the near future. It occurs in the Revillagigedo Islands Marine Reserve. Further research is needed on life history, movement patterns, habitat use, and age and growth and reproductive studies are necessary south of Mexico. Catches and landings should be monitored at the species level.

rationale:
The Browneye Skate (Okamejei schmidti) is a small (to 52 cm total length) skate endemic to southern Japan in the Northwest Pacific Ocean. It is demersal on the inner continental shelf at depths of 20–60 m, possibly to a depth of 136 m. The species is a bycatch of demersal trawl, gillnet, and set net fisheries, and is retained for human consumption.

Prevoiusly this species was considered common, though no species-specific population trend data are available. Catches of skates and rays from the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone indicate declines of 56–70% over the past three generation lengths (21 years). Historic fishing pressure was high across the species’ entire range, and although fishing pressure has declined over the past 30 years, this species' restricted spatial and depth range mean it is highly exposed with little refuge from intense fisheries. Regional congeners have been reported as common in some areas and to have high biological productivity, which would provide some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Browneye Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Browneye Skate is demersal on sand and mud habitats of the inner continental shelf at depths of 20–60 m (Last et al. 2016, Weigmann 2016), and possibly to a depth of 136 m (Kawano and Kobayashi 2010). It reaches a maximum size of 52 cm total length (TL), males and females mature at~44 cm TL (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Two congeners of similar size and depth ranges, the Spiny Skate (O. kenojei) and the Sharpspine Skate (O. acutispina) have female ages-at-maturity of 3.4 and 7.2 years and maximum ages of 10.5 and 13.2 years (Ishihara et al. 2002, Joung et al. 2011), resulting in generation lengths of 6.9 and 10.2 years, respectively. It is thus inferred that the generation length of the Browneye Skate is on the lower side of 7–10 years.
threats: The Browneye Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its entire limited spatial and depth range. It is taken as bycatch in demersal trawl, gillnet, and set net fisheries, and retained for human consumption (Ishihara et al. 2009). In Japan, fisheries developed rapidly during the 1950s–1980s, however, they began to decline in the 1980–1990s with a reduction in fish prices and the establishment of the Japan 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Swartz and Ishimura 2014, White Paper 2015). The fishing effort within the Japanese EEZ declined by approximately one-third from the 1950s to the mid-1990s (Anticamara et al. 2011). Since then, it has remained relatively stable, with only a slight decline; the number of powered vessels operating across the EEZ declined slightly from 1998 to 2007 at 236,000–232,534 (Schmidt 2003, Anticamara et al. 2011, FAO 2019). Demersal trawl fisheries effort has decreased markedly over the last three decades and is continuing to decline, mostly due to the significant decline in the numbers of fishers and vessels participating in the fishery as fishers age and there is a lack of younger people entering the industry (NFMT 2017, FAO 2019, S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). The trawl fisheries are also strictly managed to limit effort with spatial and temporal closures (S. Tanaka unpubl. data 2019). Demand for seafood in Japan is extremely high at 53.7 kg per capita in 2013 (FAO 2019, Helgil 2019).
population:
The Browneye Skate was previously reported as common (Ishihara et al. 2009), though there are no species-specific trend data prior or post 2009. In the Japan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), the catch of skates and rays from 1955 to 1995 showed a decline of 79% from a peak catch of 18,782 t in 1955 to 3,985 t in 1995 (Ishihara et al. 2002). This decline is mainly attributed to a decrease in catches in the East China Sea which consisted mostly of small Okamejei species (not identified to species level). Catches of skates and rays in the East China Sea declined by 77% from 1955 to 1986 (Ishihara et al. 2002). Although this species does not occur in the East China Sea, the decline in Okamejei species is indicative of the possible decline in the Browneye Skate over the long-term. Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Some decline may be due to reduced fishing effort, but the level of decline is much greater than the decline in fishing effort which infers there has been an actual decline in the abundance of rays and skates in the Japan EEZ.

When the decline in skates and rays across the Japan EEZ is scaled to three generation lengths of the Browneye Skate (21 years), it represents a decline of 56–70%. This level of decline is not species-specific but is informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) was high across the entire restricted spatial and depth range of the Browneye Skate, although fishing pressure has declined in Japan over the past 30 years. Regional congeners of similar size have been reported as common in some areas and to have high biological productivity, which would provide some resilience to fishing pressure (see Red List assessments of Spiny Skate (O. kenojei) and the Sharpspine Skate (O. acutispina)). Although fishing pressure has declined, the limited spatial and depth range is of concern and the species is still fished. The Browneye is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (21 years).
range: The Browneye Skate is endemic to southern Japan in the Northwest Pacific Ocean (Nakabo 2013, Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: The species is eaten as dried skate 'wings' and processed into fishcakes in Japan (Ishihara et al. 2009).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. In Japan, management measures have been implemented since the mid-1990s to control fishing effort that includes total allowable catches, seasonal closures, and gear restrictions (White Paper 2015).   Further research is needed on population size and trend, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale: The Graceful Catshark (Proscyllium habereri) is a small (to 65 cm total length) catshark that occurs from Japan to Indonesia in the Northwest and Western Central Pacific and Eastern Indian Oceans at depths of 50–320 m. The Graceful Catshark is subject to intense fishing pressure across its range. The species is likely taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple gears including trawl, seine net, gillnet, and torchlight net. The species is considered common in Taiwan where the population is inferred to have remained stable for the past 15 years and the abundance in one part of China is inferred to have also remained stable over the past 20 years. Landings data of all sharks combined from the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) and reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates and rays from the Japan, China, South Korea, and Viet Nam EEZs indicate declines of 34–96% over the past three generation lengths (45 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in sharks in the region. Declines of this species are inferred in Indonesia due to high levels of fishing pressure and declines in many elasmobranch species in the region. Stable population abundance in Taiwan and in one part of China over the past 15 and 20 years, respectively, indicate some resilience to fishing pressure. Seasonal fishing bans and inshore trawl bans in China and Taiwan, respectively, would provide the species some refuge from fishing pressure. It is inferred that the Graceful Catshark has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (45 years) due to high levels of exploitation and inferred population stability in some parts of its range, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Graceful Catshark is demersal on the continental shelf and upper slope at depths of 50–320 m (Weigmann 2016). The species reaches a maximum size of 65 cm total length; males mature at 42 cm TL and females at 51 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013a). Reproduction is oviparous with egg cases laid in pairs (Ebert et al. 2013a). Nothing else is known of its biology. There are no age estimates from the family Proscylliidae and related families (i.e., catsharks of the families Scyliorhinidae and Pentanchidae) are difficult to age. The most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) (family Pentanchidae) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). This should be treated with caution and as an estimate only as the two species are in different families.
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, seine net, gillnet, and torch light net. Trawls operate across the entire depth range of this species, while the other net fisheries likely operate in its upper depth range. In Taiwan and Japan, and possibly China and Korea, it is retained for fish meal production for aquaculture.

There is a high level of fisheries resource use across the range of the Graceful Catshark. In the East China Sea, heavy exploitation levels, small mesh sizes, and intensive fishing has caused declines in fish stocks, and a reduction in fish size and their trophic levels; the ‘fishing down’ effect from 1979 to 2014 is one of the highest estimated globally (Heileman and Tang 2009, Liang and Pauly 2017). Over 30% of the catch now consists of fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal (Cao et al. 2015, Liang and Pauly 2017). In the Korean waters of the Yellow Sea there is intense trawl fishing pressure (A. Yamaguchi pers. comm. 28 August 2019).

The northern South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore, and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019).

In China, inshore coastal fisheries resources have been depleted since the 1980s, following intensive demersal trawling and stake net fisheries during the preceding 30 years (Yu and Yu 2008, Liang and Pauly 2017). The number of powered fishing vessels increased in China from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks across China has steadily decreased and large, highly-valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012). The demand for fish meal product for aquaculture is high, with the aquaculture industry in China contributing 62% of the world’s farmed fish (FAO 2019a, Rueter et al. 2019).
