In more recent years (1981–2010), most recreational catches of Atlantic Tarpon in the USA occurred along the Gulf of Mexico coast. Applying Florida sales of harvest permits to the Marine Recreational Fisheries Statistics Survey data for Tarpon caught and released in Florida, (National Marine Fisheries Service, Fisheries Statistics Division pers. comm. 2011), indicates that less than 1% of the total catch is harvested (Guindon 2011).Over the last decade, populations in Florida appear to have remained stable; however, earlier records are statistically unreliable (Marine Recreational Fisheries Statistics Survey, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration 2011). One of the few estimates of a regional population of Atlantic Tarpon came from Boca Grande Pass. An acoustic survey was done in 1993, which estimated the Tarpon population in the Pass during peak spawning season to be between 24,700 and 25,400 individuals (Hedgepeth et al. 1993). No similar data has been collected nor another population estimate made for this area since this study to determine whether or not abundance has increased or decreased. As this species is not primarily subjected to commercial fisheries, stock assessments have not been carried out throughout its range. Stock assessments or landings records in other parts of this species' range do not exist at present, particularly in developing countries. Off Mexico, this species is considered a highly desirable sportfish where it is targeted by hook and line. It does not sustain a commercial fishery. It is considered underexploited off Mexico (SAGARPA 2012).
range: Megalops atlanticus is widely distributed across the Atlantic. In the western Atlantic it is known from Virginia (there have been records from Nova Scotia) south along the U.S., Bermuda, the Bahamas, throughout the Gulf of Mexico and Caribbean Sea, and along South America to northern Argentina (FMNH record) (Bigelow et al. 1953, Zale and Merrifield 1989, Crabtree et al. 1995, Smith 1997, Luna et al. 2005). In the eastern Atlantic it is known from Portugal, (Porto Santo, Madeira), the Azores, southern coasts of France, and along West Africa from Mauritania south to Angola (Hureau 1984, Luna et al. 2005, Anyanwu and Kusemiju 2008). Adults have been observed off the south coast of Ireland (Twomey and Byrne 1985). This species has also become established on the Pacific coast of Panama and has extended its distribution as far northward as Costa Rica, presumably via the Panama Canal (Swanson 1946).
useTrade: Megalops atlanticus is a major species in the recreational fishery in many parts of its distributional range. The recreational fishery for this species developed in 1885 in Florida. Ault and Luo (2013) stated that sport-fishing of this species in the Gulf of Mexico and southeastern United States supports an economic impact of $6 billion USD and 100,000 jobs. This species can only be fished recreationally (catch-and-release) in Florida. However, anglers can possess them for trophy purposes at the cost of $50.00 per tag, per fish. Otherwise, possession and commercial harvesting is illegal (Morey 2000, Hill 2002, Luna et al. 2005, Neidig and King 2012). It is marketed for its flesh in some areas, and is considered a delicacy in South America despite it being very bony.  Large scales are used as ornamentation for home decor, and are used in the manufacturing of artificial pearls (Morey 2000, Hill 2002, Luna et al. 2005). The scales are used for medicinal purposes in Brazil. In Africa, they are traditionally served at Christmas. They are consumed in Central America, when collected as bycatch or from small directed fisheries. There are subsistence fisheries and some commercial sale of roe and flesh in Mexico and some of the Caribbean Islands (A. Adams and K. Guindon pers. comm. 2011). They are consumed readily in Colombia (Garcia and Solano 1995). This species is cultured from wild stocks of juveniles in Nigeria (Anyanwu unpublished data). They are often taken as incidental catch by purse seiners, long-liners, and in gill nets in Mexico and Belize (J. Shenker pers. comm. 2011). Although they are not targeted by fisheries in Mexico and Belize, they often enter the market upon capture (J. Ault pers. comm. 2011).
conservationActions:
Despite their ecological and economic importance, recreational fishery regulations for tarpon in the United States and abroad differ regionally. Alabama and Georgia have size limits and bag limits (one per person per day in Georgia, in Alabama a $50 tag is needed). North and South Carolina have no minimum size requirements and the limit is one fish per person per day. In Florida, catch and release is the only fishing method allowed. In Louisiana and Mississippi, there are no regulations. In Florida and Texas, a permit is required to harvest or possess a tarpon (Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission, K. Guindon and R. Ward pers. comm. 2011). This permit allows two tarpon per permit-holder to be caught and killed per day. Catch information (location and size) must be reported by the angler to Florida Marine Research Institute. The establishment of this permit program has greatly reduced the number of tarpon killed annually. Before the permit program was in place, in 1989 it was estimated that 342 tarpon were caught and killed by anglers. In 1998, it was estimated the number of tarpon caught and killed by anglers was reduced to only 70 (Burnham 2005). Current management regulations in Mexico require a fishing permit with gear restricted to one rod and reel (line with a maximum test of 60 kg (130 lbs) and one hook per angler. The bag limit is two fish per angler per day with a request to practice catch and release. Tarpon fishing is not allowed in protected areas or reserves. In Mexico, the limit is two fish per person per day, but no minimum size requirement exists. It is recommended that regulatory measures be implemented specific to conditions for each Mexican region including the establishment of a minimum catch size that promotes growth and reproduction of the species, the implementation of a logbook to record effort, monitoring of fishing tournaments, and promoting the practice of catch and release (SAGARPA 2012). In Belize, Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, tarpon are catch-and-release only.

In an effort to conserve fish stocks and their habitats, many countries are using marine protected areas in conjunction with existing fisheries regulations to build sustainable fisheries and protect marine biodiversity. Catch-and-release is commonly practised by recreational anglers with a strong conservation ethic who travel to the region. Current levels of international harvest and by-catch should be quantified, and the tertiary effects of catch-and-release fishing on tarpon should be determined to help maintain, if present, or create, if needed, a sustainable fishery.

Effects of catch-and-release fishing on Megalops atlanticus continues to be studied. Edwards (1998) found that release mortality for this species is low when proper precautions are taken, including releasing in a short period of time and allowing the fish to remain in the water while being released. Fish that were hooked in the jaw also had decreased release mortality and recovered quickly (Edwards 1998).

rationale: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi is classified as Vulnerable. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 15,147 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 592 km2. Given the regional impacts associated with the expansion of the urban frontier (deforestation, agribusiness, effluents, and riverbed transformation), H. fernandezi is best estimated to occur in two threat-based locations. These threats have resulted in a continuing decline in the EOO and habitat. The population is considered severely fragmented because the species has small (potentially non-viable) and isolated subpopulations in different coastal drainages due to natural causes.
habitat: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi inhabits plains and piedmonts in creeks, streams and lagoons with heterogeneous substrates. It is also in estuaries and brackish water. Very little information about the habitat and ecology of H. fernandezi is known. Species of the genus Hyphessobrycon eat insects and algae in similar proportions. It can reach 54 mm in standard length (Lima et al. 2003). Reproduction may be periodic and associated with the rainy season. The genus has variable fecundity, between 300 and 2,000 oocytes (García-Alzate et al. 2008).
threats: Streams in plains are the critical habitat for the species, and there a rapid expansion of the urban and agricultural frontier is reported. Different stressors affect the integrity of rivers and their habitats for the local ichthyofauna, even more so for endemic and rare species such as H. fernandezi (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2006, 2011, 2018, 2019). Deforestation is extensive in the Aroa, Yaracuy and Urama drainages, as well as in all the plains near to the sea. Further, fluviomarine plains are associated with the regional tourism centre in beaches of Morrocoy National Park and agroindustrial developments. All rivers have cities, towns and villages on their banks. Urban and agricultural effluents are not treated before entering the rivers, and the extraction of water is high and permanent. In the plains there are several industrial centres (e.g. oil refineries). There are dams and artificial lagoons that can favour the species, but many are depauperated by urban and industrial effluents (e.g. Cumaripa and Durute reservoirs), introduced species (e.g. Oreochromis sp.) or desiccation by sedimentation.
population: Hyphessobrycon fernandezi is not a common species. In streams piedmonts in Aroa and Yaracuy drainages it comprised <0.1% of relative abundance (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011), but it could be common in lagoons and reservoirs. There are no data available to estimate the population size, and considering the human and climatic threats in the region, the population has an unknown trend. A significant population reduction is likely in the future due to environmental degradation within its distribution.
range:
Hyphessobrycon fernandezi was described near Aroa, en route to Duaca, Quebrada Cupa, Caribbean slopes of Venezuela (Fernández-Yépez 1972). It is endemic to the coastal drainages in rivers Aroa, Yaracuy, Urama and Sanchón (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011). It occurs in lowlands, less frequently in piedmonts and estuaries. It is also in Tocuyo drainage, reported for fluviomarine plains in Tacarigua reservoir, and other small neighbouring drainages: Tibana creek in Cuare, Agüide and Ricoa (García-Alzate et al. 2008). The records for the upper tributaries at north of Tocuyo River must be treated with caution, since another very similar species of recent description occurs there (Hyphessobrycon paucilepis). The records in slopes to Venezuela Gulf (Casigua, Bariro, Borojó) and upper Tocuyo are in doubt and should be reviewed. The species is reported in six localities with elevation from 2-285 m above sea level.

The extent of occurrence (EOO) is best estimated at 15,147 km2, and the area of occupancy (AOO) is best estimated at 592 km2. Given the regional impacts associated with the expansion of the urban frontier (deforestation, agribusiness, effluents, and riverbed transformation), H. fernandezi is best estimated to occur in two threat-based locations.

The geographic attributes for Hyphessobrycon fernandezi in this assessment were compiled, arranged and reviewed from the following sources: Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF 2020), FishNet2 (Fishnet2 2020), FishBase (Froese and Pauly 2019) and complemented with records from the databases of the following ichthyological collections Venezuela: MCNG (Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Nacional Experimental de los Llanos Occidentales Ezequiel Zamora, Guanare, Venezuela) and CPUCLA (Colección Regional de Peces, Museo de Ciencias Naturales de la Universidad Centroccidental Lisandro Alvarado, Barquisimeto, Venezuela).
useTrade: There is no information on the possible use and trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no specific measures for the conservation of the species Hyphessobrycon fernandezi. There are no laws, regulations and educational programs specifically oriented to its protection. This species is included in the website about freshwater fish at risk, their monitoring and conservation in coastal drainages of Venezuela (Rodríguez-Olarte and Taphorn 2007). Hyphessobrycon fernandezi was previously assessed as Vulnerable for a regional assessment in coastal drainages of the Caribbean Sea (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011) and Near Threatened in the Red Book of Venezuelan Fauna (Rodríguez et al. 2015). Records of the species are detected in protected areas (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2020). It is reported in National Parks Yurubí, San Esteban and Morrocoy, and Wildlife refuges Cuare and Tucurere. Most of these protected areas cover only the upper (piedmont) and lower (sea) limits for the species, leaving the plains unprotected and subject to extensive and intensive intervention. The fluviomarine plains in other protected areas are small and under strong human impacts. In some sectors of piedmont private conservation initiatives could be an impact on conservation, such as Hacienda Guáquira (Rodríguez-Olarte et al. 2011).

rationale: The Borneo Sand Skate (Okamejei cairae) is a small (to at least 39 cm total length) skate endemic to Sabah and Sarawak, Malaysia and Kalimantan, Indonesia in the Western Central Pacific Ocean. It is demersal on the mid-continental shelf at depths of 65–150 m, although the depth range is not well defined as its mainly known from fish market landings. The species is a bycatch of mainly trawl, and possibly set net and gillnet fisheries and is retained for human consumption. There are no species-specific time series, although reconstructed landings of all sharks, rays, and skates from Sabah and Sarawak, whiprays from Sabah, and catch-per-unit effort of rays in Indonesia infer declines of 60–72% over the past three generation lengths (31 years). Although these are not species-specific they are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure is high across the species’ range. It occurs sympatrically and is caught with the congeneric Yellow Spotted Skate (Okamejei hollandi) that is still considered common in some of its more northern range despite the intense fishing pressure. This implies the Borneo Sand Skate may also have some resilience to fishing pressure. It is suspected that the Borneo Sand Skate has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (31 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable (A2d).
habitat: The Borneo Sand Skate is demersal on sandy and muddy habitats on the mid-continental shelf at depths of 65–150 m, although the depth range is not well defined as specimens have mainly been collected at fish markets (Last et al. 2010a). It reaches a maximum size of at least 39 cm total length (TL); males mature at 34 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is oviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Ages are inferred from the similar-sized Sharpspine Skate (Okamejei acutispina) that has a verified female age-at-maturity of 7.2 years and a maximum age of 13.2 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.2 years (Joung et al. 2011).
threats:
The Borneo Sand Skate is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch in mainly trawl, and possibly set net and gillnet fisheries, and retained for human consumption. It is captured occasionally and taken sympatrically with the Yellow Spotted Skate (Okamejei hollandi) (Last et al. 2010a, Last et al. 2010b).

In Malaysia, unrestrained fisheries expansion from the mid-1960s to the 70s meant that inshore fisheries were fully exploited by the late 1970s (Teh and Teh 2014). Fishing effort in Malaysia has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has tripled in Sarawak from 2,251 vessels in 1950 to 7,650 vessels in 2014, with fishing effort in Sabah also rising, particularly in artisanal fisheries (Teh et al. 2009, Pauly et al. 2020). There has been, and still is, a currently rising trend in fish consumption throughout the country and ~85% of this comes from within the Malaysian EEZ (Fowler et al. 2002, A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020).

In Indonesia, effort across all sectors has been increasing since 1950s with steep increases in effort since the 1980s. Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Sharks and rays are an important resource and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Indonesia has the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally, and substantial catches of target and bycatch chondrichthyans (White et al. 2006). It has been among the top shark fishing nation for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019). Batoids comprised over 50% of chondrichthyan landings in 2003, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006).
population:
No data is available on the population trend of the Borneo Sand Skate. Despite the lack of species-specific data, reconstructed landings data are available on all combined sharks, rays, and skates in Sarawak and Sabah, and on whiprays in Sabah. Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Sarawak, landings showed a 50% decline from a peak of 14,690 t in 1997 to 7,300 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Landings slowly increased from the 1950s to 1980, dropped then peaked again in 1995–1997 before sharply declining. In Sabah, landings showed a 37% decline from a peak of ~27,000 t in 1998 to 17,000 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). Whipray (Dasyatidae) catches in Sabah showed a 48% decline from a peak of ~11,550 t in 1995 to ~6,000 t in 2014, despite constant effort (Pauly et al. 2020). Fishing pressure has been increasing since the 1950s and thus the declines can be used to infer reductions in these populations in Sarawak and Sabah. In Indonesia, research survey data showed an ~ 50% decline in ray catch-per-unit effort 1976–1997 throughout the Java Sea (Blaber et al. 2009) adjacent to the Borneo Sand Skate's range in northwestern Kalimantan. However, this is indicative only as the fisheries pressure is different in northwestern Kalimantan; there is no population trend data available from the northwestern Kalimantan area.

When these declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Borneo Sand Skate (31 years), they represent declines of 72% in Sarawak, and 60% and 66% in Sabah. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historical and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the spatial range of the Borneo Sand Skate. It occurs sympatrically with the similar size cogeneric Yellow Spotted Skate (Okamejei hollandi) that also occurs further north and is still considered common in some of its northern range (H. Ho and J. Zhang pers. comm. 28/08/2019), despite the intense fishing pressure. This implies some resilience to fishing pressure, however across its entire range, the Yellow Spotted Skate is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over three generation lengths (31 years). The Borneo Sand Skate is exposed to more moderate fishing pressure but has a more restricted distribution and it is suspected to have undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over three generation lengths (31 years).
range: The Borneo Sand Skate is endemic to western Borneo, Western Central Pacific Ocean where it is found in Sabah and Sarawak, Malaysia and in northwestern Kalimantan (Pontianak), Indonesia (Last et al. 2010a). It may be more wide ranging in the South China Sea (Last et al. 2016). It possibly occurs in the Gulf of Thailand (T. Krajangadara pers. comm. 03/08/2020).
useTrade: This species is used for its meat for human consumption (Last et al. 2010b).
conservationActions: No specific measures are in place. Throughout Malaysia there are 51 MPAs making up 5,462 km2 that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). In Indonesia, trawls were banned from use in 1980, however, mini trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country and the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries permits Danish seine (Cantrang) to operate but they are spatially restricted (Chong et al. 1987). Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catches should be monitored.

rationale: The Ranong Guitarfish (Rhinobatos ranongensis) is a small (to 65 cm total length) guitarfish found in Myanmar in the Andaman Sea and Bay of Bengal in the Eastern Indian Ocean. This newly described species is known only from a few specimens collected on research cruises and from Ranong fish market but may have a broader distribution. It is demersal on the inner continental shelf at depths of 68–108 m. The species is presumably taken as retained bycatch of industrial and artisanal trammel nets, gillnets, and longlines and the meat is consumed locally and fins of larger individuals are possibly traded. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across the range of this species. Population reduction is inferred from actual levels of exploitation, as well as reductions in surveyed elasmobranchs that infer a population decline of 31% over three generation lengths (18 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of guitarfish decline in the region. It is suspected that the Ranong Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the past three generation lengths (18 years) due to actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
habitat: The Ranong Guitarfish is demersal on the inner continental shelf at depths of 68–108 m (Psomadakis et al. 2019). It reaches a maximum size of at least 64.5 cm total length (TL) (Psomadakis et al. 2019). Reproduction is presumably lecithotrophic viviparous, but relatively little is known of the biology of the species. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age and, hence, generation length was inferred based on data for the Common Guitarfish (Rhinobatos rhinobatos). The Common Guitarfish has an age-at-maturity of four years and a maximum age of 24 years and, thus, a generation length of 19 years (Başusta et al. 2008). The Ranong Guitarfish has a smaller maximum size (64.5 cm TL) than the Common Guitarfish (162 cm TL), therefore generation length was scaled to be 6 years.
threats:
Sharks and rays are captured by a wide range of gears in Myanmar. Since the 2004 nationwide ban on targeting sharks in coastal waters, sharks and rays are largely taken as incidental catch in coastal gillnets, trawls (for fish or shrimp), longlines targeting mackerels, and hookah divers spearing at night (mostly catching rays and carpet sharks) (Howard et al. 2015, Mizrahi et al. 2020). These inshore fisheries are relatively small-scale, and include many subsistence fishers. At times since 1950, significant numbers of foreign vessels have operated in Myanmar waters targeting fish and shrimp. These vessels have operated in both inshore and offshore areas. Offshore fishing that incidentally catches sharks and rays is carried out by a large commercial fleet of mostly trawlers, purse seiners and longliners.

International Labour Organisation (2015) estimated the number of vessels participating in the small-scale inshore fishery to be about 26,000 in 2013, with about 50% of them unpowered. The number of locally operated larger offshore vessels numbered 2,846 in 2013, having increased nearly 30% since 2009. Foreign fishing vessels numbered 153 in 2013, but had historically been much higher. Foreign vessels were banned in 2014.
population:
Where Rhinopristiformes (sawfishes, wedgefishes, giant guitarfishes, and guitarfishes) have been targeted or exploited as incidental catch, severe declines, population depletions, and localized disappearances have occurred (e.g. Dulvy et al. 2016, Moore 2017, Jabado 2018, Kyne et al. 2020). However, there are no species-specific time-series data available for guitarfish species that can be used to calculate population reduction. This is due to a lack of species-specific reporting as well as taxonomic and identification issues (Jabado 2018).

In Myanmar, the nation provided no data to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) on landings between 1956 and 1972, making specific inference on the state of populations difficult. However, reconstructed marine fisheries landings data are available from 1950, including estimates of illegal, unregulated, and unreported (IUU) fishing (Booth and Pauly 2011). In general fisheries catches (all species, not just rays) increased steadily from about 200,000 t in 1950 to about 700,000 t in the late 1990s. From the late 1990s a rapid increase in landings from offshore fishing saw an increase in annual landings to almost 1.5 million t. Estimates of shark and ray landings from 1950 to the late 1990s varied between 15,000 t to 35,000 t with no substantial trend. However, from the late 1990s landings increased to around 40,000 t per year. This increase in landings is assumed to reflect the increase in offshore fishing that occurred during this period. These are substantial catches for a nation with a relatively small Exclusive Economic Zone. Despite the increase in shark and ray landings during the period since 1950 there are significant concerns for the status of many species. Trawl surveys in Myanmar undertaken by the Norwegian research vessel 'Dr Fridtjof Nansen' in 1978–80 and 2013 showed a 50% decline in catch rates of elasmobranchs between surveys (Krakstad et al. 2014), with a noted shift from larger long-lived species to smaller short-lived species. This is the equivalent of a 31% population reduction over the last three generation lengths (18 years) of the Ranong Guitarfish.

Declines in ray catch rates declined more than for sharks. Surveys of local markets from 2006 to 2010 (San San Khine 2010) demonstrated that landings are dominated by small short-lived species, which is typical of over-exploited elasmobranch communities (Lam and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2011). These same surveys also reported a 49% decline in the landings during this period, despite no reduction in fishing effort.

The Ranong Guitarfish has a narrow distribution and while it may have some refuge from intense inshore fisheries due to its slightly deeper depth distribution, it is suspected that the Ranong Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 30–49% over the last three generation lengths (18 years) and it is assessed as Vulnerable A2d.
range: Ranong Guitarfish is found in Myanmar in the Andaman Sea and Bay of Bengal in the Eastern Indian Ocean (Last et al. 2019). It is known only from a few specimens collected on research cruises and from the Ranong fish market in Myanmar (Last et al. 2019). This newly described species may have a broader distribution, but specimens have not been recorded elsewhere so far, such as Sri Lanka and Bangladesh (D. Fernando and A.B. Haque unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: Guitarfishes are heavily utilized across their range for their meat which is of good quality and is consumed fresh locally, although it also enters the international trade in dried and salted form (e.g. Moore 2017, Jabado 2018). Guitarfish fins are utilised, however, due to their smaller size their value is lower than the value of fins from Giant Guitarfishes or Wedgefishes, and fins from smaller individuals are generally discarded. The skin may be traded internationally as a luxury leather product to be made into accessories (e.g. handbags) (Haque et al. 2018).
conservationActions: There has been limited management of shark and rays in Myanmar. In 2004, the government established two shark reserves in the Myeik Archipelago where targeting sharks is prohibited (Notification 2/2004) (Howard et al. 2015). Rays are protected from targeting by the shark reserves. In 2008, a nationwide ban on the targeting of sharks was announced. Despite the nationwide ban sharks and rays continue to be captured in large numbers, partly because there is little or no enforcement, and little knowledge of it in fishing communities (T. MacKeracher pers. comm. 28 May 2020). Further research is needed on population size and trend, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
Anguilla borneensis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

There is limited information relating to this species beyond its current geographical distribution which appears to be almost exclusively Borneo, and parts of Sulawesi, Indonesia. There is some evidence of extirpation of this species from the Karabakan River, near Tawau, Malaysia, where during the 1960s it was found frequently within multiple sampling stations (Inger and Kong 1962), but during sampling in 1998, only A. marmorata could be found there (J. Aoyama pers. comm. 2014). Exploitation of the rainforest along the river edge is thought to be the main driver of decline, suggesting that perhaps A. borneensis is more vulnerable than other anguillid species in the area to habitat alteration and disturbance. Other threats to A. borneensis have been inferred from overlap with other species with similar ranges, however, like many of the tropical anguillid species, there is no quantitative information available on how these threats specifically impact A. borneensis. Considerably more data are required for this species but due to the suspected reduction in abundance and associated shrinking of — an already somewhat restricted — geographic range, this species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU).

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November, 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Little is known about the ecology of Anguilla borneensis. It is the only plain-coloured longfinned eel in Indonesian waters making it relatively easy to identify. Like A. celebesensis, it is thought that A. borneensis undertake much smaller-scale, local migrations to spawn (Aoyama et al. 2003, Kuroki et al. 2006a, Wouthuyzen et al. 2009, Shirotori et al. 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017). The smallest leptocephali caught was reported in the Celebes Sea (8.5 mm TL, 20 days old) and metamorphosing larvae – just before continental recruitment as elongate glass eels – were caught in the western part of the Sulu Sea, near Borneo (49.1 mm TL, 133 days old) (Kuroki et al. 2006a). Growth rate of the leptocephali – determined using otoliths – is estimated at 0.52 mm/day (Kuroki et al. 2006a). At around 80 days, growth rate slowed to a plateau and larva were therefore considered to have reached their full size (Kuroki et al. 2006a). Using otolith increment widths, leptocephali have been found to begin metamorphosis to glass eels at 117 days (Kuroki et al. 2014). Hatching dates are estimated as February to September (Kuroki et al. 2006a). The spawning season, age of recruitment of glass eels, and total length of glass eels, are currently unknown for this species (Kuroki et al. 2014). A single A. borneensis glass eel that recruited to the Southern Philippines in May 2014 was 48.9 mm TL, exhibiting a well-developed pigmentation on the tip of the caudal fin, similar to those of A. bicolor and A. interioris in the western Pacific (Shirotori et al. 2016). 

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla borneensis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight, that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

The decline of this species in the Karabakan River, Borneo is thought to have been in response to extensive exploitation of the forest alongside the river and subsequent degradation of the freshwater habitat (J. Aoyama pers. comm. 2014). As a plain coloured eel, A. borneensis may prove a possible target for future exploitation due to declines and restrictions in trade of other species (Crook 2014, Nijman 2015). There is, however, currently little information on specific demand for this species. In the Poso river watershed, dams for hydropower and unsustainable harvest of glass and larger eels are two reported threats (Watupongoh and Krismono 2015). In Sulawesi, mining for gold takes place, possibly affecting anguillid species in this area through mercury pollution (Muhammad et al. 2012, Abbas et al. 2017, Octaviano 2017). As with other anguillids, changing oceanic currents as a result of climate change may also impact this species.
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla borneensis. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

Most of the current literature refers solely to the description of the species. Inger and Chin (1962), however, reported that in a river on Borneo Island (Karabakan River), 50% of eels caught in suitable freshwater eel habitat were A. borneensis, while the other 50% comprised A. marmorata. During an expedition in 1998 to the same localities, researchers found only A. marmorata, suggesting that this species has been severely depleted, if not extirpated, in the Malaysian territory of Borneo Island (K. Tsukamoto and J. Aoyama pers. comm. 2014). Further research and monitoring of this species are required to determine the full extent of these declines, and to gauge whether A. borneensis has a restricted and contracting distribution.
range: Anguilla borneensis has a range restricted to almost exclusively to Borneo Island, as well as some parts of Sulawesi, the surrounding Celebes Sea, Sulu Sea, Maluku Sea and the Makassar Strait region (Kottelat 1993, Kuroki et al. 2006b, Fahmi 2015, Shirotori et al. 2016, Kadir et al. 2017). A single specimen of A. borneensis was identified from southern Mindanao, Philippines in May 2014 (Shirotori et al. 2016).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, Republic of Korea (also known as South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes(t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability declines and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Anguilla borneensis is very similar to A. japonica morphologically with plain skin and a long-fin, and so could potentially become a target as an alternative to A. japonica. According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~160 t of live eel fry (glass eels and larger juveniles) for farming from the Philippines and Indonesia. There is, however, no information suggesting that A. borneensis is currently used (or there are plans to use it) in eel farms in East Asia.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter, and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Even though fishing and trade of Anguilla species is known to occur in all parts of the distribution of A. borneensis very little is known of this species’ use or trade. According to FAO data, annual catches of “River eels nei” (other eel species not included elsewhere in FAO fishery statistics) in Indonesia and the Philippines (no data is available for Malaysia) fluctuated between 1355 and 6125 t between 2008 and 2017, averaging over 3000 t per year. The proportion of A. borneensis in these catches, however is unknown, as this is likely to include a number of anguillid species such as A. marmorata and A. bicolor, reported as being relatively more abundant in these waters. Eels are also being farmed in south-east Asia and predominantly in Indonesia: Anguilla farming production (estimated 90% A. bicolor and 10% A. marmorata) of 354 t in 2015 and 511 t in 2016 has been reported (SEAFDEC 2018). According to UN Comtrade, exports of eel commodities (live, fresh, frozen and prepared eel) from Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines increased from ~360 t in 2008 to ~20,000 t in 2016, however, some live Anguilla eel exports from South East Asian countries are known to be have been reported incorrectly in recent years, and have included significant quantities of Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels) and Pisodonophis  spp. (SEAFDEC 2018).

Unlike A. marmorata and A. bicolor, A. borneensis is rarely being offered for sale on online Business to Business (B2B) trade platforms. Indonesia is one of the principal sources of glass eels being advertised on online B2B trade platforms, however, and this species may be included in mixed catches/shipments sourced from Indonesian waters. One Philippine-based company is currently offering a year-round supply of glass eels and “kuroko” (larger sizes) of Anguilla “species mixes” including A. borneensis (together with A. marmorata, A. bicolor, A. celebesensis and A. luzonensis).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla borneensis. Although a rare species to the Philippines, current legislation is applicable to all anguillids: in May 2012, as a precautionary measure by the Philippine Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR), the export of juvenile anguillid eels of a size less than 15 cm was prohibited (Crook 2014). Indonesia has legislation relating to export of glass eels that dates back to 1973, in October 2012 a new regulation came into force (Nijman 2015). The “Regulation on the Export of Glass Eels (Anguilla spp.) from the Republic of Indonesia (PP 19/2012)” stipulates that the individual mass of eels exported from Indonesia must equal or be larger than 150 g, and so despite its title, encompasses glass eels, elvers, and some yellow eels (Nijman 2015).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, begun to examine the status of anguillid eels more closely (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

A scientific meeting on the “3rd International Symposium on the Tropical Eels Genus Anguilla (ISTEGA)” was held in Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia, from 1–3 August 2019. The international symposium held by the Indonesian Society of Tropical Eels (ISTES) and supported by the Indonesian Institute of Science as Indonesian Scientific Authority, and two national universities: Sam Ratulangi University of North Sulaewesi, and Tadulako University of Central Sulawesi. The theme of the 3rd ISTEGA 2019 was “science, conservation, and management of the tropical eel genus Anguilla for sustainable use”.

As there is little information regarding the population status of this species, it is clear that more research is needed to determine distribution, harvest levels, abundance trends, and information on plausible threats. It will be necessary for management and policy to be developed appropriately.

rationale:
Anguilla luzonensis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

A. luzonensis appears to have a distribution that is mainly concentrated in Luzon Island in the Philippines, with rare records of occurrence in Mindanao and Taiwan, Province of China (hereafter Taiwan) (Watanabe et al. 2009, Han et al. 2012, 2016, Shirotori et al. 2016). Without genetic testing, this recently discovered species is hard to distinguish from A. celebesensis and A. interioris adding further uncertainty to its true distribution and conservation status (Minegishi et al. 2009, Leander et al. 2012).

There is no quantitative information available to infer abundance trends for A. luzonensis. However, this species has a very limited distribution, and is currently known to exist in less than five ‘locations’ where recruitment is considered to contribute to the population of mature individuals. Of all the anguillid species that recruit to the Cagayan River, this species makes up a proportion of ~40% each year (Aoyama et al. 2015, Zoological Society London unpub. data.) and is the only locality where large recruitment of this species has been observed (Han et al. 2016). The Cagayan River system is affected by a number of stressors including habitat loss through sand-mining (Chaussard and Kerosky 2016), pollution resulting from agricultural run-off (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019), and the effects of climate change, including increased typhoon activity (Holden and Marshall 2018). Unsustainable exploitation of glass eels to stock aquaculture farms in East Asia, is a growing concern in the Philippines (Shiraishi and Crook 2015); however, exports peaked in 2012 and 2013, and in more recent years (2014–2017) have declined (Gollock et al. 2018). Despite reduced fisheries activity, bycatch is still a concern for this species, owing to sympatric distributions with species such as A. bicolor and A. marmorata, which are both currently caught and exported from the Philippines (Crook 2014, Aoyama et al. 2015, SEAFDEC 2018). In consideration of all available information, and applying the precautionary principal, A. luzonensis has been assessed as ‘Vulnerable’ (VU) under category D2, based on the level of threat to this species’ limited currently known range.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th November, 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla luzonensis is similar to other anguillids in that it has a catadromous life history. Based on the otolith microstructure, spawning season is estimated from late winter to early spring, around February to March (Kuroki et al. 2012). Leptocephali ranging from 29.2 to 51.2 mm have been collected offshore in the western North Pacific between the months of April and July (Kuroki et al. 2012). Spawning is proposed to occur in an area of the North Pacific where leptocephali are transported on the North Equatorial Current (NEC) (Kuroki et al. 2012). However, a specific localised area could not be identified, only that specimens were caught in the region west of the West Mariana Ridge to the west or northwest of Guam (Kuroki et al. 2012). As such, the spawning area potentially overlaps with those of A. marmorata and possibly A. japonica.

Using DNA identification of preserved, glass eel samples of A. luzonensis collected at the mouth of the Cagayan River, northern Luzon on 24 September 1994, metamorphosis was estimated to begin at ages of 104–147 days and recruit at 130–177 days old (Kuroki et al. 2012). Recruitment to the Cagayan River is thought to peak between June and September/October (Aoyama et al. 2015, Han et al. 2016), although elvers have been caught between February and August in Aparri, Cagayan (Zoological Society London unpub. data.). In southern Mindanao, recruitment has been observed in May, July and August, although the species is considered rare in this locality (Shirotori et al. 2016).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla luzonensis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight, that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of pressures, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to threats in both freshwater and marine environments.

The growing exploitation – and associated illegal trade – of young, glass eels, caught to stock aquaculture programs in East Asian farms, is a threat facing all species of freshwater eel in the Philippines (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). In the Cagayan River, this species can be found living sympatrically with other anguillid species, most commonly A. marmorata and A. bicolor (Aoyama et al. 2015). With an increasing market for these two species – particularly A. bicolor as a replacement for A. japonica – there is concern surrounding bycatch of other, less-economically important species such as A. luzonensis (Crook 2014, Aoyama et al. 2015, Shiraishi and Crook 2015). In 2012 the Philippines brought in a ban on the commercial export of live eels under 15 cm due to concerns in this growing exploitation, however, young eels continue to be traded illegally (Crook 2014). In recent years, glass eel fisheries have established further South in the Philippines, particularly on Mindanao.

Black sand mining for Magnetite – a type of iron used for the production of steel – has increased in the Philippines in response to demand (Chaussard and Kerosky 2016), requiring a process that uses suction pumps to filter large amounts of river water. This is believed to have reduced significantly in the Cagayan River in the last five years (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019). Additional concerns surround pollution resulting from agricultural run-off and sediment erosion. Intensive farming practices occur along the river and eels may be exposed to run-off (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2018). Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our understanding of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited. The Philippines are increasingly being affected by typhoon activity, most likely as a result of climate change (Holden and Marshall 2018), and which may have the potential to reduce habitat quality. Significant localised damage caused by typhoon activity has been observed in some tributaries of the Cagayan River system (M. Gollock pers. comm.).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer population trends for Anguilla luzonensis. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects to the species as a result of the identified pressures, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

A study was conducted by Aoyama et al. (2015) to determine species composition of glass eels at the mouth of the Cagayan River, in northern Luzon. Eels were sampled between 2008 and 2009, and again from 2011 to 2012, A. luzonensis was the second most common species present after A. marmorata (Aoyama et al. 2015). The proportion of A. luzonensis caught remained fairly stable over the two sampling periods; from 2008–2009, A. luzonensis made up 41% of total catch (8,643 glass eels), and 32.5% of total catch (23,535 glass eels) in 2011–2012 (Aoyama et al. 2015). Recruitment of A. luzonensis between 2008 and 2009 peaked between July and September, whereas from 2011 to 2012, recruitment peaked slightly earlier, between June and September (Aoyama et al. 2015). Another study of elvers in the Cagayan River found A. luzonensis to be the dominant species over a twelve-month period from May 2015 to May 2016, making up 46% of catch in a mixed system with A. marmorata (44%), and A. bicolor (10%) (Zoological Society London unpub. data.).
range:
Only described as a species in 2009, Anguilla luzonensis primarily appears to have a limited range in the Philippines with specimens found in the Cagayan River system on Luzon and in Mindanao (Watanabe et al. 2009, Han et al. 2012 (glass eels only)). In Mindanao, while recruitment of A. luzonensis has been observed, it is considered rare (Han et al. 2016, Shirotori et al. 2016). In Taiwan, glass eels of A. luzonensis have been observed, although rarely, between July and November (Han et al. 2016). Due to morphological similarities with A. celebesensis and A. interioris, molecular techniques would be required to determine the regular occurrence of this species in other areas (Minegishi et al. 2009, Leander et al. 2012).

The spawning location of A. luzonensis is thought to occur to the east of the Philippines in the North Equatorial Current region (NEC), after which larvae – leptocephali – enter the Kuroshio and Mindanao Currents (Kuroki et al. 2012, Han et al. 2016). Due to the timing of spawning between February and May, entrainment into the Kuroshio during May to August occurs at the same time as the NEC bifurcation reaches its most southern latitude, and when the volume of water entering the Kuroshio peaks (Han et al. 2016). This, combined with short larval duration, may explain why this species’ distribution is concentrated at Luzon Island (Han et al. 2016).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, the Republic of Korea (also known as South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~155 t of live eel fry (glass eels and larger juveniles) for farming from the Philippines. There is, however, no information suggesting that A. luzonensis is currently used (or there are plans to use it) in eel farms in East Asia.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years. According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Fishing and trade of Anguilla species is known to occur in A. luzonensis’s range, however very little is known of this species’ actual use or trade. According to FAO data, annual catches of “River eels nei” (other eels not included elsewhere in FAO fishery statistics) in the Philippines fluctuated between 710 and 2489 t between 2008 and 2017, averaging over 1400 t per year. The proportion of A. luzonensis in these catches is unknown, which includes other Anguilla species such as A. bicolor pacifica (the main target species in the Philippines) and A. marmorata (the dominant species) (SEAFDEC 2018). However, in the case of glass eel bycatch this species could possibly make up ~40% of catch in some areas/times of the year (Aoyama et al. 2015). According to UN Comtrade, exports of live eel from the Philippines (there being no records of trade in fresh, frozen or prepared eels) increased from ~300 t in 2008 to ~14,200 t in 2014, declining slightly in 2015 and 2016 to ~8500 t. However, some live Anguilla eel exports from South East Asian countries are known to have been reported incorrectly in recent years, and have included significant quantities of Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels) and Pisodonophis spp.

Unlike A. marmorata and A. bicolor, A. luzonensis is rarely being offered for sale on online Business to Business (B2B) trade platforms. One Philippine-based company is currently offering a year-round supply of glass eels and “kuroko” (larger sizes) of Anguilla “species mixes” including A. luzonensis (together with A. marmorata, A. bicolor pacifica, A. celebesensis and A. borneensis).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla luzonensis. In May 2012, as a precautionary measure by the Philippine Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources (BFAR), legislation was enacted to prohibit the export of juvenile Anguillid eels of a size less than 15 cm from the Philippines (Crook 2014). In the Cagayan River, located in the north of Luzon island in the Philippines, an eel management plan has been developed (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019). This has been proposed as a model for replication in other islands/regions, and even nationally (M. Gollock pers. comm. 2019).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, begun to examine the status of anguillid eels more closely (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

As there is little information regarding the population status of this species, it is clear that more research is needed to determine distribution, harvest levels, abundance trends, as well as information on plausible threats. It will be necessary for management and policy to be developed appropriately.

rationale: This species is endemic to Caribbean Colombia and has been recorded from only two localities (possibly three). It occurs in brackish areas of estuaries and rivers. It has an estimated EOO of 17,306 km<sup>2</sup> and an estimated AOO of 2,973 km<sup>2</sup>, which meet the thresholds it for Vulnerable under B1 and Near Threatened under B2. There have been few  individuals collected to date, however, it is known to be taken  in artisanal fisheries to an unknown level. The estuaries where it is found  continue to experience habitat degradation, which represents two locations. Therefore, it is listed as Vulnerable under B1ab(iii). Further research is needed to understand the impact of these threats on its population.
habitat: This species has been collected from brackish waters. Its maximum recorded size is 36.2 cm (TL) (Acero and Betancur 2002).
threats: This species has a restricted distribution. It appears to be dependent  on estuaries that have been experiencing habitat degradation. Specifically, the mangrove ecosystem has undergone deforestation. It is known to be taken in artisanal fisheries in the area.
population: It is only known from a few specimens. The type series includes only four specimens
range: This species has been recorded in the western Atlantic off Caribbean Colombia from Golfo de Uraba (Departamento  de Choco) to San Antero (Departamento de Cordoba) (Acero and Betancur 2002). It has been found in two estuaries (mouth of Rio Tinajones  and mouth of Rio Atrato) and may occur in a third. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 17,306 km<sup>2 </sup>(based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to five metre bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 2,973 km<sup>2</sup> (calculated by clipping distribution polygon to the zero to five metre bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO) and the extent of its preferred habitat is likely less than this.
useTrade: The importance of this species as a food fish is unknown, but is known to be taken by artisanal fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no conservation measures for this species. More research is needed on its distribution, population, life history and impact of threats.

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2015 assessment to accommodate the change in genus name from Himatura to Pateobatis.

Jenkins' Whipray (Pateobatis jenkinsii) is patchily distributed in inshore waters (to 90 m depth) in the Indian and Western Central Pacific Oceans. It is taken as a utilised bycatch of tangle net, gillnet, trawl net, and dropline fisheries throughout Southeast Asia and parts of the Indian Ocean where inshore fishing pressure is intense. It is caught in particularly high numbers in the target fishery for rhynchobatids operating in the Arafura Sea. Levels of exploitation are very high throughout its range in Southeast Asia and in many parts of the Indian Ocean, hence it is under a severe level of threat within most of this range. Although no species-specific data are available, overall catches of stingrays are reported to be declining in areas of Southeast Asia for which information is available, with fishermen having to travel further and further to sustain catch levels. The species is highly sought after in Southeast Asia for the high value of its skin. Little is known of the subpopulation off southeastern Africa, although the species is probably taken as bycatch of shrimp trawlers there. Fisheries in northern Australia are generally well managed and the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) has significantly reduced the bycatch of large stingrays. In Australia,  Jenkins' Whipray is considered at minimal threat throughout its wide range as there is no information to suggest that this species has declined in this area.

This large species may have limiting life history characteristics that make it biologically susceptible to depletion in fisheries and therefore, efforts should be made to assess and monitor mortality in fisheries and population trends throughout its range. Given the continuation of high levels of exploitation throughout its range in Southeast Asia where the species is caught in multiple types of fisheries, along with evidence for declines in catches of rays, the level of decline (>30% over the last three generations) and exploitation can be inferred from overall declines in fish catches in the region, as well as from habitat loss. Jenkins' Whipray is assessed as Vulnerable globally based on inferred levels of decline and exploitation across a large part of its range, but is considered to be Least Concern in Australia.
habitat: An inshore ray, usually found at less than 50 m depth, but also reportedly to 90 m (Compagno and Heemstra 1984, Kuiter and Debelius 1994, Stehmann 1995, Manjaji 2004, White et al. 2006, Last and Stevens 2009). It is also seen in reef areas off Thailand (C. Vidthyanon, pers. comm. 2007). This species attains a maximum size of at least 150 cm disc width (DW) (~300 cm total length) (Last and Compagno 1999, White et al. 2006, Last and Stevens 2009). Males mature at about 75-85 cm DW and size at birth is around 23 cm DW (White and Dharmadi 2007, Last and Stevens 2009). Reproduction is viviparous with histotrophy (White et al. 2006). A generation length of 20 years can be estimated based on the Blackspotted Whipray (Himantura astra) (Jacobsen and Bennett 2011), but noting that the Blackspotted Whipray grows to a much smaller maximum size (80 cm disc width) than Jenkins' Whipray (150 cm DW).
threats:
The inshore fishing pressure for Jenkins' Whipray is high throughout much of its range in Southeast Asia. In this area, most bycatch by commercial fisheries (especially trawlers) are landed and sold as food fish. This species is captured by demersal tangle net, bottom trawl, commercial gillnet and, to a lesser extent, longline fisheries (White et al. 2006, White et al. 2010). 

In Sabah (Malaysia), Papua New Guinea, and Indonesia, Himantura species are often caught and landed in the inshore fisheries (trawls and longlines) and are also taken by Danish seine fishing gear (M. Manjaji and Fahmi, pers. obs. 2007; Last et al. 2010; W. White, pers. obs. 2014). Jenkins' Whipray and other stingrays are an important retained bycatch of the commercial gillnet fishery in Indonesia that targets rhynchobatid rays in the Arafura Sea (Last and Compagno 1999; W. White, pers. obs. 2007). Catches in inshore waters have declined and these vessels are having to travel farther to sustain catches; the rhynchobatid fisheries are very intensive in this region, thus the level of exploitation is extremely high. The species has also been observed from fish market surveys within Thailand (Krajangdara 2014). Given that this species occurs in shallow, nearshore environments, ongoing and widespread degradation of coral reefs and coastal areas throughout Southeast Asia are likely contributing to declines in the region. 

A prawn trawl fishery consisting of about nine vessels operates in the Gulf of Papua in southern Papua New Guinea (W. White, pers. comm. 2015). Detailed species composition data for the bycatch is not currently available, but this is currently being investigated (L. Baje, National Fisheries Authority, pers. comm. 2015), and it is possible that Jenkins' Whipray is a bycatch within this fishery.

In Australia, catch data for this species is relatively limited, though large specimens have been reported as bycatch in the Australian Northern Prawn Fishery (Stobutzki et al. 2002). However, with the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) in the fishery, the ray bycatch has declined by 36.6% (Brewer et al. 2006) which should translate to reductions in the catch and associated mortality of Jenkins' Whipray.
population: Globally, shark and ray landings have declined by at least 20% since 2003, but the Indo-Pacific is amongst the regions where this decline has been more severe (Dulvy et al. 2014). Catches of sharks and rays in Southeast Asia are very high but are declining and fishers are travelling much further from port in order to increase catches (Chen 1996). Net and trawl fisheries in Indonesia (especially the Java Sea) and elsewhere are very extensive and as a result, many shark and ray species are highly exploited and stocks of most species have declined by at least an order of magnitude (Blaber et al. 2009). Batoids are heavily exploited (White and Dharmadi 2007) and datasets from as early as 1963–1972 show the considerable decline in batoids in the Gulf of Thailand (Pauly 1979). Trawl and gill net fisheries are also moving further afield. For example, in Jakarta the gillnet fishery at Muara Baru travels to waters around Kalimantan due to the decline in local populations (W.T. White, unpubl. data). While species-specific data on long-term declines in elasmobranchs in the Southeast Asian region are lacking, declines of Jenkins' Whipray in Southeast Asia and elsewhere in the Indo-West Pacific are inferred given the widespread historical and continuing declines of demersal fisheries in this region (Stobutzki et al. 2006). Furthermore, the extensive loss and degradation of habitats such as coastal mangroves are another key threat to coastal and inshore species; Southeast Asia has seen an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2010).
range: Jenkins' Whipray has a wide but patchy occurrence in the Indo-West Pacific from southern Africa to Australia, New Guinea and north to the Philippines (Compagno and Heemstra 1984, Stehmann 1995,  Manjaji 2004, Compagno et al. 2005, Last and Stevens 2009). Across northern Australia it can be found from Western Australia (Ningaloo Reef) to the eastern Gulf of Carpentaria in Queensland (Last and Stevens 2009).
useTrade: Jenkins' Whipray is predominantly captured as bycatch throughout its range, but retained for its meat, highly valued skin, and cartilage in Southeast Asia and more widely in the Indian Ocean (Last and Compagno 1999, Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2010).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Jenkins' Whipray. In Australia, the use of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) in the Northern Prawn Fishery (NPF) has been compulsory since 2000 (Day 2000) and following their introduction, ray bycatch has reduced by 36.3% (Brewer et al. 2006). It is likely to occur in some Australian marine protected areas, which would afford it refuge from fishing activities.

rationale: Sanopus astrifer has a very limited range that does not extend outside of Belize. Its estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 700 km² and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 11,218 km², which meets the thresholds for Vulnerable under criteria B1 and B2. Little information is available regarding its population status, as it is only known from a handful of specimens. It has only been found in caves or hollows beneath corals. The combination of disturbance events and chronic stresses has caused an average decline in live coral cover of 41% over the past 42 years. Coral bleaching remains the major threat to all reefs in Belize; including the most remote and most well-protected (in terms of MPA management). This species is therefore listed as Vulnerable (VU B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii)).
habitat: This reef-associated species lives in caves or hollows beneath corals. It produces high frequency sounds with its swim bladder to communicate, termed a “boatwhistle” (Mosharo and Lobel 2012). Toadfishes are anticipated to exhibit low levels of larval dispersal due to demersal eggs, direct development of larvae, and lack of a pelagic phase. Therefore, toadfish life history is also likely to result in low levels of genetic exchange between populations (Fine 1978, Greenfield et al. 2008). Maximum length recorded is 24.5 cm standard length (SL) (Collette 2002).
threats: This species is found only in coral reef habitat; the combination of disturbance events and chronic stresses has caused a decline in live coral cover and parallel increases in macroalgae on many reefs off Belize. Between 1970-2012 (42 years), there was an average 41% decline in live coral cover off Belize (Jackson et al. 2014). Major anthropogenic threats to Belize’s reefs include coastal habitat alteration (mangrove clearance, dredging operations), sedimentation, agrochemical and domestic pollution (mainly associated with coastal development, and inadequate solid and liquid waste disposal), overfishing, and direct impacts from tourists, boat anchors and groundings. The tourism industry is growing rapidly, providing the impetus for many of these growing pressures (Wilkinson and Souter 2008).
population: Little information is available on the population status of this species, as it is only known from seven specimens (Greenfield et al. 2008).
range: Sanopus astrifer has a very limited range in the western Atlantic Ocean that does not extend outside of Belize, occurring only on the outer oceanic atolls of the Mesoamerican barrier reef system: Turneffe and Glover’s Atoll (Greenfield et al. 2008). Its estimated AOO is 700 km² (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the WCMC 2013 coral layer). Its estimated EOO is 11,218 km² (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on the coral reef layer).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this fish. However, there are now many marine conservation and monitoring programs in Belize, and 18 marine protected areas (MPAs) encompassing about 250,000 ha. Furthermore, the increased global significance of Belize and the wider Mesoamerican Reef is demonstrated by the establishment of regionally focused projects and initiatives, including: the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System Project, a Global Environment Facility (GEF)/World Bank project that is now poised to enter its second 5-year phase; WWF’s Mesoamerican Reef Ecoregional Program; the Nature Conservancy’s Mesoamerican Reef Program; the Wildlife Conservation Society’s marine program in Belize; the International Coral Reef Action Network (ICRAN) Mesoamerican Reef Alliance; and the Healthy Mesoamerican Reef Ecosystem Initiative. Since late 2003, however, national reef management efforts in Belize have suffered from the loss of funding and capacity within the Belize Coastal Zone Management Authority and Institute (Wilkinson and Souter 2008). Additional research is needed into the distribution, population abundance, habitat and ecology and possible threats to this species.

rationale:
This is an amended version of the 2015 assessment to accommodate the change in genus from Himantura to Urogymnus.

The Mangrove Whipray (Urogymnus granulatus) is a large-bodied (to 141 cm disc width), uncommon stingray, with a widespread distribution in the eastern Indian and western Pacific oceans, from Sri Lanka and eastern India, through to Indonesia. It also occurs along the northern coast of Australia and throughout some of the Pacific Islands. The species appears to prefer shallow inshore waters, including mangroves, estuaries, sand flats and broken rocky-sandy substrate, although adults may move offshore to at least 85 m depth. The species' preference for inshore habitats and the fact that it is apparently uncommon compared to other Himantura species, makes it particularly vulnerable to widespread and intensive artisanal and industrial fisheries operating throughout large areas of its range, as well as habitat destruction and pollution. Significant destruction and degradation of mangrove areas and targeting of juveniles in shallow waters are thought to have significantly affected this species.

It is caught irregularly by tangle net, bottom trawl (including large numbers of trawlers targeting rhynchobatids in the Arafura Sea) and longline fisheries and retained for human consumption. Levels of exploitation are very high throughout its range in Southeast Asia and in many parts of the Indian Ocean, hence it is under a severe level of threat within most of this range. Although no species-specific data are available, overall catches of stingrays are reported to be declining in areas of Southeast Asia for which information is available, with fishermen having to travel further and further to sustain catch levels. Species that inhabit a similar habitat to this species (such as the Sicklefin Lemon Shark (Negaprion acutidens)) are now rarely observed in Indonesia due to high levels of exploitation, and significant declines are also inferred to have occurred in the Mangrove Whipray in Indonesia and other areas. Given the continuation of high levels of exploitation throughout its range in Southeast Asia where the species is caught in multiple types of fisheries, along with evidence for declines in catches of rays, the level of decline (>30% over the last three generations) and exploitation can be inferred from overall declines in fish catches in the region, as well as from habitat loss (in particular mangroves).

n Australia, the Mangrove Whipray is considered at minimal threat throughout its wide range as there is no information to suggest that this species has declined in this area. Fisheries in northern Australia are generally well managed and the introduction of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) have significantly reduced the bycatch of large stingrays. There are also significant marine protected areas in this species' range. This large species may have limiting life history characteristics that would make it biologically susceptible to depletion in fisheries and therefore, efforts should be made to assess and monitor mortality in fisheries and population trends throughout its range. The Mangrove Whipray is assessed as Vulnerable globally based on inferred levels of decline and exploitation across a large part of its range, but is considered to be Least Concern in Australia.
habitat:
The Mangrove Whipray appears to prefer shallow inshore waters, including mangroves, estuaries, sand flats, and broken rocky-sandy substrate, although adults may move offshore and it has been recorded to a depth of at least 85 m (White et al. 2006; B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto and W. White, pers. obs. 2007). This species also appears to be solitary rather than forming aggregations, like some other stingrays (B.M. Manjaji-Matsumoto, pers. obs. 2007). Reproduction is viviparous with histotrophy (White et al. 2006). The species reaches a maximum reported size of 141 cm disc width (DW),  >275 cm total length (TL) (White and Dharmadi 2007, W. White, pers. obs. 2007) and size at birth is reported at 14-28 cm DW (Manjaji 2004, White et al. 2006). Manjaji (2004) reports that males mature at 55-65 cm DW, but the biology and life-history characteristics of this species are generally poorly known. A generation length of 20 years can be estimated based on the Blackspotted Whipray (Maculabatis astra) (Jacobsen and Bennett 2011), but noting that the Blackspotted Whipray grows to a much smaller maximum size (80 cm disc width) than the Mangrove Whipray (141 cm DW).

Davy et al.
